site_title: Massive sell-off expected when China's markets reopen
summary: China's markets are expected to experience a massive sell-off when they reopen on Monday, with stocks and commodities likely to sink and bond yields to drop. The country's deadly virus, which has raised concerns about its economy, will be closely watched. The National Health Commission reported a total death toll of 213 and confirmed cases of 9,692. China's central bank is expected to intervene with a large cash injection and possibly deploy other funding tools to ensure adequate liquidity. The market's reaction is expected to be exacerbated by the high level of leverage in the market, which could create a downward spiral of steep losses.

site_title: Stakeholder capitalism: Separating the genuine from the fake
summary: Businesses must transition from shareholder primacy to stakeholder capitalism, investing proportionally across the firm and pre-committing to measurable objectives. Despite progress, only 21% of CEOs believe businesses are playing a critical role in achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals. The gap between statements and actions is significant, with 81% of companies claiming to take action but only 19% actually doing so. To achieve credibility, businesses must signal their commitment through concrete, material actions and transparent reporting, rather than tokenism or vague rhetoric.

site_title: US: Dow drops 2.1% as US stocks tumble on virus fears
summary: US stocks plummeted 2.1% on Friday, led by fears over the coronavirus, resulting in a 600-point decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped 1.8% and 1.6% respectively. This was the largest decline since August, with investors concerned about the potential impact on global growth.

site_title: Caution over virus outbreak brings corporate events to a halt
summary: Numerous corporate events in Singapore have been cancelled or postponed due to the coronavirus outbreak, with CapitaLand cancelling its spring festival celebrations and dining operators expected to see a hit to earnings. The global health emergency has sparked caution among companies, with many taking precautions to ensure guest safety.

site_title: Dealers call on Art Basel to cancel HK show
summary: Dealers at Art Basel Hong Kong are calling for the event to be cancelled due to coronavirus fears, with some galleries already dropping out. The death toll from the virus has risen to at least 170 and over 7,700 cases have been reported, with Hong Kong confirming 10 cases. The event, scheduled for March, may be jeopardized due to travel restrictions and concerns about safety. Some dealers have expressed concerns about sending staff to Hong Kong, citing the current situation with protests and the virus.

images.alt_text: Stella Zhang's winning installation at Art Basel Hong Kong 2016. Art Basel Hong Kong is one of Asia's most prestigious art fairs. This year's fair is scheduled to open to VIPs on March 17 at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre. Exhibitors would include 241 galleries from 31 countries and territories, according to the website.

site_title: TikTok hires tech trade group chief to lead policy shop
summary: TikTok has hired Michael Beckerman, the president of the Internet Association, to lead its Washington policy operations amid mounting pressure over its ties to China. Beckerman will oversee government relations and seek to persuade US regulators that TikTok is an American company. The move comes as US officials review ByteDance's purchase of Musical.ly and its potential national security implications. TikTok has denied allegations of control by the Chinese government and data risks, and has been expanding its policy staff to address concerns.

site_title: Brexit supporters say 'see EU' with a bang
summary: Thousands of pro-Brexit supporters in central London celebrated Britain's departure from the European Union, with cheers, fireworks, and chants of "freedom" and "Brexit". Organizers, including Nigel Farage, hailed the moment as a historic victory, while ordinary Britons expressed mixed emotions, with some sadness at the end of the country's 47-year EU membership. Farage declared that the UK's exit marked a "point of no return" and that democracy had won, but others lamented the potential economic and social implications.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo from President Trump targeting Canada. Creative Technology warned of H2 revenue below target and an operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and People's Bank of China agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Fighting graft with tech: How the CPIB's work has evolved
summary: Singapore's Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) has evolved its work in fighting graft with technology, 16 years after its computer forensic branch was set up. The bureau's team of nine officers examines seized devices to extract digital evidence, helping investigators establish cases. Technology advancement has changed the nature of crimes and forensic investigation, with digital evidence presenting itself in huge terabytes. The CPIB has strengthened its investigative capabilities by leveraging digital technologies such as data science and digital forensics. The bureau collaborates with strategic partners and engages in public-private partnerships to curb corruption, and is exploring new technologies to improve investigative interviews and assess truthfulness.

site_title: Manufacturers' business sentiment improves; service sectors less upbeat
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expects business conditions to improve in the first half of 2020, with companies optimistic about future growth. In contrast, the services sector is less upbeat. The Economic Development Board and Singapore Department of Statistics conducted separate surveys in December and January, which predated the Wuhan virus outbreak.

site_title: China ambassador says no need for 'unnecessary panic' over virus
summary: China's ambassador to the UN, Chen Xu, says there's no need for "unnecessary panic" over the novel coronavirus outbreak. The WHO has declared the outbreak a global health emergency, but is not recommending international trade or travel restrictions. The ambassador urges countries to reconsider measures like border closures. The UN is working with China to control the outbreak, but no specific measures were mentioned.

site_title: Africa mobilises against coronavirus as fears mount
summary: African countries are taking measures to prepare for a potential coronavirus outbreak, with some stationing nurses at airports and suspending Chinese entry visas. Despite no verified infections on the continent, concerns remain due to deep trade links with China and overstretched healthcare systems. Governments are urging caution and ordinary people are growing increasingly nervous. The poorest countries are particularly vulnerable to responding to an outbreak, highlighting the need for preparedness and support.

site_title: Housing loans shrink for 12th straight month in December
summary: Singapore's housing loans shrank for the 12th consecutive month in December, with a 0.1% decline to S$200.7 billion, and a year-on-year decrease of 1.7%. This follows a trend of shrinking consumer loans, which account for three-quarters of the market.

images.alt_text: Housing loans in Singapore shrank for the 12th straight month in December, leading to a fall in total consumer loans, preliminary Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) data showed on Friday.

site_title: Man United signs Ighalo to cover for striker shortage
summary: Manchester United signed Nigerian international Odion Ighalo on loan until the end of the season from Shanghai Shenhua in a last-minute move before the January transfer window closed. The 30-year-old joins the club due to a back injury suffered by top scorer Marcus Rashford, who is expected to be sidelined for at least another month.

site_title: 'Strong Budget' to support economy amid virus outbreak: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's government is preparing a "strong Budget for 2020" to support the economy amid the impact of the Wuhan virus outbreak. Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong stated that the government is monitoring the situation closely and expects economic impact. The budget will be announced on February 18. Wong emphasized that there will be economic challenges, but the government is taking proactive measures to mitigate them.

site_title: Singapore shares continue fall on Friday, down 2.7% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 2.7% on the week, as investors focused on the rapidly spreading Wuhan coronavirus. Despite a positive Wall Street session on Thursday, concerns about the virus's rising death toll and infection cases overshadowed market gains. The STI had registered a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, but investors' attention was shifted to the global health crisis.

site_title: Spain confirms first case of coronavirus
summary: Spain confirms its first case of coronavirus, with a man diagnosed on the remote island of La Gomera in the Canaries after coming into contact with a German man diagnosed with the virus. A group of five people were taken into observation and isolated on the island. The diagnosis was made after a plane carrying EU nationals from Wuhan landed in Madrid.

site_title: US manufacturing titans portend gloom for global economy
summary: US manufacturing giants Caterpillar and US Steel have predicted lower profits in 2020, signaling a deeper economic downturn. The losses come as the global economy faces challenges from the coronavirus outbreak, factory slump, and reduced corporate spending. This news casts a negative outlook on the global economy, contradicting the easing of trade tensions.

site_title: First Singaporean case confirmed; she was on Scoot flight from Wuhan
summary: A 47-year-old Singaporean woman, confirmed as the first local case, contracted the Wuhan virus while traveling with her family in Wuhan. She was evacuated on Thursday and arrived in Singapore the same day.

images.alt_text: A 47-year-old woman who travelled to Wuhan with her family has been confirmed as the first Singaporean with the Wuhan virus.

site_title: Cautious optimism amid Wuhan virus, but too early to buy on dips, say analysts
summary: Analysts express cautious optimism on markets despite the spread of the Wuhan virus, citing potential buying opportunities in China and emerging market equities. The ongoing correction may be a chance to invest in these sectors, but it's too early to buy on dips. Meanwhile, markets continue to rise, driven by productivity gains and shifting safe havens.

images.alt_text: Analysts say that for investors, the key is to stay calm and not succumb to the knee-jerk impulse to exit, even if markets are yet to trough.

site_title: Qantas, Air NZ to suspend China flights due to coronavirus curbs
summary: Qantas and Air New Zealand announced the suspension of direct flights from their countries to mainland China due to the coronavirus crisis. Qantas will halt flights from Sydney to Beijing and Shanghai from February 9 to March 29, while Air New Zealand will pause its Auckland to Shanghai service during the same time. The travel restrictions imposed by the Chinese government led to the decision.

site_title: Brexit is here, what changes?
summary: Brexit officially came into effect on January 31, 2020, marking the UK's departure from the European Union. A 1,317-day transition period ensued, allowing for negotiations on new arrangements until the end of the year. Despite the transition, daily business between the UK and EU has continued as before, with no significant changes observed so far.

site_title: Want to own a Ferrari? Now you can through a new digital token
summary: A new partnership between CurioInvest and MERJ Exchange allows individuals to invest in collectible cars, including Ferrari, through digital tokens. This makes luxury assets more accessible to a broader audience, as the companies claim to operate within a recognized regulatory environment. The tokens are backed by physical cars stored in secure locations, enabling international investment. This innovative approach to investing in luxury assets is facilitated by blockchain technology.

site_title: Singapore's travel curbs a tough medicine to fight Wuhan virus
summary: Singapore has closed its borders to all visitors who have been to China in the fortnight prior, starting from 11:59pm on Saturday. Chinese passport holders, except Singapore permanent residents and those on long-term passes, will not be allowed entry. The measures aim to prevent deeper damage to the economy and are seen as a necessary step to reduce the risk of community spread of the Wuhan virus. Economists believe the curbs could actually boost business and investor confidence, but the tourism-related industries will likely bear the biggest economic blow.

images.alt_text: Singapore is closing its borders to all visitors who have been to China in the fortnight prior. The latest travel curbs, which were announced on Friday evening, will take effect from 11.59pm on Saturday.

site_title: Reynolds Wrap maker jumps after raising US$1.2b in IPO
summary: Reynolds Consumer Products Inc, maker of Reynolds Wrap aluminum foil and Hefty trash bags, rose 9.8% in its trading debut after raising $1.23 billion in the largest initial public offering by a household goods maker. The company, backed by New Zealand billionaire Graeme Hart's Rank Group, sold 47.17 million shares for $26 each. Its shares closed trading at $28.55, giving the company a market value of $5.78 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 13.65 points to 1,531.94. Volume was 3.2 billion lots worth RM2.5 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 868 to 140.

site_title: SIA, SilkAir, Scoot slashing capacity on selected China routes
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its subsidiaries SilkAir and Scoot will reduce capacity on selected China routes due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. Scoot will suspend flights to mainland China from Feb 8 and reduce frequencies for Fuzhou, Guangzhou, Haikou, Qingdao, and Tianjin from Feb 1-7. The move aims to minimize the impact of the outbreak on their revenue, which currently accounts for less than 10% of their total revenue. The reductions are subject to regulatory approval.

site_title: First Singaporean confirmed to have Wuhan virus; was on Scoot flight from city
summary: A 47-year-old Singaporean woman, confirmed to be the first local case, has been diagnosed with the Wuhan virus. She was asymptomatic when boarding a Scoot flight from Wuhan and was found to have a fever upon arrival. She is currently being treated at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases. This brings the total number of infected cases in Singapore to 16.

site_title: Bidders value Thyssenkrupp's elevator unit at more than 15 billion euros: CEO
summary: Thyssenkrupp's elevator division is valued at more than 15 billion euros, according to the company's CEO. The bidders aim to conclude the sales process by the end of next month, with options including an initial public offering, partial sale, or complete divestment. The conglomerate remains open to all possibilities, keeping the future of the unit uncertain.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore temporarily closed its borders to all Chinese passport holders and visitors who were in mainland China in the past fortnight to contain the Wuhan virus. Airlines SIA, Silkair, and Scoot reduced capacity to China due to declining demand. Meanwhile, other news included Malaysia seizing assets worth RM3 billion, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

images.alt_text: Returning Singapore residents and long-term visa holders - including work permit holders, student pass holders, and dependent and long-term visit pass holders - can still come in, although they will be placed under a 14-day leave of absence.

site_title: Reits (February 1-2, 2020)
summary: US mortgage rates rose after five consecutive weeks of decline, marking a shift in the market. In the real estate sector, Q3 condo launches in Singapore are expected to test demand for projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with forecasts of further increases. Goldman Sachs acquired a hotel and retail asset portfolio in Seoul for 262 billion won. UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, while New World is selling China property assets following a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants at its Singapore location post-bankruptcy.

site_title: AA Reit posts flat Q3 DPU of 2.5 Singapore cents
summary: AIMS Apac Reit (AA Reit) posted a flat quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.5 Singapore cents for Q3, unchanged from the previous year. Gross revenue declined 1.2% to S$29.5 million, mainly due to lease conversions at two properties. However, net property income (NPI) grew 18.8% to S$23.1 million, driven by lower operating expenses. The company's aggregate leverage was 35.2% as of Dec 31.

site_title: Korean Air parent shareholders join forces to oust management
summary: Korean Air's parent company, Hanjin KAL, is facing a crisis in management after three key shareholders, Heather Cho, KCGI, and Bando Engineering & Construction, joined forces to oust the current management. The shareholders claim the current management is unable to improve the situation and propose introducing professional managers. This move comes amid a family feud between CEO Cho Won-tae and his sister Heather Cho, who has accused her brother of disobeying their late father's will. A shareholder vote in March will determine Cho Won-tae's seat on the board, which is set to expire.

site_title: Facebook to remove virus misinformation after WHO declares global emergency
summary: Facebook will remove misinformation about China's coronavirus, including false claims or conspiracy theories, after the World Health Organization declared the outbreak a global health emergency. The move, rare for Facebook, will remove content from its platform that violates its ban on misinformation leading to physical harm. Facebook will take down content flagged by leading global health organizations and local health authorities, but will not remove the original posts. This step aims to curb the spread of inaccuracies that pose major global health threats, following previous efforts to remove misinformation about vaccines in Samoa and Pakistan.

site_title: Singapore turning away new visitors with travel history to mainland China within the last 14 days to contain Wuhan virus
summary: Singapore temporarily restricts new visitors with travel history to mainland China within the last 14 days to contain the spread of the Wuhan virus, excluding returning residents and long-term visa holders. The ban, which takes effect on Saturday night, includes suspending short-term and multiple-visit visas and rejecting new work pass applications from mainland China. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will announce support measures on Saturday, and a full economic package will be introduced in Budget 2020 on February 18.

site_title: DPM Heng to give outline of Budget moves to mitigate virus impact
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will outline key budget measures to mitigate the impact of the Wuhan virus on businesses and workers in Singapore, ahead of the national Budget on Feb 18. The government is considering an economic package to assist businesses and workers, with measures including property tax rebates and working capital bridging loans. The Wuhan virus has already led to a 80% decline in visitor arrivals from China, and the government is preparing for a prolonged economic impact.

site_title: US Senate blocks trial witnesses, sets path to Trump acquittal
summary: The US Senate voted 51-49 against seeking new evidence in Donald Trump's impeachment trial, setting the stage for an acquittal. The vote, largely along party lines, was influenced by two Republican senators, Susan Collins and Mitt Romney, who joined Democrats in supporting additional testimony and documents. This move sends the trial into its final stages, with an acquittal all but certain.

images.alt_text: The US Senate voted against seeking new evidence in Donald Trump's impeachment trial, sending the process into the final stages that's all but certain to end with the eventual acquittal of the president.

site_title: Asia's oil imports from US to rebound in May after freight rates drop: sources
summary: Asia's crude oil imports from the US are expected to rebound in May after freight rates dropped by 27% from a week earlier, trade and shipping sources said. The cost of chartering a Very Large Crude Carrier to move 2 million barrels of US crude to China has fallen to around $8 million, down from $11 million a week ago. This could displace demand for similar-quality oil from the UAE, Africa, and Europe, and is seen as a positive sign for US oil exports to Asia, which have been slow in recent months due to US sanctions on Chinese shipping companies.

images.alt_text: Asia's crude oil imports from the US are set to rebound in May after freight rates for ships to carry US crude to north Asia fell by 27 per cent from a week earlier, trade and shipping sources said on Friday.

site_title: EU to check UK market rules for compliance after Brexit
summary: The European Union's markets watchdog, ESMA, will monitor the UK's application of EU financial rules during the 11-month transition period following Brexit. ESMA will assess whether the UK's market rules align with EU regulation, which is necessary for investment firms and trading platforms to access EU investors. The EU has yet to finalize new rules directly affecting major foreign derivatives clearing houses. Britain will no longer participate in EU policy-making after Brexit, and Prime Minister Boris Johnson has stated that the UK will write its own rules.

site_title: Google-backed 1Life Healthcare surges 58% in trading debut
summary: 1Life Healthcare, a primary care clinic provider backed by Google, made its trading debut with a 58% surge after raising $245 million in an initial public offering. The company closed at $22.07, valuing it at $2.7 billion. With over 70 clinics in nine markets, 1Life aims to modernize doctors' offices with its tech-driven platform, focusing on execution rather than market dynamics. This listing may signal renewed interest in growth companies, following a similar debut by Reynolds Consumer Products.

site_title: Europe: Shares climb in early trading on Brexit day
summary: European shares rose 0.3% in early trading on Friday, driven by gains in airlines and mining stocks, despite concerns over the coronavirus outbreak and Brexit. The STOXX 600 index still faces its second straight weekly decline. Travel and leisure, as well as the mining sector, outperformed, while Spain's Banco Sabadell fell 7.3% after a profit loss. Analysts expect Brexit day to have minimal market impact. The World Health Organization's decision not to impose travel restrictions on China was seen as a positive development.

images.alt_text: Gains in airlines and mining stocks helped European shares rise in early trading on Friday, on a day the United Kingdom officially ends its 40-year membership of the EU.

site_title: China virus death toll rises to 259, infections surge
summary: China's death toll from the new coronavirus outbreak has risen to 259, with 46 additional deaths reported, and nearly 12,000 confirmed infections. The virus, first detected in Wuhan, has spread globally with cases in over two dozen countries. Despite quarantine measures, the number of new deaths and cases has increased daily since China sounded the alarm a week ago, fueled by travel during the Lunar New Year holiday.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop on coronavirus cases, weak euro zone data
summary: European shares declined on Friday, ending 1.1% lower, as the UK and Italy confirmed their first coronavirus cases and disappointing euro zone data weighed on sentiment. The World Health Organization declared the epidemic a global emergency, prompting travel curbs and supply chain disruptions. Economic growth in the euro zone was less than expected, and concerns about the euro zone economy pushed stocks downwards.

site_title: Quarantined cabbies, private hire drivers to receive one-off allowance of at least S$100
summary: Taxi and private-hire drivers in Singapore who need to be quarantined due to the Wuhan virus will receive a one-time allowance of at least S$100 from their associations and the government, on top of a daily S$100 allowance. Members of the National Private Hire Vehicles Association and the National Taxi Association will also receive an additional S$200 assistance. This support aims to help drivers affected by the quarantine measures.

site_title: Isetan axes tenancy with Japan Food Town after non-payment issues
summary: Isetan has terminated its tenancy with Japan Food Town Development due to non-payment of certain sums under the tenancy agreement. The company will exercise its right of re-entry to the premises on Feb 29. The termination is expected to have a negative impact on Isetan's financial year earnings. Isetan shares rose 10 cents to S$4.63 after the announcement.

site_title: Hyundai Motor to suspend some SUV output in S Korea as virus disrupts supplies
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to suspend some SUV production in South Korea due to a supply disruption caused by the coronavirus outbreak. The company will skip production of its Palisade sport utility vehicle this weekend. Ssangyong Motor, a rival, will also idle its plant in Pyeongtaek from February 4 to 12. The disruptions highlight the ripple effects of China's extended factory closures on global supply chains. Hyundai is finding alternative suppliers in South Korea and other parts of China to mitigate the impact.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor said on Friday it planned to skip South Korean production of its Palisade sport utility vehicle this weekend to cope with a supply disruption caused by a virus outbreak, its spokesman said on Friday.

site_title: Coronavirus fears dampen global risk sentiment
summary: The World Health Organization has declared the new coronavirus a global health emergency, intensifying market fears and risk-off mood in global markets. Gold prices have received support as investors seek safe havens, while the US Federal Reserve maintains a neutral stance on interest rates. Market analysts expect investors to remain risk-adverse until positive developments on the viral outbreak surface, with gold prices potentially testing $1,588.00 and $1,611.00.

site_title: The robots are coming for fund management jobs
summary: A Japanese government pension fund is using artificial intelligence to monitor external fund managers, aiming to catch instances of "style drift" where managers deviate from their stated investment strategies. The AI system, developed by Sony, analyzed 1,000 stocks and portfolio data from existing managers, identifying cases of managers chasing performance or switching between strategies without transparency. The system's limitations, including the "black box problem" where its inner workings are opaque, raise concerns about accountability and transparency. The project's success could pave the way for smaller firms to manage the fund's $1.6 trillion in assets, but its impact on job displacement remains unclear.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate to invest in mixed-use Colombo development via JV
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has entered a joint venture with other investors to develop a mixed-use project in Colombo, Sri Lanka. The $120,000 square meter development will include residential, office, and retail spaces. Perennial will contribute $17.5 million, funded by internal cash, unit sales, and bank borrowings. The JV company, Perennial CBL, will be 31.25% owned by Perennial's subsidiary, PEMH. The project marks a significant investment in the Sri Lankan market.

site_title: Festive greetings at DBS
summary: DBS Group Holdings & DBS Bank shared Chinese New Year greetings with clients. Meanwhile, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong who is retiring. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are deepening cooperation on green and transition finance. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Gloomy outlook depresses HK home prices in December
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices declined 1.7% in December, reversing a 1.9% gain in November, due to a gloomy economic outlook and the ongoing impact of anti-government protests. Property agents expect prices to continue their downtrend until the second quarter and transaction volumes to shrink due to the new coronavirus outbreak in China. Despite a 4.8% annual increase in 2019, prices are still down 4.6% since May. Developers are expected to postpone project launches amid fears of the epidemic.

site_title: Britain reports first two cases of coronavirus
summary: Britain has reported its first two cases of coronavirus, both from the same family in England. The patients are receiving specialist NHS care and are being monitored for further spread. England's chief medical officer, Chris Whitty, stated that the NHS is well-prepared to manage the outbreak and is working to identify any contacts. This marks the beginning of the UK's response to the global pandemic.

images.alt_text: Two patients from the same family in England have tested positive for coronavirus, the first such cases in Britain.

site_title: Paying off Van Gogh and Fu Fu: Inside the Airbus bribery web
summary: Airbus has admitted to a record US$4 billion bribery settlement, with a 150-person team using a $300 million annual budget to fund bribes and win aircraft sales globally. The payoffs influenced decision makers in various countries, boosting Airbus' profits by 1.05 billion euros over 13 years. As part of the settlements, Airbus has taken significant steps to reform itself and prevent similar conduct from recurring. The company's strategy and marketing unit has been disbanded, and it has admitted to the allegations in each jurisdiction.

site_title: Ascendas Reit posts 12.3% drop in Q3 DPU to 3.507 S cents
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 12.3% drop in its third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.507 Singapore cents due to an enlarged number of units after a rights exercise in December last year. Despite a 5.9% increase in gross revenue to S$239.73 million, driven by contributions from US and Singapore properties, net property income rose 8.5% to S$182.28 million. The DPU for the quarter will be paid on March 4. Ascendas Reit's CEO William Tay expressed plans to invest in well-located properties benefiting from growth trends.

site_title: Battered Asian currencies arrest slide on WHO confidence
summary: Asian currencies stabilized on Friday after the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the coronavirus outbreak a global emergency but opposed travel restrictions, tempering concerns over the virus's spread. The WHO's assured tone halted a rush to safety, which had pounded stocks and hammered currencies exposed to China. Despite rising deaths and cases, the WHO's confidence in China's response helped pause the slide, with the New Zealand dollar and Australian dollar steady but still weak. The US has warned citizens against visiting China, and investors await details on the virus's spread and economic costs.

site_title: China PMI down a tad in January, but the worst is yet to come
summary: China's manufacturing sector stabilized in January with a PMI reading of 50.0, but analysts warn the data does not reflect the full impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak, which has halted transport links and affected the tourism industry. The virus has led to rising cases and a death toll of 213, with nearly 10,000 infected. Economists predict a significant decline in manufacturing and service PMIs in February and March due to the outbreak, potentially knocking 1-2 percentage points off GDP growth.

site_title: Should FA Cup replays be scrapped?
summary: The English Premier League is considering scrapping FA Cup replays, citing the financial burden on smaller clubs and the top teams' focus on the EPL and Champions League. However, some argue that replays are crucial for mid-table and lower-tier clubs, providing a significant financial boost. Alternative solutions, such as awarding extra time or a penalty shootout if the match ends in a draw, are proposed to reduce fixture congestion. Ultimately, scrapping replays may devalue the competition, while keeping them could provide a vital lifeline for smaller clubs.

site_title: Fear and loathing in lost Davos
summary: The article highlights the growing concern that Western companies are being sidelined in the technology race by China, which is rapidly developing its own tech industry. The World Economic Forum's (WEF) annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, saw Chinese officials and entrepreneurs confidently discuss their plans for a technology arms race, while Western leaders seemed uncertain and divided. China's tech giant Huawei was under lockdown, and its CEO, Ren Zhengfei, criticized the US for its restrictions on the company. The article concludes that the West lacks leadership, cohesion, and coordination in the face of China's growing technological prowess, which poses a threat to the global economy and geopolitical balance.

site_title: SIA to suspend additional flights between Singapore and China
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will suspend additional flights between Singapore and mainland China in February due to the growing Wuhan virus. About 10 flights between Singapore and Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Chongqing will be cancelled, with some previously affected flights having earlier cancellations starting from February 4.

site_title: UK clothing retailer French Connection drops plans to sell as it focuses on turnaround
summary: French Connection Group, a UK clothing retailer, has dropped plans to sell the company after a review, instead focusing on a turnaround by growing its wholesale business in the US and investing in its online platform. The company expects an annual pretax loss of £1-2 million, due to tough UK High Street conditions. Despite this, French Connection aims to capitalize on growing demand for its products and improve its online presence to offset losses.

site_title: Mongolia closes border to China until March 2 to stop virus
summary: Mongolia has closed its border with China until March 2 to prevent the spread of the coronavirus epidemic, citing concerns about the virus despite not having reported any cases. Citizens currently in China are given until February 6 to return home, while non-Chinese foreign nationals are barred from entering via China. The government plans to repatriate 30 Mongolian citizens from Wuhan, the epicentre of the outbreak.

images.alt_text: Mongolia will close all ports of entry from and into China until March 2 to try to prevent the spread of the coronavirus epidemic, the government said on Friday.

site_title: This could be America's priciest home - if it can find a buyer
summary: Nile Niami, a movie producer turned developer, claims to be ready to test the market with his $500 million asking price for "The One," a 9,290-sq m mansion in Bel-Air, California. Despite permit problems, construction delays, and financing issues, Niami says he is almost done with the project. The mansion features a nightclub, four swimming pools, a bowling alley, and 360-degree views of southern California. Niami believes the high price tag is justified by recent nine-figure property deals in Los Angeles, and he has a list of potential buyers.

site_title: Indian Oil Corp to raise refinery's processing capacity by 50%
summary: Indian Oil Corp plans to invest 137.79 billion rupees to expand its Barauni refinery's processing capacity by 50% to 180,000 barrels per day by April 2023. The move aims to meet growing demand for petroleum products in the country, with refined fuel consumption rising 2.6% in the December quarter. This expansion will help India capitalize on its emerging role as a bright spot for refined fuel demand.

images.alt_text: Indian Oil Corp, the country's top refiner, will invest 137.79 billion rupees (S$2.63 billion) to expand the capacity of its Barauni refinery in eastern Bihar state by 50 per cent to 180,000 barrels per day by April 2023, the company said on Friday.

site_title: Taiwan finance minister says now's not the time to intervene in markets
summary: Taiwan's Finance Minister Su Jain-rong advises against intervening in the stock markets, citing a rebound after a previous day's big fall due to coronavirus fears. The Taiwanese economy is vulnerable to a Chinese slowdown, with 40% of exports going to China. The World Health Organization has declared a global emergency, with over 200 deaths in China. Despite concerns, the stock market has seen a 5-day rally in Singapore ahead of GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: 3% cash payout under debt scheme beats liquidation: honestbee ex-chairman
summary: honestbee's proposed scheme of arrangement offers 3% cash payout to 800 creditors, with the remaining 97% paid in shares. The startup's total debt is US$230.9 million, funded by a US$7 million injection from FLK Holdings. Honestbee's chairman, Brian Koo, believes the scheme is a better option than liquidation, citing a "strong business case" for the company's service offerings in Asia. However, trade creditors who are owed over S$500 may face a tougher pill to swallow, as they may have fewer rights as shareholders than currently as creditors.

site_title: Bank of Japan warns of cyber-attack vulnerability ahead of Olympic Games
summary: The Bank of Japan warned that Japan's financial institutions are vulnerable to cyber attacks ahead of the 2020 Tokyo Olympic Games. A survey found that nearly 40% of banks and firms experienced cyber attacks in the past three years, with over 70% believing the threat has increased since 2017. Many institutions lack sufficient staff to deal with cyber attacks, despite 60% having dedicated departments. The BOJ urged vigilance ahead of the Olympics, citing the growing cyber-security risks in the financial sector.

site_title: How to prune the streaming subscriptions you no longer use
summary: Americans spent $640 on digital subscriptions in 2019, with streaming TV services accounting for a 30% increase from 2017. To avoid overspending, regularly auditing and canceling unused subscriptions is crucial. Tips include canceling ahead of time, using budget-tracking tools, and setting reminders for subscription renewals. A study found that people subscribe to streaming services for exclusive content, but often forget to cancel after use. Canceling subscriptions ahead of time, using a calendar reminder, and regularly checking credit card statements can help manage digital spending.

site_title: Seoul's export slump deepens as CNY break hits shipments
summary: South Korea's export slump deepened in January with a 6.1% decline from the previous year, following a 5.2% drop in December. Shipments of semiconductors, the country's biggest export, fell 3.4% due to the Chinese New Year break, which reduced working days. Economists had forecast an 8.6% decline. Despite the poor trade report, the Bank of Korea forecasts 2.3% growth for this year, and the government plans to front-load spending to speed up an economic recovery.

site_title: EU-Singapore FTA will still apply to UK during Brexit transition: MTI
summary: Singapore's free trade agreement (FTA) with the European Union (EU) will continue to apply to the UK during the Brexit transition period (Feb 1-Dec 31). The UK will function as an EU member-state, and the EU and UK can decide to extend the transition period. Singapore and the UK are working on maintaining trade continuity after the transition period ends. Businesses in both countries expect clarity on the UK's post-Brexit regulatory environment to plan their market strategies, but the impact on Singapore's firms may be muted due to their presence in sectors such as real estate and hospitality.

site_title: Ascendas Reit Q3 DPU down 12.3% on enlarged base following rights issue
summary: Ascendas Reit's third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) fell 12.3% to 3.507 Singapore cents due to an enlarged number of units after a rights issue in December. Gross revenue rose 5.9% to S$239.73 million, driven by new properties. Net property income increased 8.5% to S$182.28 million. The company's overall portfolio occupancy rate held steady at 90.9%. Ascendas Reit plans to invest in well-located properties and strengthen its presence in developed markets to optimize portfolio returns.

site_title: UK financial watchdog to probe ad agency M&C Saatchi after accounting scandal
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has launched an investigation into advertising agency M&C Saatchi following an accounting scandal that was revealed last year. The investigation comes after an independent forensic review found several units of the company's UK business overstated income and receivables. M&C Saatchi has issued two profit warnings and seen its co-founder Maurice Saatchi step down from the board. The company has agreed to cooperate with the FCA and is reconstructing its board with new independent directors to conduct a full review of its governance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall to near two-month low on coronavirus fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell to a near two-month low on Friday, closing 0.5% lower at 26,312.63 points, due to fears of the coronavirus outbreak in China. Healthcare and energy stocks were hit hard, while consumer stocks saw a slight gain. The Hang Seng Index ended 5.9% lower for the week, with some analysts warning that banks could require significant recapitalizations if the virus spreads. The Chinese government has also taken measures to counter the spread of the virus, including closing some bank branches temporarily.

site_title: Parc Canberra executive condo launches, prices start from S$855,000
summary: Parc Canberra, an executive condominium in Singapore's north region, has launched its sales gallery and online applications, with prices starting from S$855,000. The development, which will house 496 units, features smart home technology and luxurious amenities. Buyers can opt for a Central Provident Fund housing grant and deferred payment schemes. Located near the Canberra MRT station, the property is inspired by Australian outdoor culture, with features such as water cascades and green roofs.

site_title: Wuhan virus dents sentiment; STI down 2.7% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 2.7% on the week, finishing at 3,153.73, amid concerns over the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus. The index had initially gained on Thursday following a positive US market session, but was erased by investors' focus on the virus. Asian economies showed mixed results, with gains in Australia, Japan, and Taiwan offsetting losses in Hong Kong, Malaysia, and South Korea. The market's tourism and leisure-related plays, such as Singapore Airlines, were hit by virus concerns, leading to capacity cuts and partnership signings.

site_title: Electrolux warns Chinese virus outbreak will hamper sourcing
summary: Electrolux reported a smaller-than-expected fall in fourth-quarter profit due to US production issues and warned of potential financial impact from the Chinese coronavirus outbreak, which could disrupt sourcing. The company expects little year-on-year impact from tariffs and material prices in 2020. Adjusted operating earnings fell to 960 million Swedish kroner, beating analyst expectations. Electrolux is implementing contingency plans to mitigate supply disruptions if its Chinese suppliers are further affected.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Capital Holdings has formed a 50:50 joint venture with Australian Unity to establish funds focused on the Australian metropolitan office sector. Perennial Real Estate Holdings has also entered a joint venture to invest in a mixed-use development in Colombo, Sri Lanka. Hyflux has clarified that the appointment of new legal advisers will not impact its restructuring. Ayondo has applied for a three-month extension to submit a proposal to resume trading. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and MAS and PBOC have announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Nintendo says no new Switch in 2020
summary: Nintendo announced it will not release a new Switch console in 2020, citing the console's life cycles and customer bases as different from rival consoles. Despite increased competition from Sony's PlayStation 5 and 5G mobile phones, Nintendo reported a 16.4% increase in net profit for the nine months to December, driven by robust sales of hardware and software. The company's strong software titles, including Super Mario and Pokémon, are expected to mitigate the impact of not releasing a new console model.

site_title: Mini Cooper SE: A Mini contribution to climate health
summary: The Mini Cooper SE, a fully-electric Mini model, is set to be available in Singapore from the third quarter of this year. With an estimated price of S$160,000, it's priced lower than larger electric cars from Hyundai and Kia. The Cooper SE blends Mini's youthful styling with environmental friendliness, appealing to the younger generation. However, its range of 235-270km is limited due to packaging constraints, and it lacks the performance and handling of petrol-powered Minis. Despite this, it serves its purpose well as a fashionable, easy-to-drive city car.

site_title: Malaysian malls fight to keep shoppers' dwindling interest
summary: Malaysian malls are investing in mixed-use spaces and visitor experiences amid a retail slump and growing e-commerce. Analysts predict retailers will be selective and malls will need to create unique products to attract shoppers. The country's e-commerce market is expected to grow 16% annually to $11.2 billion by 2023. Malls have transformed into multi-functional spaces, but this may be a reaction to long-term retail vacancies. The global spread of the Wuhan virus also poses a risk to Malaysia's growth, with potential losses to tourism revenue.

site_title: Sea, Grab founders join EDB board
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) has announced a leadership reshuffle, with Sea's Forrest Li and Grab's Tan Hooi Ling joining the board as of February 1. They will be joined by representatives from traditional industries, including ExxonMobil and General Electric. The move aims to promote tech innovation and attract foreign investment to Singapore.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors posts surprise Q3 operating loss as car sales slide
summary: Mitsubishi Motors Corp posted a surprise operating loss of 6.6 billion yen (US$60.2 million) in the third quarter, its worst quarterly performance in over three years, due to falling sales in China, Japan, and South-east Asia. The loss was attributed to a stronger yen and a 16% decline in global vehicle sales to 320,000 units. The company maintained its forecast for a 73% drop in full-year operating profit to 30 billion yen. Mitsubishi also announced plans to keep some Chinese offices closed due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Hitachi makes 531.1b yen offer for full control of industrial gear unit
summary: Hitachi announced a 531.1 billion yen (S$6.63 billion) tender offer to acquire full control of Hitachi High-Technologies, a Japanese industrial equipment unit. The offer price is 8,000 yen per share, with shares closing at 7,920 yen on Friday. The takeover aims to benefit HHT's industrial equipment business through Hitachi's digital technologies expertise. The tender offer will run from February 17 to April 6, following the Japanese conglomerate's reorganization efforts, which include selling its listed chemicals and diagnostic imaging businesses.

site_title: French economy shrinks for first time in Macron's presidency
summary: France's economy shrank for the first time in Emmanuel Macron's presidency, contracting 0.1% in the fourth quarter of 2019 due to a decline in exports and a huge drag from inventories. This unexpected contraction contradicts Macron's government's claims that its reforms are working, and raises concerns about the euro area's economic stability. The euro fell 0.1% after the report, and economists warn that trade risks, including the US's threat to raise duties on EU imports, and the spread of the coronavirus could further test the region's resilience.

site_title: Aston Martin nears deal to sell stake to Formula One billionaire
summary: Aston Martin is nearing a deal to sell a minority stake to billionaire Lawrence Stroll, owner of the Formula One racing team, in a deal worth approximately 200 million pounds (US$262 million). Stroll won backing from Aston Martin's board and is likely to receive a seat on the board. The investment will help ease funding strains as the company prepares to start building its first-ever sport-utility vehicle, the DBX. The deal could be announced as early as Friday, but representatives for Stroll and Aston Martin did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

site_title: OCBC finds way to cut data-retrieval time for criminal probes
summary: OCBC Bank has successfully implemented an automated system called POET, which enables the bank to respond to production orders from law enforcement agencies within one to two working days, instead of the previously manual and time-consuming process that took up to three months. The system, developed in-house, has reduced the workload for bank staff and improved the efficiency of data processing. The bank has collaborated with multiple law enforcement agencies, including the Corrupt Practices Investigations Bureau, and expects about 70% of production orders to be processed through POET.

site_title: Helicopter firm in Kobe Bryant crash not certified to fly in poor visibility: reports
summary: A charter helicopter company, Island Express Helicopters, owned the aircraft that crashed and killed Kobe Bryant and eight others in January 2020. The company was not certified to fly in poor visibility, but its helicopter was equipped for instrument flying. The pilot, Ara Zobayan, was licensed for instrument flying but had limited experience due to the company's operating limitations. Air traffic controllers gave him special clearance to fly in the suboptimal weather, which worsened as the flight continued. The company has suspended all services.

site_title: China banks borrow from Sars playbook in preparation for market reopening
summary: Chinese financial firms are implementing measures used during the SARS outbreak to prepare for the market reopening on Monday, including traders working shifts and sales staff restricted to online pitches. Banks and brokers will pay double for essential staff who will work from the office, with China's stock and bond markets set to reopen after a week-long break due to the coronavirus outbreak. The Shanghai government has extended the holiday until Feb 9, but banks are required to reopen nationwide, with staff called to work on holidays paid double.

images.alt_text: China Construction Bank (CCB), the country's second-largest lender, and Hang Seng Bank are among those planning to split their trading teams and alternate their working days, according to three sources.

site_title: China trade body offers force majeure certificates for virus-hit firms
summary: China's trade body, the China Council for the Promotion of International Trade (CCPIT), has announced that it will issue force majeure certificates to companies affected by the Wuhan virus outbreak. The certificates can excuse parties from non-performance of contractual obligations due to extraordinary circumstances. Chinese companies can apply for the certificates if they have experienced delays or cancellations in transportation or export cargo sales contracts. The certification is recognized and accepted overseas, aiming to safeguard the rights and interests of affected companies and reduce losses.

site_title: Australia's CBA, big offshore banks grow home lending business
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia was the only major bank to grow its home lending business in the second half of 2020, with a 1.2% increase to A$444.8 billion. Offshore lenders such as HSBC, ING, and Citigroup lured customers with quick approvals and cheap money, growing by 6.6%, 5%, and 2.3% respectively. The shift is attributed to heightened regulatory scrutiny and customer backlash at domestic institutions, which have faced scandals and overhaul of management teams.

site_title: Japan drugstores plan mega-merger in Oct 2021: Nikkei
summary: Japan's MatsumotoKiyoshi Holdings and Cocokara Fine Inc plan to merge in October 2021, creating the country's largest discount pharmacy chain with around $10 billion in annual sales. MatsumotoKiyoshi will acquire 20% of Cocokara Fine shares. The merger was initially discussed in August 2020.

images.alt_text: Japanese drugstore company MatsumotoKiyoshi Holdings and rival Cocokara Fine Inc plan to merge in October 2021, the Nikkei financial daily reported on Friday.

site_title: China to bring home overseas citizens from virus-hit province: official
summary: China plans to send charter planes to bring back overseas citizens from virus-hit Hubei province, particularly from Wuhan, "as soon as possible" due to "practical difficulties" they've faced abroad.

site_title: SIA proposes joint venture with Japan's ANA
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Japan's All Nippon Airways (ANA) have signed a joint venture (JV) framework agreement, aiming to boost air connectivity between Singapore and Japan and drive passenger traffic. The proposed JV, if approved, will allow the carriers to coordinate networks, offer more flight options, and improve cost savings through digitalisation and sustainability efforts. The partnership is expected to benefit both airlines, with increased revenue and customer convenience, and could further promote Japan as a tourist destination.

site_title: Billionaire Lawrence Stroll shifts Aston Martin into the fast lane
summary: Canadian billionaire Lawrence Stroll has agreed to buy up to 20% of Aston Martin for £182 million, renaming his Formula One team after the luxury sports car brand. The deal aims to revive Aston Martin's struggling sales and finances. Stroll will join the company's board as executive chairman, bringing his experience and access to his Formula One team. The company's shares surged 30% after the announcement, and plans to invest in electric vehicles have been delayed.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after WHO virus ruling
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday after the World Health Organization declared the new coronavirus an international emergency, but held off on recommending restrictions. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 0.99% to 23,205.18, while the broader Topix index rose 0.58% to 1,684.44. Investors bought back shares, citing the WHO's "stamp of approval" to China's containment efforts and the lack of travel or trade restrictions. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe warned citizens against non-essential travel to China, while game giant Nintendo dropped 3.54% due to lower-than-expected quarterly operating profit.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday after the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the new coronavirus an international emergency but held off on recommending restrictions on the movement of people.

site_title: 3 stations on Thomson-East Coast Line begin operations
summary: The Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) in Singapore has begun operations with three stations - Woodlands North, Woodlands, and Woodlands South - opening to passengers on January 31, 2020. Commuters welcomed the new line as a convenient alternative to crowded feeder buses. While initial service was limited, free travel for three days will help commuters familiarize themselves with the line. The 43km-long line, when fully completed in 2024, is expected to reduce travel time for Woodlands commuters to half, with eight interchange stations and connections to the North-South Line.

site_title: How will you measure your life?
summary: Harvard Business School professor Clayton Christensen, a leading thought leader on disruptive innovation, passed away on January 23, 2020. Christensen's groundbreaking book "The Innovator's Dilemma" was voted one of the six most important business books ever written. His theory on disruptive innovation has had a profound impact on generations of students and scholars. Christensen's legacy extends beyond business, as he also emphasized the importance of measuring one's life by the positive impact on others, as seen in his book "How Will You Measure Your Life?"

site_title: Singapore bank lending flat in Dec from Nov
summary: Singapore bank lending remained flat in December, with total loans standing at S$692.4 billion, unchanged from the previous month. This represents a 3.1% increase from the same period last year.

site_title: Indonesian coal firm Resources Global makes year's first SGX debut at S$0.21
summary: Indonesian coal firm Resources Global Development (RGD) made its Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) debut at S$0.21, 5% above its initial public offering (IPO) price of S$0.20. The company raised S$3 million and plans to use the funds for general working capital and expand its customer base and geographical coverage. RGD's net profit for fiscal 2018 was S$2.2 million, a 86.4% surge from the previous year. The company's market capitalization is around S$18 million, bringing the total number of commodities companies on the Singapore bourse to 32.

site_title: Gold inches down as WHO eases virus fears, but set for monthly gain
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,572.96 per ounce, but are set to post a 3.7% monthly gain, its best since August, due to fears of a slowdown in global economic growth. The WHO declared the coronavirus outbreak a global emergency, but opposed travel restrictions, easing fears. Asian shares rose, and surveys showed steady Chinese factory activity, improving the mood. The US dollar strengthened, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies, with critical support at $1,545-$1,550 per ounce.

site_title: EU-Singapore free trade deal will still apply to UK during Brexit transition
summary: The EU-Singapore free trade deal will remain applicable to the UK during the Brexit transition period, which runs from February 1 to December 31, 2020. The UK will be treated as an EU member state and remain a party to EU international agreements during this period. A new agreement between Singapore and the UK aims to maintain trade continuity after the transition period ends. The EU-Singapore agreement was entered into force in November, providing certainty for continued trade between Singapore and the UK.

site_title: Oil slides as virus outbreak shakes economic growth predictions
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, tracking a fourth straight weekly loss, due to mounting concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. Brent crude dropped 13 cents to settle at US$58.16 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate fell 58 US cents to end the session at US$51.56 a barrel. Economists expect the outbreak to cut China's oil demand by over 250,000 barrels per day and reduce the US economy. Global equity markets were poised for their first monthly loss since August, with Wall Street's main averages tumbling over 1%.

site_title: US declares coronavirus public health emergency after imposing quarantines
summary: The US has declared a public health emergency due to the coronavirus outbreak, with a focus on China as the epicenter. The Trump administration has barred entry to foreign nationals who have traveled to China and imposed a 14-day mandatory quarantine on US citizens who have visited China's Hubei Province within the past two weeks. This move comes after the confirmation of a seventh US case in Northern California.

site_title: BreadTalk group CFO and CIO resigns
summary: BreadTalk Group CFO and CIO Chan Ying Jian has resigned, effective March 15, to pursue other career opportunities. Chan, 37, had been with the company since 2015 and oversaw accounting, financial, and treasury matters. His departure comes shortly after CEO Henry Chu quit for personal and health reasons, and follows a profit guidance announcement that predicted a net loss for fiscal 2019. George Quek, executive chairman and founder, will take over accounting and financial duties.

site_title: The future of recycling is sanitation workers rejecting your bin
summary: The city of Atlanta has implemented a "zero-tolerance" recycling program, where sanitation workers reject bins containing contaminated trash, leading to a 27% increase in collection of valuable materials and a 57% decrease in contamination. The program, called "Feet on the Street," uses inspectors to evaluate each recycling can and tags rejected bins with an "OOPS" label to educate residents. The initiative has shown promising results, with 70 local governments across 18 states implementing similar programs. Experts argue that single-stream recycling, which collects all recyclables in one bin, is a major contributor to contamination and advocate for more effective sorting methods, such as deposit laws.

site_title: JTC awards tender for Tuas industrial site to sole bidder
summary: JTC Corporation has awarded the tender for the Tuas West Avenue (Plot B) industrial site to Progressive Builders for approximately S$4.2 million. The 20-year site has a 9,508 square meter area and a gross plot ratio of 1.4, zoned "B2" for heavier industrial use. The project completion period is 60 months, following the site's launch in October 2019.

site_title: Singapore private residential market may be stabilising: Redas president
summary: Singapore's private residential market appears to be stabilizing, with new home sales expected to remain resilient and match 2019's level, according to Redas president Chia Ngiang Hong. Prices of new homes are not expected to change much, despite uneven sales performance across projects and segments. The Singapore government is expected to maintain a stable and sustainable property market, and the country's sound economic fundamentals and strong growth in fixed asset investments and foreign direct investments support this. The market is expected to remain resilient despite current challenges.

site_title: Singapore manufacturers' business sentiment improves, services sector less upbeat
summary: Singapore manufacturers' business sentiment has improved, with 12% of firms expecting better business prospects in the first half of 2020, according to separate surveys by the Economic Development Board and the Singapore Department of Statistics. In contrast, the services sector is less optimistic, with a 2% net weighted balance of firms predicting a less favourable business outlook. The manufacturing sector, however, expects improved business conditions, particularly in the electronics and precision engineering clusters, with expectations driven by the roll-out of 5G technology and global semiconductor demand.

site_title: Nintendo CEO says no plans to launch new Switch model in 2020
summary: Nintendo CEO Shuntaro Furukawa stated the company has no plans to launch a new Switch model in 2020, following the launch of a handheld-only version in September. This decision comes as the company drives demand for the device through the year-end shopping season.

images.alt_text: Nintendo CEO Shuntaro Furukawa said the gaming company has no plans to launch a new Switch model this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.89% or 234.74 points to 26,683.87, following the World Health Organization's declaration of the new coronavirus as an international emergency. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for the holidays.

site_title: Asia: Markets welcome WHO virus declaration
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared a global health emergency over the deadly new virus in China, sparking a rise in Asian markets. The WHO's move, which stopped short of recommending trade and travel restrictions, was welcomed by investors, with major indexes such as the Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng rising. Oil prices also recovered, partially correcting a days-long drop. The WHO's declaration, which has already killed 200 people and sickened thousands, is seen as a positive step towards international coordination to combat the outbreak.

site_title: Japan's Nippon Steel to cut 10% of crude steel capacity: Nikkei
summary: Nippon Steel, Japan's largest steelmaker, plans to cut 10% of its crude steel capacity by closing two blast furnaces at its Kure site within a few years. This move aims to boost competitiveness in the face of rising output in top producer China. The company has already announced plans to close one furnace by 2024 and another by 2021. Global crude steel production reached a record 1.87 billion tonnes last year, with China's output climbing to nearly 1 billion tonnes.

site_title: Chip maker SK Hynix posts 95% quarterly profit plunge
summary: South Korea's second-largest memory chip maker, SK Hynix, reported a 95% quarterly profit plunge due to a decline in demand and increased supply. The company's profits soared in recent years as prices for its products increased. SK Hynix supplies chips to major companies like Apple and Huawei, but the decline in demand is attributed to manufacturers investing in new factories, increasing supply.

images.alt_text: The world's second-largest memory chip maker, South Korea's SK Hynix, posted a 95 per cent quarterly profit plunge on Friday as it suffers from a long-running lull in the global market.

site_title: Humility, managing people are key to the role, says Mothercare's Pang Fu Wei
summary: Mothercare Singapore's managing director, Pang Fu Wei, attributes his success to humility and effective people management. At 31, he took a non-traditional path to the role, starting in various departments and putting in extra hours to prove his worth. Despite the company's British parent putting its business into administration, the Singapore operations continue to thrive. Pang emphasizes the importance of adapting to disruption, such as e-commerce, and has implemented a leadership renewal process to remain competitive. He attributes his success to a combination of people, process, and platform.

site_title: US tells its citizens 'do not travel' to China because of coronavirus
summary: The US State Department issued a level four warning, advising citizens not to travel to China due to the coronavirus epidemic, which has been declared an international emergency by the World Health Organization. The warning was upgraded from "reconsider" travel to China, with the department urging Americans in China to consider departing using commercial means.

site_title: Chips boost South Korea's Dec factory output, full-year worst since 1998
summary: South Korea's December factory output exceeded forecasts, jumping 3.5% from the previous month, driven by a surge in chip production. This marked the fastest jump since November 2016. Industrial output rose 4.2% from the previous year, with memory chips surging 33.8%. However, the economy is expected to face challenges due to the spreading China virus, which could dent demand in January.

site_title: BreadTalk group CFO, CIO quits
summary: BreadTalk Group CFO and CIO Chan Ying Jian, 37, has resigned on March 15 to pursue other career opportunities. He was appointed group CFO in 2015 and took on the CIO role in 2019. Executive chairman and founder George Quek will oversee financial matters, assisted by the group financial controller and division financial controller. This comes shortly after CEO Henry Chu's resignation for personal and health reasons, and follows BreadTalk's profit guidance that expects a net loss for fiscal 2019 due to weakness in its bakery and food concept divisions.

images.alt_text: Upon Mr Chan's (far right) departure, BreadTalk chairman George Quek (second from right) will oversee accounting, financial, treasury and tax matters. Also pictured (from left) are William Cheng, group COO and CEO of the restaurant division; and Jenson Ong, deputy group CEO and CEO of the food atrium division.

site_title: Medal for former ECB chief Draghi divides Germans
summary: Former European Central Bank (ECB) chief Mario Draghi will receive Germany's highest honour, the Order of Merit, despite criticism from many Germans who feel he "deprived millions of German savers of their interest payments" due to his easy-money policy. A YouGov poll found 60% of respondents disagreed with the award, citing the negative impact of low interest rates on German savers. However, some economists and politicians defended Draghi, calling him a "great European" whose policy prevented an economic depression and the break-up of the euro.

site_title: Isetan ends tenancy deal with Japan Food Town in Wisma Atria
summary: Isetan Singapore has ended its tenancy deal with Japan Food Town in Wisma Atria due to non-payment of certain sums under the tenancy agreement. Isetan will immediately terminate the tenancy and exercise its right of re-entry on February 29. The financial impact of the termination will be reflected in Isetan's full year financial statement for FY2019. Shares in Isetan rose 10 cents to S$4.63 following the announcement.

site_title: One more plot twist? Muguruza, Kenin in Australian Open final
summary: Tennis: Garbine Muguruza faces American Sofia Kenin in the Australian Open women's final on Saturday, a rematch of their first-round match in September. Muguruza, a three-time Grand Slam champion, has rediscovered her form after a six-month slump, while Kenin, 21, has defied expectations to reach the final, where she will become the top-ranked American if she wins. The final promises to be an aggressive match with both players controlling the points. Muguruza is the favourite, but acknowledges that confidence and her previous experiences will not guarantee a win.

images.alt_text: Tough American Sofia Kenin stands between Garbine Muguruza and a third Grand Slam title in Saturday's Australian Open women's final, after a tournament of twists and turns that has defied all expectations.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon down 0.34% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading on Friday, down 0.34% at 3,159.87 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 197 to 151, with about 1.04 billion securities worth S$665.6 million changing hands. Medtecs International and OEL (Holdings) were among the biggest losers, while Jardine Matheson Holdings gained 0.7%. The STI has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Wuhan virus deaths hit 213, nearly 2,000 new cases in China
summary: China's coronavirus death toll has risen to 213, with nearly 2,000 new cases confirmed, according to the National Health Commission. All 43 new deaths occurred in Hubei province, the hardest-hit area. The outbreak is ongoing, with the commission providing daily updates on the situation.

site_title: Rometty to step down as IBM CEO in April
summary: IBM CEO Ginni Rometty to step down on April 6, 2020, after 8 years in the role. She will be replaced by Arvind Krishna, who led cloud and cognitive software. Rometty emphasized cloud computing and AI during her tenure, but IBM struggled with declining sales. Krishna, 57, was a principal architect of IBM's $34 billion Red Hat acquisition. Rometty will remain executive chairman through the end of 2020 before retiring.

site_title: Volkswagen offers to buy all of Navistar for US$2.9b
summary: Volkswagen is offering to buy the remaining stake in US truck maker Navistar for $2.9 billion. This move would make Traton, Volkswagen's truck division, the sole owner of Navistar. The initial investment by Volkswagen in 2016 was $256 million, which included a strategic technology and supply chain cooperation. The deal would give Volkswagen a stronger foothold in the US market and solidify its position as a global champion. Navistar has stated it will closely study the offer.

site_title: Singapore shares inch higher tracking US rally; STI up 0.05% at open
summary: Singapore shares opened slightly higher, gaining 1.49 points or 0.05% to 3,172.17 at 9:03am, following a Wall Street rally overnight. The US economy grew at a 2.3% pace, short of President Trump's promise, but stocks still rose. Other Asia-Pacific markets, including Japan, South Korea, and Australia, also climbed.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.13 points or 0.07% to 1,546.72. Volume reached 67.80 million lots worth RM34.10 million, with gainers beating losers 116 to 105. This comes as global markets continue their rally, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after WHO ruling on virus
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on January 31, 2020, after the World Health Organization declared the new coronavirus an international emergency but did not recommend travel restrictions. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.81% and the Topix index rose 0.62%.

site_title: Japan to enforce special measures for coronavirus from Sat: government
summary: Japan is moving up the timeline to classify the coronavirus as a "designated infectious disease," bringing it forward to Saturday from February 7, amid growing concerns over the spread of the virus. The government has confirmed 14 cases and will refuse entry to anyone infected, with stricter screening measures also planned. Japan has chartered flights out of Wuhan, with a total of 565 expatriates evacuated so far. The decision was made in response to the World Health Organization's declaration of a global emergency.

site_title: China's Jan factory activity stalls as virus risks grow
summary: China's factory activity stalled in January with a Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 50.0, as export orders fell and a new virus outbreak added to economic risks. The virus has prompted widespread transport curbs and public health measures, weighing on the travel, tourism, and retail sectors. Despite this, the services sector showed a slight increase in activity. China's economic growth cooled to its weakest in nearly 30 years in 2019, and analysts warn the virus could hurt first-quarter GDP growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, BreadTalk, Olam, ComfortDelGro, AA Reit, OUE C-Reit
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will reduce capacity on selected routes to Greater China due to the Wuhan virus outbreak, while BreadTalk Group's CFO has resigned. Olam International may list its food ingredients unit and agricultural supply business. ComfortDelGro has suspended operations in Nanjing and seen declining ridership. Aims Apac Reit's distribution per unit remained unchanged, while OUE C-Reit posted a 12% year-on-year rise in DPU.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares set for first weekly drop of this year on virus fears
summary: Australian shares advanced 0.5% to 7,040, but are on track for their first weekly loss of the year due to fears over the coronavirus epidemic. The S&P/ASX 200 index is down 0.7% for the week, with mining stocks rising despite weaker commodity prices. Investors are also concerned about the economic impact of the virus, with UBS estimating a potential loss of at least US$1 billion in service exports for Australia.

site_title: Europe: Weak earnings hit stocks amid virus fears; FTSE slides as BoE stands pat
summary: European shares fell on Thursday amid virus fears and poor earnings updates, with London's blue chip index closing down 1.4% and the pan-European Stoxx 600 losing 1% for the week. The Bank of England held interest rates steady in Governor Mark Carney's final policy meeting, citing a post-election growth pick-up. The pound rallied, while shares of Royal Dutch Shell and Swatch Group fell due to lower oil prices and quarterly profit halving, respectively.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher as markets monitor Wuhan virus
summary: US stocks ended higher on Thursday, advancing after the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus an international emergency without recommending restrictions on people and goods. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.3% each. Tesla surged 10.3% on strong fourth-quarter earnings, while Facebook plummeted 6.1% despite higher profits. The market reaction was seen as a relief, as it reduced concerns of other countries restricting movement and goods.

site_title: Sarcophagus dedicated to sky god among latest ancient Egypt trove
summary: Egypt's antiquities ministry unveiled the tombs of ancient high priests and a sarcophagus dedicated to the sky god Horus at the Al-Ghoreifa site in Minya governorate. The site, 300km south of Cairo, features 16 tombs containing 20 sarcophagi, some with hieroglyphics, dating back to the Late Period around 3,000 years ago. The tombs were dedicated to high priests of the god Djehuty and senior officials, providing valuable insights into ancient Egyptian culture and history.

site_title: Apple unveils revamped map app to challenge Google
summary: Apple has unveiled a revamped map app in the US, aiming to challenge Google's popular navigation software. The redesigned "Maps" program is fast, accurate, and comprehensive, featuring transit options and prioritizing user privacy. Apple spent years rebuilding the application after a 2012 version was criticized for its inaccuracies. The app will begin rolling out in Europe in the coming months, with a focus on protecting user data and search terms. This move is part of Apple's effort to create a private and intuitive map app that enhances users' lives.

site_title: GM revives Hummer as all-electric vehicle
summary: General Motors confirmed plans to revive the Hummer brand as an all-electric vehicle, to be unveiled during the Super Bowl. The revamped GMC Hummer EV will feature 1,000 horsepower and a 0-60mph acceleration time of three seconds. Production will take place at a Detroit-Hamtramck assembly plant, which received a $2.2 billion investment. The new Hummer will have zero emissions, contrasting with the original gas-guzzling model.
