images.alt_text: It's official: General Motors on Thursday confirmed its plan to reboot the Hummer - a military-style behemoth once seen as a symbol of American excess - in an all-electric version.

site_title: VibroPower warns of FY19 loss; unit seeks to recover S$1.7m loan
summary: VibroPower Corporation, a power generator set manufacturer, warns of a full-year FY19 loss due to lower sales in the second half of the year. The subsidiary VibroPower Pte Ltd has filed a writ of summons in the Singapore High Court to recover a loan of approximately S$1.7 million from a former business partner. The loan is secured by the former partner's sole director and shareholder. The company's shares were trading at S$0.105, down 2.8%, following the announcement.

site_title: On Brexit eve, British PM hails 'new beginning'
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson hailed a "new beginning" for Britain as it prepares to leave the European Union after 47 years on the eve of Brexit. Johnson called for an end to years of bitter arguments over Brexit, saying it was time to move on and bring the country together. Britain will officially leave the EU at 11pm GMT on January 31, with Johnson promising investment in public services and infrastructure to "level up" the whole country. A special cabinet meeting and commemorative events are planned to mark the occasion.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Thursday hailed a "new beginning" for Britain as it prepares to leave the European Union after 47 years.

site_title: Setting the Bar - the rising Japanese cocktail culture in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Japanese cocktail culture is on the rise, with small, well-curated bars offering a unique experience. Shin Gi Tai, owned by Anthony Zhong, is a pioneer in this movement, showcasing classic cocktails with a modern twist and a cozy, intimate atmosphere. Bars like Live Twice and Le Binchotan are also gaining traction, with a focus on minimalist drinks lists and elevated izakaya food. The trend is driven by a shift away from loud, boisterous bars and towards quieter, more inclusive spaces where bartenders know their customers by name.

site_title: Keppel unit to set up Australian office-focused funds with new JV
summary: Keppel Capital Holdings has formed a 50:50 joint venture with Australian Unity to establish funds focused on the Australian metropolitan office sector. The joint venture aims to provide attractive income yield and total return to investors. Keppel Capital will acquire Australian Unity's wholly-owned subsidiary, AUIREL, for approximately A$400,000 in cash, funded equally by both parties. This partnership marks a significant milestone for Keppel Capital in Australia, with Christina Tan describing it as a "significant milestone" in deepening its footprint in the country.

site_title: Coronavirus spread from wife to husband in Chicago: official
summary: US health officials confirmed the first case of a person contracting the 2019 Novel Coronavirus from another person on American soil, a man in Chicago who caught the illness from his wife. The man's condition is stable, and his risk to the public remains low. This case brings the total number of confirmed US patients to six. The virus has spread globally, with 7,700 cases confirmed in China and over 60 cases reported in Asia, Europe, North America, and the Middle East, with no deaths attributed to it outside China.

site_title: Pilots sue American Airlines to halt China flights
summary: US pilots of American Airlines have sued the company to halt flights to China due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, which has claimed nearly 8,000 lives and sickened 170 people in China. The Allied Pilots Association is seeking a temporary restraining order to suspend flights between Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport and Chinese airports. The union cites "serious, and in many ways still unknown, health threats" posed by the virus, citing the World Health Organization's declaration of the outbreak as a global health emergency. The lawsuit seeks to prioritize crew and passenger safety.

site_title: Oil falls to new 3-month lows as virus fears grow, Opec mulls meeting
summary: Oil prices fell 2% to new 3-month lows on concerns over the coronavirus, with Brent crude dropping to $58.29 a barrel and US crude falling to $52.14 a barrel. The World Health Organization declared the outbreak a public health emergency of international concern, but prices pared losses after the announcement. Saudi Arabia is considering an early Opec meeting to address the slide in oil prices, which could reverse the trend if an emergency meeting is called.

site_title: Canadian lender CIBC flags layoffs as it battles challenging environment
summary: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce (CIBC) has announced layoffs as it battles a challenging environment for revenue growth. CEO Victor Dodig stated that the bank needs to become more efficient by focusing on continuous improvement and controlling costs. The exact number of job cuts was not disclosed, but staff were informed that some team members will be leaving the bank in the coming months. This move comes after another Canadian bank, Royal Bank of Canada, also revealed layoffs in recent months.

site_title: Democrats warn of 'lawless' president in impeachment arguments
summary: Democrats in the US House of Representatives warned that acquitting President Donald Trump in his impeachment trial would amount to "normalizing lawlessness," with House impeachment manager Adam Schiff calling Trump's lawyer Alan Dershowitz's argument that a president can do almost anything in the public interest "constitutional madness." Trump is accused of pressuring Ukraine to investigate Joe Biden, and his defence team has argued that the impeachment is politically driven. With conviction and removal of the president requiring a two-thirds majority, Trump's acquittal is virtually assured, but Democrats are pushing for Senate subpoenas of direct witnesses to try to convince Republicans to support removal.

site_title: Amazon shares surge on strong earnings update
summary: Amazon shares surged 12% in after-hours trade following the company's strong quarterly earnings report, with profit rising 8% to $3.3 billion and revenue growing 21% to $87.4 billion. The company's cloud division, AWS, generated nearly $10 billion in revenue, while its Prime service saw a record 150 million paid members worldwide. The strong earnings defied concerns about Amazon's investment in faster delivery and the impact of US tariffs.

site_title: SIA, Silkair and Scoot to cut capacity into China after demand hit by virus
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its subsidiaries SilkAir and Scoot will reduce capacity on selected routes to Greater China due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. Flights between Singapore and parts of mainland China will be suspended starting next month, including routes to Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Xiamen, Chengdu, and Chongqing. Affected customers will be notified and re-accommodated onto other flights. Regulatory approvals are required for the capacity cuts.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines, its subsidiaries SilkAir and Scoot will reduce capacity on selected routes to Greater China starting next month, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Singapore Airlines proposes joint venture with Japan's ANA
summary: Singapore Airlines and Japan's ANA signed a joint venture framework agreement to boost air connectivity between Singapore and Japan, and improve flight options for passengers. The proposed joint venture, if approved, will drive passenger traffic and offer more flight options, strengthening cooperation on services between the two carriers and their respective key markets. The airlines will also offer customers joint fare products, access to flights in their respective route networks, and aligned corporate programs. This will give customers increased flight frequencies and travel convenience.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Japan's All Nippon Airways (ANA) on Friday signed a joint venture (JV) framework agreement, with a view to boost the Singapore and Japan air hubs and improve flight connectivity for passengers.

site_title: SIT, SMRT, SkillsFuture to upskill land transport sector SMEs
summary: The Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT), SMRT Corporation, and SkillsFuture Singapore have partnered to upskill small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the land transport sector. The collaboration aims to improve rail reliability and drive innovation and productivity enhancements. The initiative will help SMEs in the sector to enhance their skills and stay competitive in the industry.

site_title: UK consumer morale hits 16-month high as post-election bounce continues
summary: British consumer morale reached a 16-month high in January, with a confidence index of -9, up from -11 in December, according to a GfK survey. This marks a post-election bounce in the economy, with other indicators also pointing to a pick-up since the December election in which Prime Minister Boris Johnson secured a majority in parliament. The increase in consumer confidence bolsters signs of economic growth, but the UK's economy has also shrunk for a second month.

site_title: Facebook's revenue rises again, but more slowly than ever
summary: Facebook reported its slowest growth ever, with revenue rising 25% to $21 billion in the last quarter of 2019, and profits jumping 7% to $7.3 billion. Despite this, the company's stock fell 7% in after-hours trading due to concerns about decelerating growth rates. Facebook has managed to increase marketing dollars from advertisers, suggesting it has overcome regulatory concerns and competitive pressure. The company plans to focus on election security and explore new business avenues, including augmented reality and peer-to-peer payments.

site_title: AA Reit declares flat DPU of 2.5 S cents for Q3
summary: AA Reit declared a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.5 Singapore cents for Q3, unchanged from the previous year. Gross revenue decreased 1.2% to S$29.5 million due to lease conversions, while net property income grew 18.8% to S$23.1 million. Distributions to unitholders rose 2.1% to S$17.6 million. The Q3 distribution will be paid out on March 26.

site_title: Airlines curb or cancel China flights
summary: Several airlines have suspended or reduced flights to China due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, citing reduced customer demand. Airlines such as AirAsia, Air France, Air India, American Airlines, British Airways, Cathay Pacific, Delta, and others have made changes to their flight schedules. The suspension affects routes to mainland China, Hong Kong, and Macau, with some airlines reducing capacity by 50% or more. The move comes as China advises citizens to postpone trips abroad and several countries urge their citizens to avoid travel to China, where the virus has killed 170 people and infected over 7,000 worldwide.

site_title: ECB should maintain strict inflation mandate: Weidmann
summary: European Central Bank President Jens Weidmann urges the ECB to maintain its strict inflation mandate, warning that a broader interpretation could jeopardize its independence. Weidmann suggests the ECB focus on economic impact of climate change through bank supervision, rather than direct climate action. He also recommends considering climate policy in monetary policy analysis.

site_title: Wuhan virus could score a point - off Singapore's economic growth
summary: Singapore's economy may lose up to one percentage point of growth due to the Wuhan virus, according to economists. The outbreak's impact could be similar to the 2003 Sars epidemic, with a delay or more subdued recovery. Nomura's Euben Paracuelles and OCBC Bank's Selena Ling predict a 0.4-point hit to first-quarter growth, while Moody's Analytics' Steven Cochrane estimates a half-point reduction. However, the government has "sizeable fiscal space" to mitigate the economic risks, and some analysts suggest temporary measures, such as tax breaks and cash grants, could help.

site_title: US gender wage gap narrowed significantly since 1980: study
summary: A US study by the Pew Research Centre found the pay gap between men and women narrowed significantly since 1980, with women's average hourly wages increasing 45% to $22, compared to a 14% increase for men to $26. The study attributes the narrowing gap to women's growing presence in higher-skill occupations, such as critical thinking and social skills. However, women still comprise a smaller share of the workforce, and men's wages remain higher, with a labor force participation rate of 75.3% for prime-age women compared to 89% for men.

site_title: Tesla extends profit run, promises record output
summary: Tesla reported its second consecutive quarterly profit, driven by record vehicle deliveries and strong demand in China. The company forecasts producing over half a million units this year, with its Shanghai factory running smoothly. However, a coronavirus outbreak in China may cause a 1-1.5 week delay in production. Despite this, Tesla's shares rose 13% after hours, reaching a new high of $600, driven by improved manufacturing efficiency and a growing cash balance.

images.alt_text: Tesla said the manufacturing process at its new Shanghai factory (left), which started delivering Model 3 sedans a month ago, was running as expected and that it would increase production of the mass-market cars because of strong demand in China.

site_title: Economy again misses Trump's 3% growth target
summary: The US economy missed President Trump's 3% growth target for the second consecutive year, growing 2.3% in 2019, the slowest annual growth since 2016. The slowdown was attributed to a slump in business investment and trade tensions. Despite the White House's tax cut package, the economy maintained a moderate pace of growth in the fourth quarter, thanks to lower interest rates and increased government spending. Economists expect the economy to continue growing at a moderate pace, but warn of risks, including the ongoing coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Beauty Queens of Bishan
summary: The article "Beauty Queens of Bishan" is not available, but a podcast titled "Weekend Mornings: Beauty Queens of Bishan" is mentioned. The article is not provided, however, I can summarize the provided articles.

site_title: In-room mini bar
summary: Singapore's Oakwood Premier AMTD Singapore introduces a mobile bar service, allowing guests to enjoy free-flow canapes and cocktails from the comfort of their in-room mini bar. The service, available for S$55 per person per night, is believed to be the first of its kind in the region. Guests can indulge in freshly made cocktails for three hours each night, without having to mingle with other guests at the club lounge. The service is offered at the Oakwood Premier AMTD Singapore, located at OUE Downtown 1.

site_title: Proposal to 800 honestbee creditors: 3% cash repayment, 97% in shares of new entity
summary: Former honestbee chairman Brian Koo and his venture firm, Formation Group, plan to repay 3% of the startup's $209 million debt in cash, while the remaining 97% will be repaid in shares of a new entity. Over 1,000 trade creditors owed $500 or less each will receive full repayment. The new entity will own honestbee's assets, with creditors set to own 70-75% of the firm, valuing it at approximately $290 million. The scheme requires approval from the High Court and at least 50% of voting creditors and 75% of debt value.

site_title: Apple delivers best quarter from gains in iPhone sales
summary: Apple reported its best quarter ever, driven by gains in iPhone sales, despite the company's transition to digital services and wearables. The tech giant posted record revenue of $91.8 billion and a net profit of $22 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. iPhone sales rose nearly 8% to $55.9 billion, while services revenue surged 17% to $12.7 billion, fueled by the launch of Apple TV+. The company's shares rose slightly in after-market trades, extending a remarkable streak of growth.

images.alt_text: Apple has stopped reporting unit sales for the iPhone (above), its cash cow in recent years, but revenue for its smartphone sales was up nearly 8 per cent in the final quarter of 2019.

site_title: WHO declares global virus emergency after deadliest day for China
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared a global emergency over the deadly coronavirus, which has killed 170 people in China and spread to over 15 countries. The virus has caused widespread disruptions, including flight cancellations, evacuations, and economic concerns. The WHO's declaration comes after a crisis meeting, with the organization's chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, urging countries to "act together" to limit the spread of the virus. Travel restrictions and economic measures have been implemented, but the WHO has also cautioned against unnecessary measures, saying that travel and trade restrictions with China are not necessary.

images.alt_text: (From left): Michael Ryan, executive director, WHO Health Emergencies Programme, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director general of WHO, Didier Houssin, Chair of Emergency Committee, Maria van Kerkhove, Head AI Emerging Diseases and Zoonoses Unit of WHO, talk to the media at the WHO headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, Jan 30, 2020.

site_title: Oil resumes fall after US stockpile build-up adds to China virus fears
summary: Oil prices resumed their decline after the US stockpile build-up added to concerns over weak demand amid China's spreading coronavirus. US crude inventories rose 3.5 million barrels, fueling fears of a supply glut. The World Health Organization is considering a global alarm as the death toll reached 170. Oil is heading for the biggest monthly drop since May, with the global benchmark crude trading at a US$6.34 premium to WTI. Analysts cut forecasts for Chinese crude consumption, citing the virus's impact on jet fuel demand.

site_title: US economic growth slowed in 2019, hit by trade wars
summary: US economic growth in 2019 slowed to 2.3% due to trade wars, falling short of President Trump's target of 3.0% or higher. Investment and exports were negatively impacted by worsening trade friction with China, leading to a decline in business investments and a collapse in trade in the final quarter. Despite some upbeat consumer spending, economists warn that the details of the data are less encouraging, citing a weakening in wage gains and businesses' unwillingness to spend. The outlook remains uncertain, with the ongoing coronavirus outbreak in China threatening to derail growth.

images.alt_text: The US economy in 2019 expanded by the slowest rate since President Donald Trump took office as worsening trade friction undermined investment and exports, according to new government data released on Thursday.

site_title: Pricing unicorn secondaries a smoke-and-mirrors game
summary: The private markets for unicorn secondaries are opaque and lack standard price discovery mechanisms, making it a "game of smoke and mirrors." Secondaries often trade at a discount to the unicorn's latest valuation, typically between 10-50% off, due to riskier shares issued in earlier rounds. Savvy buyers can use benchmarks such as the company's share price at an upcoming funding round or comparable listed firms to clinch a reasonable deal. Institutional players with access to company information and due diligence can navigate this market, while individual investors face higher risks due to limited public information and price transparency.

site_title: Fast Cash
summary: The HBO six-part documentary "McMillion$" premieres on February 4th, exploring the true crime story of "Uncle Jerry," an ex-policeman who orchestrated a $24m scam in the 1990s McDonald's Monopoly game. The scam involved family and friends cashing in winning pieces, with a web of deceit, revenge, and drugs also uncovered by the FBI. Directed by James Lee Hernandez and Brian Lazarte, the documentary promises to be a thrilling true crime story.

site_title: Paris tour operators, retailers fret as Chinese tourist flows slow
summary: The French tourism industry is experiencing a slowdown in Chinese tourist arrivals due to the coronavirus epidemic, with 2.2 million Chinese visitors expected in 2020. Airlines have suspended flights to and from China, and tour operators are facing significant losses, with some considering staff layoffs. Chinese tourists in France, who account for 7% of tourist revenue, are outsize spenders but their custom is now in jeopardy. While some industry leaders remain optimistic that the epidemic will be brought under control within two to four months, the impact on the French tourism industry appears significant.

site_title: The idea of training has been turned on its head
summary: The traditional approach to learning and training is being reevaluated, with a focus on motivation, adaptability, and creativity. As information becomes increasingly accessible, the key to learning lies not in the content, but in understanding what drives individuals and how they process data. A new model, where the pupil teaches the teacher, is gaining traction, and examinations are shifting from knowledge-pumping to evaluating the productive use of accessed knowledge. Effective learning requires creative thinking, and teacher training will become fieldwork-oriented, prioritizing personal connections and adaptability.

site_title: Portugal looks to cut 'golden visa' incentives for foreign property buyers
summary: Portugal is considering reducing incentives for foreign property buyers through its "golden visa" program, which has pumped 4.5 billion euros into real estate since its inception in 2012. The program aims to attract investors to areas outside Lisbon and Porto, where speculation has driven up housing prices, making it difficult for locals to access affordable housing. Prime Minister Antonio Costa believes the changes will contain speculation and help the middle class access housing, but real estate brokers warn it may prompt investors to buy property elsewhere in Europe.

site_title: Hidden Gems
summary: The Safdie brothers' film Uncut Gems, starring Adam Sandler, has been criticized for its Oscar snub, now available on Netflix. Meanwhile, Netflix has announced the addition of 21 classic Studio Ghibli animated films, starting with My Neighbour Totoro on Feb 1. These releases showcase the streaming service's growing library of international content.

site_title: Deutsche Bank runs up unexpected heavy loss on restructuring costs
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a 1.6 billion euro loss in the fourth quarter, its third consecutive quarterly loss and fifth straight annual loss, due to restructuring costs. The bank's revenue fell 4% in the quarter and 8% for the year, missing analyst expectations. Despite a 31% rise in bond-trading revenue, the bank aims for annual revenue of 24.5 billion euros by 2022. Analysts express concerns about the bank's ability to achieve revenue goals, with Barclays stating that the latest plan does not mark a turning point for the bank.

site_title: OUE C-Reit posts 12% increase in Q4 DPU, NPI soars post-merger
summary: OUE C-Reit reported a 12% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.84 Singapore cents for Q4 2019, driven by a full quarter's contribution from the merger with OUE Hospitality Trust and OUE Downtown Office. Revenue surged 80% to S$86.79 million and net property income jumped 93% to S$70.58 million. The Reit's income available for distribution more than doubled to S$46.63 million, offset by higher interest expense. The company expects continued positive operational performance for its Singapore office portfolio.

site_title: US refiners, chemical plants pare insurance cover
summary: US refineries and petrochemical plants are cutting back on insurance coverage due to rising costs following several years of severe accidents. Industry and insurance sources say this move could leave companies liable for millions in repairs and lost business in the case of an explosion or fire. Inadequate insurance coverage could even lead to refinery closures, posing significant financial risks.

site_title: Singapore cracks down on bids to profiteer from mask sales
summary: Singapore has taken measures to prevent profiteering from surgical mask sales amid Wuhan coronavirus concerns. Retailers and e-commerce platforms will cooperate with authorities, and the government will distribute masks to households. The national stockpile will remain prioritized for healthcare workers. This move follows threats from platforms like Carousell and Qoo10 to suspend profiteering sellers.

site_title: Post-Brexit Britain cannot rely on a special relationship
summary: Post-Brexit Britain faces a new reality where it must choose its alliances in great power politics. The decision to allow Huawei to build Britain's 5G network drew criticism from the US, highlighting the country's lack of a post-Brexit foreign policy. The "special relationship" with the US is unlikely to be as influential as it once was, with the US turning its attention to China and the UK being a less valuable ally. Boris Johnson must navigate the delicate balance between pleasing Washington and avoiding accusations of servility, as the media scrutiny of the special relationship will intensify.

site_title: Fed keeps rates steady, to tailor Treasury bill purchases later this year
summary: The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady at 1.50-1.75% in its first policy meeting of the year, citing continued moderate economic growth and a strong job market. Fed Chair Jerome Powell noted the stabilizing global economic growth and diminishing trade policy uncertainties, but acknowledged the impact of the new coronavirus outbreak on China's economy. The Fed will likely begin scaling back its $60 billion monthly Treasury bill purchases in April-June, and will monitor the situation to ensure adequate short-term liquidity in bank funding markets.

site_title: Olam to list new food ingredients unit first: CEO
summary: Olam International Ltd, a Singapore-based agri-food company, plans to list its food ingredients unit, Olam Food Ingredients (OFI), first in two years, followed by its agricultural supply business, Olam Global Agri (OGA), which is expected to list a year later. The company's CEO, Sunny Verghese, stated that the decision to list the units sequentially is due to the complexity of carving out two large businesses. OFI focuses on sustainable, natural, and value-added ingredients, while OGA targets emerging markets in Asia and Africa. The parent company, Olam International, will provide shared services to both units, aiming to increase liquidity and attract investors who value these businesses differently.

site_title: Interview: David Thompson, chef-restaurateur
summary: Celebrity chef David Thompson, 60, is opening a new Thai fine dining restaurant in Bangkok's MahaNakhon building, marking a return to his roots. Thompson, known for his globally acclaimed restaurants, has been jumping between projects, including Long Chim, Aaharn, and Long Dtai. He credits his Australian restaurants for teaching him the importance of profitability, but emphasizes the need for integrity, quality, and staff commitment to maintain a successful business. Despite criticism of celebrity chefs, Thompson values his independence and is driven by a desire to protect the environment.

site_title: Airlines face steep drop in earnings from virus spread, but will bounce back: reports
summary: Airlines face a steep decline in earnings due to the global spread of the Wuhan coronavirus, but the industry has proven resilient in the past, according to reports. During the 2003 Sars crisis, airlines returned to pre-outbreak levels within nine months. This time, significant routes in China and Asia-Pacific will be most affected, with many airlines suspending or canceling flights. Despite the risks, Iata notes that any impact will be temporary, and air travel has rebounded quickly in previous instances.

site_title: Raising the style bar for men
summary: TAFF, the Textile and Fashion Federation, organizes its first-ever trunk show for men, featuring 14 style brands and tailors, to engage the under-served market. The event aims to promote sustainable fashion and personalized services. The trunk show, held on Feb 8-9, will include workshops on scents, gin blending, and bespoke tuxedos. This initiative, led by TAFF's director of design resource development, aims to address the lack of resources for men's fashion in Singapore.

site_title: Nomura posts 4th straight quarterly profit, led by wholesale business
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc, Japan's largest brokerage and investment bank, reported a 57.1 billion yen (S$709 million) third-quarter net profit, marking its fourth consecutive quarterly profit. The profit was driven by a significant improvement in the wholesale business, with pre-tax income rising to 43.2 billion yen. The retail division also saw a 26% increase in pre-tax income. The company is undergoing a management reshuffle, with Kentaro Okuda being appointed as new CEO, aiming to speed up reform and achieve 140 billion yen in cost cuts by March 2022.

site_title: Sassy girl
summary: Singaporean comedian Jocelyn Chia, who left a law career to pursue stand-up comedy in New York, is set to perform at The Merry Lion on Jan 31 and Feb 1. Chia, who often pokes fun at cultural differences between Asians and Americans, has appeared on MTV, Comedy Central, and the Howard Stern Channel, winning awards for her emerging comedian work. Her upcoming show will feature material on Tinder-dating, money woes, and other aspects of her life in New York.

site_title: Yen and Swiss franc gain on virus fears; yuan falls
summary: The Japanese yen and Swiss franc gained on Thursday as investors sought safe-haven currencies amid rising death tolls from the coronavirus in China. The Chinese yuan fell to a one-month low, while the US dollar rose to a two-month high due to its high interest rates. The yen firmed 0.1% to 108.90 yen per US dollar, while the Swiss franc strengthened against most other currencies. Risk aversion also knocked the Aussie and Kiwi dollars lower, with the US dollar emerging as the preferred safe-haven destination.

site_title: The world of mezcal evolves and grows
summary: The world of mezcal has evolved significantly since 2010, with a growing number of small-production, geographically specific bottles available. Del Maguey, a pioneer in the US market, has sold a controlling interest to Pernod Ricard, but its founder's emphasis on cultural significance remains a benchmark. The industry now boasts dozens of small-production bottles, each highlighting the styles of local mezcaleros and production techniques. Unlike tequila, mezcal can be made in 10 Mexican states, resulting in a wide variety of flavors and aromas. A recent tasting of 20 bottles revealed a high level of quality, with complex and strange flavors, and no single defining feature.

site_title: a-iTrust's Q3 net lifted by higher occupancies, positive rent reversions
summary: Ascendas India Trust (a-iTrust) reported a 4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.12 Singapore cents for its third quarter, driven by higher occupancies, positive rent reversions, and income from the completion of the Anchor building at International Tech Park Bangalore (ITPB). Total property income rose 15% to S$51.5 million, and net property income increased 8% to S$36.6 million. The company's committed portfolio occupancy stood at 99% as of December 31, with a portfolio valuation of S$2.1 billion.

site_title: Singapore the PE, VC hub to watch
summary: Singapore is poised to remain a key hub for private equity (PE) and venture capital (VC) fund management in Asia and globally, driven by four key factors: booming South-east Asian markets, investor demand, efficient operations, and a growing business ecosystem and talent pool. The region's GDP rose over 57% from 2010 to 2019, with 11 "unicorns" and a surge in VC deal value. Singapore's favorable policies, cost-effectiveness, and transparent operations make it an attractive destination for fund managers and investors. As the country continues to attract global talent and investors, it is expected to capture an increasing share of the market for PE and VC fund management in the region and globally.

images.alt_text: There has been a rise in the number of global institutional investors who prefer to invest into South-east Asia and Asia generally via Singapore-domiciled funds, due to the city state's reputation as a well-regulated, transparent jurisdiction.

site_title: Blood ties
summary: A play called "The Long Goodbye" explores the complex relationship between a grown-up son and his father suffering from dementia. The father retains memories of a book he wrote about fatherhood, which helps the son reconnect with him. The play, staged by Taiwan's Story Works X Dreamland, runs at the Esplanade Theatre from Feb 7 to 9 in Mandarin with English surtitles.

site_title: Fighting the good fight with strong tech
summary: The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) has seen significant advancements in its fight against financial misdemeanors, thanks to technology and the internet. While digital paper trails make it easier for perpetrators to cover their tracks, CPIB's tools and agents have become more sophisticated and effective. Companies like Ping An are investing in technology, affirming stakeholder capitalism, and taking a step back from prioritizing shareholder interests. However, there is a gap between stated business values and actual practices, highlighting the need for business leaders to be more authentic in their commitment to corporate purpose.

site_title: Spring Dance
summary: Gardens by the Bay is hosting a 'Spring Surprise' event until Feb 9, featuring free performances including the debut of a "Golden Pyro Dragon Dance" with cold pyrotechnics, and "The Story of Nian", a colourful retelling of a Chinese folk legend. The event marks the first time cold pyrotechnics are used in a dragon dance in Singapore. Performances are produced by Dick Lee Asia and include elaborate costumes and pageantry. Visit gardensbythebay.com.sg for details.

images.alt_text: Spring Surprise is on now until Feb 9 at various timings.

site_title: ST Engineering wins over S$1.5b of new contracts in Q4
summary: ST Engineering secured over S$1.5 billion in new contracts in the fourth quarter of 2019, bringing the group's total announced contract value for 2019 to about S$8 billion. The aerospace sector secured S$1.1 billion, while the electronics sector secured S$449 million. Notable wins include a Boeing 757 maintenance contract and a smart mobility system for Bangkok's Mass Transit System Silom Line. The group's other business sectors also secured undisclosed contracts due to customer confidentiality reasons.

images.alt_text: About S$1.1 billion of the new contracts stemmed from the group's aerospace sector.

site_title: Shapes of the Future
summary: A Japanese design engineer, Shunji Yamanaka, has showcased a prototype, Flagella, at the "Prototyping in Tokyo: Illustrating Design-Led Innovation" exhibition. Flagella is a 3D-printed, robotic creature with natural-like movements, created by combining technology with creativity. The exhibition features various prototypes, including prosthetics, bio-likeness robots, and additive manufacturing pieces, which demonstrate innovative design and technology. Yamanaka's laboratory has been studying the interaction between robots and humans, producing prototypes to envision the future of design-led innovation.

site_title: Employment growth for Singapore residents eased slightly in 2019: MOM
summary: Employment growth for Singapore residents eased slightly in 2019, with the annual average unemployment rate for Singaporeans rising to 3.3% from 3% in 2018. Despite this, employment growth was better than expected, with 55,200 more people employed in Singapore over the course of last year. The challenge lies in job-skills mismatches, according to Manpower Minister Josephine Teo, who noted that employment growth was strong in services industries but contracted in manufacturing and wholesale trade.

site_title: US economy may derail Trump 2020 victory
summary: The US economy may derail President Donald Trump's re-election chances in 2020, despite its current strong performance. The International Monetary Fund estimates 90% of the world's economies are experiencing slowdowns, and experts warn of a global credit and asset price bubble that could burst before the election. This could lead to a disruptively large economic and financial market fallout, similar to the 2008 crisis. Trump's fragile trade truce with China and worsening global economic conditions may ultimately decide the outcome of the election.

site_title: Spice and all things nice at Mott 32
summary: Mott 32, a Hong Kong-based Chinese eatery, has opened its Singapore outpost in The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands. The restaurant offers authentic Chinese cuisine in a lavish, designer setting with controlled opulence. Signature dishes include the Apple Wood Roasted 42 Days Peking Duck and Barbecue Pluma Iberico Pork with Yellow Mountain Honey. Dim sum and evening dim sum options are also available, with high-end ingredients and unique flavor combinations. While not a cheap affair, Mott 32 excels in Szechuan cuisine, with dishes like Poached Garoupa Fillet in Szechuan Pepper Broth and Signature Lobster Mapo Tofu.

site_title: Reskilling efforts for electronics sector get a leg-up
summary: Workforce Singapore has teamed up with the Singapore Semiconductor Industry Association to expand the Professional Conversion Programmes (PCPs) for electronics engineers, benefiting 1,000 professionals over three and a half years. The six-month-long PCPs will cover both classroom and on-the-job training for mid-career workers, while a new Place-and-Train (PnT) Programme will cater to electronics operators. The expansion aims to prepare the industry for future growth in areas like wearable technology and artificial intelligence, with participating employers receiving up to 90% salary support for reskilled employees.

site_title: Hong Realty flipping Suntec office floor for 26% or S$7.6m gross gain
summary: Hong Realty, a private vehicle of the Hong Leong Group, is selling a floor in Suntec City for S$37.1 million, a 26% gain from its 2018 purchase price. The sale price works out to S$2,580 per square foot, comparable to a recent bulk sale of office floors. The company has also secured a tenant for the entire 10th floor under a long lease, offering a net yield of 3.4%. Meanwhile, a deal for six Peck Seah St shophouses is in advanced stages, valued at about S$54 million.

images.alt_text: Hong Realty is selling the 10th floor of Suntec Tower One (extreme left) for S$37.1m, higher than the S$29.48m it paid for the property less than two years ago. The buyer is the Hong Kong-based Rosa family that set up Rosa Securities.

Aberdeen Standard Investments is close to concluding due diligence with a view to buying Nos 48 to 56 Peck Seah Street (above) from a fund managed by Hong Kong-based private equity real estate firm Phoenix Property Investors.

site_title: Beijing expected to cut rates among other efforts to cushion blow from coronavirus
summary: China is expected to unveil efforts to cushion the economic blow from the coronavirus, with the central bank set to keep liquidity ample and the government likely to step up spending. Analysts predict a hit to Q1 GDP, with some forecasting growth as low as 5%, worse than the 2003 Sars outbreak. Measures such as cutting interest rates and increasing government spending may be implemented to slow the downward spiral of economic activities, but may not be enough to boost growth, with the outbreak potentially dragging growth below 5% and affecting the global economy.

site_title: Samsung Electronics Q4 profit slumps 38% on weak demand
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 38% slump in fourth-quarter net profits to 5.23 trillion won (S$6 billion) due to weak demand in key products and falling chip prices. The firm cited a global memory chip market hit by rising supply and falling demand, as well as competition from Apple's new iPhone models. Operating profit dropped 30% year-on-year to 7.2 trillion won, and sales in the fourth quarter stood at 59.9 trillion won. The company expects weak sales in the first quarter of 2020, with a global business environment marked by uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Vice chairman Lee Jae-yong is facing trial a second time for bribery charges.

site_title: Bombay Dining
summary: Bombay Canteen, a restaurant named 'Best Modern Indian Cuisine 2019' by BBC Good Food Awards, will take over the kitchen at Straits Clan in Singapore from Feb 6 to 8. Chef-partner Thomas Zacharias will helm the kitchen for a three-day guest stint. Bombay Canteen focuses on local and seasonal ingredients, showcasing India's regional cuisines in a five-course tasting menu. This event is part of Straits Clan's kitchen takeover series celebrating Asian cuisine.

site_title: Ascott Reit sees drop in bookings from Wuhan virus, has limited exposure to China
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) expects a short-term impact from the novel coronavirus, with reduced global travel affecting bookings. However, CEO Beh Siew Kim believes the Reit's diversified portfolio will ride through the pain, with medium- to long-term trends of increased business travel favoring serviced residences. ART's properties in China, which made up 7% of its portfolio, will be divested, reducing exposure to Wuhan and the Hebei province. The Reit reported a 6% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for Q4 2019, driven by divestment gains and capital distribution.

images.alt_text: Beh Siew Kim, CEO of Ascott Residence Trust Management Ltd, says bookings were in fact up year on year at the start of 2020, before news of the virus broke.

site_title: Expectations shift from Budget goodies to virus relief measures
summary: Singapore's government has shifted its focus from budget goodies to virus relief measures due to the emergence of the Wuhan coronavirus. Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing hinted at a support package, citing previous measures taken during the Sars outbreak in 2003. The government's priority now lies in providing business support, rather than just economic incentives. This move comes as the country prepares for an election year, where the government has accumulated surpluses.

site_title: STI resumes slide on Wuhan virus worries
summary: Asian markets resumed their downward trend on Thursday, with the Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) falling 11.89 points or 0.4% to 3,170.68, amid rising deaths and total infections from the Wuhan virus. Despite concerns, Chinese authorities are ramping up efforts to contain the spread. Healthcare-related stocks, which had seen a surge, saw their gains fizzle out, while other sectors like property management and technology companies gained. The decline in markets was attributed to market worry over the virus, but analysts noted that the fatality rate is lower than during the SARS outbreak.

site_title: Darkness and Light
summary: A couple in Singapore, Mr. and Mrs. Chan, have defied conventional wisdom by choosing dark hues for their two-storey terrace house. Despite being in the banking industry and having young children, they wanted a cozy atmosphere, which they achieved with dark colors. The design solution involved using dark colors to create a warm and intimate feel, rather than relying on skylights to bring in more light. The couple's unique approach to interior design has resulted in a unique and cozy home that feels more welcoming than one might expect from a dark-colored space.

site_title: Shell slows rate of share buybacks as Q4 net halves
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has slowed the pace of its $25 billion share buyback program due to lower oil and natural gas prices, which halved its profit in the last quarter of 2019. The company will now buy $1 billion of shares in the first quarter of 2020, down from $2.75 billion per quarter, and is unlikely to meet its target of completing the program by the end of 2020. Shell's debt ratio has risen to 29.3%, above its 25% target, and the company's cash generation has fallen sharply.

site_title: HK exports up 3.3% in December; full year shows decline of 4.1%
summary: Hong Kong's exports rose 3.3% in December to HK$351.3 billion, ending a 13-month decline streak, driven by increased shipments to mainland China. However, the full-year exports fell 4.1%, the biggest annual decline since 2009, due to the US-China trade war and recession. Imports contracted 6.5% in the year, widening the trade deficit. The COVID-19 outbreak and ongoing trade tensions may impact economic recovery, with the government warning of high uncertainties in the near term.

site_title: Sun, Sea and Spice in Koh Samui
summary: Chef David Thompson has opened his newest restaurant, Long Dtai, in Cape Fahn, a luxurious resort on a private island off the coast of Koh Samui, Thailand. The resort features 22 villas with private pools and offers stunning views of the Gulf of Thailand. Long Dtai emphasizes family-style southern Thai cooking with a sustainability approach, serving dishes such as sweet smoky grilled mussels and smoky bonito relish. The resort, owned by the Pangsrivongse family, was built four years ago as an eco-friendly property, offering a tranquil retreat with easy access to the island's amenities.

site_title: Atari plans to open 8 video-game themed hotels
summary: Atari plans to open 8 video-game themed hotels, following the trend of building larger venues to accommodate esports' growing audiences. The hotels will combine immersive virtual and augmented reality experiences with retro and futuristic video game themes. Construction of the first hotel in Phoenix is set to begin this autumn, with additional locations planned for Las Vegas, Denver, and other cities. The move aims to attract both nostalgic gamers and esports competitors, capitalizing on the global games market's estimated $152.1 billion in 2019.

site_title: Work on fixing India's economy will go beyond Budget this week
summary: India's Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman will present her budget on Saturday, which is expected to address the country's economic woes. The International Monetary Fund has cut its GDP growth estimates for India to 4.8% for the fiscal year ending in March 2020. The government has struggled to meet its tax collection targets, but revenue from the goods and services tax has reached targets in November and December. Sitharaman is likely to announce a boost in government spending, including $1.5 trillion in infrastructure projects, and increased import duties to trim the import bill.

site_title: Suntec Reit to issue S$200m 2.95% notes
summary: Suntec Reit has issued S$200 million worth of new seven-year notes carrying a 2.95% coupon per annum. The notes will mature on Feb 5, 2027, and will be used to finance acquisitions, investments, and general corporate purposes. The proceeds will also fund asset enhancement works and refinancing existing borrowings. The notes are expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange and are guaranteed by Suntec Reit's trustee. DBS Bank and OCBC are the appointed joint lead managers and bookrunners for the deal.

site_title: Boeing says 737 Max costs to surpass US$18b
summary: Boeing has revised its estimate of costs associated with the grounding of the 737 Max, citing a significant increase to over $18.6 billion, surpassing initial forecasts of $18 billion. The new estimate includes costs for shutting down and restarting the factory, compensating airlines, and producing the 737 Max. Boeing's revenue declined 24% in the quarter, and the company's shares rose 2% in response to the report. The company's new CEO, David Calhoun, has vowed to restore trust and transparency, but a precise timeline for the Max's return to service remains uncertain.

site_title: China virus triggers global rush for protective masks
summary: China's coronavirus outbreak has triggered a global rush for protective masks, with factories scrambling to meet demand. The virus has killed 170 people and infected over 8,000, spreading through droplets from coughs and sneezes. Manufacturers have ramped up production, with some running 24-hour shifts, and shops selling out. Governments and retailers have sought to curb hoarding and price gouging, with Taiwan banning the export of specialist masks and Singapore limiting customer purchases. The surge in demand has boosted shares of mask makers, with some companies experiencing record highs.

site_title: Apple, Broadcom to pay Caltech US$1.1b for patent infringement
summary: A California jury ordered Apple and Broadcom to pay US$1.1 billion to Caltech for patent infringement related to Wi-Fi technology. Apple was ordered to pay US$837 million, while Broadcom was ordered to pay US$270 million. The verdict is considered one of the largest patent verdicts in history, stemming from Caltech's lawsuit alleging that Apple products used Broadcom components that infringed on its patents.

site_title: Singapore retailers, e-commerce platforms asked to cooperate in stopping mask profiteering
summary: Singapore's government is taking steps to curb mask profiteering amid the Wuhan coronavirus concerns. Retailers and e-commerce platforms such as Carousell and Qoo10 are being asked to cooperate with authorities to identify and stop errant sellers. Warning letters will be sent to suspected profiteers, and a one-off distribution of masks to households will be implemented. The government also plans to work with the Consumers Association of Singapore and the Competition and Consumer Commission to monitor the situation and investigate any unfair practices.

site_title: Creative Technology's Q2 net loss narrows to US$2.8m
summary: Creative Technology's Q2 net loss narrowed to US$2.8 million, down from US$4.92 million a year ago. Sales rose 6% to US$17.2 million, while gross profit slipped 1% to US$4.75 million due to higher tariffs. The company expects revenue to be lower in the next two quarters and reports an operating loss. Net loss for the six months ended Dec 31 was trimmed to US$8.47 million. Market conditions remain challenging, and the novel coronavirus outbreak in China may negatively affect market conditions.

site_title: S-E Asian unicorn secondaries sought amid IPO drought
summary: South-east Asian unicorns are seeing a surge in secondary share sales, driven by investors seeking liquidity and family offices wanting exposure to the region's growing tech sector. Investors are buying junior classes of shares from founders and early backers, as well as vested options and shares of early employees. The market is expected to gain momentum as the region's unicorns mature and more exits occur, with demand coming from family offices, high-net-worth individuals, and investment firms. Specialized funds are also investing in secondary shares, with one fund raising US$71 million for a fund focused on pre-IPO tech firms.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as China epidemic raises growth concerns
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on Thursday as concerns over the coronavirus epidemic in China and mixed technology earnings weighed on sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 94.29 points, or 0.33%, to 28,640.16, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The decline follows a recent rally in the US market.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 94.29 points, or 0.33 per cent, at the open to 28,640.16.

site_title: Silk Routes offers restructuring lifeline to BM Mobility
summary: BM Mobility, a Singapore-based electric transport company, has received a proposal from Silk Routes Financials to explore restructuring or reorganisation. The proposal includes up to S$1 million in rescue funding to finance the restructuring, which may involve an investment in the company or acquisition of assets. BMM has committed to exclusive negotiations for three months to carve out a definitive agreement. The company's shares have been suspended since July 2019. The restructuring is seen as a lifeline to the struggling company, which may consider court-ordered administration or judicial management to gain temporary respite from creditors.

site_title: Shophouse Appeal
summary: Singaporean artist Zhu Hong's exhibition "Streetscape of Singapore" showcases oil paintings of shophouses and street scenes in historically rich neighborhoods. The 18 artworks, on display at East Garden Gallery, The Fullerton Hotel Singapore, feature distorted architectural elements and are for sale. A portion of the proceeds will be donated to DEBRA Singapore and Make-A-Wish Foundation Singapore. Zhu, a former architect, finds inspiration in shophouses, which he views as "veritable windows to Singapore's past." The exhibition runs until February 28.

site_title: Saving Hongbao
summary: United Overseas Bank is launching a sustainability campaign to upcycle unwanted red packets from Chinese New Year into functional furniture, which will be donated to charity. The campaign, running until February 14, allows customers to drop off their old red packets at 20 selected branches. The upcycled furniture will be created in partnership with an international firm and will help reduce waste. The initiative aims to promote a zero-waste future and encourage customers to reuse and recycle materials.

images.alt_text: As part of its red packet sustainability campaign, United Overseas Bank is upcycling unwanted red packets.

site_title: Hyflux appoints Clifford Chance, Cavenagh Law as legal advisers
summary: Hyflux appoints Clifford Chance and Cavenagh Law as new legal advisers after WongPartnership withdrew from representing the water treatment firm due to a "serious loss of confidence" and other reasons. The move comes as Hyflux undergoes restructuring and considers a S$400 million rescue package from Utico. A court hearing has been adjourned until Feb 20 to resolve the conflict, with Hyflux needing creditor approval for the deal.

site_title: Is your innovation process a corporate illusion?
summary: Innovation labs, often seen as hubs for creativity and disruption, have failed to deliver results for many companies, leading to lab shutdowns. Common blind spots include weak navigational direction, a focus on tweaks rather than transformative changes, lack of credibility with the corporate core, mismanagement of disruption fears, failure to reconcile mindset differences, and sheer impatience. To overcome these constraints, companies must articulate a clear purpose, foster collaboration between the lab and core business, manage disruption fears, and define the innovation lab's role as a long-term strategic initiative. Effective innovation labs require solid executive sponsorship and a diverse team of thought leaders.

site_title: Hotel, tour and F&B sectors casualties of Wuhan virus outbreak
summary: Singapore's hotel, tour, and F&B sectors are experiencing a decline in sales due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. ComfortDelGro Corp has suspended operations in China, reduced ridership for its taxi services, and closed some stores in the country. The company remains stable in Australia and the UK, with precautions in place. The Charles & Keith Group has also shut stores and offices in affected areas, with plans to reopen them when safe. The unions are working with the government to provide support to affected businesses.

site_title: Sterling gains after BoE leaves interest rates unchanged
summary: The Bank of England kept interest rates at 0.75% on Thursday, defying market expectations of a rate cut. Sterling rose 0.6% to US$1.3095, driven by the decision and split vote on the Monetary Policy Committee. The move is seen as a signal that the economy is recovering, but analysts expect the BoE to cut rates in the next six months to support the economy. The decision also saw a shift in market expectations for a March rate cut, with the probability of a cut now at 16%.

site_title: Japan seeks arrests of 3 Americans accused of helping Ghosn escape
summary: Japanese prosecutors have issued arrest warrants for three Americans suspected of helping former Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn escape Japan in December. The suspects, Michael Taylor, Peter Maxwell Taylor, and George Antoine Zayek, are accused of helping Ghosn avoid immigration checks and board a private jet in Osaka that took him to Turkey. The warrants allege they assisted Ghosn in evading authorities and will seek their arrest.

site_title: Britain after Brexit will not be alone, but it will be lonelier
summary: Britain's decision to leave the EU, known as Brexit, has led to the UK being "lonelier" despite not being alone. The UK will lose the right to move and work across the EU, reducing freedom, and citizens will face restrictions on living and working in the UK. This outcome is a result of prioritizing a narrow British identity over a European one.

site_title: Creative Technology posts loss of US$2.8m for Q2FY20
summary: Creative Technology reported a net loss of US$2.8 million for Q2FY20, down from US$4.92 million a year ago, with sales rising 6% to US$17.2 million. The company narrowed its loss per share to four US cents from seven cents in the same period in 2018. For the six months ended Dec 31, revenue was 6% higher at US$31.21 million, while net loss was trimmed to US$8.47 million. The company expects revenue to be lower for the next two quarters and reports an operating loss.

site_title: OUE C-Reit posts 12% rise in Q4 DPU to 0.84 S cent
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (C-Reit) reported a 12% year-on-year increase in Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.84 Singapore cents, driven by a 93% surge in net property income. Revenue rose 80% to S$86.79 million, largely due to the merger with OUE Hospitality Trust and the acquisition of OUE Downtown Office in 2018. The amount available for distribution more than doubled to S$46.63 million.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.88 points to 1,545.59. The index saw a volume of 2.8 billion lots worth RM2.3 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 646 to 253.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; prior week revised sharply higher
summary: US jobless claims fell to 216,000 for the week ended Jan 25, beating economist forecasts of 215,000. However, the prior week's claims were revised to 12,000 higher than initially reported, suggesting a possible correction in the data. This week's drop indicates continued labor market strength, but the revised prior week's data may impact the overall trend.

images.alt_text: The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits fell last week, pointing to continued labour market strength, though applications for the prior week were much higher than initially estimated.

site_title: Taiwan not currently considering calling meeting of national stabilisation fund
summary: Taiwan's Deputy Finance Minister Frank Juan stated there are no current plans to convene the National Stabilisation Fund to address the island's 4.86% stock market decline, driven by fears over China's virus outbreak.

images.alt_text: Taiwan Deputy Finance Minister Frank Juan said on Thursday there is no current plan to call a meeting of the island's National Stabilisation Fund to intervene in the stock market, which is down 4.86 per cent in early trade on fears of China's rapidly spreading virus.

site_title: South Korea reports local human-to-human virus transmission
summary: South Korea reported its first local case of human-to-human transmission of the COVID-19 virus, with six confirmed cases, including two more cases in the country. The patients, including a 56-year-old man who was in contact with the third patient, were diagnosed after arrival from Wuhan, China, or being in contact with other infected individuals. This brings the total number of reported cases to 170 worldwide, with human-to-human transmission also reported in Japan, Germany, and Thailand.

images.alt_text: A sanitation worker sprays disinfectant for precaution against coronavirus on the train at Suseo Station in Seoul. South Korea on Thursday reported the first local case of human-to-human transmission of the deadly virus that has killed 170 people in China and spread to more than a dozen countries.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Price Controller will issue notification letters to retailers and e-commerce platforms to stop mask profiteering. Honestbee plans to repay 3 cents on dollar in cash and equity to creditors. Employment growth for residents slowed in 2019, with unemployment rising to 3.3% in 2019. BM Mobility received a restructuring proposal and MOU. Singapore shares fell 0.4% due to virus fears. Meanwhile, international news includes Malaysia seizing assets, China's GDP growth slowing, and the UK economy shrinking.

site_title: Wuhan virus: 3 new cases confirmed in Singapore, bringing total to 13
summary: Three Chinese nationals from Wuhan, Singapore have tested positive for the Wuhan virus, bringing the total to 13 cases. All are in stable condition and being treated in isolation. There is no evidence of community spread in Singapore. The government has distributed over 5.2 million masks to households, with 5 million already released to retailers, and is sourcing new supplies amid a global shortage.

site_title: ComfortDelGro, Charles & Keith see virus-induced impact on China operations
summary: Singaporean transport operator ComfortDelGro and fashion retailer Charles & Keith Group have seen their Chinese operations affected by the Wuhan virus outbreak. ComfortDelGro suspended operations at a driving school in Nanjing, while ridership for its taxi services and bus trips declined. Charles & Keith Group has shut 55 stores and four Pedro stores in China, citing precautionary measures. The companies' operations in Australia and the UK remain stable, but precautions have been taken. The situation is expected to be closely monitored, with the companies aiming to reopen affected stores as soon as possible.

site_title: BT warns of £500m hit from British limits on Huawei
summary: BT warns that the UK's decision to limit Huawei's role in 5G networks will cost the company £500m, as it needs to remove Huawei's gear from its network and replace it with pricier rivals. This adds to investor concerns about BT's financial performance, which has already seen a 25% decline in shares over the past year. Despite this, BT remains committed to building nationwide gigabit fixed and mobile networks, with plans to roll out 5G using alternative providers.

images.alt_text: Britain's decision to cap Huawei's role in 5G will cost BT £500 million (S$891.2 million), the telecoms company said, as it will need to remove some of the Chinese group's gear from its network and tap pricier rivals.

site_title: Training capacity of PCP for electronics engineers expanded
summary: The Professional Conversion Programmes (PCP) for electronics engineers have been expanded to benefit 1,000 professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) over three-and-a-half years. The six-month PCPs cover classroom and on-the-job training, aiming to reskill mid-career PMETs for growth in the electronics and semiconductor industries. A new Place-and-Train Programme for electronics operators is also being introduced, with 50 initial jobseekers. The expansion aims to address the industry's need for higher-skilled workers, particularly in areas like wearable technology and artificial intelligence.

site_title: The Power of Studio Ghibli
summary: Studio Ghibli's animation legacy, led by Hayao Miyazaki, may prove more enduring than Walt Disney's. Miyazaki's films empower female characters, showcasing them as fearless heroines saving the world since his 1984 film "Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind." His films, such as "Princess Mononoke" and "Spirited Away," promote eco-conscious and anti-war perspectives, while featuring complex, multi-dimensional characters. As the Disney stereotype of the beautiful, gentle princess has been deemed passé, Miyazaki's heroines inspire young viewers to take action against climate change and challenge social norms, making his legacy a significant cultural impact.

site_title: US economy misses Trump's 3% growth target in 2019
summary: The US economy grew 2.3% in 2019, missing President Trump's 3% growth target for the second consecutive year. This marked the slowest annual growth since 2016, largely due to a slump in business investment amid trade tensions. Despite the White House's tax cut package and the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts, the economy maintained a moderate pace of growth in the fourth quarter. Economists expect moderate growth to continue, but warn of risks, including the ongoing coronavirus outbreak and the impact of US tariffs on Chinese imports.

images.alt_text: The US economy missed the Trump administration's 3 per cent growth target for a second straight year, posting its slowest annual growth in three years in 2019 as the slump in business investment deepened amid damaging trade tensions.

site_title: Renault-Nissan can overhaul alliance without ownership change, chairman says
summary: Renault-Nissan chairman Jean-Dominique Senard said the companies can improve their alliance without changing ownership, reversing a previous push for a full merger. The move comes as the automakers struggle to repair a strained relationship after Carlos Ghosn's ouster in 2018. Renault and Nissan will announce revised mid-term plans by May, with each company taking the lead in a specific region: Nissan in China, Renault in Europe, and Mitsubishi in Southeast Asia. The companies aim to add at least $4.4 billion to their bottom line by 2023.

site_title: Turnaround costs push Deutsche Bank to bigger than expected loss
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a loss of 5.7 billion euros (S$8.55 billion) for 2019, its fifth consecutive loss, due to high turnaround costs. The bank's efforts to cut 18,000 jobs and focus on corporate banking are being hindered by a faltering global economy and low interest rates. CEO Christian Sewing attributed the loss to revamp costs, but analysts expressed concerns over weak core operating trends and the bank's ability to generate revenue.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall 2.6% on virus fears
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 2.6% on January 30, 2020, amid concerns over a new SARS-like virus that has killed 170 people in China. The benchmark Hang Seng Index closed at 26,449.13. Markets were also affected by the Chinese New Year holidays, which kept mainland markets closed.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close sharply lower on virus woes
summary: Tokyo stocks closed sharply lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index tumbling 1.72% and the Topix index falling 1.48%. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over the further spread of the new coronavirus. This is the second day of losses for the Tokyo market, with the benchmark index declining 2.21% on Wednesday. The market's downturn is in line with global trends, as investors remain cautious amid the ongoing pandemic and trade uncertainty.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover boss to step down in September
summary: Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) boss Ralf Speth will step down in September after a contract term. Despite a 6% decline in 2019 sales, JLR has shown signs of improvement, with overall sales rising 1.3% in December. The company has bounced back in China, where sales have been strong in recent months. Speth will remain on the board of Tata Sons, the parent group of Tata Motors, which owns JLR, and will be succeeded by a new leader identified by a search committee.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts Q4 DPS flat at 2.77 S cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts posted a flat distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 2.77 Singapore cents for Q4 2020, unchanged from the year-ago period. Revenue rose 3.2% to S$54 million, driven by contributions from rebranded resorts and higher hotel occupancy in Singapore. However, net property income (NPI) fell 1.2% due to lower income from Pullman Hotel Munich and weaker local currencies in Tokyo and Australia. Full-year DPS slipped 2.6% to 9.02 Singapore cents, with NPI and revenue also declining.

site_title: Some Singaporeans with symptoms of virus staying behind in Wuhan even as 92 are evacuated
summary: Singaporeans with Wuhan virus symptoms remain stranded in Wuhan as 92 are evacuated, with some displaying symptoms that may require quarantine upon return. National Development Minister Lawrence Wong said it's "probably not safe" for them to come back on the same plane, and they will undergo medical screening upon arrival. Those with fever or respiratory symptoms will be taken to designated hospitals for further examination.

site_title: Sri Lanka central bank cuts key interest rates to support growth
summary: The Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) cut its key interest rates by 50 basis points, reducing the standing deposit facility rate and standing lending facility rate to 6.50% and 7.50% respectively. This is the third rate cut in less than nine months, aimed at supporting domestic economic recovery and stimulating growth. The decision comes amid concerns over domestic supply disruptions and inflation, which is expected to hover below 5% in 2020.

site_title: BM Mobility receives restructuring proposal, MOU
summary: BM Mobility, a Singapore-based electric transport company, has received a restructuring proposal and a memorandum of understanding (MOU) from Silk Routes Financials. The proposal includes up to S$1 million in rescue funding and may involve an investment in the company or the acquisition/disposal of assets. The MOU is not binding, except for confidentiality and exclusivity provisions. BM Mobility's shares have been suspended since July 2019, and the company is considering court-ordered administration or judicial management to gain more time to assess its options.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets slid at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 1.1% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also losing 1.4% and 1.5% respectively. The declines were driven by growing concerns over the economic impact of the new coronavirus. Investors also looked ahead to the Bank of England meeting on Thursday, which could see interest rate cuts to boost Britain's stalled economy ahead of Brexit.

site_title: Singapore shares resume drop on Thursday on virus fears
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 11.89 points or 0.4% to 3,170.68 on Thursday, amid growing concerns over the Wuhan Coronavirus. Asian markets declined, with Taiwan's Taiex Index plummeting 5.8% and China's markets set to resume trading on Monday. Despite the downturn, some healthcare-related stocks saw gains, while others, including property management group OEL, surged 66.7% on Thursday. Analysts note that while the fatality rate is lower than during the Sars outbreak, the market remains cautious due to the virus's rapid spread.

site_title: On Myanmar's property scene, cheaper condos are hot
summary: In Myanmar, cheaper condos are attracting buyers, with developers and banks offering attractive loan rates. However, a higher supply of serviced residences may put pressure on rents. Analysts from Colliers International warn that this could lead to increased competition and downward pressure on rents across unit configurations. The market is seen as a key sector to watch in Q1 2020, with developers advised to focus on the mid-scale category.

site_title: a-iTrust posts 4% rise in Q3 DPU to 2.12 S cents
summary: A-Trust, an IT park owner, reported a 4% year-over-year increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.12 Singapore cents. Total property income rose 15% to S$51.5 million, driven by income from new properties and positive rental reversions. Net property income increased 8% to S$36.6 million, while income available for distribution rose 7%. The portfolio valuation rose 7% to S$2.1 billion, driven by higher rent and development gains. Units in A-Trust closed one cent lower at S$1.61.

site_title: Two defunct satellites narrowly miss collision: officials
summary: Two decommissioned satellites, an international space telescope and an experimental US craft, narrowly avoided collision on Wednesday, traveling at 53,000kmh. The satellites crossed paths 900km above Pittsburgh without incident, despite a 1-5% risk of impact considered high in the space community. This incident highlights the dangers of hypervelocity satellite crashes, which can generate debris threatening other spacecraft. The closest encounter since 2009, when Iridium 33 struck Cosmos 2251, resulted in a debris field of 1,000 large objects in low Earth orbit.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip on fears of economic pain from coronavirus
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.3% to 7,008.40 due to fears of economic pain from the coronavirus epidemic, which has claimed 170 lives in China and raised concerns of an economic slowdown. Analysts predict Australia's GDP could be 0.2% lower in 2020, with most of the impact felt in Q1 and Q2.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall on fears over economic impact of Wuhan virus
summary: Asian markets fell on January 30, 2020, amid concerns over the economic impact of the Wuhan virus. China reported over 1,700 new infections, prompting airlines to suspend or reduce services, and manufacturers to cut operations. The World Health Organization warned governments to be "on alert" as it considered declaring a global health emergency. US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell expressed concern over the virus's impact on growth in China and elsewhere, leading to market declines in Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Taiwan.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan IPO deal filing nixed in Hong Kong
summary: Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase & Co's application to take Chinese biotechnology company Akeso Inc public was rejected by the Hong Kong stock exchange due to incomplete IPO application. The rejection is part of the "name and shame" list, where incomplete applications are returned, with no tangible punishment for banks. This is the 22nd rejection by HKEX since 2014, with most being from local and mainland Chinese banks. The companies will have to wait at least eight weeks to re-submit an application.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase & Co's application to take a Chinese biotechnology company public was rejected by the Hong Kong stock exchange.

site_title: Employment growth for residents slowed slightly in 2019, unemployment edged up: MOM
summary: Singapore's employment growth for residents slowed slightly in 2019, with the annual average unemployment rate rising to 3.3% from 3% in 2018. Despite this, local employment growth was better than expected, with 26,500 more residents in jobs. Foreign employment grew faster, with 28,700 new hires. The main issue is whether Singaporeans have access to good jobs, with the employment rate of citizens rising over the past decade. Retrenchments were slightly lower than the previous year, at 10,700.

site_title: New Zealand charters flight to assist with Wuhan evacuation
summary: New Zealand has chartered a 300-seat aircraft to evacuate 53 confirmed nationals from Wuhan, China, amid the coronavirus outbreak. The flight, operated by Air New Zealand, will also prioritize Pacific Island and Australian citizens. The government will absorb most of the costs, with passengers paying a nominal fee. Pre-departure health screening, infection control, and isolation measures will be implemented to minimize risks. No confirmed cases of coronavirus have been reported in New Zealand, but a student is undergoing tests in an Auckland hospital.

images.alt_text: New Zealand announced on Thursday it will charter a 300-seat aircraft to evacuate nationals from Wuhan, the Chinese city at the centre of the deadly coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks post 7-week closing low on chip makers, virus fears
summary: South Korean shares fell 1.5% to a seven-week closing low on Thursday, weighed down by chip makers and concerns over the coronavirus in China. The KOSPI index ended 37.28 points, or 1.71%, at 2,148.00. China's National Health Commission reported 170 confirmed deaths and 7,711 infected patients, while Samsung Electronics Co. flagged uncertainties in chip demand. This is the lowest close since December 12.

images.alt_text: The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI ended down 37.28 points, or 1.71 per cent, at 2,148.00, its lowest close since Dec 12.

site_title: Apple, Broadcom ordered to pay US$1.1b for patent infringement
summary: A Los Angeles jury ordered Apple and Broadcom to pay US$1.1 billion to the California Institute of Technology for infringing on four Wi-Fi technology patents. Apple was ordered to pay US$837 million, while Broadcom must pay US$270 million. The university stated it is pleased the jury found Apple and Broadcom infringed on its patents, and committed to protecting its intellectual property.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon down 0.59% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.59% to 3,163.73 as trading resumed on Thursday, with 1.2 billion securities worth S$590.9 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 247 to 133, with healthcare-related stocks Medtecs, Healthway Medical, and UG Healthcare falling, while OEL Holdings jumped 28.6%. The decline was partly attributed to concerns over the economic impact of the new coronavirus, with other Asian markets also falling.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.48% due to concerns over the spread of the new coronavirus. Mainland Chinese markets remained closed for the holidays. The benchmark index ended at 27,030.61 points.

site_title: Wuhan virus deaths hit 170 in China, more than 1,700 new cases
summary: China's viral epidemic death toll has risen to 170, with over 1,700 new cases confirmed, according to the government. Thirty-seven of the 38 new deaths occurred in Hubei province, the epicentre of the contagion. The nationwide cases are causing mounting global fear.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday due to lingering worries about the spread of the new coronavirus, with the Nikkei 225 index sliding 0.47% or 109.31 points to 23,270.09. This followed a choppy session in New York.

site_title: US House Democrats call for US$760b in infrastructure spending over five years
summary: US House Democrats unveiled a proposed $760 billion infrastructure spending bill over five years to rebuild roads, bridges, and reduce carbon pollution. The plan, which includes $329 billion for surface transportation and $1.5 billion for electric vehicle charging, aims to address the country's infrastructure crisis. Democrats want to discuss payment plans with the White House, while the White House criticizes the plan as "far from bipartisan."
