The proposal comes ahead of a September 30 deadline to reauthorize surface transportation spending.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars struggle to shake virus fears
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are under pressure due to concerns about the economic impact of the coronavirus, with investors seeking safe-haven assets. The Aussie dollar fell to a three-month low, while the kiwi dollar remained near its two-month low. Economists warn of a potential loss of A$4.5 billion in tourism revenue and 0.2 percentage points off economic growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia is unlikely to ease interest rates, with analysts predicting a cut in April instead of February.

site_title: G-20 funds fossil fuels US$30b a year under the radar: analysis
summary: Rich nations are providing $30 billion annually through government-backed financial institutions to fossil fuel projects, contradicting the Paris Agreement's goal to slash carbon emissions. G-20 countries' export credit agencies (ECAs) favor oil, gas, and coal projects over renewable energy schemes, with the US providing $7.1 billion annually since the 2015 Paris treaty. The worst offenders include China, Japan, South Korea, and Canada, accounting for 78% of G-20 fossil fuel support.

site_title: Shopee, SUTD offer bond-free scholarships to groom local tech talent
summary: Shopee and the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) have partnered to offer bond-free scholarships to groom local tech talent. Four Singaporean undergraduates will receive full, four-year scholarships worth S$15,000 annually, covering tuition fees and study-related expenses. The scholarships aim to support "financially disadvantaged" students in pursuing education in technology and design. The partnership also includes dialogue sessions to explore collaboration avenues, combining SUTD's educational expertise with Shopee's industry know-how and regional presence.

images.alt_text: From left: Prof Chong Tow Chong, President of SUTD; Gang Ye, group chief operating officer of Sea; and Prof David Rosen, research director of the SUTD digital manufacturing and design centre

site_title: Airlines may face 'steep' drop in earnings, air traffic from virus spread: S&P
summary: Airlines face a "steep" drop in earnings and air traffic due to the global spread of the Wuhan coronavirus, similar to the Sars outbreak in 2003. The International Air Transport Association notes the industry's resilience to shocks, with air travel volumes recovering quickly in past instances. Significant routes in China and the APAC region will be most affected, with airlines already suspending or cancelling flights. S&P Global Ratings expects a similar effect to the Sars outbreak, with airlines potentially losing 8% of annual RPKs and US$6 billion in revenues.

site_title: India reports its first case of coronavirus
summary: India reported its first case of coronavirus on January 30, 2020, in the southern state of Kerala. A patient, a Wuhan University student, tested positive and is stable in isolation. The Indian government initially considered not bringing in nationals from Wuhan due to infection risk but ultimately did so under pressure from students and their parents.

images.alt_text: Indian people who recently travelled from China get themselves checked at Coronavirus ward at Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Disease, in Bangalore, India, 29 Jan 2020. India said on Thursday a patient in the southern state of Kerala had tested positive for novel coronavirus, the first case in the country of the virus.

site_title: Singapore stocks edge down on lingering virus jitters; STI opens 0.1% lower
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% lower on Thursday, January 30, 2020, amid lingering Wuhan virus fears. The Straits Times Index fell 3.18 points to 3,179.39 points, with healthcare and medical plays among the most heavily traded. Banking stocks started the morning mixed, while US and European markets closed slightly higher overnight on stronger corporate results.

site_title: Paris tour operators fret as Chinese tourist flows slow
summary: The French tourism industry is concerned about a decline in Chinese tourist arrivals due to the coronavirus epidemic. Airlines have suspended flights to and from China, and tour operators are experiencing significant losses. Chinese tourists in France account for 7% of tourist revenue, but their spending is now in jeopardy. While the impact appears "marginal" so far, the French consultancy MKG expects the epidemic to eventually affect the wider market.

site_title: SIT, SMRT and SkillsFuture to upskill land transport sector SMEs in tie-up
summary: The Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT), SMRT Corporation, and SkillsFuture Singapore have partnered to upskill 100 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the land transport sector over three years. The collaboration aims to improve rail reliability, drive innovation, and enhance productivity in the sector. The target SMEs include cleaning companies and rolling stock maintenance providers, and the partnership is expected to benefit the sector as a whole.

site_title: honestbee proposes to repay creditors 3 cents on dollar in cash, rest in equity
summary: Former honestbee chairman Brian Koo and his venture firm, Formation Group, propose to repay 3% of honestbee's US$209 million debt in cash, totaling around US$6.27 million, and the remaining 97% through the issuance of shares in a new entity owning honestbee's assets. This plan, known as a scheme of arrangement, aims to restructure the startup's debt. Over 1,000 trade creditors owed S$500 or less each will receive full repayment.

site_title: UK economy seeks to balance Brexit with global strains
summary: The UK economy is navigating the challenges of Brexit and global economic strains. Despite recent positive data, the economy risks turbulence as Prime Minister Boris Johnson seeks trade deals. The Bank of England is expected to announce its first interest rate cut in over three years due to economic headwinds. The UK economy contracted for the second month, dealing a blow to opposition leader Keir Starmer. Global economic concerns, including the coronavirus and slowing China's GDP growth, are also affecting the UK's economic outlook.

site_title: Japan Display shares suspended after fresh report of Ichigo stake
summary: Japan Display shares were suspended after a report from the Nikkei business daily stated that Ichigo Asset Management would invest approximately 100 billion yen (S$1.22 billion) into the company. This investment aligns with previous reports, which mentioned Ichigo would provide up to 90 billion yen in financial support. Japan Display aims to finalize the funding deal by the end of the month.

site_title: Shell appoints Singaporean Euleen Goh as deputy chair
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has appointed Singaporean Euleen Goh as its deputy chair, effective May 20. Goh, who joined Shell in 2014, succeeds Gerard Kleisterlee, who will not seek re-election at the company's annual general meeting. Goh's appointment marks a significant change in Shell's leadership, with the company undergoing a transition in its senior management roles.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell said on Wednesday director Euleen Goh would take over as its deputy chair from May 20.

site_title: Trump, White House seek to quash Bolton testimony at Senate trial
summary: US President Donald Trump and the White House are pushing back against Democratic efforts to have former national security adviser John Bolton testify at the Senate impeachment trial, arguing that his testimony could reveal government secrets. The Senate is divided, with 53 Republicans holding a majority, and Democrats need at least four Republicans to support calling Bolton as a witness. Trump has called the push for witnesses an "uphill fight" and blasted Bolton, who has corroborated charges that Trump withheld military aid to Ukraine in a bid to influence the 2020 presidential election.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump and White House lawyers pushed back on Wednesday against Democratic efforts to have John Bolton testify at the Senate impeachment trial of the president, arguing that the former national security adviser could reveal government secrets.

site_title: US sees record year for private space sector in 2020
summary: The US plans to issue 40-50 space licenses in 2020, a significant increase from 31 licenses in 2019. This growth is driven by private sector companies like SpaceX, which is expected to send astronauts to the International Space Station for the first time this year. The FAA attributes the surge to the industry's rapid progress, citing SpaceX's recent Starlink launch and Rocket Lab's 10 successful launches since 2018. China remains the leader in rocket launches, with 34 in 2019, but the US is catching up with a renewed focus on commercial space transportation.

site_title: UOB, clients raise over S$1.8m for charity at Chinese New Year fundraiser
summary: UOB Group Commercial Banking and over 800 clients raised more than S$1.8 million for local charities at the bank's annual Chinese New Year fundraiser. The event, held at The Ritz-Carlton, Millennia Singapore, saw UOB match clients' donations dollar for dollar up to S$250,000. Beneficiaries included local charities and arts organizations.

site_title: White House bars Bolton book release over 'top secret' material
summary: The White House has barred the release of former national security advisor John Bolton's book, "The Room Where it Happened," due to the presence of "top secret" information. A letter to Bolton's lawyer stated that the book contains "significant amounts of classified information" and that it cannot be published without the deletion of this information. The warning was made as Bolton's book corroborates the abuse-of-power impeachment charge against President Donald Trump, particularly regarding Ukraine.

site_title: New coronavirus study places incubation period at around 5 days
summary: A study published in the New England Journal of Medicine estimates the incubation period of the new coronavirus to be around 5.2 days on average, with symptoms emerging between 2-10 days after exposure. The Chinese team behind the study supports a 14-day medical observation period for those exposed to the pathogen. This estimate varies from the World Health Organization's 2-10 day range, but the study's findings contribute to the understanding of the virus's progression.

images.alt_text: The period between exposure to the new coronavirus that originated in China and symptoms is 5.2 days on average, but varies greatly among patients, according to one of the largest studies yet published on the deadly epidemic.

site_title: News Corp aggregator aims to break free from tech platforms
summary: News Corp's new online news aggregation service, Knewz, aims to break away from tech platforms by offering a diverse range of sources, including major outlets like Al-Jazeera and Fox News. The app combines AI with experienced editors to curate headlines, providing a broad perspective on stories. Knewz will share data with publishers, allowing them to monetize their content, and is seen as a competitor to tech giants like Google and Facebook. The service is being tested and its success is uncertain, but it could potentially steer readers away from major tech platforms.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge lower on mining stocks, rising virus death toll
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 7,018.4, weighed down by Newcrest Mining's 5.1% drop due to a lower quarterly gold output and rising coronavirus death toll in China, now at 170. The World Health Organisation expressed "grave concern" but did not declare a global emergency. Fortescue Metals Group rose 3% despite a 9% jump in second-quarter shipments to China. Treasury Wine Estates recovered 5.3% after its biggest fall on Wednesday.

site_title: Warren proposes criminalising disinformation about voting in US
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren proposed civil and criminal penalties for spreading false voting information in US elections. The proposal aims to combat disinformation, which Warren blames on major tech companies for spreading in their pursuit of profits. The move comes amid concerns that disinformation, including efforts by Russia in the 2016 election, could influence this year's vote.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 5.96 points or 0.38% to 1,544.51, with a trading volume of 104.52 million lots worth RM38.96 million. The market opened lower on Thursday.

site_title: Morgan Stanley warns coronavirus could drag on global, Chinese GDP growth
summary: Morgan Stanley warns that the coronavirus outbreak in China could drag on global growth and shave up to 1 percentage point off Chinese GDP growth in the first quarter. Assuming the virus peaks in February or March, global economic growth could be reduced by 0.15 to 0.3 percentage point. If the outbreak continues for three to four months, global growth could be further hit by 0.2 to 0.4 percentage point in the second quarter.

site_title: White House economic adviser says he would like to see bolder Federal Reserve
summary: White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow expressed a desire for the Federal Reserve to be bolder in its monetary policy decisions, hours after the central bank announced keeping interest rates steady. Kudlow praised the Fed for moving in the right direction and making the right decision.

site_title: Three Japanese evacuated from Wuhan have new coronavirus: health minister
summary: Three Japanese citizens evacuated from Wuhan, China, have tested positive for the new coronavirus strain, according to Japan's health minister. The three individuals arrived in Japan on the first flight from Wuhan, where a deadly outbreak has killed 170 people and infected thousands. This news comes as the virus continues to spread globally, with over 200 Japanese citizens evacuated from the city.

site_title: CDLHT's Q4 DPS flat at 2.77 S cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a flat quarterly distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 2.77 Singapore cents for Q4, unchanged from the previous year. Revenue rose 3.2% to S$54 million, driven by contributions from the Raffles Maldives Meradhoo resort and Italy hotel. However, net property income (NPI) fell 1.2% due to lower income from Pullman Hotel Munich. Full-year DPS declined 2.6% to 9.02 Singapore cents, while NPI and revenue also fell.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Suntec Reit, CDLHT, Ascott Reit, Starhill Global, First Reit, EC World Reit, Micro-Mechanics
summary: Singapore stocks to watch on Thursday include Singtel, which announced a Thai associate's order to pay S$1.37 billion in damages; Suntec Reit, which launched S$200 million worth of new notes; and CDLHT, which posted unchanged quarterly distribution. Ascott Residence Trust saw a 6% increase in its quarterly distribution, while Starhill Global Reit and First Reit reported flat quarterly distributions. EC World Reit and Micro-Mechanics also reported unchanged operations.

site_title: Wuhan virus outbreak tests world's dependence on China
summary: The Wuhan virus outbreak is testing the world's dependence on China, with the country's economic and travel restrictions affecting global industries. Companies like Ford, Toyota, and Apple are idling factories, closing stores, and rerouting supply chains due to the outbreak, which has killed over 100 people and sickened thousands. China's importance to the global economy is highlighted, with the country accounting for roughly one-sixth of global output, and its consumers and tourists generating significant revenue. The outbreak is also prompting businesses to consider shifting their factories to countries with better relations with the US, exacerbating the ongoing trade war.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Operation Broken Wing
summary: The Money FM podcast "Operation Broken Wing" explores how fitness has improved the lives of marginalized youth in Singapore. Claressa Monteiro interviews Innervate Fitness co-founders Lionel Choong and Moses James, as well as Daryl Tan from the Singapore Children's Society. The program highlights the benefits of the program and the society's involvement, showcasing how fitness can positively impact young people's lives.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics shuts Suzhou factory amid virus outbreak
summary: Micro-Mechanics Holdings has temporarily closed its Suzhou factory in China due to the Wuhan virus outbreak, with operations expected to resume on February 10. The factory serves only Chinese customers, but the closure is not expected to affect other markets. The company's revenue from China accounted for 30% of its total revenue in the first quarter of 2019. Micro-Mechanics is monitoring the situation closely and will keep shareholders informed.

site_title: No US passengers evacuated from China show symptoms of virus: officials
summary: US citizens evacuated from China's Wuhan city, the epicentre of a deadly virus outbreak, have been cleared of showing symptoms of infection. The 195 Americans, who were flown to California, are being held in isolation at a military base for 72 hours on a voluntary basis. No symptoms have been reported, according to a senior US health official. The individuals will remain in quarantine until the 72-hour period ends, after which they will be allowed to leave the base.

site_title: Facebook results beat forecasts but shares take a hit
summary: Facebook reported stronger-than-expected quarterly earnings and user growth, with net income rising 7% to $7.3 billion and revenue increasing 25% to $21 billion. However, shares dropped 6% in after-market trades due to concerns over increasing costs and investments in protecting user data and preventing hate, abuse, and disinformation. Despite this, analysts praised the company's continued growth in advertising revenue and user base, with some expecting Facebook's momentum to continue.

site_title: Canada to bring home up to 160 from China over coronavirus
summary: Canada has chartered a plane to repatriate up to 160 of its nationals from China due to the coronavirus epidemic. Foreign Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne confirmed the move, stating it may take several days to obtain permission to land. Canada has warned Canadians to avoid non-essential travel to China, and its flagship airline Air Canada has suspended flights to mainland China. The Chinese government has sealed off Wuhan and neighboring cities to contain the spread of the virus, with 6,000 infected and 132 deaths reported.

site_title: Oil mixed as virus fears, US stock build face talk of further Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices were mixed on Wednesday, with Brent crude rising 0.5% to $59.81 per barrel and US crude falling 0.3% to $53.33 per barrel. Worries about the coronavirus outbreak and swelling US crude inventories weighed on prices, but talk of Opec extending oil output cuts boosted the market. US crude inventories grew more than expected, while petrol stocks hit record highs. Opec is considering extending production cuts until at least June, with the potential for deeper reductions if oil demand in China falls significantly due to the virus.

site_title: Five people in France confirmed to have coronavirus
summary: Five people in France have been confirmed to have coronavirus, including the daughter of an 80-year-old Chinese tourist in a Paris hospital who is seriously ill. This is the fifth confirmed case in France, with over 100 deaths reported globally since the virus emerged in Wuhan, China in December. A plane is set to repatriate 200 French people stranded in Wuhan on Wednesday evening.

images.alt_text: The daughter of a Chinese tourist who is seriously ill in a Paris hospital has become the fifth person in France to be confirmed with the coronavirus, officials said Wednesday.

site_title: Suntec Reit prices new S$200m 7-year notes at 2.95%
summary: Suntec Reit has priced new S$200m 7-year notes at 2.95% per annum. The notes, to be issued under a US$1.5 billion euro medium-term note programme, will be listed on the Singapore Exchange and used to finance acquisitions, investments, and corporate purposes. Net proceeds will also be used for asset enhancement works and refinancing existing borrowings. The notes are expected to be issued at par on February 5 in denominations of S$250,000.

site_title: SGX approves POSH's proposed delisting
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has approved PACC Offshore Services Holdings' (POSH) proposed delisting. POSH, a loss-making offshore support vessel operator, had suspended trading of its shares on January 3 after Quetzal Capital's cash offer of S$0.215 per share was accepted by all dissenting shareholders. Quetzal Capital, which exercised its right of compulsory acquisition, will now own all shares of the company, paving the way for its delisting from the SGX.

site_title: Canada starts ratification of North America trade pact
summary: Canada has begun the process of ratifying the USMCA trade pact, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau expressing hope for a swift passage. The agreement, signed by US President Donald Trump and Mexico, replaces the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement and aims to promote good jobs, stability, and trade opportunities for Canadians. Trudeau acknowledged opposition and industry questions, but emphasized the pact's importance for Canada's economy. A final Canadian vote is expected after several weeks of parliamentary debate.

site_title: Microsoft gets lift from rise in earnings
summary: Microsoft reported a 38% increase in overall profit to $11.6 billion in the fiscal second quarter, driven by 14% revenue growth to $36.9 billion. The company's cloud computing division saw a 27% revenue gain, while productivity and business division revenue rose 17%. Microsoft shares gained 2% in after-hours trade following the release. The earnings highlighted the company's successful transition to a diversified tech giant focused on business services, with CEO Satya Nadella emphasizing innovation and sustainability.

site_title: Wing Fong Mansions and Wing Fong Court up for collective sale
summary: Singapore's Wing Fong Mansions and Wing Fong Court, two adjacent freehold condominiums in Geylang, have been launched for collective sale with reserve prices of S$176 million and S$108 million, respectively. At least 80% of owners at Wing Fong Mansions have given consent for an en bloc sale, with the potential for a redevelopment into a larger integrated development. The sites are zoned for commercial or institutional use and are a 10-minute drive to the central business district, with plans to gentrify the area into a new entertainment district.

site_title: Tesla extends profit run, promises record production, driving stock up 13%
summary: Tesla Inc. reported its second consecutive quarterly profit, driven by record vehicle deliveries and increased production. The company expects to deliver over 500,000 units in 2020, with a cash balance of $6.3 billion. Shares surged 13% to an all-time high of $654, reaching $600 for the first time. Tesla plans to allocate production capacity for its new Model Y and increase production of the Model 3 due to strong demand in China.

images.alt_text: Tesla Inc on Wednesday posted the second quarterly profit in a row on record vehicle deliveries and said it would deliver more than 500,000 units this year, as the electric carmaker's shares surged to new highs.

site_title: Europe: Santander buoys shares but coronavirus fears persist
summary: European shares ended higher on Wednesday, led by a 4.4% rise in Banco Santander's shares after the lender posted a higher quarterly net profit. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5% despite subdued sentiment due to ongoing coronavirus concerns. Analysts warn that the virus could impact global economic growth, with China's government economist predicting a potential drop to 5% or lower. Central bank meetings, including the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, are expected to influence market sentiment.

site_title: Sunseap lands S$50m from Temasek and private equity fund for solar projects
summary: Sunseap, a Singapore-based solar-energy system company, has secured S$50 million in funding from Temasek and private equity fund ABC World Asia. The funds will be used for solar projects in Singapore and Asia. ABC World Asia's managing director Tan Shao Ming has joined Sunseap's board of directors. This investment marks a significant growth milestone for Sunseap, which has also recently partnered with UOB's U-Solar programme and secured previous investments from Shell, Banpu, and Trirec.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust posts 6% rise in Q4 DPS to 2.27 S cents
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) reported a 6% rise in quarterly distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 2.27 Singapore cents, up from 2.15 cents a year ago. Revenue declined 2% to S$134.1 million, while gross profit improved 3% to S$65.3 million. Unitholders' distribution rose 6% to S$49.3 million, with a one-off partial distribution of divestment gain. For the full year, DPS rose 6% to 7.61 cents, and gross profit improved 6% to S$252.6 million.

site_title: Trans-cab calls off IPO a second time amid virus outbreak
summary: Trans-cab Holdings, Singapore's second largest taxi operator, has postponed its second attempt to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to bad market conditions amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The company cited the virus as a major threat to global stock markets. This is the second time Trans-cab has delayed its initial public offering (IPO). The company's decision reflects the uncertainty and volatility caused by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: On Wednesday, Singapore's second largest taxi operator by fleet size, Trans-cab Holdings, was forced to postpone its second attempt to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), citing bad market conditions.

site_title: Federal Reserve holds US interest rate steady but eyes virus outbreak
summary: The US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady at 1.5-1.75% but emphasized its monitoring of the global economy due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak in China. Chairman Jerome Powell noted the outbreak's potential impact on global supply chains and Chinese output, while also expressing cautious optimism about the global outlook. Policymakers signaled a desire for higher inflation to reach the 2% target, and the decision was seen as a response to the economic uncertainty, despite President Trump's calls for lower interest rates.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q4 net profit slumps 38%
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 38% slump in fourth-quarter net profits to 5.23 trillion won (S$6 billion), citing weakening demand in key products and falling chip prices. The firm's operating profit dropped 30% year-on-year to 7.2 trillion won. Despite a boost from strong demand for mid-range A-series handsets, Samsung faces increased competition from Apple and challenges from a global trade war and diplomatic tensions. The company expects weak sales in the first quarter of 2020 due to seasonality and uncertainties in the global business environment.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics said on Thursday its operating profit fell 34 per cent in the October-December quarter, in line with its estimate earlier this month, as the South Korean conglomerate battled a downturn in the memory chip market.

site_title: African nations take first measures to stop spread of Chinese virus
summary: African nations, including Nigeria, have begun measures to stop the spread of the new coronavirus, with no verified infections reported in sub-Saharan Africa. Nigeria issued a travel advisory, advising citizens to delay travel to China unless essential, and requiring airlines to report sickness on flights. Equatorial Guinea quarantined four travelers from Beijing, while the Chinese embassy in Mauritania advised its nationals to remain confined for 14 days. Experts warn of concerns due to poor healthcare infrastructure in Africa, with many countries having close economic ties with China.

site_title: STI little moved after Tuesday's sell-off
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 1.32 points or 0.04% to close at 3,182.57 after Tuesday's sell-off, driven by investors buying on dips triggered by the China virus scare. The rebound was partly attributed to medical groups and rubber glove makers benefiting from the outbreak. However, analysts warned that the market may experience temporary gains before clarity on the Wuhan virus outbreak is established.

site_title: Zuckerberg to visit Brussels amid EU bid to revamp tech rules
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is set to visit Brussels in mid-February to discuss a framework for new EU rules and regulations on the internet, amid antitrust and privacy scrutiny over user data. The visit comes as the EU prepares to unveil plans to regulate artificial intelligence. Zuckerberg will meet with European officials to address concerns over data handling, disinformation, and liability for hate speech and illegal content. The trip follows a recent visit by Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai, and Zuckerberg's previous visit to Brussels in 2018.

site_title: Property stocks weaken in Hong Kong amid virus concerns
summary: Hong Kong property stocks declined 3.6% on Wednesday, with Hang Lung Properties and Kerry Properties falling over 5%. Investors worry about the coronavirus's impact on the sector, with sales transaction volumes for 10 large housing estates tumbling 75% last weekend. Developers are taking precautions, but real estate companies have stronger balance sheets than during the 2003 Sars outbreak. Analysts predict concerns will continue until a material coronavirus outbreak is seen, with the Chinese New Year holiday contributing to the decline.

site_title: ESG preparing business continuity guide for firms
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) advises businesses to prepare for different Wuhan coronavirus scenarios and develop business continuity plans, even though the situation in Singapore is currently stable. ESG is creating a business continuity guide, supported by the Singapore Business Federation (SBF), to help firms develop such plans. The guide aims to provide a framework for businesses to prepare for various scenarios and minimize disruptions.

site_title: Bitcoin has lost steam, but criminals still love it
summary: Bitcoin's value has dropped, but its use for illegal activities, such as buying stolen credit card information and drugs on darknet markets, has surged 60% to a new high of $601 million in the last three months of 2019. Despite efforts by authorities to contain illegal activity, illicit transactions account for only 1% of all bitcoin transactions, nearly doubling from the previous year. The FBI remains undeterred, while Chainalysis' data suggests that some illicit activity may be underreported.

site_title: Airlines scramble to cancel China flights as virus spreads
summary: Airlines worldwide suspended flights to China as the Wuhan virus spread, with British Airways halting flights to Beijing and Shanghai, Finnair suspending flights to Nanjing and Beijing, and Cathay Pacific cutting capacity by 50%. The virus has claimed 132 deaths and 5,974 confirmed cases in China, with clusters reported in Germany and other countries. Governments tightened travel restrictions, causing a 7.4% drop in domestic travel in China during the Chinese New Year holiday season, and several airlines, including Jetstar Asia and Lion Air, suspended flights to Chinese cities.

site_title: Thailand cuts growth forecast from 3.3% to 2.8%
summary: Thailand cuts its 2020 economic growth forecast to 2.8% from 3.3%, citing weaker exports, a delayed budget, and the spread of the Wuhan virus. Weaker exports, downgraded to 1% growth, and a decline in tourism due to China's ban on group tours are major setbacks. The finance ministry expects private investment and large public projects to drive growth, despite the downgrades, and forecasts overall foreign tourist numbers to drop by 400,000 to 41.1 million this year.

site_title: Why Brexit transition has risk, not just opportunity
summary: The UK is entering an 11-month transition period after Brexit, with a tight deadline to agree on a future trade deal by the end of the year. However, the process is fraught with risks, including the need for approval from 40 national and regional parliaments across Europe and the European Court of Justice. The UK government's desire for significant freedom to diverge from EU regulations also poses a challenge, potentially leading to a "bare bones" trade agreement. The threat of a disorderly Brexit raises the risk of a cliff-edge in negotiations, requiring both sides to return to the negotiating table with new incentives.

site_title: LVMH sales growth slows ahead of Chinese virus impact
summary: LVMH's sales growth slowed to 8% in the fourth quarter, down from 11% in the third quarter, due to protests in Hong Kong and concerns over the Chinese coronavirus outbreak. Analysts had expected an 8.7% increase. The luxury goods maker cited a weaker yuan and slowing domestic growth as headwinds. Shares fell 0.8% on Wednesday. LVMH chairman Bernard Arnault believes the crisis may be partially resolved by the end of March, but warns it could last two years if not resolved sooner.

site_title: From comprehensive deal to full-scale rupture
summary: The UK is set to leave the European Union on January 31, 2020, with 25,000 civil servants working on Brexit. Chancellor Sajid Javid initially stated that the UK would not align with EU regulations, but later reversed his position, claiming a new comprehensive free trade agreement (FTA) would be signed by the end of the year. Possible scenarios for Brexit include a bespoke UK-EU deal, a goods-only FTA, or a "skinny" agreement, with a full-scale rupture also possible, potentially leading to queues at borders and re-negotiation of treaties.

site_title: Renault names VW's De Meo as CEO, finalises management shakeup
summary: Renault has named Luca de Meo, former head of Volkswagen's Seat brand, as its new CEO, effective July 1. This appointment comes after a year of turmoil and a management shake-up, including the departure of former CEO Carlos Ghosn. De Meo will lead Renault in its efforts to reset its strained alliance with Nissan and address a downturn in demand. Meanwhile, Nissan has announced plans to scale back its US sales operations, closing two regional offices and offering buyouts to some staff as part of a broader restructuring effort.

site_title: Home prices in 20 US cities up the most in 9 months
summary: Home prices in 20 US cities rose 2.6% in November, the fastest pace in nine months, driven by stronger demand and lean housing inventory. This exceeds the median forecast of a 2.4% annual advance. The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller index reported this increase, marking a reversal of the decline in home prices seen in previous months.

site_title: Singapore companies in China experiencing limited fallout
summary: Singapore-listed companies in China are experiencing limited fallout from the Wuhan virus outbreak. Koufu Group's operations in Macau took a hit, but its Singapore operations remain unaffected. EC World Reit, which has a portfolio of eight assets in China, reported no significant impact on tenants' businesses. Wilmar International, which operates over 350 plants in China, also said its business has not been hurt despite shutting down nine plants in Wuhan. Micro-Mechanics (Holdings) is closing a factory in Suzhou until February 9.

site_title: Historic Washington bank reborn as swanky hotel
summary: The historic Riggs National Bank in Washington D.C. will reopen as the 181-room Riggs Washington DC hotel on February 3, operated by the Lore Group. The hotel, located in a 120-year-old Romanesque Revival building, features a rooftop event space, bold design, and a subterranean bar. The hotel's design reinterpretation of the original building includes custom-created rooms, art deco-inspired chandeliers, and marble floors. The hotel aims to fill gaps in the downtown DC market, offering a non-partisan alternative to existing luxury hotels, and is seen as a key part of the city's renaissance.

site_title: This is a chance to stamp out lingering attitudes and practices
summary: Singaporeans are taking pre-emptive steps to combat the Wuhan coronavirus, a chance to change work attitudes that spread diseases. Presenteeism while ill persists despite warnings, often encouraged by attendance bonuses. In 2017, Singapore Airlines docked points from employees submitting medical certificates for common ailments, potentially discouraging them from reporting illnesses. This practice could lead to employees turning up to work unwell, endangering themselves and others. The article highlights the need for companies to prioritize employee health over productivity.

site_title: North-eastern India can be a trade hinge linking South Asia and Asean
summary: North-eastern India's eight mountainous states are strategically located to serve as a trade hinge between South Asia and Asean. The region's growing trade links with Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepal, and Asean countries require improved transport connectivity to support the potential for transit trade. The NER's informal trade with Myanmar is estimated to be greater than its formal trade, with smuggling and services such as tourism, health, and hospitality being key drivers. Despite India's free trade agreement with Asean, non-tariff measures remain a barrier to boosting bilateral trade.

images.alt_text: At present, the spectacle at the border crossings showcases the hurdles of bureaucracy. The clearance processes are time-consuming.

site_title: US: Dow edges higher as strong Apple results offsets virus fears
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose less than 0.1% to 28,734.45 on Wednesday, driven by strong profits from Apple, which reported record quarterly profits of $22 billion. However, the broader market was mixed, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also experiencing slight gains. Companies such as Starbucks and McDonald's curtailed China activities due to the Sars-like virus, while Boeing announced its first annual loss in over two decades due to the 737 Max grounding. The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, citing the virus as a potential risk.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 dipped 0.1 per cent to 3,273.40, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.1 per cent to 9.275.16.

site_title: Law Society plans mediation clause in property template
summary: The Law Society in Singapore plans to insert a mediation clause into its property transaction agreement template, requiring buyers and sellers to attempt to resolve disputes through mediation before resorting to litigation. This move aims to make mediation the first port of call for resolving disputes, following Singapore's signing of the Singapore Convention on Mediation in August last year. The Law Society's mediation scheme, established in 2017, has received 38 applications and has a 70% settlement rate at the Singapore Mediation Centre.

site_title: Business interruption is the top risk for Singapore businesses: Allianz survey
summary: A recent survey by Allianz found business interruption to be the top risk for Singapore businesses for the third consecutive year, with 40% of respondents citing it as an important risk. Cyber incidents came in second, followed by changes in legislation and regulation. The survey, which surveyed 2,718 businesses from 102 countries, noted that health issues, such as a pandemic outbreak, are emerging as a risk, particularly in Asia. The survey also highlighted the growing concern of climate change in the region.

images.alt_text: Mr Mitchell expects health issues to be among the top risks for businesses beyond China, in future surveys.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Trends and challenges SMEs will face in 2020
summary: The Money FM podcast "Trends and challenges SMEs will face in 2020" discussed key issues affecting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in 2020. Experts from Cisco highlighted trends such as the increasing use of digital technologies, cybersecurity threats, and changing consumer behaviors. SMEs are also expected to face challenges like global economic uncertainty, increasing competition, and the need for sustainable practices. The podcast also touched on various business news, including the opening of a specialist healthcare center in Japan, a startup aiming to reduce the price of sustainable marine fuel, and the closure of a training restaurant in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore firms shut China malls, cut hours amid outbreak
summary: Singapore-listed property firms CapitaLand, Dasin Retail Trust, and Sasseur Reit have temporarily closed or shortened hours at their malls in China amid the coronavirus outbreak. CapitaLand closed six malls, including four in Wuhan, while Dasin Retail Trust shortened hours at its five malls and Sasseur Reit closed four outlet malls. The moves aim to minimize contagious risk due to crowd gatherings. Despite the measures, supermarkets and essential services remain open to ensure food and daily essentials supply.

site_title: Make the punishment fit the white-collar crime
summary: The Swiss banking regulator punished a local bank chief for insider trading, confiscating 730,000 francs and banning him from managing a bank for four years. In contrast, US regulators took action against former Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf, who paid $17.5 million to settle a probe and was banned from working in banks. Critics argue that holding CEOs personally accountable is essential for deterring white-collar crime, but actual cases remain few and far between. The US has experimented with corporate fines, but their effectiveness is disputed, with some studies showing that share prices actually rise after penalties are announced.

site_title: Meghmani Organics to split businesses into 2 India listings
summary: Meghmani Organics, an India-based company, is restructuring its businesses into two separately listed companies on the Indian stock exchanges. The company will be wound up after the restructuring, and its depository shares on the Singapore Exchange will be delisted. Shareholders who do not wish to receive shares in the new listcos can opt for a cash offer of S$0.72 per share. The company's decision comes after a restructuring process, with the goal of simplifying its operations and focusing on its core businesses.

site_title: Garena buys Phoenix Labs; price said to be over US$150m
summary: Garena, the gaming arm of Sea Ltd, has acquired Phoenix Labs for over US$150 million, expanding its focus on game development. Phoenix Labs, behind the free-to-play game Dauntless, will remain distributed on Epic Games' platform. The acquisition signals Garena's efforts to capture a larger gaming industry share, projected to reach US$300 billion by 2025. Over 100 top "AAA" game developers will join Garena, with the companies exploring new growth opportunities in Asia, Latin America, and potentially mobile distribution for Dauntless.

site_title: Where everybody knows your name - and your drink
summary: A Singaporean bar scene is shifting towards intimate, curated experiences with a focus on personalized service, as seen in bartender Anthony Zhong's cult following for his expertly crafted Negroni. Meanwhile, Australian-born chef David Thompson celebrates his 60th milestone with the launch of his latest Thai restaurant in Koh Samui. The article also explores alternative design approaches, such as dark color palettes, and local menswear brands offering style tips, as well as a preview of Studio Ghibli's streaming on Netflix.

site_title: USD holds gains as investors assess virus' damage
summary: The US dollar held near two-month highs on Wednesday, driven by its safe-haven credentials amid the coronavirus outbreak in China. The dollar index increased 0.1% to 98.091, while the euro fell 0.2% versus the US currency. Investors are awaiting the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates, expected to remain unchanged, but are watching for chairman Jerome Powell's language on the economy. Despite concerns about economic damage, the dollar is seen as a stable currency, with other safe-haven currencies like the yen and Swiss franc also showing gains.

site_title: GIC buys substantial stake in Yoma Bank, adding to Myanmar deals
summary: GIC Pte Ltd has acquired a 30% stake in Myanmar's Yoma Bank Ltd for 130 billion kyat (S$121.3 million) as part of a funding round. Yoma Bank, one of the country's largest lenders, was founded by local tycoon Serge Pun in 1993. The deal is part of Myanmar's efforts to attract foreign capital from the region. GIC and Norway's Norfund AS are the main investors in this latest round, aiming to support the country's economic growth and development.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit posts DPU of 1.13 S cents for Q2 FY19/20
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.13 Singapore cents for Q2 FY19/20, with revenue and net property income falling 4.5% and 5.9% year-over-year, respectively. The decline was mainly due to rental rebates to the master tenant at Starhill Gallery in Malaysia. Income available for distribution was flat at S$25.16 million, and units closed at 71 Singapore cents, half a cent lower.

site_title: Will Trump's Deal of the Century succeed?
summary: US President Donald Trump's "Deal of the Century" plan to bring peace between Israelis and Palestinians has faced a major setback as the Palestinian Authority has refused to participate in the anticipated negotiations. The plan, unveiled by Trump in Washington, calls for the establishment of an independent Palestinian state with its capital in East Jerusalem, but has been met with rejection by Palestinian leaders. The Trump administration has been criticized for its handling of the conflict, with many Palestinians viewing it as biased towards Israel. The plan's future is now uncertain, with the Palestinian Authority and Hamas movement opposing it, and the Israeli election looming.

site_title: Why fashion's fairy grandmother Agnes b. is a true believer
summary: French designer Agnes b. is opening her own gallery, Fab, in an up-and-coming corner of Paris. The 78-year-old, who has built a fashion empire and dressed artists like David Bowie, aims to bring together art, music, fashion, and publishing worlds with the local tech crowd and residents. Her gallery will feature her eclectic private collection of over 5,000 works, including photographs and paintings by notable artists. Agnes b. seeks to promote social solidarity and challenge the ruthless art world, viewing an artwork as needing to be "adopted, loved, and understood" after leaving its artist's studio.

site_title: Urgent demand for healthcare staff for temperature screening
summary: Singapore institutions urgently seek hundreds of healthcare assistants for temperature screening roles amid the Wuhan virus outbreak. Job postings for part-time or contract roles have increased, with hourly pay ranging from S$9 to S$48. However, some postings have been misrepresenting rates, with a Raffles Medical spokesperson clarifying that the accurate hourly pay is S$12 for day shift and S$16 for night shift. The demand for healthcare assistants is expected to be challenging, with the hiring volume appearing to be very big.

site_title: Wuhan virus makes ghost towns out of luxury hotels
summary: In Wuhan, China, the luxury Marco Polo hotel has been transformed into a ghost town due to the deadly coronavirus outbreak. The hotel, usually 80% full during Chinese New Year, now has only 20 guests, with the rest quarantined. Staff wear face masks, and temperature checks are conducted daily. The hotel's restaurant is closed, and meals are limited to room service. Some staff members have been helping prepare meals for local hospitals. The hotel's management has decided not to accept new guests to minimize the risk of transmission.

site_title: Democrats' plan for 100% clean power panned by some environmentalists
summary: House Democrats unveiled a plan for 100% clean power, but some environmentalists are criticizing the proposal, citing concerns over feasibility and cost. The criticism highlights the challenges in balancing idealism with pragmatism on reducing emissions. The legislation faces opposition from both the left and moderate wings of the party, making it uncertain whether it will be passed this year.

site_title: Macau now resembles a near-ghost town
summary: Macau, a Chinese territory known for its casinos, has become a near-ghost town due to measures to contain the new coronavirus. Authorities have suspended inbound package tours and curbed individual visit schemes, leading to a 69% drop in arrivals since Friday. The virus has also affected the gaming industry, with casino operators' share prices plummeting 4-6%. The local government has extended the Chinese New Year break, keeping banks and businesses closed, and warned that casinos could close if the virus continues to spread.

site_title: US pending home sales post biggest decline since 2010
summary: US pending home sales declined 4.9% in December, the largest drop since 2010, due to a shortage of affordable homes and rising asking prices. Despite a strong job market and income growth, housing demand is being thwarted by lean inventory. Economists forecast home sales growth of around 3% for the year, with mortgage rates likely to remain below 4%. The decline in pending home sales contrasts with a gauge of loan applications to buy homes reaching an 11-year high in the previous week.

site_title: Virus worries knock HK stocks to 7-week low after Chinese New Year break
summary: Hong Kong's stock market plummeted 3% on its first trading session after the Chinese New Year break, hitting a seven-week low. The Hang Seng index fell 791.99 points, with shares in China-exposed sectors leading declines. Investors are bracing for the economic impact of the Wuhan coronavirus, which has disrupted transportation, travel, and tourism. Analysts expect Beijing to roll out liquidity and credit support measures to support businesses if the virus spreads rapidly.

site_title: Boeing reports 2019 loss of US$636m, first year in red since 1997
summary: Boeing reported its first annual loss in over 20 years, with a loss of $636 million for 2019, due to the prolonged grounding of the 737 MAX. The company's revenues dropped 24.3% to $76.6 billion, and new costs related to the MAX crisis totaled $9.2 billion. Newly-installed CEO David Calhoun pledged to turn the company around and aims to win approval to resume flights on the MAX by mid-2020. The crisis has also affected suppliers and airlines, with some announcing layoffs and cancellations of flights.

site_title: Singapore property investment sales likely to cross S$31b in 2020: Colliers
summary: Singapore property investment sales are expected to reach S$31.3 billion in 2020, a 6% increase from 2019, driven by the commercial sector, which led sales in 2019 and is forecasted to do so again. The hospitality sector is also expected to see growth, with investment sales more than quadrupling to an all-time high of S$5.7 billion in 2019. A 3% year-on-year increase is anticipated for residential investment sales, while industrial sales are forecasted to accelerate by 15% per annum from 2019 to 2024.

images.alt_text: Colliers says the improved economic outlook should help to lift investor confidence. According to Oxford Economics, the economy could expand by 1.4% this year compared with 0.7% growth in 2019.

site_title: Keppel Capital's new infrastructure fund secures US$360m in initial commitments
summary: Keppel Capital Holdings has launched a new infrastructure private equity fund with an initial capital commitment of US$360 million, exceeding its target size of US$1 billion. The fund, which closed its first round, was backed by a sovereign wealth fund and an endowment fund. The launch marks a significant step for Keppel Capital in the infrastructure sector, as the company seeks to capitalize on growing demand for green and transition finance.

site_title: Survey of microplastics to be done in seas off Japan
summary: Scientists in Japan will begin a two-year survey of microplastics in coastal waters off Japan in April. The survey aims to measure the impact of plastics on marine life and raise awareness about the issue. Conducted by multiple marine research facilities, the study will also identify the source of plastic pollution and involve local communities, including fishermen and schoolchildren. The goal is to develop strategies to limit pollution and create models to illustrate the flow of plastic, as 7.2 tonnes of plastics enter the world's oceans every year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: FIRST Reit's Q4 2019 distribution per unit remained flat year-over-year at 2.15 Singapore cents, with rental and other income down 1.6% and net property and other income down 0.8%. For the full year, rental and other income edged down 0.8% and net property and other income was 1.3% lower. Meanwhile, Singtel's associate Advanced Info Service (AIS) has been ordered to pay 31.07 billion Baht (S$1.37 billion) plus interest to Thai telco TOT Public Company.

site_title: Feedback invited on Korean shipbuilders' proposed merger
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) is conducting an in-depth review of a proposed merger between Korea Shipbuilding & Offshore Engineering (KSOE) and Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering (DSME). The merger, which would combine the two Korean shipbuilders, was initially met with competition concerns due to overlapping supply of commercial vessels. The CCCS is now seeking public feedback until February 19 and will decide on the merger's impact on competition within 120 business days. The watchdog expressed concerns that the merger could reduce competition and raise barriers to entry.

site_title: 2 major collections to pump US$1 billion in art auctions in 2020
summary: The late financier Don Marron's collection of modern and contemporary art may be headed to auction, with his family seeking proposals from top auction houses. The collection, valued at over US$1 billion, features paintings by Rothko, Picasso, and de Kooning. This follows a similar announcement from the Macklowe collection, also valued at over US$1 billion, which includes works by the same artists. The combined value of both collections is expected to exceed US$2 billion, making them two of the largest art auctions in history.

site_title: Singtel associate AIS ordered to pay 31.07b baht by Arbitral Tribunal
summary: A Thai Arbitral Tribunal has ordered Singtel's associate, Advanced Info Service (AIS), to pay 31.07 billion baht (S$1.37 billion) to TOT Public Company, plus interest, due to alleged unlawful contract amendments in 2001 and 2002. AIS has disputed the award and plans to submit the case to the Central Administrative Court for revocation within 90 days. The dispute concerns amendments to a Cellular Mobile Telephone Service agreement that allegedly resulted in TOT losing revenue. AIS maintains its financial status is unaffected by the decision.

site_title: Nigeria's biggest city partially bans motorbike taxis
summary: Nigeria's Lagos state government has partially banned motorbike taxis following a surge in fatal accidents, citing them as a "menace" that ignores traffic laws and allows criminals to use the services as getaway vehicles. The ban aims to reduce the number of lives lost, dealing a blow to OPay and potentially boosting Uber Technologies Inc. The move is seen as a response to the growing concerns about road safety in the commercial capital of Africa's most populous country.

site_title: Asia jet fuel demand slumps as airlines cancel flights amid virus outbreak
summary: Asian jet fuel demand has plummeted amid a virus outbreak in China, with airlines canceling flights and tour operators canceling trips. The Lunar New Year travel season, a peak period for Chinese jet demand, is expected to see a lower-than-average seasonal uptick. Industry analysts predict a decline in jet fuel and overall oil demand, with some forecasting a 300,000 barrels-per-day drop in jet kerosene demand from China. This could lead to lower profits for refiners and a decrease in global oil demand growth.

images.alt_text: Industry analysts are cutting their 2020 forecasts for jet fuel and overall oil demand.

site_title: Pompeo urges UK to rethink move to give Huawei limited role in 5G networks
summary: The US has urged the UK to reconsider its decision to allow China's Huawei a limited role in Britain's 5G networks, citing concerns over American information security. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated that trusted networks are necessary to protect sensitive data. The UK had previously granted Huawei a limited role, despite US efforts to exclude the company from Western 5G networks. The European Union has also issued guidelines for 5G security, but has stopped short of banning Huawei, allowing member states to assess the risk profile of suppliers and apply restrictions accordingly.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: WongPartnership has applied to discharge itself from representing Hyflux due to loss of confidence and good cause. Singapore-listed property firms have closed or shortened hours at China malls as precautionary measures against the Wuhan virus. Colliers forecasts a 3% increase in residential investment sales in 2020. The Wing Fong Mansions are up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$176m. Vena Energy will build a 100MW solar battery in Queensland at a cost of A$120m. The STI ended flat at 3,182.57 after a virus-induced sell-off on Tuesday.

site_title: iPhone sales propel Apple results to record high
summary: Apple reported record-breaking results for its fiscal first quarter, with net profit reaching an all-time high of $22 billion and quarterly revenue of $91.8 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. The company's iPhone sales propelled the results, with revenue from the iPhone 11 and iPhone 11 Pro models setting new records. Apple is shifting its focus to services, with services revenue rising 17% and paid subscriptions to Apple services reaching 480 million. The company is also taking precautions due to the COVID-19 outbreak in China, with some stores closed and employees undergoing temperature checks.

site_title: Ikea to close half its stores in China over virus outbreak
summary: Ikea temporarily closed half of its 30 stores in mainland China due to the deadly new coronavirus outbreak, following the Chinese government's call for strict disease control. The closures are effective from January 29, with employees at affected stores advised to stay home with paid leave. The company is monitoring the situation closely and will act in accordance with authorities' recommendations. This move is part of the growing concerns over the virus, which has already disrupted air traffic, industrial production, and international trade.

site_title: Virus outbreak a curveball for hospitality sector recovery
summary: The Wuhan virus outbreak is expected to significantly impact Singapore's hospitality sector, which was poised for recovery after a long downcycle. The number of confirmed cases is rising, and analysts predict revenue per available room (RevPAR) growth to be dented this year. The outbreak is also affecting air travel and visitor arrivals, with Singapore's largest source market, China, experiencing a decline. Hotel stock prices have declined, and investors are jittery about the sector's impact. Analysts expect a protracted outbreak to result in corporate travel curbs and tourists staying home, potentially denting RevPAR growth.

site_title: PetroChina tops Singapore's shrinking list of 2019 marine fuel suppliers
summary: PetroChina's Singapore unit became the top marine fuel supplier in Singapore in 2019, surpassing Sentek Marine & Trading. The number of licensed bunker suppliers decreased to 45 from 51 a year earlier, as tough market conditions and industry crackdowns took effect. Despite a 5% drop in bunkering sales volumes in Singapore, most suppliers saw improved profit margins due to new global rules requiring cleaner fuels. The top 20 suppliers account for most delivered volumes, limiting the impact of the decline in suppliers.

site_title: US Senate to begin questioning ahead of crucial vote for Trump trial
summary: The US Senate will begin questioning the prosecution and defense in President Donald Trump's impeachment trial on Wednesday, ahead of a crucial vote on whether to call witnesses. The questioning will alternate between Republican and Democratic senators and will last up to two days. The Senate is expected to turn to a debate and vote on whether to call witnesses on Friday. Despite Republican opposition, Democrats are pushing for witnesses, including former national security adviser John Bolton, who has made explosive allegations about Trump's actions. A two-thirds vote is required to convict and remove a president from office, and Trump is expected to be acquitted.

site_title: Warren Buffett throws in the towel on his newspaper empire
summary: Warren Buffett's newspaper empire is being sold to Lee Enterprises for $140 million in cash. Berkshire Hathaway, Buffett's company, is loaning Lee $576 million to finance the purchase and refinance other debt. The sale includes 30 daily newspapers, including the Omaha World-Herald and Buffalo News, and 49 weekly publications. Buffett cited the decline of print advertising and circulation as the reason for the sale, noting that Lee is better positioned to manage the industry's challenges. This marks Buffett's second divestiture in less than a year, following the sale of an insurance business in 2019.

site_title: Britain's BBC to axe 450 newsroom jobs in cost-cutting drive
summary: The BBC announced plans to cut 450 jobs from its news division as part of a cost-cutting drive. The layoffs will result in reorganization of the newsroom, adopting a "story-led" model where staff will be assigned to specific stories rather than individual programs. The BBC aims to save £80 million by 2022, shifting resources from traditional linear broadcasting to digital news. The cuts will lead to a reduction in overall story coverage, but the BBC will invest more in digital news, including a new BBC News app.

site_title: China business unaffected by Wuhan virus: EC World Reit's manager
summary: EC World Reit's manager says the company's business in China remains unaffected by the Wuhan virus due to its e-commerce sector focus. The Wuhan asset accounts for less than 2% of the portfolio's net property income, and no major disruptions have been observed. The manager expects no material impact on operations if the current situation does not worsen.

site_title: Modi says India could defeat Pakistan 'in 10 days'
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has stated that his country could defeat Pakistan "in 10 days" in the event of a new war with its arch-rival. This claim comes amid domestic pressure, including protests over a citizenship law and economic concerns. Modi attributed India's military prowess to "youthful thinking" and pointed to past strikes against militants in Pakistan-administered Kashmir as evidence. Pakistan has rejected Modi's comments as "irresponsible and war-mongering". The two nations have a history of conflict, having fought three wars since independence in 1947.

site_title: British Airways suspends bookings for China flights after coronavirus warnings
summary: British Airways has suspended bookings for direct flights from London to Beijing and Shanghai until March due to warnings over the coronavirus outbreak in China. The airline prioritizes customer safety, advising those traveling to or from China to check BA.com for updates. Britain has advised against "all but essential" travel to mainland China, following the outbreak.

site_title: Asean supply-chain shifts: Can Singapore banks be the real winners?
summary: Singapore banks, particularly DBS Bank and United Overseas Bank (UOB), are poised to benefit from supply chain shifts into South-east Asia due to their cutting-edge technology, regional footprint, and access to US dollar deposits. Analysts from Maybank Kim Eng predict a significant increase in these banks' investments in technology, with DBS' spending expected to rise by 8% and UOB's by 15% in 2021. This shift is driven by multinational corporations and Chinese businesses relocating out of China, seeking high-quality balance sheets and product sophistication in the region.

images.alt_text: A United Overseas Bank branch in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.

site_title: Mastercard beats profit estimates on strong holiday season spending
summary: Mastercard reported a quarterly profit beat, driven by strong holiday season spending in the US and Europe, resulting in a 12% increase in gross dollar volume to $1.73 trillion. The company processed 29.38 billion transactions, a 19% rise from the previous year, and net revenue rose 16% to $4.41 billion, surpassing analyst estimates. Adjusted net income increased to $2.0 billion, with earnings per share reaching $1.96, beating expectations of $1.87 per share.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.17 points to 1,550.47. The index saw 2.7 billion lots traded worth RM2.6 billion, with 500 gainers outnumbering 370 losers.

site_title: Boeing says total costs for 737 MAX will surpass US$18b
summary: Boeing reported total costs for its grounded 737 MAX will surpass $18 billion, including a $2.6 billion pretax writedown and $9 billion in Max-related costs. The company expects "future abnormal costs" of $4 billion as it restarts Max production, and notched its first annual loss since 1997. New CEO Dave Calhoun acknowledged the challenges ahead, but expressed confidence in the company's financial liquidity and commitment to restoring trust with the flying public. Boeing's shares have fallen 25% since the 737 MAX crisis began.

images.alt_text: An aerial photo shows several Boeing 737 MAX airplanes grounded at Boeing Field in Seattle.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit Q2 DPU flat at 1.13 Singapore cents
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.13 Singapore cents for the second quarter ended Dec 31, 2019, due to a 4.5% year-on-year decline in revenue to S$48.74 million and a 5.9% drop in net property income to S$37.17 million. The decline was mainly attributed to a rental rebate extended to the master tenant during an asset enhancement period in Malaysia. The Reit's manager will receive part of its base management fees in units to mitigate the income disruption.

site_title: Chinese family in UAE diagnosed as first virus cases in Middle East
summary: A Chinese family of four, including a 9-year-old child and a 63-year-old grandmother, has been diagnosed with the new coronavirus in the UAE, marking the first known cases in the Middle East. The family arrived in the UAE on January 16 and were diagnosed on January 23 after one family member felt unwell. All four are in stable condition and under medical observation. The UAE government has traced contacts and tested them negative, and flights to and from China remain unaffected.

site_title: Keppel Capital Holdings launches new infrastructure fund
summary: Keppel Capital Holdings has launched a new closed-end infrastructure private equity fund with initial capital commitments of US$360 million, targeting a total of US$1 billion. The fund will be managed by Keppel Capital Alternative Asset and will focus on expanding its portfolio in the Asia-Pacific through operational and greenfield projects. The fund's first planned investment is a stake in the Gimi floating liquefied natural gas facility. This move leverages Keppel Capital's experience and investor network to capitalize on infrastructure growth opportunities in the region.

site_title: Singapore confirms 3 more Wuhan virus cases, bringing total to 10; all are from Wuhan
summary: Singapore confirms 3 more Wuhan virus cases, bringing total to 10, all of whom are Chinese nationals from Wuhan. The new cases include a 56-year-old woman and her husband, who arrived on January 19 and developed symptoms on Friday, and a 56-year-old man who arrived on January 20 and was admitted to the National Centre for Infectious Diseases on Tuesday. MOH has initiated epidemiological investigations and contact tracing to identify individuals who had close contact with the cases.

site_title: United States tells Britain: Look again at Huawei 5G decision
summary: The US has urged Britain to reconsider its decision to allow Huawei a limited role in its 5G networks, citing concerns that American information should only pass across trusted networks. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo made the statement as he arrived in London, where Prime Minister Boris Johnson had previously granted Huawei a limited role. The move has frustrated a global attempt to exclude the Chinese telecoms giant from the West's 5G networks.

images.alt_text: "There is also a chance for the United Kingdom to relook at this as implementation moves forward," US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo told reporters as he flew to London, according to a pooled report.

site_title: Jetstar suspends flights to 3 Chinese cities, Singapore-HK ticket sales
summary: Jetstar Asia has suspended flights to Hefei, Guiyang, and Xuzhou in China until March 31, citing a drop in demand due to the coronavirus outbreak. The airline will continue flights to Shantou and Haikou, and has suspended ticket sales for Singapore-Hong Kong flights until March 28. Affected passengers will receive refunds or credit vouchers. This decision follows a decline in demand and efforts by Chinese authorities to limit the spread of the virus.

site_title: EU announces strict 5G rules, but no Huawei ban
summary: The European Union has announced strict 5G rules, allowing telecoms operators deemed a security risk to be barred from critical parts of the network, but no outright ban on Huawei. The guidelines, which mirror Britain's approach, urge countries to assess the risk profile of suppliers and apply restrictions accordingly. The EU will leave it to individual member states to make decisions on Huawei, giving European capitals to resist US pressure. Huawei welcomed the guidelines, saying they would allow it to continue playing a role in Europe's 5G rollout.

site_title: CCCS calls for feedback on proposed merger of 2 Korean shipbuilders
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) is seeking public feedback on a proposed merger between Korea Shipbuilding & Offshore Engineering (KSOE) and Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering (DSME). The merger, which would remove competition to the detriment of customers in Singapore, was initially raised concerns by the CCCS in November. An in-depth review of the effect of the proposed merger is now underway, with the CCCS seeking feedback until February 19. The merger would overlap in the supply of commercial vessels, including oil tankers and liquefied natural gas carriers.

site_title: Trump attacks Bolton as impeachment trial heats up
summary: US President Donald Trump has intensified his attacks on former national security advisor John Bolton, whose upcoming book allegedly reveals that Trump wanted to freeze military aid to Ukraine until an investigation into Joe Biden was opened. Democrats are pushing for Bolton to testify in the Senate trial, with some Republican senators potentially supporting the demand. This could harm Trump's defense in the ongoing impeachment trial.

site_title: UK house prices rise at fastest pace since Nov 2018: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices rose at their fastest annual rate since November 2018, increasing 1.9% from December, according to Nationwide Building Society. This surpasses economists' forecasts and marks a modest pick-up in the housing market. The monthly increase was 0.5%. The news follows signs of economic confidence since the UK's election in December.

site_title: Colliers forecasts Singapore property investment sales to cross S$31b in 2020
summary: Singapore property investment sales are forecasted to reach S$31.3 billion in 2020, a 6% increase from 2019, according to Colliers International. The commercial sector is expected to drive sales, with a 5% year-over-year increase, while residential sales are predicted to grow 3% due to a stable supply of public land sales. Despite a near-term downside risk from the Wuhan coronavirus, Colliers believes long-term growth drivers for the tourism sector remain intact, with sustained demand for hospitality assets.

site_title: First Reit posts flat DPU for Q4 2019
summary: First Reit reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.15 Singapore cents for Q4 2019, compared to the same period last year. Rental and other income decreased 1.6% to S$28.86 million, while net property and other income dropped 0.8% to S$28.3 million. The full-year rental and other income edged down 0.8%, while net property and other income declined 1.3%. The company's units closed at 99.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Wuhan virus may persuade Singapore, Malaysia to ease casino policies
summary: Singapore and Malaysia may ease casino policies if the Wuhan virus significantly impacts the gaming sector. Analyst Samuel Yin suggests that the ongoing pandemic could lead to a "materially negative impact" on tourism-related industries, similar to the 2003 Sars outbreak. This could result in Malaysia easing part of its 10-point casino duty rate hike and Singapore rolling back its casino entry levies. The potential relief could boost Genting Malaysia earnings by 3-4% per one-point reduction in casino duties.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: European stock markets steadied at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.1% to 7,488.37 points. Shares in IAG, the parent group of British Airways, rose 0.3% due to the airline's decision to suspend flights to mainland China. In other news, US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, and Singapore's STI index gained 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Saudi Telecom offers US$2.39b for Vodafone Egypt stake
summary: Saudi Telecom offered US$2.39 billion to acquire Vodafone Group's 55% stake in Vodafone Egypt, the largest mobile operator in the country. The deal aims to expand the company outside its home market and gain access to Egypt's 80 million population. Vodafone Egypt holds a 44% market share. The deal is non-binding and valid for 75 days, with Vodafone planning to use proceeds to reduce debt. Telecom Egypt, which holds a 45% stake, is considering its options.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch higher on financials, tech; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 7,031.50, driven by financial and technology stocks, despite cautious trading amid the coronavirus outbreak. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.4% the previous day. Financial stocks, led by the Big Four banks, rose 1% while technology stocks advanced 1.7%. New Zealand's benchmark index slipped 0.07% due to a 2.1% drop in gold stocks and declines in Air New Zealand and Kathmandu Holdings.

site_title: Thai finance ministry cuts 2020 GDP growth forecast to 2.8%
summary: Thailand's finance ministry has cut its 2020 GDP growth forecast to 2.8% from 3.3% due to weaker exports. The ministry downgraded its 2020 estimate for exports, a key driver of growth, to a rise of just 1% from an earlier 2.6% increase. This marks a significant downgrade, with the country's 2019 growth estimated at 2.5%, a five-year low.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close sharply lower on virus fears
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 2.82% on January 29, 2020, as investors returned from the Lunar New Year break amid global panic over the spread of a deadly virus. The Hang Seng index closed at 27,160.63, its lowest level in weeks. Mainland Chinese markets remained closed for the holidays, exacerbating the decline. The sharp losses were a result of heightened fears about the virus's impact on the global economy.

site_title: WongPartnership applies to discharge itself from representing Hyflux
summary: Hyflux's lawyers from WongPartnership, led by Manoj Sandrasegara, applied to discharge themselves from representing the company due to a loss of confidence and good cause. This comes amid issues with assurances given to the court about adviser fees at a November 2019 hearing. The High Court adjourned the hearing to February 20 to allow the company and WongPartnership to resolve the conflict, which may impact Hyflux's deal with rescue investor Utico. A pre-trial conference is also scheduled.

site_title: Gold little changed as investors assess virus impact, await Fed decision
summary: Gold prices remained largely unchanged on Wednesday, up 0.1% at $1,567.18 per ounce, as investors evaluated the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in China and awaited the US Federal Reserve's policy decision. The virus has caused panic in the market, with gold seen as a safe store of value during times of economic and political turmoil. Analysts expect the Fed to stand pat on interest rates, with lower rates reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, supporting gold prices.

site_title: Wing Fong Mansions up for collective sale
summary: Singapore's Wing Fong Mansions, a 130-unit freehold condominium, has been launched for collective sale with a reserve price of S$176 million. The property, located in Geylang, has garnered consent from at least 80% of its owners for an en bloc sale. The site, spanning 47,880 sq ft, is zoned for commercial or institutional use and has a plot ratio of 2.8. Tenders for the property and an adjacent condo, Wing Fong Court, will close on May 18.

site_title: Tokyo 2020 unveils Olympic 'plaza' made from donated wood
summary: Tokyo 2020 unveiled the "Village Plaza", a key part of the Athletes' Village built from wood donated by 63 municipalities across Japan. The structure combines modern and traditional elements, featuring wooden floors, walls, and parts of the roof. The wood will be dismantled after the Games, with the timber returned for re-use, as part of the organisers' commitment to a sustainable Olympics. The facility will serve as a gathering place for athletes and teams, hosting welcome ceremonies and press briefings.

site_title: Metal Component inks agreement for 75.5m yuan sale of Chinese unit
summary: Metal Component Engineering has agreed to sell its dormant Chinese subsidiary, MCE Industries (Shanghai), to Hong Sheng Holding for 75.5 million yuan (S$14.8 million) in cash. The sale is part of the company's consolidation and cost-savings efforts. Metal Component expects to recognize a gain of S$8.4 million from the sale, which will be used to invest in property, repay bank borrowings, and cover general working capital requirements. The sale does not require shareholder approval due to a waiver from the bourse operator.

site_title: Kone makes highest offer for Thyssenkrupp elevators: sources
