summary: Kone Oyj has made the highest offer for Thyssenkrupp's elevator business, valued at around 17 billion euros, in an attempt to outbid buyout firms and overcome antitrust concerns. The Finnish company, teamed up with CVC Capital Partners, has offered a mix of cash and stock, as well as a multibillion-euro upfront payment, to address concerns. Thyssenkrupp is now facing a difficult decision, weighing the need to bring in funds for restructuring against avoiding a long antitrust review.

site_title: Qantas could axe Beijing route early as coronavirus hits demand: CEO
summary: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce mentioned reviewing the airline's decision to end its underperforming Sydney-Beijing route early due to the impact of China's coronavirus epidemic. Initially set to end in March, Qantas is assessing whether to cut the route earlier or maintain it until that date. This decision is influenced by reduced loads and weak business class demand.

site_title: Urgent demand for healthcare assistants as institutions ramp up screening
summary: Singapore institutions urgently seek hundreds of healthcare assistants for temperature screening roles amid the Wuhan virus outbreak. Job postings have increased by 12 on mobile job portal FastJobs, with hourly rates ranging from S$9 to S$48. Recruiters are looking for part-time or contract staff to work 9-12 hour shifts, with some job openings offering up to S$16 per hour. However, some postings have been misrepresenting rates, with false claims of S$33 per hour for a three-month contract. Authorities have implemented temperature screening for travellers on all flights into Changi Airport and at all land and sea checkpoints.

site_title: US: Apple, Boeing bolster Wall Street at open
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Wednesday, driven by a surge in shares of Apple, Boeing, and General Electric. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 97.68 points, or 0.34%, to 28,820.53, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, reaching fresh records. The economic impact of the coronavirus was overshadowed by the strong earnings reports from these companies, indicating a positive start to the day for US stocks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after Wall St rebound despite virus fears
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.71% on Wednesday, closing at 23,379.40, as Wall Street rebounded despite concerns over the spread of the novel coronavirus. The Nikkei 225 index added 163.69 points, while the Topix index rose 7.67 points. Investors eyed developments related to the virus, but the rebound on Wall Street helped to boost Asian markets.

site_title: Beijing drugstore fined for hiking mask prices amid virus outbreak
summary: A Beijing drugstore, Beijing Jimin Kangtai Pharmacy, has been fined 3 million yuan (S$590,000) for nearly doubling the price of N95 masks during the coronavirus outbreak in China. The price hike was seen as a price gouging tactic, with the store selling masks for 850 yuan per box while the online price was 143 yuan. This case is part of a broader crackdown by the Beijing municipal market regulator on price violations and hoarding of protective gear.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on bargain hunting after Tuesday's sharp drop
summary: South Korean stocks rose on Wednesday, rebounding from a sharp 3.1% drop the previous day due to bargain hunting. The Kospi index gained 8.56 points, or 0.39%, at 2,185.28, as investors bought beaten-down stocks. The death toll from the coronavirus in China rose to 132, while Japan flew citizens out of Wuhan. Despite volatility, South Korea's exports are expected to fall in January due to the Chinese New Year holiday and concerns over the virus. Foreigners and individual investors were net buyers of shares, with the won trading little changed against the dollar.

site_title: Brexit to be sealed with final Brussels vote
summary: The European Parliament in Brussels is set to vote on Wednesday to ratify the UK's divorce deal from the EU, allowing Brexit to officially take effect on Friday at 2300 GMT. The deal protects the rights of EU and British citizens, financial obligations, and a customs regime that will keep Northern Ireland under European rules. However, negotiations on a future relationship between the two sides are expected to begin later this year, with the EU signaling demands for EU fishermen to operate in British waters and the UK facing opposition from the US over its decision to use Huawei technology.

site_title: Economic burnout: India's struggling workforce
summary: India's government faces pressure as the country struggles with economic burnout, marked by record unemployment, inflation, and a widening wealth gap. The 2020 budget release has been overshadowed by the economic slowdown, which has led to widespread job losses and financial struggles for many Indians. The top 1% of the population has seen a 46% increase in wealth, while the majority of the population faces financial insecurity and reduced consumer spending.

site_title: Sunseap secures S$50m from Temasek, private equity fund for solar projects
summary: Sunseap Group has secured S$50 million in funding from Temasek and Asia-focused private equity fund ABC World Asia to support solar projects in Singapore and Asia. The funds will be used for solar projects, with installation of over 170,000 solar panels expected to begin in early 2020 and be completed by the third quarter of 2022. The company also joined UOB's U-Solar programme as a partner, aiming to drive positive environmental impact through solar solutions.

site_title: Firms should 'be prepared for different scenarios' involving Wuhan virus: ESG
summary: Enterprise Singapore advises businesses to develop business continuity plans for the Wuhan coronavirus, even with no community spread in Singapore. The plan should cover actions for each alert level, and firms are advised to defer non-essential travel to mainland China and Hubei province, and monitor employees' health upon return. Firms can consider flexible work arrangements and provide paid leave for employees who are unwell or require quarantine. The guide, available soon on ESG's website, will serve as a general reference for planning a pandemic response.

site_title: Post-Brexit UK faces '3D chess game' in world trade
summary: The UK's departure from the European Union marks a new era in world trade, with the country set to negotiate its own trade agreements. However, the process is proving complex, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson insisting on a tight deadline and finance minister Sajid Javid warning of regulatory divergences. The UK will initially remain in the EU's customs union and single market until December 31, while seeking new deals with major partners like the US, China, and Japan. Experts say the task is akin to playing "three-dimensional chess," with difficult trade-offs and competing regulatory blocs.

site_title: Asia's foreign bond bid matches China's 'savings glut' era peak
summary: Japan and several industrialized east Asian economies are rapidly accumulating overseas bonds, reaching a magnitude similar to China's "savings glut" era peak in 2006-08. This increase in cross-border portfolio allocation may exacerbate financial risks, particularly among Asian pension funds and life insurers. The surge is not due to overall capital outflows, but rather a recomposition of outflows towards bonds. Regulators in Japan and Taiwan are scrutinizing foreign investments to avoid low or negative yields at home, with the four economies forecast to purchase $400 billion in foreign bonds this year.

site_title: Asia: Hong Kong tanks at reopen on virus fear but most markets bounce
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.6% on their reopening from the Lunar New Year break, while most other Asian markets rebounded due to bargain-buying. The decline was attributed to concerns over the deadly coronavirus, which has killed at least 132 people and infected more than in the 2003 Sars outbreak. However, healthy US data and a record earnings report from Apple supported a rally across US and European markets, lifting Asia's mood.

site_title: Raffles Family Office to invest U$15m in HK's WorkTech for Asean expansion
summary: Raffles Family Office (RFO) has invested $15 million in co-working space operator WorkTech to accelerate its expansion in South-east Asia. The investment will support WorkTech's plans to enter markets such as Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand, and the Philippines. This strategic move deepens the partnership between RFO and WorkTech, allowing RFO to bolster its service offerings to family offices in the region. WorkTech will use the funding to build a cross-border community and develop ecosystems for subsectors like fintech.

site_title: China battles virus spread with masks and disinfectant
summary: China is battling a viral outbreak, which has killed over 130 people, by implementing measures to halt its spread. Authorities are disinfecting public areas, encouraging people to wear masks, and restricting travel. Some cities, including Wuhan, have been almost completely sealed off. People are staying home or wearing masks if they must venture out, and businesses are being disinfected to reassure customers. The Lunar New Year holiday has been affected, with many malls and streets eerily quiet, and residents are taking precautions to protect themselves from infection.

images.alt_text: At a deserted restaurant in China's capital, one black-and-white sign stands out among colourful the decor and neon signs advertising braised meat dishes: "this store has been disinfected today.".

site_title: South Korea's Jan exports seen falling faster on Lunar New Year, coronavirus to add strains: poll
summary: South Korea's exports are expected to fall 7.8% in January, extending a 14th consecutive month of contraction, due to fewer working days around the Lunar New Year holiday and concerns over the new coronavirus. Shipments in December fell 5.2%. However, economists expect exports to turn positive in February due to chip sales and Chinese demand. The contagious virus may add pressure on the trade-reliant economy, with some analysts predicting a temporary slowdown in Chinese demand.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares gain after Wall Street rebound despite virus fears
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.40% in early trade on January 29, 2020, after Wall Street rebounded despite concerns over the spread of the coronavirus. The Nikkei 225 index gained 93.89 points to 23,309.60 points, while the Topix index rose 3.35 points to 1,695.63 points. Investors kept a close eye on the virus's development.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge 3% at open on virus fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3% at the start of trade on January 29, 2020, amid fears of the deadly virus spreading from China. The Hang Seng index dropped 848.10 points to 27,101.54, following a Lunar New Year break. Chinese markets remained closed. Investors' panic over the virus's spread led to the significant decline in Hong Kong's stock market.

site_title: Number infected by Wuhan virus rises to nearly 6,000: official
summary: China reported 5,974 confirmed cases of a new virus, surpassing the 2002-2003 Sars epidemic, with 132 deaths. Over 1,400 new cases were confirmed on Wednesday. Japan and the US evacuated nationals from Wuhan. Experts praise Beijing's response, but some criticize local officials for prioritizing stability over responding to the outbreak.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Dasin Retail, Straco, Sasseur Reit, Medtecs, AsiaMedic
summary: Singapore-listed companies affected by the Wuhan virus outbreak include CapitaLand, which closed six malls in China, and Straco Corporation, which temporarily closed three attractions. Dasin Retail Trust and Sasseur Reit also closed some businesses in China as a precautionary measure. In contrast, medical plays and glove makers such as Medtecs International, AsiaMedic, and Healthway Medical gained on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore property firms shut China malls, announce early closures over Wuhan virus
summary: Singapore-listed property firms CapitaLand, Dasin Retail Trust, and Sasseur Reit have closed or shortened business hours at their malls in China due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. CapitaLand closed six malls, including four in Wuhan, while Dasin Retail Trust shortened hours at five malls and Sasseur Reit closed four outlet malls. These measures aim to prevent the spread of the virus and ensure food and daily essentials supply to local communities. The closures affect 42% of CapitaLand's revenue and all of Dasin Retail Trust's and Sasseur Reit's revenue.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.79 points or 0.05% to 1,550.85. The market saw 109.43 million lots traded, with gainers beating losers 172 to 81. This comes amidst global market trends, including a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Opportunities arise in Vietnam due to US-China trade war
summary: Vietnam has benefited from the US-China trade war, with a significant increase in orders received by manufacturers, particularly in the garment industry. The country's growing middle class has created opportunities for consumer-related industries, with Singaporean companies expanding their presence. Despite challenges such as increasing competition and labor costs, Vietnam remains a dynamic emerging market, attracting investment in manufacturing. The country's trade associations, such as the Singapore Business Group and the Singapore Business Association Vietnam, facilitate business relationships and provide valuable information. Entrepreneurs are advised to build relationships, trust, and patience, as well as utilize local communication channels, to succeed in Vietnam's business environment.

images.alt_text: The US-China trade war has spurred the growth of the manufacturing industry in Vietnam. Garment orders received by Norfolk Global have increased, but not without a rise in labor costs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Travel, tourism stocks dive on virus woes
summary: Hong Kong's travel, tourism, and property stocks plummeted on January 29, 2020, amid the economic impact of the virus in China, which has killed at least 132 people and infected more than Sars on the mainland. The Hang Seng Index fell over 2% as panicked investors sold, wiping over $1 trillion off valuations. Key sectors, including Macau casino operators, Cathay Pacific Airways, and energy firms, were particularly hard hit. The crisis echoes the Sars outbreak of 17 years ago, which paralyzed regional travel and battered local economies.

site_title: Singapore firm Vena Energy to build 100 MW solar battery in Queensland
summary: Singapore-based Vena Energy plans to build a 100 MW solar battery in Queensland, Australia, for energy retailer AGL. The project, valued at A$120 million, will store 150 MW hours of energy and power up to 57,000 homes annually. Construction is set to begin in July and will employ 30 workers. This is the first construction milestone of Vena's Wandoan South Project, which aims to generate 1,000 MW of solar electricity and 450 MW of energy storage.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon up 0.26% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday afternoon, with the Straits Times Index up 8.17 points or 0.26% to 3,189.42. Medtecs International led gains, rising 2.7 Singapore cents or 15.7% to 19.9 cents. Healthcare-related stocks also saw significant movements, with UG Healthcare surging 15.5 Singapore cents or 62% to 40.5 cents. Meanwhile, CapitaLand closed six malls in China due to the coronavirus outbreak and Dasin Retail Trust shortened opening hours at its Chinese malls.

site_title: Kobe Bryant's body identified among helicopter crash victims
summary: The body of NBA legend Kobe Bryant was officially identified by medical examiners two days after a helicopter crash near Los Angeles, where nine people, including Bryant, died. The identification was confirmed using fingerprints. Federal investigators completed their inspection of the crash site and handed it over to local authorities. The victims include Bryant, along with eight others, and their remains were recovered from the rugged hillside.

site_title: Australia inflation edges up but still below target
summary: Australia's inflation rate rose 0.7% in the December quarter, higher than forecast, but still below the Reserve Bank of Australia's 2-3% target band. Core measures, a key indicator of underlying inflation, remained at 1.6%, four years below target. The annual inflation rate rose to 1.8%, driven by increases in cigarette, travel, fuel, and fruit prices. Despite three interest rate cuts, the central bank may need to take further action to revive consumer prices.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher tracking US stocks rebound; STI up 0.09%
summary: Singapore shares edged higher at the open, with the Straits Times Index gaining 2.98 points or 0.09% to 3,184.23. The rebound was attributed to Wall Street stocks rising overnight following solid US economic data and mixed earnings. European shares also rebounded, while Asian markets, including Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index, rose.

site_title: White House holds off on suspending China-US flights amid virus outbreak
summary: The White House has decided not to suspend flights from China to the US amid the coronavirus outbreak, despite considering a temporary ban on flights. The Trump administration held daily meetings on the issue and has not ruled out any options, including a flight ban, if public health data supports the move. The decision comes as the administration continues to discuss ways to deal with the outbreak.

site_title: CapitaLand closes 6 malls in China; shorter hours at remaining 45
summary: CapitaLand, a property giant, has closed six malls in China due to the Wuhan virus outbreak, with four in Wuhan and two in Xian. The remaining 45 malls operate with shorter hours. The company has set up a special task force and adopted precautionary measures, including temperature checks and contact tracing. CapitaLand's business operations remain stable, with a focus on ensuring the well-being of its tenants, shoppers, and employees.

site_title: Europe: Shares recover from viral outbreak fuelled sell-off
summary: European shares recovered from a sell-off fueled by concerns over the coronavirus outbreak, with the Stoxx 600 index rising 0.8% after a 2.6% gain from Italy's lender-heavy index. Luxury goods makers and banks, such as Swedbank and Virgin Money UK, rallied after a 3% drop on Monday. Despite rising death tolls, President Xi Jinping expressed confidence in defeating the virus, and investors are now looking for short-term bargains ahead of central bank meetings and Brexit talks.

site_title: Plane carrying Japanese evacuees from Wuhan lands in Tokyo
summary: A plane carrying 206 Japanese evacuees from Wuhan, China, landed at Tokyo's Haneda airport on January 29, 2020. The evacuees were on a flight carrying emergency relief supplies and medical professionals to monitor returning passengers. Health checks and testing for the new coronavirus strain were planned, with those showing symptoms to be taken to hospital immediately. Evacuees were asked to remain at home and avoid crowds until test results were known, with those living in Tokyo allowed to head home and others taken to local hotels.

site_title: Australia: Shares tick higher on financials, tech
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 7,019.90, driven by gains in financial and technology stocks, despite concerns over the coronavirus outbreak in China. The S&P/ASX 200 index was boosted by financial stocks, including the "Big Four" banks, and technology stocks like Apple and Afterpay. Energy stocks also climbed, while gold stocks fell due to lower bullion prices. Treasury Wine Estates slumped 20% after lowering earnings expectations. Global markets stabilized after the World Health Organisation expressed confidence in China's ability to control the virus.

site_title: Australia to help some citizens leave China, quarantine them on Christmas Island
summary: Australia will assist citizens from Hubei province in China, particularly isolated and vulnerable Australians, in leaving the region and quarantining them on Christmas Island. Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced the plan following a briefing by the Chinese government. The exact number of citizens to be helped is not specified, but Australia will also assist New Zealand and Pacific island citizens in Hubei.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust shortens hours, shuts businesses at China malls
summary: DASIN Retail Trust has shortened business hours at its five malls in China due to the coronavirus outbreak, with malls now open from 10am to 4pm daily. The trust has also closed crowded places such as cinemas and karaoke lounges. The move aims to minimize contagious risk and maintain at least six hours of business hours per day, in line with Chinese government requirements. The financial impact is uncertain, but the trust expects minimal impact due to pure turnover rent making up only 3% of its gross rental income.

site_title: JPMorgan plans to cut hundreds of jobs across consumer division: sources
summary: JPMorgan plans to cut hundreds of jobs from its consumer division as the bank seeks to reduce costs. The cuts, expected to be notified to employees on February 6, will be scattered across the division and represent about 1% of employees. The move is part of a broader review of operations as customers increasingly access banking services through digital platforms. The cuts come after JPMorgan cut around 7,000 operations jobs from the unit in the four years through 2018.

site_title: UN health agency to send experts to China
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) announced it will send international experts to China to help inform the global response against a deadly virus outbreak. The experts will work with Chinese counterparts to increase understanding of the outbreak and guide global response efforts. The agreement follows talks between WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus and Chinese President Xi Jinping, who agreed to share biological material with the WHO. The outbreak has killed over 100 people and infected thousands in China and other countries.

site_title: Airbus to set aside 3.6b euros to settle corruption probe
summary: Airbus has agreed to set aside up to 3.6 billion euros to settle a corruption probe by authorities in France, Britain, and the US. The proposed settlement, which could be approved by courts on Friday, would result in Airbus taking a provision of 3.6 billion euros for potential penalties to the French, UK, and US authorities. This amount is roughly equivalent to the company's 2018 net profit and will be booked in the 2019 accounts.

site_title: Garena buys gaming developer Phoenix Labs for reportedly over US$150m
summary: Garena, the gaming arm of Sea Ltd, has acquired Phoenix Labs, a Canadian gaming developer, for over US$150 million. Phoenix Labs is behind the free-to-play game Dauntless, which will continue to be distributed on Epic Games' platform. The acquisition signals Garena's increased focus on game development to capture a larger gaming industry share, projected to reach US$300 billion by 2025. The deal brings over 100 top developers to Garena, with plans to add more features to Dauntless and explore new growth opportunities.

site_title: Apple delivers record results, sees growth in iPhones, services
summary: Apple reported record quarterly revenue of $91.8 billion, with a net profit of $22 billion, driven by strong demand for iPhones, digital services, and wearables like AirPods. CEO Tim Cook attributed the success to the popularity of iPhone 11 and iPhone 11 Pro models, as well as all-time records for services and wearables. Apple shares rose 2% in after-market trades following the earnings report.

site_title: Britain warns nationals against visiting mainland China
summary: The British Foreign Office warned nationals against "all but essential travel" to mainland China due to the deadly novel coronavirus outbreak, advising against travel to the worst-affected Hubei Province. The ministry is working to facilitate evacuations for British citizens in the area, with estimates suggesting up to 200 citizens may want to return to Britain. Meanwhile, the Chinese government has imposed further restrictions on movement within China, which may make it harder for those who wish to leave to do so in the coming weeks.

site_title: Renault turns to Volkswagen's De Meo as car maker seeks fresh start
summary: Renault appoints Luca de Meo, former head of Volkswagen's Seat brand, as its new CEO, effective July 1, as the company seeks a fresh start following a year of turmoil. De Meo's appointment fills a key gap left after the arrest of former boss Carlos Ghosn and aims to reset the strained alliance with Nissan Motor. Clotilde Delbos will become deputy CEO. De Meo's task will be to turn around the firm amidst a downturn in demand and pressure to meet new emissions targets and deliver on cost savings.

site_title: Airbus agrees to settle bribery cases for about US$3b
summary: Airbus has agreed to settle bribery investigations in the UK, France, and the US for approximately US$3 billion. The settlement, pending court and authority approval, resolves long-running investigations into bribery practices. The European airplane manufacturer has yet to announce the final terms of the agreement, but a settlement could be announced as early as this week.

site_title: How the world is reacting to Trump's Middle East plan
summary: Europe and Russia have given a lukewarm response to President Trump's Middle East plan, with the EU and Russia pledging to study the proposal but emphasizing its need to satisfy both Israelis and Palestinians. Key Muslim countries, including Turkey, Iran, and the Palestinian Authority, have strongly denounced the plan as a betrayal of the Palestinians. The Palestinian Authority has vowed to resist the deal, while Hezbollah has called it an attempt to "wipe out the Palestinian people's rights." Britain has welcomed the plan, calling it a "serious proposal."

site_title: Decline in UK shop prices eases in January: BRC
summary: The rate of decline in UK shop prices slowed in January, falling 0.3% in annual terms, according to the British Retail Consortium and Nielsen. This marks a decrease from a 0.4% drop in December. The slowdown is attributed to shoppers remaining cautious about spending, with discounting continuing for non-food retailers. Prices have fallen by an average 0.5% over the previous six months.

images.alt_text: The rate of decline in prices on the British high street slowed in January, an industry survey showed on Wednesday. Shop prices fell by 0.3 per cent in annual terms, following a 0.4 per cent drop in December, the British Retail Consortium trade body and market research firm Nielsen said.

site_title: MOM to reject all new work pass applications for foreign workers from Hubei
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower has rejected all new work pass applications for foreign workers from Hubei province due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. Over 30 applications have been turned down, with renewal applications for existing work pass holders unaffected. Employees from Hubei will be quarantined upon return to Singapore, and new travel curbs have been implemented to prevent entry into or transit through Singapore for those with a Hubei passport or recent travel history.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce back after virus-fueled rout
summary: US stocks rebounded on Tuesday after a virus-fueled rout, driven by solid economic data and mixed earnings. Authorities remain vigilant about the Sars-like virus, but investors see it as a buying opportunity, with some optimism that the outbreak won't spread out of control. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the US economy showing resilience.

site_title: US deficit seen ballooning over US$1t this year: CBO
summary: The US budget deficit is expected to reach over $1 trillion this year and remain above that level for a decade due to growing government debt, according to the Congressional Budget Office. The deficit is expected to average $1.3 trillion from 2021 to 2030, and US debt is projected to grow to 98% of the American economy by 2030 and 180% by 2050. The large deficits are attributed to the 2017 tax cut package and recent legislation, despite promises that the tax cuts would pay for themselves.

site_title: Google aims AI at whales, words and well-being
summary: Google unveiled AI projects aimed at protecting whales, breaking language barriers, and improving well-being. The company showcased a "bioacoustics" project to track endangered species, while also working on AI-powered tools for language translation and understanding. Google's efforts come after CEO Sundar Pichai urged a "proportional approach" to regulating AI. The company's focus on using AI for good highlights its commitment to responsible innovation.

site_title: United Airlines trims service from US to China over virus
summary: United Airlines will suspend flights from the US to China from Feb 1-8 due to a significant decline in demand amid a Sars-like virus outbreak. The cancellations affect routes from San Francisco, Chicago, and Newark, New Jersey. US health officials have urged Americans to avoid nonessential travel to China, while China advises citizens to postpone trips abroad. The novel coronavirus has killed over 100 people and infected over 4,000, with cases reported in 15 countries. United Airlines will monitor the situation and adjust its schedule as needed.

site_title: Caribbean quake rocks Cuban capital Havana
summary: A major earthquake struck the Caribbean on Tuesday, hitting the Cuban capital Havana, causing buildings to be evacuated and sending hundreds into the streets. The quake was felt in several provinces, including Guantanamo, Santiago de Cuba, Cienfuegos, and Havana. Several tall buildings in Havana were evacuated as a precaution. The exact magnitude of the quake is not specified in the article.

site_title: Bank of Japan debated scope for policy review in January: summary
summary: The Bank of Japan's rate review in January highlighted the need for a review of its monetary policy framework due to prolonged low growth and subdued inflation. The nine-member board debated the effectiveness of negative interest rates, which could lower inflation expectations by making households and companies pessimistic about the outlook. Despite this, the BOJ kept policy steady and raised its economic growth forecasts following easing US-China tensions and subsiding global risks.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan ought to conduct a review of its monetary policy framework as the economy suffers prolonged low growth and subdued inflation, one of its board members said in a rate review in January.

site_title: Facebook rolls out tool globally to clear third-party data
summary: Facebook has rolled out a new tool globally to allow its estimated 2 billion users to view and delete data collected from third parties, part of an effort to improve privacy practices. The tool, which allows users to see and clear "off Facebook activity" used for targeted advertising, offers "a new level of transparency and control" according to CEO Mark Zuckerberg. This move comes after past revelations on how Facebook collects and uses data, aiming to regain user trust and confidence in the social network.

images.alt_text: Facebook said on Tuesday a new tool allowing users of the social network to view and delete data it collects from third parties is rolling out to the estimated two billion members of the leading social network worldwide.

site_title: Make your hongbao green - recycle the empty red packets
summary: OCBC Bank in Singapore is launching a recycling initiative for the bank's red packets, encouraging customers to recycle the empty packets into new products such as toilet paper and cardboard boxes. The bank has set up recycling boxes at its branches and will collect and recycle the packets, which can produce up to 17 million trees if recycled. This initiative aims to reduce carbon emissions and promote environmental sustainability, joining OCBC's broader efforts to combat climate change.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust plans 22.2b yen acquisition of Japan facility
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) plans to acquire an effective interest of 98.47% in a 22.2 billion yen (S$272.5 million) freehold logistics property in Kobe, Japan. The four-storey facility has modern Grade A specifications and is 99.7% occupied. The acquisition is expected to increase MLT's exposure to Japan and deepen its network connectivity in the country. Unitholders' approval is required due to the transaction being an interested party transaction.

site_title: UK banks approve most mortgages since 2015
summary: UK banks approved a record number of mortgages in December, with 46,815 house purchase approvals on a seasonally-adjusted basis, the highest since August 2015. This marks a turnaround in the housing market since the general election, with mortgage lending value rising by a net £3.773 billion. Economist Howard Archer notes that early signs of a recovery suggest the housing market may be changing, but caution remains, with consumer credit growing at a weak pace and credit card lending up only 2.4%. The Bank of England considers cutting interest rates in response to weak economic data.

site_title: Beijing in shutdown mode as fears grip locals
summary: Beijing, China is in shutdown mode due to the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak, with thousands of yellow-and-green taxis missing and residents avoiding public gatherings. The city has 80 registered cases and one reported death, with nearby provinces also experiencing confirmed cases. The government has taken drastic measures, including banning intra-province bus travel, closing schools and universities, and imposing temperature checks at subway stations. The Lunar New Year celebrations, usually a major event, have been significantly impacted, with many popular tourist spots and temple fairs shut down.

site_title: Humans created the coronavirus epidemic
summary: A coronavirus, provisionally named "nCoV-2019," has infected over 4,500 people and killed at least 106 in China, sparking a global health crisis. Scientists believe the virus may have originated from a bat in a cave in Yunnan Province, China, and was transmitted to humans through an intermediate host. The Wuhan Institute of Virology, where the virus was first identified, has been studying coronaviruses in bats since 2005, warning of the potential for human pandemics. The outbreak highlights the risks of human-wildlife interactions and the need for increased global preparedness and cooperation to prevent and respond to future pandemics.

site_title: Sars-era injection may be what the doctor orders
summary: Singapore is considering a S$230 million relief package to support tourism-related businesses affected by the Wuhan virus, similar to the 2003 Sars relief package. The government is looking at measures such as property tax rebates, working capital loans for SMEs, and lower foreign worker levies. Analysts expect the government to provide targeted support, including solvency support for SMEs, and may offer relief after the Budget on February 18. The scale of the impact is uncertain, but experts predict short-term slowing in tourism and retail sectors.

site_title: Sasseur Reit drops 10.3% after closures at China malls to guard against virus
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, has temporarily closed four of its outlet malls in China due to the coronavirus outbreak. The closures were made as a precautionary measure to safeguard the health and safety of shoppers, customers, and employees. The manager believes the financial impact, if any, will be minimal if the crisis is resolved in the short term. The Reit's units have dropped 10.3% following the closures.

site_title: Rolls-Royce B787 engines hit by safety order
summary: Rolls-Royce is swapping out over 30 Boeing 787 engines due to concerns that they may experience a power surge, potentially leading to mid-flight shutdowns. The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) has issued an airworthiness directive requiring the engines to be "de-paired." This is part of a broader issue with Trent 1000 design glitches, which have plagued Rolls-Royce since 2016 and are expected to cost £2.4 billion through 2023. The move affects five operators and around 4% of the total fleet of 787 engines.

site_title: Euro falls to 33-month low vs Swiss franc on China virus fears
summary: The euro plummeted to a 33-month low against the Swiss franc on January 28, 2020, amid concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in China. Investors sought safe-havens, driving the Australian dollar to losses and the US dollar to an eight-week high. Global markets stabilized, but risk aversion persisted, with the euro's decline attributed to China's economic uncertainty.

site_title: Philips to sell off domestic appliances business
summary: Dutch health technology company Philips plans to sell its domestic appliances division, generating 2.3 billion euros in sales last year, within 12-18 months. The division, which includes coffee machines, air purifiers, and air fryers, no longer fits with Philips' hospital equipment and personal health products. CEO Frans van Houten stated that the business has a double-digit profit margin and will be sold to a "good home" as Philips expands in consumer health and professional healthcare. The decision comes after Philips reported a 10% increase in core earnings but missed its initial goal of improving the profit margin.

site_title: New rules to navigate financial world powered by AI and automation
summary: A growing number of financial services organizations in the Asia-Pacific region have started adopting Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies, with 52% already on their AI journey. Spending on AI in the region increased by 54% in 2019, with the banking industry leading in AI usage for fraud analysis and automated customer service. As Industry 4.0 technologies continue to transform the business landscape, companies are expected to navigate the financial world powered by AI and automation.

site_title: Outbreak may disrupt iPhone plans
summary: Apple's plan to increase iPhone production by 10% in the first half of 2020 may be disrupted due to the coronavirus outbreak in China. The company has ordered suppliers to produce up to 80 million iPhones, but the third-week-of-February production start may be delayed. Apple has booked orders for 65 million older iPhones and 15 million new cut-price models. The outbreak affects Apple's efforts to boost iPhone sales, which have been declining. The company's earnings report is scheduled for Tuesday.

site_title: China vows to beat 'devil' virus as countries rush to evacuate citizens
summary: China President Xi Jinping vows to defeat the 'devil' coronavirus, which has killed 106 people, despite international alarm. The US expands airport screenings and considers travel curbs, while other countries take precautions to contain the outbreak. The US Health Secretary, Alex Azar, says all options for dealing with the outbreak should be on the table, including travel restrictions.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping said on Tuesday that China was sure of defeating a "devil" coronavirus that has killed 106 people, but international alarm was rising as the outbreak spread across the world.

site_title: Renewed push in Nissan to get Renault to cut its stake
summary: Nissan is proposing a plan to reduce its stake in Renault, aiming to balance the partnership. The plan involves both companies cutting cross-shareholdings and using the funds for joint technology investments. Details, such as the timing of a stake sale, are undecided. The proposal is still in its early stages, but it could potentially bolster the alliance between the two carmakers.

site_title: Abe sticks with reflationist balance on BOJ board
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe maintained the number of reflationists on the Bank of Japan policy board, sending a signal of continuity for central bank policy. Seiji Adachi, head of economic research at Marusan Securities, was chosen to replace Yutaka Harada, maintaining the current balance of reflationists on the board.

site_title: UBP posts strong performance in Asian business
summary: Union Bancaire Privee (UBP) reported strong results in its Asian operations in 2019, driven by growth in client mandates. The Swiss bank's assets in Asia have grown significantly since acquiring the international wealth management business of the Royal Bank of Scotland in 2015. UBP's CEO, Guy de Picciotto, described the business as "extremely positive and growing." The success is attributed to the acquisition, which provided UBP with a foothold in the region.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Transcorp Holdings, a catalyst-listed company, has signed a non-binding letter of intent with undisclosed investors to raise approximately S$1 million. The move comes as the company faces claims from creditors, including Fuji Xerox Singapore and Ace Financial Services. Meanwhile, Olam has entered an agreement with AP Moller Capital and Africa Finance Corporation to infuse capital into ARISE Port & Logistics, resulting in a cash release of US$31 million. Straco Corp has temporarily closed three attractions in China to prevent the spread of the Wuhan virus.

site_title: New Zealand sets polling date on Sept 19
summary: New Zealand has set a polling date of September 19 for a general election to decide on a second term for Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, amidst a backdrop of slowing economic growth and low business confidence. The election will also include referendums on legalizing cannabis and euthanasia. Ardern's popularity has been affected by domestic issues, but she remains popular overseas due to her response to the mass shooting and climate change action. A close contest is predicted, with her ruling coalition facing a challenging election campaign.

site_title: US developing vaccine against deadly China virus: officials
summary: The US is developing a vaccine against the deadly China virus, with the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and biotech firm Moderna working on the project. The process will take three months to start trials and gather data, with the US urging China to step up cooperation with international health authorities. The US has offered China assistance three times, but to no avail. Meanwhile, the World Health Organization has agreed to allow a team of international experts into China to work with their Chinese counterparts, following China's rapid sequencing of the virus's genome.

images.alt_text: "We have already started at the NIH and with many of our collaborators on the developing of a vaccine," National Institutes of Health (NIH) official Anthony Fauci told reporters.

site_title: New York apartment building sales plunge
summary: New York City apartment building sales plummeted to near-decade lows in 2019, with a 40% decline in dollar value to $6.91 billion. This was the lowest total since 2011, according to Ariel Property Advisors. The decline was driven by the new rent law, which made it difficult for landlords to raise rents, remove units from regulation, or recoup capital improvements. As a result, investors shifted towards non-regulated units, with 60% of units changing hands being market rate, according to the report.

site_title: Hana Financial Group to sponsor first Singapore Women's golf open in November
summary: Hana Financial Group is set to sponsor the first Singapore Women's golf open, taking place in November at Tanah Merah Country Club from November 6 to 8, and then at Laguna National from November 26 to 29. This marks a significant expansion of golf opportunities for Singaporean women golfers, previously limited to the HSBC Women's World Championship qualifiers. The two tournaments will provide a platform for professional golfers to compete and showcase their skills.

site_title: Singapore-listed companies with China exposure feel the heat
summary: Singapore-listed companies with China exposure saw significant declines on Tuesday, with 35 stocks out of 44 with at least 20% of annual revenues from China registering falls. Travel and leisure plays, such as Sasseur Reit and Straco Corporation, were particularly hard hit, with business and consumer sentiment undermined by fears of contagion. Analysts predict a downturn in the hospitality, tourism, and airline sectors, with some companies already seeing cancellations and room occupancy affected.

site_title: China calls for investors to assess epidemic 'rationally'
summary: China's top securities regulator has urged investors to evaluate the impact of the deadly coronavirus "rationally and objectively", amid a global market retreat. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) advises securities firms to guide investors to assess the disease's impact and "adhere to the concept of long-term investment and value investment". This comes as the yuan retreated in offshore trading and global equities declined. The regulator's statement aims to calm market sentiment during the Chinese New Year holiday.

site_title: Wuhan virus: More short-term pain but lasting damage unlikely
summary: A deadly coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan, China, has led to a global spike in confirmed cases, with over 4,500 cases and 100 deaths as of January 28, 2020. Despite concerns, the outbreak is expected to last between two and four months, with a limited impact on China's GDP growth, estimated at 0.5% or less. This is considered less severe than the SARS outbreak in 2003, due to China's swift response and lower fatality rate. The economic impact is expected to be mostly limited to sectors affected by reduced consumer spending, but long-term fundamentals remain intact, and investors with a long-term horizon may benefit from buying on weakness.

site_title: Medical plays, glove makers soar as Wuhan virus fears spread
summary: Investors in Singapore's medical sector and glove makers saw significant gains on January 28, 2020, amid fears of the Wuhan coronavirus spreading. Shares in medical firms like Medtecs International, AsiaMedic Limited, and Healthway Medical rose 65.4%, 13.3%, and 17.9% respectively, while glove makers Top Glove, UG Healthcare, and Riverstone Holdings surged 23.7%, 61.3%, and 19.6% respectively. Analysts attribute the price increases to investor concerns about a potential global pandemic, with some companies benefiting from previous outbreaks.

site_title: Wuhan virus contagion pummels Asian markets
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Tuesday, January 28, 2020, amid growing concerns over the Wuhan coronavirus, with the Straits Times Index in Singapore falling 2.9% and the Nikkei 225 in Japan sliding 0.6%. The virus has tripled in deaths and swelled past 3,000 confirmed cases, with market watchers warning that sentiment could worsen before improving. Despite this, analysts believe the region is well-positioned for a speedy recovery if positive news emerges from China.

images.alt_text: Asian equity markets returning from the Chinese New Year (CNY) break joined others in a sea of red as fears mounted over the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus - jolting memories of 2003's Sars outbreak in Asia and weighing on the region's risk assets.

site_title: Making diversity part of 'everyday' business
summary: Singapore ranked second-worst in workplace diversity and inclusion practices globally, with 24% of workers experiencing bullying and 32% feeling uncomfortable with their employers. Despite the country's business focus on diversity, many employees fear speaking up due to concerns about discrimination. To address this, companies must make diversity and inclusion a part of everyday business, not just a compliance measure. This requires understanding the intersectional makeup of the workforce, collecting in-depth D&I data, and implementing tactics such as setting clear expectations for inclusive leadership behaviors and "small wins" to improve D&I practices.

site_title: More help for seniors to lead active lives: Indranee
summary: Singapore's Minister in the Prime Minister's Office Indranee Rajah announced that the government will offer additional incentives to encourage voluntary work and support retirees in leading active lives. Budget 2020 will include measures to promote volunteerism and ensure retirees' well-being, such as increasing funding for the Silver Volunteer Fund. Indranee emphasized the importance of empowering seniors to contribute and live fulfilling lives, and the government aims to create a place where retirees can feel assured and still contribute to society.

images.alt_text: Ms Indranee taking part in a drone demonstration at RSVP Singapore. RSVP conducts courses on drones for IT-savvy seniors who are looking to upskill themselves outside of basic IT courses.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after Monday's selloff
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Tuesday after the S&P 500 suffered its worst day in nearly four months due to concerns over a coronavirus outbreak in China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 58.48 points, the S&P 500 opened higher by 11.72 points, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 62.51 points. The market rebounded despite concerns about global economic growth and US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit prices units at £0.68 or S$1.21 each
summary: Elite Commercial Reit launched its initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore, pricing units at £0.68 or S$1.21 each. The £130.9 million offering is the first pound-denominated Reit listing in Singapore and could pave the way for more UK-focused Reits to list here. The Reit has a forecast distribution yield of 7.1% for 2020 and 7.2% for 2022, with 43.7% of its assets held by private trust investors and 67.2% by cornerstone investors. The Reit's assets are 99% let to the UK government, making them stable and counter-cyclical.

site_title: Global Invacom expects Shanghai ops closure to incur losses of up to US$10.5m
summary: Global Invacom expects to incur losses of up to US$10.5 million due to the closure of its Shanghai operations, which is ongoing and expected to be completed by June 2020. The company has relocated its manufacturing to the Philippines, where it will account for 45% of global production. The Shanghai closure resulted in a decrease in workers from 1,100 in 2014 to 300 by end-2019, despite rising production costs. Global Invacom expects to announce its FY2019 unaudited results in late February 2020.

site_title: Wuhan virus fears put squeeze on travel sector
summary: Wuhan virus fears are affecting Singapore's travel sector, with hotels and travel firms reporting lower occupancy and cancellations. Local restaurants are also seeing a fall in demand. Despite taking health precautions, companies are waiting for further government directives. The situation is being closely monitored, but so far, the impact on the services sector appears to be limited, with F&B and retail staying afloat.

site_title: WHO chief confident about China's ability to contain virus
summary: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus expressed confidence in China's ability to contain the new coronavirus, calling for calm and saying no need to evacuate foreigners. The virus has killed 106 people, with 4,515 confirmed cases in China, and has spread to other countries. Despite concerns, the WHO declined to declare an international emergency, citing only one case of human-to-human transmission outside China. The WHO aims to strengthen its partnership with China to combat the outbreak, which has sparked economic and travel concerns globally.

site_title: Piracy is still an unacceptable reality
summary: Piracy incidents continue to plague shipping lanes, particularly in the Singapore Strait, with 31 reported incidents in 2019, including 14 on barges and 8 bulk carriers, tankers, and barges. Gunmen abducted eight crew members from a Malaysian fishing trawler, with three recovered safely. The International Maritime Bureau (IMB) reports a significant rise in crew kidnappings in the Gulf of Guinea, with 121 incidents in 2019, an increase of over 50% from 2018. The IMB urges increased information exchange and coordination to address the growing piracy threat.

site_title: US new home sales fall unexpectedly in December
summary: US new home sales fell 0.4% in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 694,000 units, below economists' expectations. Lower mortgage rates supported the overall housing market, with sales concentrated in the $200,000-$749,000 price range. The housing market is expected to offset some of the drag on economic growth from weakness in business spending and manufacturing, with the Atlanta Fed forecasting GDP growth at a 1.8% annualized rate in Q4.

images.alt_text: Reports this month showed sales of previously owned homes jumped to near a two-year high in December and housing starts raced to a 13-year peak. The housing sector accounts for about 3.1 per cent of gross domestic product.

site_title: Singapore must continue to ensure social mobility for better growth
summary: Singapore ranks 20th in the Global Social Mobility Index, scoring 74.6 out of 100. The Nordic nations lead the list, with Denmark and Finland ranking first and second respectively. The index assesses education, work opportunities, social protection, and institutions. Singapore's performance highlights the need to maintain social mobility to drive growth, as rapid technological advances threaten to widen inequality.

site_title: UK grants Huawei a limited role in 5G, defying President Trump
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has granted Huawei a limited role in Britain's 5G mobile network, despite US pressure to exclude the company due to concerns over data security. Huawei's involvement will be capped at 35% and limited to non-sensitive parts of the network. The decision allows Huawei to continue working with UK customers and provides access to world-leading technology, but may scale back US intelligence cooperation.

site_title: China has a major soft power problem in Asia
summary: China faces a growing soft power problem in Asia, with recent polls showing very low trust in the country as a major power. The ISEAS State of South-east Asia opinion poll found 60.4% of respondents expressed little or no trust in China, down from 51.5% in 2019. Similar results were seen in Pew Center and Lowy Institute polls, with only 16.1% expressing confidence in China's benevolent nature and 32% trusting it as a responsible major power. China's increasing economic and strategic weight is not translating into trust, posing a challenge to its growing global influence.

site_title: World's pile of negative debt surges the most since 2016 amid health scare
summary: The world's stockpile of negative-yielding bonds surged by $1.16 trillion last week, the largest weekly increase since 2016, amid growing fears over a deadly virus spreading from China. The total negative-yielding debt now stands at $12.4 trillion, the highest level in two months, as investors worldwide ditch riskier assets and pile into bonds. Policy makers have assured markets that ultra-low rates will continue to flow, but analysts expect the peak of negative yields to be behind them, with some predicting a return to higher yields in the near future.

site_title: Straco temporarily shuts 3 China attractions to curb Wuhan virus spread
summary: Straco Corporation, a tourism operator, has temporarily closed three attractions in China - Shanghai Ocean Aquarium, Underwater World Xiamen, and Lixing Cable Car - due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. The closures began on January 25 and are in compliance with local authorities' advice to prevent the spread of the virus. The company will closely monitor updates and put in place precautionary health and hygiene measures, including increased cleaning and employee screening. The reopening of the attractions will be announced at a later date.

site_title: BorgWarner to buy Delphi for US$1.5b in auto-parts deal
summary: BorgWarner agreed to acquire Delphi Technologies for about $1.5 billion in an all-stock deal, uniting two auto suppliers for the industry's shift to hybrid and electric vehicles. The deal values Delphi Technologies at $3.3 billion, including debt, and both companies expect a period of decline due to carmakers' consolidation and pivot to electric cars. The combined company will have cost savings of $125 million by 2023, with BorgWarner owning 84% and Delphi Technologies owners holding 16%.

site_title: IMF sees medium-term risks to global economy; more easing not the answer
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns policymakers of medium-term risks to the global economy due to rising debt levels and financial vulnerabilities. The IMF forecasts a slight global economic rebound this year and next, but notes that further monetary easing may not be the solution. Rising debt levels, asset valuations, and large capital flows to emerging markets pose a threat to growth in the medium term, and policymakers should be vigilant about emerging risks and deploy other policy tools to mitigate these vulnerabilities.

site_title: Adidas to launch new fabrics from recycled ocean plastic, polyester
summary: Adidas plans to launch new fabrics made from recycled polyester and marine plastic waste, expanding its product lines after the success of shoes made with the Parley for the Oceans initiative. The company collected over 11 million pairs of shoes using plastic collected on beaches in 2019. However, the Ellen MacArthur Foundation states that only 0.1% of clothing materials are recycled, resulting in a loss of over $100 billion annually. This move aims to increase sustainability in the fashion industry.

site_title: US business-equipment orders down in Dec
summary: US business-equipment orders declined 0.9% in December, missing estimates, after a 0.1% gain in the prior month. This marks a subdued business investment year, weighing on expansion. Full-year capital equipment orders rose 0.8% to $827 billion, but business investment was a drag on growth in the second and third quarters. The data adds to signs of lackluster corporate investment amid weaker overseas demand and trade uncertainty.

site_title: Debit card spend could overtake credit cards in Indonesia in 2019
summary: Indonesia's card transactions are expected to grow 7.1% annually from 2019 to 2023, with debit card spending surpassing credit cards in 2019 and eventually making up half of all transactions. The growth is driven by government initiatives and the emergence of mobile-only banks, which will further accelerate electronic payments. Better payment infrastructure, lower card acceptance costs, and e-commerce are also key factors.

site_title: SGInnovate's founding CEO Steve Leonard to step down in May
summary: SGInnovate's founding CEO Steve Leonard will step down in May 2020, marking the end of his four-year term. Leonard expressed pride in the organization's growth, having invested in 90 startups and engaged a community of over 33,000 people. The board and management thanked Leonard for his leadership, but did not announce a replacement. The organization does not anticipate significant structural changes, citing a focus on organizational renewal.

site_title: South Korea 'all out' to contain virus outbreak, vows to stabilise market
summary: South Korea has vowed to contain the spreading coronavirus outbreak, with Finance Minister Hong Nam-ki stating the government will "go all out" to protect citizens and minimize its economic impact. The government will use a 20.8 billion won emergency fund to combat the virus, which has spread to several countries and killed at least 81 people. South Korea has previously prepared for such an outbreak, drawing up a supplementary budget in 2015 to cope with the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome. The government aims to stabilize financial markets if volatility worsens.

site_title: US new home sales drop for third straight month in December
summary: US new home sales dropped 0.4% in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 694,000 units, marking the third straight monthly decline. The decline was attributed to a shortage of affordable homes, with new homes priced below $200,000 accounting for only 10% of sales. Despite this, the housing market remains supported by lower mortgage rates, with the 30-year fixed mortgage rate averaging 3.60%.

site_title: Singapore shares tumble 1.8% on widening Wuhan virus fears
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.8% on January 28, 2020, amid widening fears of the Wuhan coronavirus. The index closed at 3,181.25 after a sharp opening lower. Other regional markets also declined, with benchmarks in Australia, Japan, and South Korea lower. Medical groups and rubber glove makers saw gains, while those with significant Chinese exposure took a beating, including property trusts and real estate giants. Despite concerns, analysts noted that the growth outlook for most companies remains intact.

site_title: 3M to cut 1,500 jobs in revamp amid auto, electronics woes
summary: 3M is cutting 1,500 jobs globally as part of a restructuring effort aimed at addressing challenges in the auto and electronics markets. The company expects pretax savings of up to $120 million annually. The move follows a tough year for 3M, marked by escalating trade disputes, headwinds in China, and declining demand in the automotive and electronics sectors. CEO Mike Roman anticipates a rebound in the market, while the company also reported a pretax charge of $134 million in the fourth quarter due to the job cuts.

site_title: TikTok rival Byte debuts at top of US app store
summary: Byte, a new video-sharing app, has debuted at the top of Apple's US App Store, competing with TikTok. Created by Dom Hofmann, Byte reboots the deprecated Vine service, which was sold to Twitter in 2012. The app is currently the No. 1 free iPhone app in the US and top free iOS app in Canada. It also ranks in the top 10 in several other countries. Byte is sixth among free apps in the US on Android's Play Store.

site_title: UK gives Huawei partial role in 5G network despite US push for total ban
summary: The UK has decided to allow Huawei to play a limited role in building its 5G mobile phone networks, despite US pressure for a total ban. Huawei will be kept out of most sensitive core parts but allowed to supply other critical gear, such as antennas and base stations. The decision will impose a cap of up to 35% on Huawei's radio access components and exclude the company from sensitive geographic locations. This compromise aims to balance access to cutting-edge technology with security concerns, as the UK seeks to maintain ties with the US and other allies.

site_title: Reflections on Singapore's 20-year corporate governance journey
summary: Singapore's 20-year corporate governance journey has seen mixed results. The first Corporate Governance Committee was established in 2000, releasing the first Code of Corporate Governance in 2001. Initially, the "comply or explain" approach was adopted, but it proved ineffective in enforcing high standards. The introduction of the second Code in 2005 marked a shift towards stricter regulations, including quarterly reporting and enhanced disclosure requirements. However, concerns about S-chips, excessive remuneration, and lack of accountability for independent directors remain. The 2012 Code raised the bar on board independence and introduced guidelines on clawbacks of remuneration, but progress has been slow.

images.alt_text: Future code revisions will likely continue the increasing focus on broader stakeholders' interests and ESG issues, to further promote their integration into corporate strategies and board decision-making.

site_title: Govt debunks fake news linking closure of Woodlands MRT to Wuhan virus
summary: The Singapore government has debunked fake news claiming the Woodlands MRT station was closed due to a suspected Wuhan coronavirus case. The Ministry of Transport stated the station was fully operational on January 28, 2020. Facebook was asked to carry a correction notice, and the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) was invoked for the second time in relation to the virus. The government urged people to report suspected falsehoods and to get updates through official channels.

site_title: Airbus agrees to settle bribery cases for about US$3b
summary: Airbus has agreed to settle bribery allegations in the US, UK, and France for approximately $3 billion, according to sources familiar with the matter. The settlement, which could be announced as soon as this week, involves the use of intermediaries to secure jet orders and is subject to court approval. The agreement comes as Airbus's main competitor, Boeing, is struggling with the grounding of its 737 Max aircraft following two deadly crashes. The settlement is expected to trigger one of the largest fines for corporate corruption in recent years, and shares in Airbus have jumped in response.

images.alt_text: Airbus agreed to settle allegations of bribery in three countries in a deal that will likely see the the European airplane manufacturer pay billion of dollars to move past an investigation that has shadowed it for four years.

site_title: Europe: Stocks firmer at open after heavy losses
summary: Europe's main equity markets opened firmer on Tuesday, rebounding from heavy losses the previous day due to investor panic over the deadly coronavirus. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.3%, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also increased 0.3% and 0.4% respectively. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: WHO chief says confident in China's ability to contain virus, urges calm
summary: WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus expressed confidence in China's ability to contain the new coronavirus outbreak, approving of the Chinese government's measures. He urged calm and did not advocate for the evacuation of foreign nationals in China. The death toll has climbed to 106 in China, with cases reported in multiple countries.

site_title: UK healthcare cost agency rejects J&J's nasal spray for depression
summary: The UK's National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) has rejected Johnson & Johnson's nasal spray, Spravato, for treating depression, citing uncertainties over its clinical and cost effectiveness. The agency questioned the treatment's long-term benefits and potential increased costs. NICE recommended against including Spravato in Britain's National Healthcare System (NHS).

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower for second day on virus fear
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower for the second day due to concerns over the widening coronavirus outbreak in China. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.55%, while the Topix index dropped 0.60%. This follows a similar decline on Monday. The downturn is attributed to investor fears about the potential economic impact of the virus.

site_title: France to ban systematic culling of male chicks: minister
summary: France is set to ban the systematic culling of male chicks in the poultry industry by the end of 2021, following a ban on the castration of piglets without anaesthetic also to be implemented within the same timeframe. The practice, which involves killing millions of male chicks each year due to their inability to produce eggs, is widely criticized by animal rights activists. Researchers have yet to develop an effective method to determine chick sex in eggs on an industrial scale, prompting the French government's move to phase out the practice.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares slump on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market plummeted on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 21.17 points to 1,551.64. The market saw 3.3 billion lots traded worth RM2.9 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 793 to 165.

site_title: New Zealand PM set to announce Sept 19 general election
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is set to announce a general election on September 19, according to a news conference scheduled for Tuesday. The next general election is due by November, with the last one held in September 2017.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Markets in Asia experienced volatility due to fears over the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus, with equities tumbling and stocks such as Sasseur Reit and Mapletree Logistics Trust declining. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) fell 1.8% as investors sought safety. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. In other news, Malaysia's agency plans to seize assets worth RM3 billion, and Citigroup has set a target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon down 2.49% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 2.49% on Tuesday, closing at 3,159.36, amid mounting fears over the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus. The index saw a sell-off in the morning, with losers outnumbering gainers 406 to 68. Key losers included Singtel, DBS, UOB, and OCBC. Other Asian markets also fell, contributing to the downturn.

site_title: Delta fined US$50,000 for discriminating against Muslim passengers
summary: Delta Air Lines has been fined $50,000 by the US Transportation Department for discriminating against three Muslim passengers who were cleared for flights but barred from boarding. The incidents occurred in 2016 and involved passengers from Paris to Cincinnati and Amsterdam to New York. The airline was ordered to provide civil rights training for flight crews and customer service representatives. Delta disputed the agency's findings, but a lawyer for the couple who filed the complaint said the fine was a step in the right direction to address discriminatory treatment of Muslim passengers.

site_title: Myanmar expects 5m tourists in 2020 despite virus fears
summary: Myanmar expects to attract 5 million tourists in 2020 despite concerns over the novel coronavirus, which has already affected Asia's top economy. The country has implemented measures to screen for the disease at international gateways. Last year, Myanmar received 4.4 million visitors, a 23% increase from 2018, with Chinese tourists making up a significant portion of the growth. The tourism industry supports over 1 million jobs and accounts for 7% of the economy, making it a crucial sector for the country. Officials are also working to overcome negative perceptions of the country due to human rights concerns.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit prices units at £0.68 or S$1.21 each
summary: Elite Commercial Reit launched its initial public offering, pricing units at £0.68 or S$1.21 each, with a forecast distribution yield of 7.1% for 2020 and 7.2% for 2022. The offering, which includes a retail tranche and cornerstone units, is expected to raise £130.9 million in gross proceeds.

site_title: Singapore's Shiok Meats hopes to hook diners with lab-grown shrimp
summary: Shiok Meats, a Singapore-based start-up, aims to become the first company to bring lab-grown shrimp to market. The company grows minced meat by extracting cells from shrimp and feeding them nutrients, resulting in a four- to six-week production process. Currently, a kilogram of lab-grown shrimp meat costs $5,000, but the company hopes to cut the cost to $50 per kilogram by the end of the year. Shiok aims to raise $5 million to fund a pilot plant and is backed by Monde Nissin Corp, which owns British meat substitute firm Quorn.

site_title: Wuhan virus death toll jumps to 106, nearly 1,300 new cases: Chinese government
summary: China reports a significant increase in the death toll from a coronavirus outbreak, with 106 fatalities and nearly 1,300 new cases confirmed, raising the total number of confirmed cases to over 4,000 nationwide.

site_title: Bolton revelations roil Trump trial, witness push grows
summary: Donald Trump's lawyers pushed back against allegations from former national security advisor John Bolton, saying his dealings with Ukraine were motivated by concerns about corruption, not political gain. Bolton's draft book alleges Trump withheld military aid to Ukraine in exchange for investigations into Joe Biden and his family. Republicans face pressure to subpoena Bolton as a witness, with some senators indicating they could support his testimony. The Senate trial is set to vote on whether to accept witnesses this week, with 67 senators needed to remove Trump from office.

site_title: New Payment Services Act comes into force
summary: The Payment Services Act (PS Act) in Singapore came into force on January 28, 2020, expanding the regulator's scope to include new payment services such as digital payment token services. The Act aims to enhance consumer protection and promote confidence in e-payments with a new, risk-focused regulatory structure. The Money-changing and Remittance Businesses Act and the Payment Systems (Oversight) Act will be repealed, and a payments regulatory evaluation programme has been initiated to support firms in their transition. The implementation follows a public consultation and Parliament's passage of the Act in January 2019.

images.alt_text: In line with the newly introduced Payment Services Act, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has initiated a payments regulatory evaluation programme to help payment services firms in their transition.

site_title: Michou, whose drag cabaret was the toast of Paris, dies at 88
summary: Michou, a flamboyant French drag performer and cabaret owner, died at 88 on Sunday after a pulmonary embolism. Born Michel Georges Alfred Catty in 1931, Michou was a fixture in Paris's nightlife scene, known for his iconic cabaret "Chez Michou" and colorful drag performances. He was a close friend of prominent politicians and celebrities, and was awarded the Legion of Honor by French President Jacques Chirac. Michou's legacy as a cultural icon and advocate for LGBTQ+ rights will be remembered, with his final wish to be shut down on the day of his passing, but his blue-tinted legacy will live on in Montmartre.

site_title: Wall Street venture-fund curbs to be eased in Volcker revamp: sources
summary: Regulators plan to ease restrictions on Wall Street banks investing in venture-capital funds under the Volcker Rule. The proposal, set to be voted on January 30, would allow lenders to take stakes in venture funds, easing restrictions imposed after the 2008 financial crisis. The changes aim to help banks invest in startups, boost economic growth, and align with the industry's practices. The overhaul is part of a broader revamp of the Volcker Rule, which regulators say has gone "way too far."

site_title: Swiss watch export growth slows to weakest pace in 3 years
summary: Swiss watch exports declined to the weakest pace in three years in 2019, growing 2.4% to 21.7 billion Swiss francs. Exports to Hong Kong dropped 11% due to store closures, while the coronavirus outbreak threatens to impact Chinese consumption. The industry faces a challenging year, with potential earnings reductions of up to 8% due to the outbreak. Shipments of lower-end timepieces have struggled, and luxury-goods companies like Swatch Group AG may be affected, with some analysts estimating a 20% drop in international travel during the Sars epidemic in 2003.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks post sharpest fall in 15 months as China virus spreads
summary: South Korea's stocks plummeted 3.09% on Tuesday, their sharpest one-day fall in 15 months, due to concerns over the economic impact of the new coronavirus outbreak in China. The KOSPI index fell 69.41 points to 2,176.72. Companies exposed to China, such as cosmetics makers, were heavily affected, while mask producers were the best performers. Foreign investors sold US$448.25 million worth of local stocks, marking their largest net sales since November 2019. The economic impact is expected to be more significant for South Korea due to its large trade volume with China.

site_title: Hyflux white knight Utico proposes changes to adviser fees' pot
summary: Utico, a white knight for Hyflux, proposes increasing the adviser fees pot from S$40 million to S$50 million if all advisers support the Hyflux scheme and restructuring agreement (RA). If advisers fail to support the scheme, the pot would decline to S$30 million. Utico's rescue package for Hyflux includes a S$400 million offer. The advisers will be treated separately if their efforts result in P&P votes. The proposal hinges on completing the scheme by April with the support of all advisers.

site_title: Banks tell Hong Kong staff to work at home after China visit
summary: Global banks Credit Suisse and UBS have instructed Hong Kong staff to work from home for two weeks if they've recently visited mainland China due to the coronavirus outbreak. Employees with fever or flu-like symptoms are required to stay home until cleared by a doctor. The measures aim to safeguard staff and clients. The Hong Kong government has also urged residents to stay home for 14 days and closed sports and cultural facilities.

site_title: GM to pour billions into hub for electric and self-driving cars
summary: General Motors is investing $2.2 billion in its Detroit-Hamtramck assembly plant, which will produce all-electric trucks and SUVs. The investment meets a promise made during last year's union negotiations, which spared the plant from closure. The plant, which employs over 2,200 people, will undergo upgrades and production is scheduled to begin in late 2021 on an all-electric pickup truck and the Cruise Origin, a self-driving taxi. The investment also includes an additional $800 million for supplier tooling and related projects, fulfilling a $3 billion commitment made during the union negotiations.

site_title: Facebook asks employees to put off non-essential travel to China
summary: Facebook has asked employees to suspend non-essential travel to mainland China due to the coronavirus outbreak, which has killed over 100 people and spread to more than 10 countries. Employees who had already traveled to China are being told to work from home as a precautionary measure. The company cited an "abundance of caution" in protecting employee health and safety.

site_title: Tuas South Link industrial site up for application: JTC
summary: JTC is accepting applications for a reserve list site at Tuas South Link 3, with a 20-year tenure, 0.45-hectare area, and a gross plot ratio of 1.4. The site is zoned "B2" for industrial purposes and has a minimum price of S$2.55 million. This is the second reserve list site under the 2020 industrial government land sales programme. Applications can be submitted at any time, and the site will be launched if a developer's bid price is acceptable to the government.

site_title: Foreigners prepare to flee as China virus toll tops 100
