summary: Singapore's factory output declined 0.7% year-on-year in December, moderating from a 8.9% fall in November. This marks the first decline in three months. The full-year industrial production fell 1.4% in 2019, according to the Singapore Economic Development Board. The result is below private-sector economists' estimates of a 0.6% fall, but comes as expectations of a bottoming-out in manufacturing in 2020 are considered.

images.alt_text: On a seasonally-adjusted monthly basis, manufacturing output rose 4.1% in December - the fastest month-on-month pace in five months.

site_title: Singapore biotech firm Veredus will have Wuhan virus test ready by Feb 1
summary: Singapore-based biotech firm Veredus Laboratories announced the development of a Wuhan virus test, expected to be commercially available by February 1. The VereCoV detection kit, a portable lab-on-chip application, can detect the Wuhan coronavirus, Sars, and Mers viruses with high specificity and sensitivity in about two hours. This will be one of the first commercially available kits to detect all three coronaviruses in a single test. The test will be available on February 1, ahead of the initially stated Q1.

site_title: Malaysia's lower voting age could benefit BN, PAS
summary: Malaysia's lowered voting age from 21 to 18 may benefit the country's two biggest Malay Muslim political parties, Barisan Nasional (BN) and Parti Islam Se Malaysia (PAS), in the next general election. According to a report by Dr. Cassey Lee, the increase in voter base, expected to reach 22.7 million voters by 2023, will favor BN and PAS, as bumiputera voters make up 72.8% of the new voters. This could lead to a decrease in safe parliamentary seats for all parties, increasing the incentive for cooperation between BN and PAS.

site_title: Australia mourns US firefighters as probe into plane crash begins
summary: Australia is mourning the deaths of three US firefighters who were killed in a plane crash while fighting a wildfire in remote bushland. The C-130 Hercules aircraft, operated by Coulson Aviation, crashed while dropping retardant, and an investigation has begun. Flags have been flown at half-mast in New South Wales state as a mark of respect. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau will provide a preliminary report in 30 days, while a US National Transportation Safety Board official plans to send an investigator to Australia. The incident brings the death toll from Australia's bushfire season to 32, including eight firefighters.

site_title: China building 1,000-bed hospital over the weekend to treat coronavirus
summary: China rapidly builds a 1,000-bed hospital in Wuhan to treat coronavirus victims, with construction expected to be completed by early next week. The hospital aims to alleviate the shortage of medical resources, inspired by Beijing's experience in 2003 with Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (Sars). The new facility will have prefabricated buildings and is being built to treat the growing number of cases, which have killed 25 people and infected over 800 in China.

site_title: Rich Capital gets new legal demand from Batam project partner
summary: Rich Capital has received a new legal letter from its project partner Karya Indo Batam (KIB), alleging unlawful conspiracy and breaches of duties in a property development project in Batam. The letter demands payment for loss and damage suffered by KIB, with the parties required to provide a written confirmation and agree to pay damages in the High Court of Singapore. This is the second such demand from KIB, following a previous letter sent in September 2019. Rich Capital has denied the allegations and is seeking legal advice to resist the claims.

site_title: Singapore shares up on Friday, drop 1.3% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,240.02 on Friday, gaining 5.46 points or 0.2% in a shortened session. The index lost 1.3% for the week, closing at 3,281.03 on January 17. Trading volume was 1.11 billion securities, with total turnover at S$760.13 million. StarHub's shares rose 0.6% to 79.5 cents after agreeing to a joint-bid for a 5G network licence, while Keppel Corp's parent company, M1, edged up 0.15% to S$6.75 after posting a 42% increase in Q4 earnings.

site_title: Singapore factory output down 0.7% in Dec, posts full-year fall of 1.4%
summary: Singapore's factory output declined 0.7% in December, posting a full-year fall of 1.4%, according to preliminary figures from the Singapore Economic Development Board. This was an improvement from November's 8.9% fall. Biomedical manufacturing output rose 10.3% in December, led by higher export demand for medical devices. However, precision engineering and electronics output were weak, with general manufacturing and transport engineering posting significant declines. Despite this, economists remain cautiously optimistic about manufacturing growth in 2020, expecting a 0.5% expansion.

site_title: Singapore schools ask for holiday travel details as China virus spreads
summary: Singapore schools are asking parents to provide details of travel plans during the lunar new year holidays due to the spread of a coronavirus in China. The first case in Singapore was confirmed, with another preliminary case reported. The Ministry of Education has instituted travel declarations for students and staff, with no planned trips to Hubei province or China in February. Schools may postpone trips in March if necessary to ensure safety and well-being.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks erase gains as China virus fears offset tech earnings hopes
summary: Japanese shares erased early gains on Friday, closing little changed, as fears over the new coronavirus in China outweighed hopes for technology company earnings. The Nikkei index edged down 0.01% to 23,792.01, heading for a 1% weekly drop. China reported 25 deaths and 830 confirmed cases, prompting concerns about travel and tourism spending. Investors turned cautious, with reports of more infections and deaths denting airline and consumer goods companies.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output fell 0.7% in December, posting a full-year decline of 1.4%. Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May, below forecast. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The UK economy shrank for the second month, while South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks. Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident his daughter will be cleared as Thailand's PM in an ethics case. Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Asean agrees Myanmar's election is not a priority.

site_title: Gold eases after WHO says China virus not a global emergency
summary: Gold prices eased on Friday after the World Health Organization (WHO) stopped short of declaring the China virus outbreak a global emergency, but were on track to post a weekly gain. Spot gold fell 0.2% to $1,560.50 per ounce, while US gold futures slipped 0.4%. The WHO's decision followed concerns about the virus's spread to several countries, including China's Lunar New Year celebrations, which could increase the risk of transmission. Investors now focus on the US Federal Reserve's meeting on January 28-29.

images.alt_text: Gold inched lower on Friday as investors opted for riskier assets after the World Health Organization (WHO) stopped short of declaring the China virus outbreak a global emergency, but the precious metal was on track to post a weekly gain.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat after week of virus jitters
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat in Friday's opening trade, stabilizing after a week of investor nerves over the China coronavirus outbreak. The Hang Seng index started the day at 27,902.84, down 0.02% or 6.28 points. Mainland Chinese bourses were closed for the Lunar New Year holiday, contributing to the market's stability.

site_title: Cirque du Soleil cancels shows in China over coronavirus
summary: Cirque du Soleil has cancelled its shows in Hangzhou, China due to concerns over a coronavirus outbreak in the country. Chinese officials requested the closure of indoor activities with 100 or more attendees to contain the outbreak. The company prioritizes people's health and safety, saying it will continue to lead in preventive efforts.

site_title: Saudi Arabia denies case of coronavirus infection
summary: Saudi Arabia's health ministry denied reports of a coronavirus infection, stating there were no cases in the kingdom. Earlier, an Indian nurse working in southwestern Saudi Arabia was reported to be infected with the virus, but this was later clarified as a case of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS). The Saudi government has taken precautionary measures, including screening passengers arriving from China, amid the global outbreak that has killed 25 people in China and infected over 630 worldwide.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS raises SGX's target price on index firm acquisition
summary: DBS Group Research has raised its target price for the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to S$9.60, up from S$8.90, citing the bourse operator's acquisition of smart beta index firm Scientific Beta as a growth driver. The acquisition is expected to broaden SGX's index offering and create opportunities for cross-selling. DBS also notes that SGX's strong demand for risk management instruments and its growth strategies will benefit its share price. However, competition in its derivatives business and potential earnings downside from the Hong Kong stock exchange's launch of futures contracts are key risks.

site_title: OEL obtains S$1.2m loan from controlling shareholder
summary: OEL Holdings Limited has secured a S$1.2 million interest-free loan from controlling shareholder Zhang Jian to repay existing loans and boost working capital. The loan is fully repayable in 399 days and is considered an interest person transaction, but the audit committee believes it is not prejudicial to the company's interests. This follows a 4.2% increase in OEL shares, trading at 2.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: How fashion uses greenwashing to hide its dirty secrets
summary: The Paris fashion fortnight highlighted the industry's greenwashing efforts, with designers using environmental warnings and rescue animal images to create a sustainable brand image. However, critics argue that these efforts are superficial and do not address the industry's significant environmental impact. The fashion industry's reliance on fast fashion and resource-intensive production methods continues to contribute to pollution, waste, and climate change, despite its greenwashing attempts.

images.alt_text: "Our Mother Earth will not be able to support life, we will not be able to breathe... If we don't open our hearts and our minds, it's the End," a disembodied voice intoned as hot Hollywood label Rhude made its Paris debut.

site_title: US to unveil crackdown on counterfeit, pirated e-commerce goods
summary: The US government plans to unveil efforts to crack down on counterfeit and pirated goods sold on major e-commerce sites, with officials set to discuss the initiative at a news conference on Friday. The administration aims to increase self-policing efforts by third-party sellers and increase penalties for those selling counterfeit goods. Enforcement agencies plan "immediate actions" to identify counterfeit goods, and the government seeks legal authority to seek injunctive relief against third-party marketplaces and intermediaries. The move follows a report estimating that global trade in counterfeit and pirated goods may reach $500 billion annually.

site_title: China virus toll jumps to 25 dead with 830 confirmed cases: government
summary: China's death toll from a viral outbreak has risen to 25, with 830 confirmed cases, according to the national health commission. Authorities are also examining 1,072 suspected cases. The outbreak has raised pressure on policymakers, with China's GDP growth expected to slow.

images.alt_text: The death toll in China's viral outbreak has risen to 25, with the number of confirmed cases also leaping to 830, the national health commission said on Friday.

site_title: Westpac economists now see RBA delaying rate cut to April
summary: Westpac economists now expect the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to delay interest rate cuts to April, rather than February, due to strong jobs data showing a nine-month low of 5.1% unemployment in December. This move follows a second month of upbeat jobs data and the RBA's emphasis on the labor market as a key policy driver. The RBA holds its next policy meeting on February 4.

images.alt_text: Analysts at Westpac Banking Corp now expect the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will cut interest rates in April, rather than February, following a second month of surprisingly upbeat jobs data.

site_title: ARA H-Trust sets up S$800m debt issuance programme
summary: ARA H-Trust sets up an S$800 million debt issuance programme, offering stapled notes and perpetual securities in Singapore. The net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes. OCBC has been appointed as the programme's arranger and initial dealer. Each series of notes or perps issued by ARA H-Trust's hotel arm will be stapled to a corresponding series issued by its property arm, requiring equal offerings at the same time.

site_title: US tells Thunberg to 'study economics' in Davos climate spat
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin told Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg to study economics before giving out lessons on climate change, sparking a heated exchange. Thunberg responded by saying it doesn't take a degree to understand the science, and called for an immediate halt to investments in fossil fuels. UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres warned that the world is losing the war against global warming, urging rapid action to prevent humanity's doom. German Chancellor Angela Merkel also emphasized the need for governments to act on climate change, while US President Donald Trump dismissed climate predictions as "apocalyptic."

site_title: Slowing contraction in Japan factory activity eases fears of recession: flash PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity contracted for a ninth straight month in January but at the slowest pace in five months, easing fears of a recession. The Jibun Bank Flash Japan Manufacturing PMI edged up to 49.3, below the 50.0 threshold for the ninth month. Output and new orders remained in contraction, but production pace eased, and new export orders expanded for the first time in 14 months. Separate data showed the services sector expanding at the quickest pace in four months, suggesting a domestic-led economic recovery.

site_title: Cloud cooking land: Indian housewives become gig economy chefs
summary: In India, a growing gig economy is transforming the way food is prepared and delivered, with housewives turning their homes into "cloud kitchens" to cater to time-starved millennials. Apps like Curryful and Homefoodi are tapping the skills of housewives to prepare meals, while companies like Swiggy and Rebel Foods are investing in cloud kitchens to meet the demand. The sector is expected to reach $1.05 billion by 2023, providing a new career opportunity for women who were previously limited by conservative families.

site_title: Grammys set to honour music's best, but scandal overshadows gala
summary: The Grammys, music's marquee night, are set to honor the best in music, but a scandal has overshadowed the gala. Deborah Dugan, the first female CEO of the Recording Academy, filed a discrimination complaint alleging sexual harassment, voting irregularities, and misconduct. The allegations include a claim that a former CEO raped a foreign female musician. Despite this, the ceremony features a diverse slate of nominees, including Lizzo, Billie Eilish, and Lil Nas X. The Grammys' efforts to reinvent itself and shed its out-of-touch image are being questioned, with some artists calling the awards irrelevant.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain amid China virus fears
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Friday, driven by financial sector gains, as investors sought defensive positions amid concerns over the coronavirus outbreak in China. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its third straight weekly gain, with financial stocks, including the "Big Four" banks, trading higher. However, commodity prices were weighed down by lower iron ore and steel prices, while healthcare stocks firmed. The World Health Organization declared the virus an emergency in China but stopped short of declaring an international epidemic.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose nearly half a per cent on Friday on the back of financials, while trading was cautious as fears mounted about the coronavirus outbreak in China and its potential economic fallout.

site_title: Euro near 7-week low after ECB holds rates steady; virus fears support yen
summary: The euro fell to a 7-week low of $1.1036 against the dollar after the European Central Bank (ECB) held interest rates steady and launched a policy review. The ECB's dovish stance was seen as a surprise, while concerns over China's coronavirus outbreak supported the safe-haven yen. The euro's decline was also influenced by ECB President Christine Lagarde's redefinition of the central bank's main goal.

site_title: Joey Yap, Feng Shui Master
summary: Malaysian Feng Shui master Joey Yap is renowned for his popular seminars and workshops, and has built a corporate entity that includes a consulting company. He aims to dispel the stereotype of Feng Shui as a dubious practice and has developed a syllabus for his Mastery Academy of Chinese Metaphysics, which incorporates Feng Shui, bazi, and qi men dun jia. With a focus on complex mathematical formulas, Yap seeks to educate clients on the practice, rather than fortune telling. As the founder of the academy, he commands a significant following and has established himself as a leading expert in the field.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by a calm session on Wall Street despite investor caution over a new deadly virus from China. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.25% to 23,854.82, while the Topix index gained 0.12% to 1,732.66. The gains followed a rally in US stocks, which edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: In Hong Kong, choosing restaurants has become a political act
summary: In Hong Kong, choosing restaurants has become a polarized act due to the ongoing unrest. A mobile app categorizes eateries as "yellow" (pro-democracy) or "blue" (pro-government), with over 1,300 yellow and 1,600 blue outlets listed. This politicization of restaurants is a strategy by the protest movement to force businesses and residents to take sides and pressure the government for more freedoms. The move aims to keep up the protest momentum, even if some shop owners pretend to be yellow to avoid boycotts.

site_title: PM Lee says Hong Kong's leaders must act on grievances
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Hong Kong's leaders must address protester grievances over affordable housing, which he believes is a "basic hygiene issue." Lee expressed sympathy for Hong Kong protesters but questioned their violent methods, saying they won't resolve problems. He warned that if Hong Kong authorities don't act on economic grievances, China's 50-year promise to guarantee Hong Kong separate freedoms under "one country, two systems" may not be sustainable. Lee urged the Hong Kong government to make progress on basic issues, or risk the system's long-term viability.

site_title: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon gets US$31.5m for bank's knockout year
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co awarded CEO Jamie Dimon a total compensation of US$31.5 million for 2019, a 1.6% increase after posting record profits for the second consecutive year. Dimon's pay package includes US$25 million in restricted stock, an annual base salary of US$1.5 million, and a US$5 million cash bonus. This marks the second year in a row JPMorgan notched the highest profit in US banking history, with US$36.4 billion in 2019. Dimon, 63, has been the best-paid of major US bank CEOs since 2016.

site_title: Japan confirms second coronavirus case
summary: Japan's health ministry confirmed its second coronavirus case, a 40-year-old man who traveled from Wuhan, China, and arrived in Japan on January 19. The man reported a fever upon arrival and is receiving treatment in a Tokyo hospital. He denied visiting the Wuhan market linked to the outbreak and wore a medical mask during travel. This case comes just over a week after Japan's first incidence of the new virus, which has killed 18 and infected hundreds worldwide. The World Health Organization has not declared a global health emergency.

site_title: WHO urges China to keep city lockdowns short
summary: The World Health Organization's head, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, urged China to keep city lockdowns short in duration to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. China has taken measures to contain the virus in Wuhan and other cities, and the WHO hopes these measures will be effective and short-lived.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Starhub, SGX, UOL, CDLHT, ARA H-Trust, Frasers Hospitality
summary: Key developments in Singapore stocks include: Keppel Corporation reporting 41.5% higher net earnings, Starhub and M1 announcing an exclusive pact to jointly bid for a 5G network licence, and Singapore Exchange (SGX) coughing up €280 million for a 93% stake in Scientific Beta. UOL Group entered into an agreement to buy a hotel in Jakarta, while CDL Hospitality Trusts and ARA US Hospitality Trust made announcements related to proposed hotel deals. Frasers Hospitality posted a first-quarter distribution per stapled security, and Koh Brothers Group reported a 29% rise in net profit.

site_title: Singapore confirms China visitor as 1st case
summary: Singapore confirmed its first case of the Wuhan virus, a 66-year-old Chinese national who arrived with nine companions on January 20, 2020. Another suspected case, a 53-year-old Chinese woman, is awaiting confirmation. The man's son and eight companions have left Singapore, while the ministry has expanded temperature screening at Changi Airport for all Chinese travelers. There is no evidence of the virus spreading in Singapore, but the country is preparing for potential cases, with a multi-ministry task force meeting to enhance border control and intensify screening.

site_title: US regulator fines ex-Wells Fargo CEO US$17.5m over fake accounts
summary: The US Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) fined former Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf $17.5 million for his role in the bank's fake accounts scandal, which occurred from 2002 to 2016. Stumpf was also banned from working in the banking industry for life. The scandal involved employees opening millions of unauthorized accounts, leading to a lifetime ban on former executives Carrie Tolstedt and Claudia Russ Anderson. The OCC also charged five other former officials, stating their failure to perform their duties contributed to the bank's systemic problems.

site_title: Soros pledges US$1b to battle 'would-be and actual dictators'
summary: US financier George Soros pledged $1 billion to the Open Society University Network to combat the erosion of civil society and climate change. He described a "revolutionary situation" where would-be and actual dictators rule, including President Donald Trump and China's Xi Jinping. Soros warned that the US economy may be overheated, and his concerns over Xi Jinping's authoritarian ambitions are growing, as the Chinese economy faces demographic challenges.

images.alt_text: US financier and philanthropist George Soros on Thursday pledged one billion dollars for a new university network project to battle the erosion of civil society in a world increasingly ruled by "would-be and actual dictators" and beset by climate change.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to companies: Hire at least one woman director if you want to go public
summary: Goldman Sachs will no longer take a company public unless it has at least one diverse board member, with a focus on women, starting June 30, 2020. The bank requires US and European companies to meet this standard, increasing to two diverse board members in June 2021. Companies with diverse boards have seen a 44% jump in average share price, compared to 13% for those without. Goldman aims to help clients meet this standard by introducing them to qualified candidates.

site_title: 'Doomsday Clock' closer to midnight than ever
summary: The Doomsday Clock, a symbol of global peril, has been set at 100 seconds to midnight, its closest point to catastrophe since its creation in 1947. The clock's warning is driven by climate change, nuclear proliferation, and emerging technologies like deepfakes and hypersonic missiles. Experts warn of catastrophic consequences if these threats are not addressed. The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, which sets the clock, emphasizes the need for world leaders to unite and act to prevent disaster.

site_title: Lian Beng plans to sell stake in asphalt premix maker for S$9.4m
summary: Lian Beng Group is selling its 40% stake in asphalt premix maker United E&P (UEP) for S$9.4 million. The construction firm decided the ownership is "not strategic" to its business, freeing up capital for better returns. The buyer, KKC Investment Holding, is beneficially owned by UEP's existing management. The sale price was determined based on UEP's unaudited financials as of November 2019. Lian Beng shares fell 0.5 cents or 0.9% following the announcement.

site_title: US pharma boss gets 5 years' jail for fueling opioid crisis
summary: John Kapoor, founder of US pharmaceutical company Insys, was sentenced to 5.5 years in prison for his role in fueling the opioid crisis, which has killed tens of thousands of Americans. Kapoor was convicted of an elaborate scheme that involved Insys paying doctors to prescribe its addictive painkiller Subsys to patients who didn't need it. Kapoor is the first pharmaceutical company owner to be imprisoned over the crisis.

site_title: Koh Bros Q4 net profit up 29% to S$2.4m
summary: Koh Brothers Group, a mainboard-listed construction player, reported a 29% increase in net profit to S$2.4 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2019. Revenue fell 25% to S$98 million due to lower recognition from the construction and building materials division. The group recommended a final cash dividend of 0.4 Singapore cent per share. Managing director Francis Koh emphasized the company's focus on advanced technologies and raised productivity to stay ahead of competition.

site_title: Trump 'flagrantly' abused power: impeachment trial
summary: US President Donald Trump's impeachment trial began with Democrats presenting evidence that he "flagrantly abused his power" to gain a political advantage. House impeachment managers argued that Trump's actions were a clear impeachable offense, contradicting Republican claims that he did nothing wrong in soliciting electoral help from Ukraine. The trial's prosecutors played videos of Trump's defenders stating that abuse of power is an impeachable offense, and Democrats are hoping to break Republican unity and sway voters before the trial concludes on Tuesday.

site_title: Sabana Reit posts Q4 DPU of 0.77 S cent
summary: Sabana Reit posted a Q4 DPU of 0.77 Singapore cents, a 8.5% increase from the same period last year, mainly due to the distribution of 5.5% of distributable income withheld during the third quarter. Net property income remained stable at S$13 million, while gross revenue slipped 2.9% to S$19.4 million.

site_title: Intel sees 2020 revenue above estimates as chip demand recovers
summary: Intel Corp. has forecasted full-year revenue and profit above analysts' estimates, driven by cloud computing demand and a recovery in chip demand. The company's data center business saw a 19% increase in sales, and cloud computing sales jumped 48% year-over-year. Intel's shares rose 7% in extended trading, and the company expects fiscal year 2020 revenue of around $73.5 billion, beating analysts' average estimate. The company's transition to newer chipmaking technology is progressing better than expected, and it expects to start building inventory at the end of the year.

site_title: Europe: Fears over China coronavirus wallop shares
summary: European shares fell for a fourth consecutive session, dropping 0.7% due to concerns over the spread of a new coronavirus in China, with mining stocks, airlines, and luxury goods makers posting significant losses. The outbreak has killed 18 people and infected over 630, prompting lockdowns in two Chinese cities. Analysts question the virus's long-term economic impact, citing a quick market bounce-back after the Sars epidemic in 2003.

site_title: Some in Bank of Japan warned of soft inflation expectations: Dec meeting minutes
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers expressed concerns about soft inflation expectations following the sales tax hike in October, according to the central bank's December meeting minutes. One board member warned that the BOJ might need to increase stimulus if private consumption is negatively affected. Despite keeping monetary policy steady, Governor Haruhiko Kuroda noted that risks to Japan's economic recovery remain high.

site_title: China locks down two cities at epicentre of virus outbreak
summary: China has locked down two cities at the epicentre of a new coronavirus outbreak, killing 17 people and infecting nearly 600, amid fears of a global pandemic. Health authorities are concerned about the transmission rate accelerating with millions of Chinese traveling during the week-long Chinese New Year holidays.

site_title: Showroom SPA
summary: The Kohler Experience Centre in Singapore now offers an interactive space where customers can test out the company's bath and shower products, including a multi-sensory DTV showering system and a bubble massage bath. The Experiential Spa allows customers to customize their shower experience with lighting, music, and water temperature, creating a unique massage-like experience. The centre is located at 52/56 Peck Seah Street and can be booked in advance by calling 6224 0039. This interactive experience aims to engage customers and provide a memorable experience, potentially leading to increased sales.

site_title: Czech tycoon's CPI Property sells S$150m perp in market first
summary: CPI Property Group, a Luxembourg-based real estate player, has made its debut in the Singapore dollar corporate hybrid bond market, selling S$150 million of perpetual bonds at par with a 5.8% coupon. The bonds, issued on January 17, offer a 5% step-up upon a change of control event and staggered step-ups every five years. The proceeds will fund CPI's acquisition pipeline, including the acquisition of over 900 million euros worth of office properties in central Warsaw in Poland. This marks the first time a European non-bank issuer has tapped the SGD corporate hybrids market.

site_title: ESR-Reit DPU for Q4 slips 0.5% to S$0.01
summary: ESR-Reit reported a 0.5% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01 for the fourth quarter, but saw higher gross revenue and net property income. The real estate investment trust (Reit) attributed the decline to a one-time adjustment, while citing contributions from recent acquisitions and asset enhancements. Despite this, the Reit's full-year DPU rose 4% to 4.011 Singapore cents, and total income available for distribution surged 78% to S$132.6 million. CEO Adrian Chui expressed openness to mergers to strengthen the portfolio and diversify risks.

site_title: US: Nasdaq edges to record as investors monitor China virus
summary: US stocks ended mostly higher on Thursday, with the Nasdaq edging to a fresh record despite concerns over the coronavirus in China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1%, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.1%. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.2% and surpassed its January 17 record by 14 points. Companies like Procter & Gamble, Comcast, and Netflix reported mixed results, with Comcast and Netflix experiencing significant gains. The World Health Organization's decision not to declare a public health emergency helped shift sentiment.

site_title: TikTok inks music deal as it sets up shop in California
summary: TikTok has signed a music licensing deal with Merlin, a digital rights agency for independent music labels, to promote its short-form video service. The deal allows Merlin members to build new revenue streams on TikTok. The partnership comes as TikTok opens an office in Los Angeles to advance its US ambitions. The social network, launched by ByteDance in 2017, has become one of the most popular social networks worldwide, with over 1.5 billion downloads. The deal follows recent scrutiny over TikTok's content curation.

site_title: Waymo self-driving minivans take to more US roads
summary: Waymo, Alphabet's self-driving vehicle unit, is expanding its testing to more US regions, including Texas and New Mexico, to explore new transportation solutions. The company will use its Waymo Chrysler Pacifica minivans and long-haul trucks to test autonomous ride services on commercial routes. This move builds on the company's existing project in Arizona and follows similar efforts by other companies, including Uber, General Motors' Cruise, and Tesla. The goal is to create safer, cost-effective, and more accessible transportation options.

site_title: Oil falls 2% as specter of China virus threatens fuel demand
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Thursday as concerns over the spread of a virus from China threatened to lower fuel demand, but losses were limited by a drawdown in US crude inventories. Brent crude futures dropped 1.9% to $62.04 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 2% to $55.59 a barrel. The potential for a pandemic has stirred memories of the 2002-03 Sars outbreak, with some estimating a price shock of up to $5 a barrel if the crisis develops into an epidemic.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell 2 per cent on Thursday on concern that the spread of a virus from China could lower fuel demand if it stunts economic growth, but losses were limited by a drawdown in US crude inventories.

site_title: Money FM podcast: HBO Invisible Stories
summary: There is no article content provided, only links to various articles on different topics.

site_title: US investigating second suspected case of Chinese virus
summary: US authorities are investigating a second suspected case of the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) on US soil, a college student from Texas who recently returned from Wuhan, China. The patient, believed to be between 20 and 30 years old, had mild upper respiratory symptoms and is being kept isolated at home while testing is performed. If confirmed, this would be the second case in the US, following a man in his 30s near Seattle who reported himself to authorities on January 19.

images.alt_text: Authorities in Texas are investigating a second suspected case on US soil of a deadly Chinese virus, namely a college student who had recently returned from the city at the heart of the outbreak, officials said Thursday.

site_title: Citizen labour trends track those of residents: MOM
summary: Singapore's labour statistics for citizens and permanent residents (PRs) closely track each other, with an average 3.1% unemployment rate for citizens and 3.3% for residents from 2010 to 2019. Citizens' employment outcomes have been positive, with rising employment rates and faster income growth. The proportion of professionals and managers among the employed has also risen similarly in both groups. The median gross monthly income has grown for both citizens and residents, but retrenchment incidence was higher among residents.

site_title: 'Sopranos' actress Sciorra tells Weinstein trial: 'He raped me'
summary: Actress Annabella Sciorra testified in Harvey Weinstein's trial, recounting how he raped her in her New York apartment in the early 1990s. Sciorra described the attack as traumatic, leading to self-harm and withdrawal, and she only came forward with her allegations in 2017. She claimed Weinstein, who denies all allegations, held her down and performed oral sex on her after a business dinner. Sciorra's testimony supports the prosecution's case that Weinstein is a career sexual predator, and her allegations are too old to be included on the charge sheet but could be used to prove predatory sexual assault.

site_title: AMTD, Xiaomi to create fintech programme with SMU and NUS
summary: AMTD Group, Xiaomi Finance, Singapore Management University (SMU), and the National University of Singapore (NUS) have partnered to create a two-week fintech training program for entrepreneurs, executives, and policymakers. The Singapore Digital Finance Leadership Programme aims to develop digital finance leaders in Singapore, Asean, and the Greater Bay Area. The program, running annually, will be designed by AMTD, Xiaomi Finance, SMU, and NUS, and will be supported by a S$5 million investment. The program will be conducted at various locations and will feature guest speakers from industry, regulators, and academics.

site_title: In Praise Of Friendship
summary: Danez Smith, a prominent young African-American poet, has released a new collection of poems titled "Homie". The collection, which celebrates the power of friendship, was inspired by Smith's experiences with violence and bigotry in the US. The poems are described as radical and powerful, and are available in bookstores. Smith's spoken word performance at the Singapore Writers Festival was met with an emotional response from the audience, highlighting the impact of their words and emotions.

site_title: Chinese Folklore
summary: Singapore theatre company Toy Factory Productions adapts the classic Chinese folklore "The 7 Sages of the Bamboo Grove" to a dystopian future, where an omniscient Organisation polices every human being. Seven artists, led by Sharon Au and Nelson Chia, resist the Organisation's suppression of free speech and artistic expression, attempting to overthrow it and change the future. The production runs at the Esplanade Theatre on Jan 31 and Feb 1 at 8pm.

site_title: Wuhan virus so far does not appear to be as deadly as Sars: PM
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has urged Singaporeans to remain calm but vigilant as authorities implement measures to combat the Wuhan virus, which has been confirmed in the country. Lee noted that the virus, while serious, does not appear as deadly as SARS, and the government is well-prepared to handle the situation. He also highlighted the importance of family support, calling on young couples to start families, and encouraged Singaporeans to reach out to those in need during tough times.

site_title: Go For Gold
summary: Far East Flora is offering limited edition table gardens for Chinese New Year, including the Golden Rat of Fortune, featuring a gold rat figure amidst festive plants. These hardy, long-lasting plants require minimal care and can last through the 15-day celebration. Available from S$78 at 555 Thomson Road, the nursery is open till after midnight on the eve of Chinese New Year.

site_title: ECB launches 'strategic review', leaves policy unchanged
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) launched a strategic review of its inflation goal and tools, but left monetary policy unchanged. ECB President Christine Lagarde stated that monetary policy must remain highly accommodative to support underlying inflation pressures and headline inflation developments over the medium-term.

images.alt_text: ECB President Christine Lagarde said risks to the eurozone economy had become "less pronounced" in the wake of a US-China trade truce.

site_title: Airlines scour the world for scarce Boeing 737 MAX simulators
summary: Airlines are scrambling to book time in limited 737 MAX simulators as Boeing recommends pilots undergo training in one of the few simulators replicating the latest model. The estimated 34 simulators in service are less than a quarter of the number of older 737 NG simulators. Airlines are facing challenges in booking slots, with some carriers expecting delays and others selling unused simulator time to other airlines. Boeing expects to win approval for returning the 737 MAX to service in mid-year, but regulators are working on new pilot training requirements, leading to delays.

images.alt_text: Airlines are scrambling to book time in 737 MAX training facilities as far afield as Fiji, Iceland and Panama, operators said, after Boeing Co recommended pilots be trained in one of the few simulators replicating the latest model.

site_title: A new phase of diplomacy beckons
summary: The UK is set to withdraw from the EU next week, marking a new phase in Brexit negotiations. The UK government has made final preparations for departure, but this is not the endgame of Brexit, as negotiations will see an increase in UK-EU activity on a broader range of topics, including transport, fisheries, and financial services. The EU's resolve on Brexit reflects concerns about the UK's divisions and the potential existential threat to the EU. A UK withdrawal agreement is now agreed, prompting the EU to think more "out of the box" and consider greater flexibility in its approach to Brexit.

site_title: A Minimalist Touch
summary: Entrepreneur Rachel Tan, founder of Urban Li'l, has adopted a minimalist approach to decorating her home for Chinese New Year. Her design philosophy emphasizes aesthetics and functionality, with a focus on subtle, understated elements such as laser-cut ornaments and a customized wooden plaque. The decor is mostly confined to the living room, with a pink pussy willow wreath and a decal with blessings for the year ahead. Tan credits her online store's convenience and her team's creativity in producing unique, customized items that cater to modern homeowners.

site_title: Trump's backward march on trade
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade policies have led to a disastrous outcome, damaging global trade and economic growth. The administration's abandonment of the multilateral trading system has resulted in trade wars with major partners, including Canada, Mexico, China, and the European Union. Tariffs imposed on steel and aluminum hurt US allies, while the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement has tightened regulations on imports. The trade war with China has undercut global trade and strained bilateral relations. The US has also imposed tariffs on numerous other countries, including India, and deployed economic sanctions. The refusal to allow new appointments to the WTO's Appellate Body has rendered the global trading system ineffective, ultimately making the US the big loser.

site_title: Check out this lean machine
summary: The Swiss Quadro Qooder is a unique, four-wheeled scooter with a 399cc engine that offers a comfortable and stable ride. It has a distinctive design, with a plump saddle and storage space, and can reach speeds of up to 135km/h. The Qooder's four-wheel setup provides stability and grip, making it less likely to skitter across the road. However, it requires a motorcycle license and has limitations, such as a slow engine and high fuel consumption. Despite its high price tag, the Qooder is considered a safe and enjoyable ride, with a unique feel that masks some of its speed.

site_title: Prices, rents of industrial space stable in 2019; new supply to rise significantly this year: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial property market saw stable prices and rents in 2019, despite headwinds, with an occupancy rate of 89.2%. However, 2020 will bring a significant increase in new supply, with around 2.2 million sq m coming onstream, potentially affecting certain segments. Analysts expect overall factory rents to remain muted, while warehouse rents are expected to be more resilient. Demand prospects will remain mixed, with industrial developments catering to new economy firms and higher-value-added industries likely to outperform the market.

site_title: Bangkok steps up its fight against plastic trash
summary: Bangkok aims to eliminate single-use plastic bags, straws, and cups by 2021, 2022, and 2027, respectively. The Thai government has signed up big retailers like 7-Eleven to stop handing out plastic bags, but street vendors face challenges in finding alternatives. Entrepreneurs are developing biodegradable packaging solutions, such as microwavable containers made from bagasse and plates from palm leaves. The government is studying laws from other countries to determine effective measures to enforce the ban and has seen a shift in public sentiment, with many feeling ashamed to use plastic.

site_title: Allied Tech CEO, CFO to assist in CAD probe
summary: Allied Technologies' CEO Clement Leow Wee Kia and CFO Ong Lizhen will assist the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) in its investigation into the company's missing funds and related matters. The company has cooperated fully with the probe and will provide updates to shareholders. Meanwhile, JLC managing partner Jeffrey Ong has been charged with 26 counts, including a serious breach of trust offence, unrelated to Allied Tech's funds. The company reported a Q3 net profit of S$537,000, despite a decline in gross profit margin and a net loss for the nine months ended September 30.

site_title: Home-Fix gets High Court nod for debt restructuring
summary: Home-Fix, a Singaporean home-improvement retail company, has received a High Court nod for debt restructuring after facing financial woes, leading to the closure of its retail stores. The company will undergo restructuring for six months, with the goal of reviving its business or achieving better asset realization. With S$19.8 million in liabilities, Home-Fix aims to provide better returns to creditors than liquidation, which would result in only five cents on the dollar. The company remains in talks with potential investors and plans to transform its operations.

site_title: Altis still raises the bar on all fronts
summary: The Toyota Corolla Altis sedan has returned with a significantly improved experience, recalibrating expectations of mainstream cars. The new model features a sporty design, improved ergonomics, and a smooth driving experience. It also boasts advanced safety features, including adaptive cruise control and lane departure warning systems. Powered by a 1.6-litre engine, the Corolla Altis achieves a top speed of 190km/h and has a fuel efficiency of 6.4L/100km. The new platform, Toyota New Generation Architecture (TNGA), enhances handling and stability, making it a more enjoyable and safe drive.

images.alt_text: Above: The new model is the same size as before (give or take a few millimetres) and has the same 1.6-litre engine, but everything else is new.
Above: The enlarged driver's digital display is clear and useful, and backed by comprehensive steering wheel controls.

site_title: Frasers Property buying London office buildings for £135m
summary: Frasers Property is acquiring the entire stake in Bedfont Lakes, a London business park with three office buildings, for £135m. The acquisition is funded from internal resources and will be completed in cash. This deal marks a significant investment by Frasers Property in the London market, further expanding its presence in the region.

site_title: Why startups need to tread carefully with data
summary: Startups struggle to protect customer data from bad actors, posing a significant threat to their business. With the increasing reliance on digital economy, startups must tread carefully to avoid data breaches. Industry expert Jean Marc Chery emphasizes the importance of data protection for startups.

site_title: Keppel Corp Q4 net profit up on better showing from most divisions
summary: Keppel Corporation reported a 41.5% increase in net earnings to S$191.4 million for the fourth quarter, driven by stronger performance from its offshore and marine, property, and investments divisions. Narrower losses at the offshore and marine business, marginally better showing by the property division, and returning to profitability at the investments segment contributed to the higher earnings.

site_title: Two camps on China-US ties: Engagement Plus vs a new cold war
summary: The US-China relationship is at a crossroads, with two camps emerging: "Engagement Plus" and a new cold war. The Phase One trade pact between the two nations is seen as a temporary pause in an ongoing economic war, rather than a lasting resolution. Washington is divided between those who want to gradually address disagreements and those who view China as a clear threat, similar to the Soviet Union during the Cold War. President Trump will face pressure from these two camps, setting the agenda for US policy towards China, regardless of who is in power.

site_title: Trump on trial - more than an 'ouch' for the president
summary: US President Donald Trump is on trial in the Senate after being impeached by the House of Representatives. The trial, which began on Tuesday, will be a legal and political undertaking as senators must consider their party interests and the Constitution's checks and balances. With the Republicans controlling the Senate, conviction is unlikely, and the outcome will reflect the balance of power between parties. Moderate Republican senators, including Mitt Romney, may be swayed by public opinion polls, while a televised trial could produce surprises, including new witnesses or documents that could strengthen the case against Trump.

site_title: Office rental cycle has peaked; retail rents may have bottomed out
summary: Singapore's office rental cycle has peaked, with a 3.2% quarter-on-quarter decline in the central region in Q4 2019, the largest drop since 2017. In contrast, retail rents have shown signs of stabilization, with a 2.3% quarter-on-quarter increase in Q4 2019. The uptick in retail rents is mainly driven by the prime Orchard Road shopping belt, where median rents rose 3.9% quarter-on-quarter. Analysts project a mixed outlook on the retail rental market, with some expecting modest growth while others predict a subdued recovery.

images.alt_text: It seems a tale of two cities between Singapore's office and rental markets, going by the latest data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA).

site_title: StarHub, M1 join forces to vie for Singapore 5G network licence
summary: StarHub and M1, two major telcos in Singapore, have formed an exclusive pact to jointly bid for a 5G network licence, with observers predicting they will compete for a nationwide network licence. The move is seen as a rational step to share capital expenditure and costs, and could help them target the enterprise segment. Industry analysts welcome the collaboration, but note that a shared network may lead to capacity constraints compared to a standalone network held by Singtel, which is also expected to bid for the licence.

site_title: Back in Time
summary: Luxury watch brands Omega, Longines, Richard Mille, Vacheron Constantin, and Corum have released new timepieces inspired by their heritage and past models. Omega introduced the stainless steel version of its Speedmaster Moonwatch 321, priced at S$19,500, while Longines reissued its 1946 Heritage Classic Chronograph. Richard Mille reworked its RM33-02 watch with a sporty vibe and limited to 140 pieces, priced at S$193,200. Vacheron Constantin unveiled a scaled-down Patrimony Self-Winding for women, priced at S$35,400. Corum's Heritage Lab 01l features a barrel-shaped case made of Damascus steel, priced at S$22,600.

site_title: HDB resale volume and prices inch up in Q4 2019
summary: In Q4 2019, HDB resale flats in Singapore saw 6,339 transactions, a 12.5% increase from the same period in 2018, and a 2.7% increase from the previous year. Resale prices rose by 0.5% from the previous quarter, making them 0.1% higher than the previous year. This marks a surprising turnaround after prices dipped for 11 consecutive quarters since 2016. The HDB approved 12,079 applications to rent out flats, up 0.6% from the previous quarter.

site_title: Heavy Metal
summary: Luxury watch brands such as H Moser & Cie, A Lange & Sohne, Chopard, and Bell & Ross are launching new stainless steel timepieces with integrated bracelets, following California's ban on the sale of goods made from crocodile and alligator skin. The watches, which range from $17,200 to $60,700, feature unique designs and materials, including Moser's Streamliner Flyback Chronograph Automatic and A Lange & Sohne's Odysseus. The new line aims to cater to the growing demand for steel sports watches with bracelets, offering a more sustainable alternative to traditional leather straps.

site_title: Black Marble offers some suburban shine
summary: Black Marble, a mid-scale restaurant in Singapore, offers a pleasant dining experience with a pleasant atmosphere and comfortable bistro-like interior. The menu features a short selection of appetizers, chef signature dishes, grilled meats, and seafood. Service can be skittish, but dishes such as oysters, black truffle mushroom emulsion, and spicy seafood capellini are highly praised. However, the burnt banana waffle is a disappointment. With prices ranging from S$8 to S$90, Black Marble is not cheap, but the food comes quickly and is of good quality, earning a rating of 6.5.

site_title: Joey Yap, Chinese Metaphysics Consultant & Academy Founder
summary: Malaysian Feng Shui consultant Joey Yap dispels misconceptions about the practice, emphasizing its scientific aspect. He explains that Feng Shui is a tool to align energy vibrations with goals, improving optimism and happiness. Yap stresses that luck is not inherent, but rather a result of one's energy level and emotions. Despite building a successful business, he acknowledges that he and others can fail, and that Feng Shui is not a guarantee of success. Yap hopes to make Chinese metaphysics more mainstream and sees increasing acceptance from big corporations, with notable successes in consulting with Citibank and Microsoft.

site_title: More than hope needed to build a sustainable future
summary: Sustainability efforts are crucial to mitigate climate change's impact on Southeast Asia, where the region's GDP is projected to be reduced by 11% by the end of the century if left unaddressed. The UN's Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) provide a roadmap to achieving sustainable development by 2030, recognizing the interconnected nature of environmental and socio-economic issues. Governments, businesses, and citizens must work together to address these complex issues, with a focus on education and concrete plans to bring about tangible change, as a mere intention is not enough to create a sustainable future.

site_title: Yen jumps, yuan sags on Wuhan virus fears
summary: The Japanese yen strengthened to 109.57 against the US dollar, its strongest since January 13, while China's yuan fell to a two-week low due to growing concerns about the spread of the Wuhan virus. The virus has infected almost 600 people and killed 17, prompting China to lock down the city of Wuhan. Investors are worried that the virus could hurt China's domestic demand, leading to a risk-off mode in the FX market, with the euro and dollar remaining relatively calm ahead of the European Central Bank meeting.

site_title: From Trash to Treasure
summary: Entrepreneurs are upcycling plastic waste into high-end products, such as swimwear, reducing ocean pollution. August Society's founder, Toni Chan, uses recycled plastic from ghost fishing nets, carpeting, and plastic bottles to create sustainable swimwear. The brand's use of nylon from ghost fishing nets and polyester from recycled plastic bottles aims to minimize ocean pollution and promote a zero-waste future. By incorporating recycled materials into their products, August Society is making a positive impact on the environment and setting an example for the fashion industry to follow.

site_title: Japan exports shrink for 13th month in further blow to economy
summary: Japan's exports fell 6.3% year-on-year in December for a 13th straight month, worse than expected, due to weak US-bound shipments. Analysts expect a preliminary trade deal between the US and China and progress on Brexit to ease trade concerns, but a modest slowing in contraction suggests a recovery may be months away. Exports to China grew 0.8% year-on-year, while shipments to the US fell 14.9% and to Asia decreased 3.6%. The Bank of Japan maintains its stimulus, citing solid domestic demand.

site_title: SGX invests 186m euros in index firm; Q2 net profit up 3%
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has invested 186 million euros (S$280 million) in Scientific Beta Pte Ltd, a smart beta index firm, to strengthen its research-based index design capabilities and broaden its index products. The investment is expected to be earnings-per-share accretive from FY2021. SGX's Q2 net profit rose 3% to S$99 million, driven by higher revenue from its data, connectivity, and indices (DCI) business, which accounts for 12% of total revenues. The exchange also plans to welcome more initial public offerings (IPOs) in the next six months.

site_title: Global Invacom - much promise, but not yet 'ready to launch'
summary: Global Invacom, a Singapore-listed satellite communications equipment provider, has yet to meet the minimum trading price (MTP) rule of 20 Singapore cents, putting it at risk of being delisted from the Singapore Exchange. The company has been trying to pull itself out of the watch list since 2018 with a reverse takeover deal, but it was abandoned in April 2019. Despite its outperformance last year, Global Invacom expects to record a net loss in FY2019 due to one-off charges related to the closure of its Shanghai facility. The company is relocating to the Philippines and expects robust demand for DOS products amid the growing need for low-orbit internet services.

site_title: Cable Goodies
summary: StarHub Entertainment is offering a free preview of over 100 channels from Jan 24-28, including Hub VV Drama, FOX Movies, BBC Earth, and beIN Sports. Highlights include Guy Ritchie's Aladdin, Shazam!, Stephen Chow's The King of Comedy, MasterChef Australia Season 11, and the 62nd Annual Grammy Awards. Viewers can access these channels via the StarHub Go streaming app.

site_title: Doing business the Disney way
summary: Bob Iger, former CEO of Disney, shares his approach to managing creative enterprises in a web series. Iger recalls his experience with the TV series Cop Rock, which he greenlit in the late 1980s despite its unusual concept of cops in song and dance. The show was a critical and commercial failure, but Iger saw it as a necessary risk, rather than a failure. He emphasizes the importance of taking calculated risks in a creative industry, rather than relying on tried-and-tested formulas. This approach is reflective of Iger's management style at Disney.

site_title: A better world through better business
summary: Business leaders can create long-term value by taking four key actions: engaging employees, measuring and reporting long-term value, engaging the business community, and supporting communities and protecting the environment. By empowering employees with re-training programs, shifting focus from short-term financial performance to long-term value creation, and collaborating with other companies and stakeholders, leaders can drive sustainable growth and create a more inclusive future. This shift in focus is crucial to addressing societal challenges such as unemployment and climate change.

site_title: 2019 core inflation comes in at 1%; MAS likely to stand pat in April review
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is likely to maintain its monetary policy stance in April, as core inflation rose to 1% for the year, slightly above the forecast of 0.5-1.5%. Headline inflation also increased to 0.8% in 2019, its highest level since May. Analysts attribute the uptick to a faster increase in private road transport and services prices. The MAS will monitor the resilience of the services sector and growth recovery before making a decision.

images.alt_text: Singapore's central bank will probably leave monetary policy untouched at its next review in April, analysts said on Thursday, as the latest data showed inflation picking up again in the final stretch of 2019.

site_title: Virus fears continue to unsettle investors
summary: Wall Street experienced a positive showing on Wednesday due to strong US corporate earnings, but regional markets in Asia failed to follow suit. Investors remain concerned about the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus, drawing parallels to the 2003 Sars epidemic. Asian markets, including Singapore's Straits Times Index, fell 1.5% on Thursday, with trading volume reaching 2.19 billion securities. The proposed merger of CapitaLand Commercial Trust and CapitaLand Mall Trust to form the largest Reit in Singapore received positive reactions from analysts, who see the combined entity as having greater financial capacity and competitiveness.

site_title: Temasek, EQT to invest US$500m in India renewable energy projects
summary: Temasek Holdings and EQT are investing US$500 million in India's renewable energy projects, aiming for over 4 gigawatts of installed capacity through solar and wind projects.

images.alt_text: Singapore state investment firm Temasek Holdings and Sweden-based asset manager EQT will invest a total of US$500 million to develop utility-scale renewable projects in India, both companies said on Wednesday.

site_title: Data matters, but trust determines value, says new study
summary: A new study by the IBM Institute for Business Value and Oxford Economics finds that data alone is no longer a unique asset, but rather trust determines its value. The study of 13,484 C-suite executives from 98 countries reveals that trust in data has passed its tipping point, and organizations must rebuild trust to unlock the full potential of data. The study categorizes executives into four stages: Torchbearers, Explorers, Builders, and Aspirationals, with Torchbearers demonstrating a strong culture of data believers and a willingness to share data across partner networks.

site_title: On the dining trail in Fukuoka
summary: Fukuoka, Japan, is a compact city with a unique culinary culture, offering a laid-back charm and a vibrant food scene. The city's proximity to China and Korea makes it a regional hub, and its high quality-of-life surveys rank it among the best cities in the world. Fukuoka's famous yatai (open-air food stands) serve affordable and delicious options, such as yakitori, oden, and udon, while also featuring local specialties like mizutaki and umegae mochi. The city's culinary appeal is attributed to its access to fresh produce at a low cost, making good meals affordable for all levels.

site_title: Indian housewives become gig economy chefs
summary: In India, a growing number of housewives are turning their homes into "cloud kitchens" to cater to time-starved millennials through gig economy apps like Curryful and Homefoodi. These women, often with decades of cooking experience, prepare meals for hungry urbanites while earning up to $150 a month. The cloud kitchen sector is expected to reach $1.05 billion by 2023, offering a new opportunity for women to break into the workforce.

site_title: Australian dollar cheers jobs data, New Zealand dollar holds steady
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.5% to US$0.6879 after data showed the country's unemployment rate fell to a nine-month low of 5.1% in December, reducing market expectations of a February interest rate cut. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) may still consider cutting interest rates due to wage growth not meeting its inflation target, but labor market spare capacity is diminishing. The New Zealand dollar remained steady at US$0.6590, despite concerns about the spread of a flu-like coronavirus in China.

site_title: Award-Winning Cinema
summary: The Projector in Singapore is screening award-winning films, including "The Garden of Evening Mists" (nominated for nine Golden Horse Awards) and the uncut NC16 version of "Knives Out". The drama "The Lighthouse" by Robert Eggers is also playing exclusively. The Projector offers a unique alternative to mainstream Chinese New Year blockbusters, showcasing under-the-radar gems. For screening times, visit www.theprojector.sg.

site_title: Shareholders of Alita Resources seek answers amid 'forced takeover'
summary: Shareholders of Singapore-listed lithium miner Alita Resources are fighting a "forced takeover" by a Chinese entity acquiring the company's assets. The company had been insolvent since June 2019, with significant losses and negative cash flow. Alita's board of directors resigned after appointing administrators, who are now investigating a potential breach of disclosure requirements. Shareholders are opposing a court application to transfer shares to a related entity of the Chinese party, citing potential for future reserve upgrades and extension of mine-life. Around 100 shareholders have banded together to oppose the takeover, with some citing concerns over the company's management and governance.

site_title: Singapore Art Week 2020: Its best yet
summary: Singapore Art Week 2020, its 8th edition, was the most confident yet, featuring over 100 art events and showcasing bold and provocative art. Despite losing its anchor art fair Art Stage, the week saw strong shows and a willingness to present challenging art to the public. The exhibition "De:voted" explored the complexities of modern life, while the National Archives of Singapore featured a large exhibition on the history of performance art. However, buying activity remained modest, with a limited number of galleries participating in SEA Focus, a commercial platform. The local art market continues to struggle, with the global art market experiencing growth and new millennial collectors entering the scene.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on virus scare, mixed earnings
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday due to rising concerns over the coronavirus outbreak in China, prompting a lockdown of two cities. The Dow Jones fell 0.26%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.18%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.06%. A mixed bag of earnings results also contributed to the dour sentiment.

site_title: Baker Boy
summary: Tiong Bahru Bakery has rebranded its two outlets in Raffles City and Funan as Tiong Bahru Bakery Diner, introducing an all-day dining concept led by new chef de cuisine Paul Albert. The menu features healthy, plant-based dishes aligned with the Slow Food movement, incorporating local ingredients and fermentation techniques. Albert's creations include Chayote Kimchi, Mung Bean Salad, and Super Green Warm Soup, catering to a gut-friendly diet. The diner marks the bakery's progression from a casual eatery to a full-service restaurant offering full meals.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 73% decline in net profit to S$31.4 million for Q4 2019, due to a decrease in fair value gain from investment properties. Revenue rose 11% to S$92.3 million. Koh Brothers Eco Engineering is exploring a spin-off of its Oiltek subsidiary. CDL Hospitality Trusts secured approval for two hotel deals. UOL Group agreed to buy a 154-room hotel in Jakarta for US$50 million. DESIGN Studio Group's CFO has resigned amid restructuring plans.

site_title: Home sales achieve soft landing in 2019 with 2.7% price gain
summary: Singapore's private home market achieved a soft landing in 2019, with prices rising 2.7% despite cooling measures and higher sales. Demand remained resilient, with developers selling 9,912 units, a 12.7% increase from 2018. Landed property prices rose 5.7% and non-landed properties increased 1.9%. Rental index fell 1%, but analysts expect rents to rise in 2020, driven by tech demand and low supply. Experts predict a 2-5% price increase and higher sales in 2020, driven by HDB upgraders and tech firms.

site_title: Bank Indonesia stands pat on key interest rate
summary: Bank Indonesia maintained its benchmark interest rate at 5% for a third consecutive month, citing an improving economic outlook. The decision was in line with predictions from 29 of 34 economists surveyed. Although the door remains open for future rate cuts, the central bank prioritizes maintaining stability.

site_title: ECB launches review, keeps policy on hold
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) left its monetary policy unchanged, keeping interest rates at record lows and committing to buying bonds at €20 billion per month until euro zone inflation reaches its target of 2%. The ECB also launched a strategic review of its inflation goal and tools, spanning topics such as digital money and climate change. This decision maintains the ECB's ultra-easy stance, suggesting that economic data has not been deemed sufficient to tighten policy.

site_title: For Rolls-Royce, Bespoke is big bucks
summary: Rolls-Royce has launched the Cullinan Black Badge in Singapore, its most powerful car in the country, featuring 600 horsepower and bespoke cosmetic upgrades. The Black Badge package costs S$1,418,888, with options adding up to S$500,000. The company's Bespoke Collective tailors cars to clients' tastes, with unique requests including a 7-layer surface paint job and a floral design for the headliner. This latest model showcases the brand's commitment to customization, with prices rivaling those of high-end art pieces.

site_title: Queen gives assent for Britain to leave EU
summary: Queen Elizabeth II gave her formal assent on Thursday, January 23, 2020, allowing Britain to officially leave the European Union, marking the end of a decades-long involvement. Prime Minister Boris Johnson, a key pro-Brexit figure, hailed the milestone as a victory, saying it's time to focus on delivering a bright future. The UK will now begin formal talks with the EU in March, with Johnson insisting on a quick post-Brexit agreement.

site_title: Keeping Traditions Alive
summary: Chinese New Year festivities remain unchanged despite time passing, with families continuing to prioritize reunion dinners, new clothes, and traditional rituals. Traditional high-end foods, such as rabbit fish, are still served alongside modern premium meats. The festive atmosphere, including shopping in Chinatown and visiting amusement parks, remains intact. The celebration also includes haggling with fishmongers, ordering new clothes and haircuts, and attending public events like the Istana's opening. Overall, the core traditions and values of Chinese New Year have endured.

images.alt_text: Buying ingredients from the wet market to cook for the reunion dinner.
A traditional family reunion dinner during Chinese New Year.
Children at the Chinese New Year fun fair at the Great World Park.
A family going to the Istana open house during the Chinese New Year festival.

site_title: Hong Bao Bao
summary: A miniaturized version of the popular Bao Bao Issey Miyake bag, the #hellobaobao, has been introduced by the brand for 2020. The versatile tote bag comes in various patterns and is one-quarter of its original size. It can be used as a standalone bag or as a bag-in-a-bag to keep small items organized. The #hellobaobao is available at a pop-up store in Paragon Atrium 2 until February 9.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust Q4 DPU falls 8.4% to 1.376 S cents
summary: Cache Logistics Trust's fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) fell 8.4% to 1.376 Singapore cents, down from 1.502 cents a year ago, due to lower revenue from leasing conversions, vacancy downtime, and weaker Australian dollar. The trust's net property income and distributable income also declined 12.4% and 7.6% year-over-year, respectively. Despite this, the trust maintained a committed portfolio occupancy of 95.3% and a weighted average lease expiry of three years.

site_title: Searching for distinctive character of California syrah
summary: A recent tasting of California syrah wines revealed a range of distinctive characters, from the intense, earthy flavors of the Arnot-Roberts Sonoma Coast Syrah 2015, made using traditional whole-cluster fermentation, to the more mainstream, fruit-forward style of the Stolpman Vineyards Ballard Canyon Estate Grown Syrah 2016. The Ojai Vineyard Santa Barbara County Syrah 2016 blended syrah with grenache and sangiovese, resulting in a floral and lively wine. The tasting highlighted the importance of site and winemaking techniques in shaping the unique character of syrah, with the Arnot-Roberts showcasing the grape's potential for complexity and distinctiveness.

site_title: Payment Services Act: The case for reviewing e-wallet caps
summary: The Payment Services Act, set to take effect on January 28, will have a significant impact on the management of money in Singapore. Introduced by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, the law adopts an activity-based regulation approach, focusing on what companies do rather than who they are. Fintech companies, including TransferWise, have expressed both optimism and concerns about specific rules, including a $5,000 cap on what Singaporeans can hold with fintechs. The law marks a shift in thinking for central banks worldwide.

site_title: Coronavirus deaths are so far mostly older men, many with health issues
summary: China's health commission confirmed 17 deaths from the new coronavirus, with the majority being older men, many with underlying health issues. The victims included 13 men and four women, with the youngest being a 48-year-old woman and the oldest being two 89-year-old men. Most had spent more than a week in hospitals, with some undergoing treatment for a month or longer. Medical experts warn that the virus could spread rapidly despite controls in place, and that infected people outside Wuhan could continue to spread the disease.

images.alt_text: A picture released by the Central Hospital of Wuhan shows medical staff attending to patient at the The Central Hospital Of Wuhan.

site_title: Tuan Sing Q4 net profit slumps 73% on lower fair-value adjustment
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings' fourth-quarter net profit plummeted 73% to S$31.4 million due to a significant decrease in fair-value adjustment. The fair-value adjustment decreased from S$113.2 million a year ago, primarily resulting from a decline in fair-value gains from revaluing investment properties.

site_title: China orders 'unprecedented' lockdown of two cities at virus epicentre
summary: China has locked down two cities, Wuhan and Huanggang, at the epicentre of a coronavirus outbreak that has killed 17 people and infected nearly 600, amid fears of a global pandemic. The lockdowns, affecting over 18 million people, come as millions travel during the Lunar New Year holidays. Health officials warn the transmission rate could accelerate, while the World Health Organization (WHO) considers declaring a global health emergency, which would step up international response.

site_title: Malaysia's 5G plan follows China's path
summary: Malaysia is offering airwaves for 5G networks at a low cost to carriers, following China's model. The government will allocate airwaves to a consortium of carriers via a tender starting after April, allowing them to invest in 5G infrastructure with a potential cost of RM7 billion over five years. This approach aims to reduce investment needed for 5G, while also setting up competition among carriers to form groups that will vie for the licence to operate the country's first 5G network.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.6% as Wuhan virus fears rattle investors
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% on Thursday, with heavy trading volume and 285 decliners surpassing 152 advancers. Investors remain unsettled over the Wuhan coronavirus, drawing parallels to the 2003 Sars epidemic. Despite Chinese authorities' efforts to contain the spread, regional markets in Asia averaged a 1.5% fall. Reit earnings season is underway, with CapitaLand's plans to form a new entity, and analysts remain bullish on Keppel Reit's prospects.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core inflation cooled to 1% in 2019, down from 0.6% in the previous year. The country's private home price index rose 0.5% in Q4, but declined 2.8% in prime areas. StarHub and M1 signed an agreement to jointly bid for a 5G licence in Singapore. Employment outcomes for Singapore citizens have been positive, with rising employment rates and faster income growth. The STI fell 0.6% on Thursday, amid concerns over the Wuhan virus.

site_title: Dubai's largest Islamic bank acquires smaller lender
summary: Dubai Islamic Bank (DIB) completed the acquisition of Noor Bank, consolidating its position as the top Islamic lender in the UAE. The acquisition raised DIB's assets to $75 billion, making it one of the largest Islamic banks globally. Despite being the fourth largest lender in the UAE, DIB maintains its top spot among Islamic banks. The acquisition was carried out through a share swap after securing necessary approvals from regulatory authorities.

site_title: Hong Kong turns holiday camps into quarantine zones as virus fears spike
summary: Hong Kong is converting two holiday camps into quarantine zones to contain the spread of the Wuhan virus, which has killed 17 people since its outbreak in central China. Two people in Hong Kong have tested positive for the virus, and three others in close contact will be isolated. The move is similar to the one taken during the Sars outbreak 17 years ago, which killed nearly 300 people and left a profound psychological impact on the densely populated city. Officials are also considering extending health declaration forms to cover the high-speed rail link with the mainland.

site_title: US Treasury Secretary pledges tax cuts for 'middle class'
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced a new round of tax cuts aimed at benefiting the middle class. This follows President Donald Trump's earlier proposal, which could be rolled out within three months. The new tax cuts would add to the 2017 round of tax cuts, mostly benefiting corporations and wealthy taxpayers. The move is seen as a potential boost to Trump's reelection bid.

images.alt_text: "The president has asked us to start working on what we call tax 2.0," Mr Mnuchin said told CNBC from the global economic forum Davos, Switzerland.

site_title: SIA mulls adding more planes in India to fight Emirates: sources
summary: Singapore Airlines is considering adding more planes in India to compete with Emirates, with Vistara, its Indian joint venture, potentially ordering more 787 Dreamliner jets and A320neo-family planes. The move aims to loosen Emirates and Etihad Airways' grip on the lucrative India-Europe/US market. This comes as Singapore Airlines faces increasing competition from budget carriers in South-east Asia. The airline's plans would be part of its strategy to strengthen its presence in India and counter Emirates' dominance in the market.

site_title: Singapore keeps high score in fight against graft
summary: Singapore has maintained its high score of 85 in the Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI) 2019, ranking it among the top 10 globally. The country's strong enforcement of campaign finance regulations and broader range of political consultation are key factors contributing to its high score.
