The CAD advises investors to lodge a police report and bring documents related to transactions with the company, including agreements and bank statements.

site_title: Comcast bets ads work on streaming TV, plans NBC Peacock debut for April
summary: NBCUniversal's streaming service Peacock will debut in April with a free, ad-supported option and a paid, ad-free option for $5/month. The service will offer over 7,500 hours of content, including classic NBC series and movies, and aims to reach 30-35 million active accounts by 2024. Peacock will generate hundreds of millions in ad revenue, and NBCUniversal believes affordability will be crucial in the crowded streaming market. The service will be available to Comcast customers first, with a wider US launch in July.

site_title: China Q4 GDP grows 6.0%, in line with expectations and hovering near 30-year low
summary: China's economy grew 6.0% in Q4 2019, in line with expectations and near a 30-year low. This follows sluggish demand at home and abroad, as well as US trade pressure. Policymakers have rolled out growth-boosting measures, but financial and debt risks remain a concern. The Q4 growth rate matches the previous quarter, indicating no significant improvement. Analysts expect China's GDP growth to slow further, putting pressure on policymakers to address the economic challenges.

site_title: Singapore shares open almost flat on Friday; STI up 0.01%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.01% to 3,278.21 on Friday, despite US stocks closing at all-time highs. Gainers outnumbered losers 104 to 31, with notable movers including Rex International, AsiaPhos, and ST Engineering. The US Senate approved a new North American trade pact, contributing to the surge in US stocks.

site_title: China 2019 pork production falls 21.3% from a year ago
summary: China's 2019 pork production fell 21.3% from a year ago, reaching 42.55 million tonnes, due to the fatal African swine fever that killed millions of pigs. The pig herd declined 27.5% to 310.41 million head, and the number of slaughtered hogs fell 21.6% to 544.19 million head. This decline is expected to have significant economic implications for China, the world's top pork producer.

images.alt_text: China produced 42.55 million tonnes of pork in 2019, down 21.3 per cent from a year earlier, official data showed on Friday, after the fatal hog disease African swine fever killed millions of pigs in the world's top producer during the year.

site_title: Pay2Home app allows overseas remittance using cash at 7-Eleven
summary: Pay2Home, a Singapore-based fintech, has launched a service allowing users to pay for digital remittance transactions with cash at 7-Eleven stores. The app, targeting the underbanked, enables migrant workers to send cash overseas using the Pay2Home mobile app and pay with a generated QR code bill at 400 7-Eleven stores island-wide. This move aims to promote financial inclusion and education among those who prefer cash transactions.

site_title: Christopher Tolkien, son of Lord of the Rings author, dies aged 95
summary: Christopher Tolkien, son of J.R.R. Tolkien, has died at 95, according to the Tolkien Society. He was a former lecturer at the University of Oxford and played a crucial role in publishing his father's works, including 'The Silmarillion' (1977) and 'The Fall of Gondolin' (2018). Christopher drew the 1954 map of Middle-earth for 'The Lord of the Rings' and spent years compiling and editing his father's works after his death in 1973.

site_title: Bank of England to hold steady on Jan 30 but chance of a cut high: poll
summary: The Bank of England is likely to keep interest rates steady on January 30, but a poll of economists suggests a 35% chance of a 25 basis point cut due to weak data, including a 1.3% inflation rate in December. The UK's departure from the EU on January 30 and ongoing Brexit uncertainty have fueled expectations of a rate cut. Despite this, median forecasts among economists show no change to borrowing costs until 2023. The UK's economy is expected to expand 1.1% this year before accelerating to 1.5% next year.

site_title: Bank of Korea stands pat as it weighs housing boom, past cuts
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, kept its benchmark interest rate steady at 1.25% as expected, amid concerns about a potential property bubble. Despite earlier rate cuts, the economy expanded only 2.0% in 2019, the slowest in a decade. Analysts are split on whether further easing is needed, with some predicting another cut within the year. Governor Lee Ju Yeol's speech will be closely watched for an announcement on the replacement of four board members.

site_title: US to introduce 20-year bond to finance substantial debt
summary: The US Treasury plans to introduce a 20-year bond to finance the country's growing deficit, which exceeded $1 trillion last year. The new bond is intended to serve as an intermediate option between 10- and 30-year bonds. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the move aims to finance the government at the least possible cost to taxpayers over time. The first 20-year bonds are expected to be issued during the first half of the year, with more details to be released on February 5.

site_title: US video game spending fell in 2019: industry group
summary: US video game spending declined 13% to $14.6 billion in 2019, with December spending down 15% to $3.0 billion, according to market-tracker NPD Group. New console releases and cloud gaming services, such as Google's Stadia, may have contributed to the decline. Meanwhile, mobile gaming spending increased 24% to $11.82 billion, driven by growth in the US and Canada. The top-selling game of 2019 was "Call of Duty: Modern Warfare," which also held the top spot for three consecutive months.

site_title: Investing in Indonesia: How to ride the Garuda and avoid the nagas
summary: Indonesia's investment landscape is shifting with the second Jokowi administration's efforts to attract foreign direct investment (FDI). Singapore remains Indonesia's largest source of FDI, with a significant investment in ride-hailing firm Go-Jek. To mitigate risks, international investors should partner with domestic companies with a proven track record, ensuring environmental, labor, and health regulations are met. A well-structured Joint Venture (JV) agreement with clear provisions for dispute resolution and flexibility is crucial to minimize conflicts. Indonesia's vast market offers great potential for FDI, but investors must navigate potential environmental and reputational risks.

site_title: Hot stock: BreadTalk shares fall 8% on net loss warning for FY2019
summary: BreadTalk shares fell 8% on Friday after the company warned of a net loss for FY2019 due to weakness in its bakery and food concept divisions, and turmoil in Hong Kong. The share price dropped 5.5 Singapore cents to S$0.635, its lowest price this week. The company attributed the loss to a combination of factors, including a decline in sales and increased competition.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Wall Street gains, higher dollar
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Friday, following US markets' new record highs driven by strong corporate earnings and a higher dollar. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.76% to 24,115.00, while the Topix index gained 0.49% to 1,737.17. This upward trend continues despite global market uncertainty and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on Friday, extending gains from the previous day. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.36% to 28,988.16, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.24% and 0.23% respectively. Investors focused on corporate earnings and turned away from the China-US trade deal.

site_title: EU mulls 5-year ban on facial recognition tech in public areas
summary: The European Union is considering a 5-year ban on facial recognition technology in public areas to address concerns over privacy and data rights. The EU Commission proposes introducing new regulations to bolster existing protections, including obligations for developers and users of artificial intelligence. Exceptions could be made for security projects and research and development. The proposal aims to give the EU time to work out how to prevent abuses and develop risk management measures.

site_title: Singapore exports clock surprise rise of 2.4% in December
summary: Singapore's exports unexpectedly rose 2.4% in December, the first growth in nine months, driven by a surge in non-monetary gold, pharmaceuticals, and specialized machinery exports. Despite a 21.3% decline in the electronics sector, other top markets such as China, Taiwan, and the US saw growth. The total trade grew 0.7% in December, reversing a 5.9% decline in the previous month. The positive trend is seen as a sign of a stabilizing global economy, which could benefit Singapore's export-oriented economy.

site_title: Second person dies from mystery virus in China: official
summary: A 69-year-old man in Wuhan, China has died from a mystery virus, marking the second reported death from the outbreak. At least 41 people in China have been affected with pneumonia linked to the virus, while two cases have been detected in Thailand and Japan. Authorities believe a seafood market in Wuhan may be the epicentre of the outbreak, and no human-to-human transmission has been confirmed. The Wuhan health commission reported 12 recoveries and 5 in serious condition, but warned the possibility of human-to-human transmission "cannot be excluded".

site_title: Trump to nominate Shelton, Waller to serve on Federal Reserve Board
summary: President Donald Trump is set to nominate Judy Shelton and Christopher Waller to the Federal Reserve Board, aiming to shape the central bank in his favor. Shelton, a former Trump campaign advisor, advocates for lower interest rates, while Waller, a St Louis Fed research director, supports lower interest rates and more government coordination. Both nominees must be approved by the US Senate, which has been critical of the Fed under Chair Jerome Powell. The move is seen as a response to the Fed's recent actions and raises concerns about the central bank's independence.

site_title: Auto tariff threat not mentioned in US talks: EU commissioner
summary: US Trade Commissioner Phil Hogan said US threats to impose 25% tariffs on European autos did not come up during talks in Washington. German Defence Minister Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer confirmed the threat existed, but Hogan learned of it through media reports. The US had previously threatened tariffs to pressure Iran, but a deadline for the decision appeared to have lapsed without comment. Hogan also expressed frustration over US refusal to lift tariffs on European exports, particularly in the aircraft sector, and said Europeans had met US demands on agriculture imports.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GuocoLand, Cache Logistics Trust, Q&M, BreadTalk, Rex
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Stocks to watch: GuocoLand saw its earnings rise threefold to S$32.4 million, driven by revenue growth. Cache Logistics Trust's shares rose 0.7% after a public consultation on a strategic deal. Q&M Dental Group agreed to pay RM3.5 million to settle a lawsuit. BreadTalk Group expects a net loss for FY2019 due to weakness in its bakery division. Rex International's shares fell 1.6% after clinching stakes in two new offshore licenses. TEE International secured an engineering maintenance contract and Ellipsiz exited a loss-making joint venture. IPC Corp expects a fair-value writedown adjustment in its FY2019 results.

site_title: Trump predicts Senate trial 'should go very quickly'
summary: US President Donald Trump predicted his impeachment trial in the US Senate will be "very quick" and dismissed abuse of power charges as a "hoax." Trump claimed new Ukraine-related accusations against him had nothing to do with him, despite his personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani's involvement. Trump denied knowing Lev Parnas, a former associate of Giuliani, and said he had no idea what Parnas was referring to. The trial is set to begin after Senate members were sworn in as the jury.

site_title: US must be involved on Afghanistan after troops leave: Pakistan
summary: Pakistan's foreign minister Shah Mehmood Qureshi urged the US to remain involved in Afghanistan's reconstruction even after withdrawing troops, warning against neglecting the country. Qureshi made the statement after meeting with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, following a proposed deal between the US and the Taliban. The US has plans to withdraw its 12,000 troops, but Qureshi emphasized that challenges will remain, and the US must remain engaged to rebuild.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as US-China trade deal clears fog; London lags
summary: European shares rose on Thursday after the US-China trade deal was signed, lifting near-term uncertainty. Despite concerns over China's purchase commitments and existing tariffs, the deal's signing encouraged a risk-on mode. In contrast, London shares were dragged down by disappointing earnings. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records, but investors remain cautious due to tariff uncertainty. The Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) ended 0.4% higher, despite split Fed views.

site_title: EU's Hogan says off to 'a good start' on resetting trade ties with US
summary: European Union trade commissioner Phil Hogan said his meeting with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer marked a "good start" to resetting trade ties, with discussions focusing on resolving open disputes and avoiding tit-for-tat tariffs. The EU is open to negotiating non-tariff barriers, such as phyto-sanitary standards, to break the impasse. However, agriculture is not on the table for broader trade talks, and more work remains to be done to reach a resolution.

site_title: Didi rival said to seek up to US$300m in a pre-IPO round
summary: Chinese ride-hailing startup Dida Chuxing is seeking up to $300 million in a pre-IPO round, escalating competition with larger rival Didi Chuxing. The company, backed by IDG Capital, is considering an initial public offering on Hong Kong exchanges. Dida has grown its popularity after two female passengers were murdered while using Didi's services, and has seen its daily orders surpass 3.65 million. The company has become profitable, earning 29 million yuan in the second quarter of 2019, and expects its revenue to jump to 643 million yuan last year.

site_title: Oil ends higher, as trade deal progress spurs energy demand hopes
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Thursday, driven by optimism over energy demand growth in 2020, despite bearish comments from the International Energy Agency. The US Senate approved a revamp of the US-Mexico-Canada Free Trade Agreement, and the US and China signed a Phase 1 trade deal calling for increased US energy imports. Brent settled at $64.62 a barrel, and US WTI crude rose to $58.52 a barrel, with analysts warning that China's ability to meet the target is uncertain.

site_title: Apparel company Gap spikes plan to spin off Old Navy
summary: Gap spikes plan to spin off Old Navy, citing softer business performance and operational inefficiencies. The company, which also operates Banana Republic and Athleta, will appoint a new CEO and give additional responsibilities to senior leaders. The decision to spin off Old Navy was made after the company's financial performance struggled since announcing the plan in February 2019. Gap's shares jumped 6.7% in after-hours trading following the announcement. The company's interim CEO, Robert Fisher, stated that the decision will focus on creating value from the company's growth brands through a "more rigorous and transformational manner."

site_title: US: Stocks end at records on international trade deal progress
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records on Thursday after the Senate approved a new North American trade pact, following the US-China trade deal. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.9%, the S&P 500 gained 0.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.1%. Alphabet, Apple, and Microsoft became the first companies to reach $1 trillion in market capitalization, while investors welcomed the reduced uncertainty and recession fears. The new trade deal requires only President Trump's signature and approval from Canada before entering into force.

site_title: Bombardier reviews minority stake in Airbus JV, flags writedown; shares tumble
summary: Bombardier Inc. reported lower-than-expected 2019 profits due to problematic rail contracts and said it might write down the value of its partnership with Airbus on the A220 jet programme. The company expects adjusted earnings before interest and taxes to be around $400 million, down from a previously forecast range of $700-800 million. Shares fell 38.6% to a record low, and the company's bonds surged in value. Airbus remains committed to funding the A220 programme, but the partnership may require additional investment and could lead to a writedown.

images.alt_text: Bombardier Inc shares shed nearly third of its value on Thursday after the company warned its 2019 profits would be lower because of problematic rail contracts and said it might have to write down the value of a plane partnership with Airbus.

site_title: Money FM podcast: On a mission to inspire success
summary: Glenn van Zutphen interviews Jit Puru, founder of Ideas & Inspiration, on his podcast Weekend Mornings. Jit shares his motivation for starting the operation and overcoming life's challenges, emphasizing the power of a good public speaker. The conversation aims to inspire success and provide insights into Jit's experiences.

site_title: Microsoft pledges to be 'carbon negative' by 2030
summary: Microsoft pledges to be 'carbon negative' by 2030, aiming to remove all carbon emissions since its founding in 1975 by 2050. The initiative, part of its effort to combat climate change, was announced by CEO Satya Nadella. The company's goal is to offset its emissions through investments in renewable energy and carbon removal technologies. This move follows the scientific consensus that the world faces an urgent carbon crisis.

images.alt_text: Microsoft said on Thursday it would become "carbon negative" by 2030 as part of a ramped-up effort by the US tech giant to combat climate change.

site_title: Renault 'wants partnership with Nissan to succeed'
summary: Renault chairman Jean-Dominique Senard expressed a "real desire" to make the Renault-Nissan alliance a success, amid concerns the 20-year partnership was on the rocks. The alliance was shaken by Carlos Ghosn's arrest in 2018 and his recent dramatic flight from Japanese justice. Senard defended the changes made since Ghosn's arrest and stated a common desire to associate strategic plans and make the alliance a success. Analysts view the cost-cutting alliance as vital to both companies' fortunes, particularly in the face of a slowdown in demand and investments in cleaner vehicles.

site_title: Crowded Monaco reclaims land to build more luxury flats with sea view
summary: Monaco is set to expand by six hectares through land reclamation to build luxury apartments and boutiques with sea views. The €2 billion project, expected to be completed in 2021, will include 60,000 sq m of luxury accommodation and 3,000 sq m of retail space. The construction, led by French industrial group Bouygues, aims to alleviate pressure on housing in the principality, which is surrounded by France. The project's impact on local animal and plant life has been minimized, with efforts made to restore habitats as soon as possible.

site_title: Significant MICE events in Singapore
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival was one of the largest MICE events in the Republic, attracting 45,000 attendees from over 130 countries in 2018. The event featured the Global Investor Summit and Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS) World Congress, with a focus on fintech growth, sustainable impacts, and efficient transportation. Demonstrations and technical tours showcased developmental vehicles and systems, including the world's first electric autonomous bus. The event also included side events, such as a C-level forum on Mobility Solutions for Smart Cities, which brought together industry leaders to discuss solutions for enhancing city quality.

site_title: GuocoLand's Q2 earnings nearly triple on boost from Martin Modern sales
summary: GuocoLand's Q2 earnings nearly tripled to S$32.4 million due to higher progressive recognition of sales from Martin Modern, with revenue more than doubling to S$299.6 million. The company's earnings per share surged to 2.49 cents from 0.55 cents a year earlier, despite a 180% rise in other expenses.

site_title: British Airways often worse than rivals on emissions: consumer group
summary: British Airways is often worse than rival airlines on emissions, according to consumer group "Which?", which compared carbon dioxide emissions on six international routes from London. On four routes, British Airways was the worst performer, pumping out more emissions per passenger. The airline, owned by IAG, is trying to offset its emissions, but consumers can make smart choices to reduce their own carbon footprint.

site_title: SGX's latest proposal addresses foreign audit concerns: analysts
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has proposed a new rule requiring all listed firms to appoint an auditor registered with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra). This move aims to address concerns over foreign audit quality and enhance oversight. The rule applies to foreign issuers, who will need to designate an additional Acra-registered auditor. The proposal is seen as a step to restore confidence among investors amid global corporate scandals.

site_title: CapitaLand wins tender to manage Bugis Village and Bugis Street
summary: CapitaLand has won the tender to manage Bugis Village and Bugis Street for up to a decade, with an initial three-year tenancy starting on April 1, 2020. Existing tenants can continue their business operations until March 31, 2021. CapitaLand plans to introduce new retail concepts, including a day-to-night market and shared economy spaces, to complement existing offerings in the area. The integrated management will increase CapitaLand's retail NLA in the Bras Basah/Bugis precinct to over 800,000 sq ft.

site_title: SPH to issue S$500m 3.2% senior unsecured notes due 2030
summary: SPH to issue S$500m 3.2% senior unsecured notes due 2030. The 10-year notes will be listed on the Singapore Exchange on Jan 23 and mature on Jan 22, 2030. Proceeds will be used for general working capital, capital expenditure, and refinancing existing borrowings. The deal has attracted S$750m in orders from 35 accounts, with 60% coming from fund managers, institutional investors, and banks. DBS Bank, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank are joint lead managers and bookrunners for the deal.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: BreadTalk Group, a Mainboard-listed company, expects a net loss for FY2019 due to weakness in its bakery and food concept divisions, largely attributed to turmoil in Hong Kong. The company's bakery business in China and Thailand, as well as several brands within its 4orth food concepts division, are expected to contribute to widening losses. This is the first time the company has announced a net loss for the year.

site_title: Politics may stoke fears but its impact on markets is temporary: Citi Private Bank
summary: Citi Private Bank expects politics to have a temporary impact on markets, despite ongoing concerns over the US-China trade war, US elections, and Brexit. The bank predicts global growth to rise to over 3% in 2020, driven by industrial activity and international trade rebounding. Investors should consider equities with histories of earnings and dividend growth, and avoid negative, low-yield bonds. Citi also highlights three "unstoppable" trends for 2020: cybersecurity, fintech, and the future of energy, and recommends exposing portfolios to these areas.

site_title: Keeping up with game changers in the MICE industry
summary: Singapore aims to maintain its position as a leading MICE destination by providing a holistic experience for business travelers, combining business and leisure. The industry is expected to evolve with a focus on multi-sensory, hybrid events and sustainability. Key stakeholders, including Singex Holdings, Kingsmen Exhibits, and Resorts World Sentosa, are working together to deliver maximum return on engagement and experience for customers. The development of new technologies, digital platforms, and attractions on Sentosa Island are expected to drive growth and sustainability in the MICE industry.

site_title: Taiwan chipmaker forecasts spike in Q1 revenue
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) forecasts a 45% spike in Q1 revenue, driven by robust demand for 5G smartphones. The prediction comes as the global smartphone market recovers from three years of decline. TSMC's clients, including Apple and Huawei, are expected to fuel the growth. The company also raised its capital expenditure plan for the year, betting on the 5G trend to boost profits.

site_title: Predictable Chinese cooking at Jia He
summary: Jia He Chinese Restaurant in Singapore offers predictable and passable Chinese food in a low-key setting. The restaurant's decor is non-descript, and its dishes, such as roasted crispy chicken and double-boiled chicken broth, are unremarkable. However, some dishes, like the Szechuan Hot and Sour Soup and crispy seafood hor fun, show promise. Despite a few standout moments, the restaurant's overall cooking is uninspired, and it falls short of being excellent. With some improvements, Jia He could rise up the ranks and become a more memorable dining experience. Rating: 6/10.

images.alt_text: Above: A surprising fusion creation of roasted cherry tomato wrapped in not too salty bacon with the refreshing mouthfeel of bursting tomatoes and cured meat, drizzled with salad cream.
Roasted crispy chicken with tangerine peel is a signature dish.

Above left: Double-boiled Superior Chicken Broth with Stuffed Fish Maw is suitably collagen-rich and milky white. Above right: Szechuan Hot and Sour Soup, with a mildly peppery thick broth with all the fun bits of black fungus, tofu, chicken strips to munch on, plus a fat prawn as a bonus.
Chewy black glutinous rice and vanilla ice cream in a ring of firm white coconut jelly.
Crispy seafood hor fun where a large tangle of deep fried skinny kway teow appears like a nest of light airy keropok.

site_title: FAI-driven jobs filled mostly by Singaporeans
summary: Singapore's economy has seen 85% of new jobs created from $15.2 billion in investments in 2019 being filled by Singaporeans, with 15% by permanent residents. This ratio is consistent with the unemployment rate. Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for a range of jobs to cater to older workers, while acknowledging that high-tech sectors will see more foreign employees due to global talent shortages. The government aims to reskill and upskill workers in their 40s to 50s to remain relevant in the job market.

site_title: Fixed asset investments hit 7-year high; EDB drops yearly forecasts
summary: Singapore attracted S$15.2 billion in fixed asset investments in 2019, exceeding the forecast of S$8 billion to S$10 billion. This marked the highest figure since 2012, up from S$10.9 billion in 2018. The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) stated that yearly forecasts are not meaningful in relation to how firms make decisions.

images.alt_text: Dr Beh (left) and Mr Chng at the EDB year-in-review briefing on Thursday. Chemicals and electronics were the top two sources of investment commitments in 2019.

site_title: Too soon to pop the bubbly for Singapore economy
summary: Singapore's economy is unlikely to see significant growth due to the Phase One US-China trade deal, according to analysts. While the agreement offers more certainty, the expected recovery is largely driven by improving business confidence and sentiments, rather than material factors. Economists project a shallow recovery for the Singapore economy in 2020, with sluggishness potentially extending to China, as tariffs remain in force and demand for recovery may be restrained.

site_title: Art On Foot
summary: A 70m long wall mural, Mayura, is part of the ARTWALK Little India event, now in its sixth year. The event features guided art tours, pop-up markets, workshops, and dining experiences. ARTWALK is jointly organised by LASALLE College of the Arts and the Singapore Tourism Board, aiming to bring more life to Little India. The event is scheduled for January 17-18, with details available at artwalklittleindia.sg.

site_title: US continues modest growth, with fairly favourable outlook: beige book survey
summary: The US economy showed modest growth in the final weeks of 2019, with solid holiday sales and a "moderately favourable" outlook for 2020. The Federal Reserve's "beige book" survey found mixed conditions nationwide, with improvements in the Richmond and Dallas regions but lacklustre growth in others. Tariffs and trade uncertainty continued to weigh on some businesses, but expectations for the near-term outlook remained positive. The US and China signed a partial trade truce on the same day, with many tariffs still in place.

site_title: Malcolm Wood - Entrepreneur/Adventurer
summary: Malcolm Wood, entrepreneur and adventurer, has opened Mott 32 in Singapore, a modern Chinese restaurant part of his global culinary brand. Wood, a passionate advocate for sustainability, has built a string of eco-friendly eateries in Hong Kong, Las Vegas, Vancouver, and Seoul. His love for nature and the outdoors led him to campaign against climate change and create a documentary, "The Last Glaciers," which explores the effects of climate change on glaciers. Wood's businesses, including his film production company, prioritize environmentalism and wellness.

site_title: Purpose of SACEOS is unchanged 40 years from its beginning
summary: Singapore Association of Convention and Exhibition Organisers and Suppliers (SACEOS) is celebrating its 40th year, remaining committed to enhancing Singapore's position as a central MICE hub. Established in 1979, SACEOS has championed MICE events in Singapore, promoting capacity building and training to maintain its attractiveness in the Asia-Pacific region. The association's core values of commerce development, capabilities enhancement, and community engagement ensure its relevance, with a focus on professional development, industry and enterprise, digital and innovation, community and advocacy, and communications.

site_title: New bank loans in Dec miss Chinese forecast, but hit record in 2019
summary: China's new bank loans in December fell short of forecast, with 1.14 trillion yuan extended, down from 1.39 trillion yuan in November. Despite this, lending for all of 2019 reached a record, driven by central bank easing policies to support the slowing economy. Outstanding yuan loans grew 12.3% in 2019, below forecast, but total social financing (TSF) rose 10.7% in December, in line with November's growth. Analysts predict additional rate cuts to stimulate credit growth, as the US-China trade deal may help lower economic risks.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet valuation hit US$1t
summary: Google's parent company Alphabet has reached a valuation of US$1 trillion, becoming the fourth US tech company to achieve this milestone. Shares rose 0.76% to reach the trillion-dollar mark, joining Apple ($1.38 trillion) and Microsoft ($1.26 trillion).

images.alt_text: Google's parent company Alphabet saw its value reach US$1 trillion for the first time on Thursday, becoming the fourth US tech company to hit the milestone.

site_title: Tech firms' concerns with China remain despite US deal
summary: The US-China Phase One deal aims to address long-standing concerns of US tech firms regarding intellectual property (IP) protections and technology transfers in China. China has pledged to end its practice of pressuring US companies to transfer tech expertise, and amend domestic laws to make it easier for US companies to identify and penalize IP theft. However, critics question the deal's effectiveness, citing that few provisions impose new obligations on China and that it fails to address pressing issues like cyber crime. The deal's enforcement mechanism allows the Trump administration to penalize China with tariffs or other measures if officials decide China is not fulfilling its pledges.

site_title: HK's special status can endure beyond 2047, says Carrie Lam
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam has stated that the "one country, two systems" framework, which grants Hong Kong freedoms unknown in China, could endure beyond its 2047 deadline if loyalty to Beijing is upheld. This comes as the city has been wracked by anti-government protests since June, which have diminished in scale following a landslide win by opposition candidates. Lam's comments echo China's Communist Party leaders, who say Hong Kong's unique system relies on respect for Chinese sovereignty.

site_title: Malaysia talks to India in bid to resolve concerns over new palm oil import curbs
summary: Malaysia is in talks with India to resolve concerns over new palm oil import curbs imposed by the Indian government. The curbs, which include restrictions on refined palm oil and other products, have raised concerns for Malaysia, the world's second-largest palm oil producer and exporter. Indian Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal has denied imposing any curbs on imports from Malaysia, but the country's palm oil exports to India are expected to fall below a million tonnes if relations do not improve. Malaysian officials are trying to sell more to other countries, but replacing India's massive market will be challenging.

site_title: Time To Buy Art
summary: S.E.A. Focus, a platform featuring 20 galleries showcasing 35 artists connected to Southeast Asia, is now open at Gillman Barracks until Jan 19. The event includes notable galleries like Vitamin Creative Space, ROH Projects, and STPI, as well as artists such as Rirkrit Tiravanija, Danh Vo, and Melati Suryodarmo. To coincide, Gillman Barracks will host Art After Dark on Jan 17, keeping galleries open late.

site_title: Spectre of more US restrictions weighs on Huawei
summary: US sanctions on Huawei could slow China's 5G networking rollout, affecting Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) and other tech suppliers. Analysts at Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse warn that restrictions could lead to a 40 million decline in Huawei's smartphone volume this year. Without access to Google Mobile Services, Huawei's smartphone shipments in Western Europe would be nearly zero. Chipmaker TSMC relies on Huawei for 10% of revenue, which could be impacted by increased sanctions.

site_title: Beijing speeds up opening of market to investment bank giants
summary: China has accelerated its plan to open its $21 trillion capital market to global investment banks, including Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, and Morgan Stanley, by eight months. The move, part of a trade deal with the US, allows these banks to apply for fully owned units to participate in various investment banking and securities dealings. China has also committed to opening its $45 trillion financial markets to foreign investment, including asset management and insurance markets, and has pledged to remove restrictions for US-owned companies.

site_title: Relief in Asian markets, but no big gains as news already priced in
summary: Asian markets experienced relief on Thursday following the signing of the partial US-China trade deal, which puts a lid on worsening tensions and marks a breakthrough in a nearly two-year-long spat. Despite the news, markets didn't see significant gains, as the agreement's details were already largely priced in. Analysts expect a "honeymoon period" for markets, with a respectable macro environment and fair valuations suggesting a respectable year for Asian markets.

site_title: Trade deal not changing Singapore firms' outlook yet
summary: Singapore companies remain cautious about the impact of the US-China trade deal, despite positive pledges from both countries. Some firms have already reduced their exposure to trade frictions, while others view the deal as a "sentiment booster" for trade. The initial optimism is seen as early days, with much still to be determined, and companies are unlikely to change their outlook just yet. Key sectors remain uncertain, with no clear indication of a significant improvement in global trade.

images.alt_text: News of the trade deal seen on a giant screen in Beijing. One company boss said the spat was a wake-up call; it "forces you to think out of the box, get out of your comfort zone, re-look the business model".

site_title: Honey, I Shrunk Chinatown
summary: Singaporean couple Caleb Lin and Terra Chua create miniature figures, 'Miniature Stories', to remember the nation's past. Their Heritage series focuses on life in Singapore from the 1950s to 1970s, recreating notable characters and shophouses. Each 1:26 scale figure is hand-sculpted, cast in metal, and hand-painted individually, showcasing attention to detail. The couple's goal is to create pieces true to form, highlighting the nation's heritage through unique and detailed miniatures.

site_title: House Proud
summary: For Chinese New Year, home decor can be spruced up with items like a limited edition pink rat sculpture ($1,600), Oriental Blooms floral arrangement ($168), and Hermès pillows ($860). The season's auspicious colors can also be incorporated through a Pappelina Mono Rug ($780), FU Porcelain Plate ($36), and FU Chopsticks ($29.90). Luxury items like a 24K Swiss gold-plated rat pair ($6,888) and Onlewo's Singapore Orchid Plate ($52) are also available.

site_title: Analysts expect China's recent wave of corporate bond defaults to continue
summary: China's corporate bond defaults reached a record high in 2019, with a 4.5% default rate among privately-owned enterprises and 0.2% among state-owned enterprises. Analysts expect this trend to continue as the central bank seeks to clean up the financial sector. The defaults have affected various industries, including some major players and local governments. This move is part of China's efforts to address its slowing GDP growth and rising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Utico to hold Hyflux town halls on Jan 20
summary: Utico, a Middle Eastern utility firm, will hold town hall meetings on Jan 20 for investors holding Hyflux's medium-term notes, perpetual securities, and preference shares. The meetings will take place at Sheraton Towers and Suntec Convention Centre, targeting noteholders at 12pm and PnP investors in the evening.

site_title: Not end of the road for TPG even if it doesn't snare 5G licence
summary: Singapore's call for 5G proposals is nearing its end, with analysts predicting Singtel and a StarHub-M1 joint bid as likely winners. However, newcomer TPG Telecom may not be forced out of the market if it secures a wholesale network-leasing deal with a licence winner. Despite the potential for significant losses, TPG could still reap benefits from 5G by leveraging its existing 4G infrastructure and tapping into wholesale options, potentially earning a similar price premium to incumbents. A sharply focused game plan is crucial for would-be players, as the 5G market's development is at a critical stage.

site_title: Pumped up kicks: the sneaker resale boom
summary: Sneaker resale market has exploded, with rare shoes trading for many times their original price on secondary market platforms. The resale market's growth is attributed to scarcity and strategic buyers, turning sneakers into an investment-like commodity. This phenomenon has been fueled by big-name collaborations and the growing popularity of sneakers among consumers. The resale market has become a lucrative business, with prices for certain shoes reaching S$200 or more. The market's growth has also led to new opportunities for businesses and individuals to invest in sneakers.

site_title: OCBC withdraws 2 properties after tender closing
summary: OCBC has withdrawn two properties from sale: a 22-storey serviced residence block at 2 Mount Elizabeth Link and a portfolio of 32 shophouses along Lavender Street and Serangoon Road. The withdrawals follow a strategic decision by the bank's top management to hold its remaining freehold properties, potentially anticipating future capital appreciation. The properties were launched through separate tender exercises in September last year, but no reasons were cited for the withdrawals.

site_title: MICE industry will continue to be key for Singapore
summary: Singapore's meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions (MICE) tourism industry will continue to be a key contributor to the country's growth, despite slow economic progress and external pressure. The nation's resilience and proven ability to handle challenges make it an attractive destination for MICE events. The industry's uniqueness, which focuses on knowledge exchange and sharing, creates opportunities for job creation and spillover effects on other supporting industries. Recent initiatives, such as the WeChat Mini Program targeting Chinese MICE travelers, demonstrate Singapore's efforts to stay relevant and attract more MICE events.

images.alt_text: ''MICE industry is a fairly resilient one, in good or in bad times . . . it's not a case whereeverything stops, I think that would be really foolish. I think what's important to think about (is) where to be, where economic collaboration is and what new markets to venture into.'' - Aloysius Arlando, president of the Singapore Association of Convention and Exhibition Organisers and Suppliers (SACEOS).

site_title: Playing With Light
summary: International art collective teamLab brings seven digital art installations to Singapore's Gardens by the Bay as part of the #futuretogether event, a finale of the Singapore Bicentennial. The installations, spread across indoor and outdoor spaces, include Autonomous Resonating Life on the Water and Resonating Trees, featuring 300 oval sculptures that light up and emit sounds when pushed. The event runs until March 15 at Bayfront Plaza.

site_title: Singapore architects, engineers sign green petition
summary: Singapore has become the first country in Asia to sign the Construction Declares, a global initiative aiming to reduce climate crises. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to address environmental problems, including rising temperatures, sea levels, and more frequent heavy rainfall. Buildings and construction are a significant contributor to carbon dioxide emissions, accounting for nearly 40% of energy-related emissions. This signing marks a crucial step towards reducing the country's environmental footprint and mitigating the effects of climate change.

site_title: Abolish time-wasting meetings
summary: A new approach to management is proposed to speed up thinking, doing, and achieving by reducing time-wasting meetings. To do this, a "Meeting Maestro" is recommended to collect data on meetings, including duration, attendees, and decisions made. The findings will be used to identify areas for improvement, such as reducing meeting lengths and increasing informal meetings. A list of actions will be created to implement cultural change, including restricting meeting room use and implementing digital equipment. The benefits of this approach extend beyond meetings, leading to increased productivity and efficiency.

site_title: Qipao Power / Bling In The New Year
summary: Asian designers are reimagining the traditional Chinese qipao dress, infusing it with modernity and functionality. Local brands like Laichan, The Missing Piece, and YeoMama Batik, and international houses like Shanghai Tang are creating convertible, casual, and wearable qipao-inspired designs. These modern interpretations celebrate Asian heritage, global multiculturalism, and individuality, making the qipao a staple in everyday fashion. Designers are also incorporating traditional elements, such as mandarin collars and jade, into modern pieces, appealing to a wide range of consumers, from young women to high-powered professionals.

images.alt_text: The Missing Piece's qipao designs can be worn on non-festive occasions.
Victoria Tang-Owen, creative director of Shanghai Tang, and her latest creations.
Victoria Tang-Owen, creative director of Shanghai Tang, and her latest creations.

YeoMama Batik reinvents the qipao in bold batik.

Caratell's Lion Dance ring with rubies and diamonds.

Madly Gems' brooch/ pendant with rare mandarin spessartite garnet.
Gioia's icy jade and gold dragon ring.

site_title: Fund managers must walk the sustainability talk to effect change
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest fund manager, has announced a significant pivot towards sustainability, with Larry Fink stating that climate change will force a "significant reallocation of capital". The firm plans to reduce exposure to thermal coal producers and vote against companies not making progress on sustainability. This move could signal an inflection point in the rise of sustainable finance, as the UN warns that inaction on climate change will lead to drastic emissions reductions. However, BlackRock's voting record has been mixed, with a recent report showing that the firm voted with management more often than its peers.

site_title: Festive Blockbusters
summary: Chinese New Year brings a surge of star-studded blockbusters to Singapore cinemas, including Enter the Fat Dragon (Jan 23) starring Donnie Yen and Jackie Chan's Vanguard (Jan 25). The latter is touted as Chinese cinema's answer to Hollywood's Fast and Furious franchise. A reboot of All's Well Ends Well also opens on the same day, led by an ensemble cast. These films offer a festive break from house visits during the holiday period.

site_title: Tech groups cannot be allowed to hide from scrutiny
summary: Technology companies wield significant influence over governments, with many relying on private sector infrastructure and AI. However, a growing information asymmetry exists between companies and governments, with companies resisting transparency and accountability. This has profound implications for democracy, as governments and companies have different incentives for openness and secrecy. Companies prioritize protecting trade secrets, while governments value transparency. This lack of oversight raises concerns about the potential for companies to manipulate data and influence elections, posing a threat to democratic institutions. Governments must find ways to balance their dependence on private sector technology with accountability and oversight.

site_title: China renews 'Belt and Road' push for global sway
summary: China has renewed its push for the Belt and Road Initiative, a program aimed at building ports, rail lines, and telecommunications networks worldwide to increase Beijing's global sway. The initiative, which had seemed to be running out of steam, has come back strong, raising concerns among Western officials and companies about potential losses in business and political clout. The US is particularly wary, fearing a bloc of nations tilting toward China's authoritarian model and mostly buying Chinese goods. This move may heighten tensions with the US.

site_title: Ellipsiz restructures vending business with JV exit, fresh investment
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Ellipsiz has exited its loss-making joint venture Kalms Investment Pte Ltd (KIPL) and instead invested S$500,000 in Indovend, a newly-incorporated company involved in vending machines. Ellipsiz's restructuring aims to exit a loss-making venture and immediately pursue the business independently. The company has transferred its stake in KIPL and assigned its loans to Kalms International, allowing EIR to engage in the same vending-solutions business in nine South-east Asian countries, excluding others.

site_title: Bon Again
summary: Bon Iver, a Grammy-winning indie folk rock act, is set to play a concert in Singapore on January 17, 2024, after selling out its last gig in 2016. The concert comes in support of the band's fourth studio album, i,i, released in 2019. The album marks the culmination of a cycle of work that began with Bon Iver's debut album For Emma, Forever Ago in 2008. Lead singer Justin Vernon describes the album as a record about deciphering and bolstering one's identity.

site_title: Time for executive salaries to take ESG into account
summary: Executive salaries should consider environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, according to Business Roundtable leaders. Companies like Royal DSM NV and Royal Dutch Shell plc have already linked pay to ESG goals, but only a small portion of total pay is currently tied to these metrics. Experts argue that clear and quantifiable ESG pay metrics are necessary to hold executives accountable. A sustainability adjustment to financial incentives, such as penalizing executives for neglecting stakeholders, could also be effective. Ultimately, a shift towards stakeholder capitalism may require rethinking the quantum of executive pay.

site_title: Over 20,000 apply to be Japanese billionaire's girlfriend
summary: Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa has received over 20,000 applications to be his girlfriend ahead of his moon voyage, with a documentary on his search for a "life partner" airing on AbemaTV. The streaming service, backed by online ad agency CyberAgent, has seen a surge in social media traffic and views following Maezawa's US$9 million giveaway to his followers. The application site includes a "love diagnostic test" and features multiple-choice questions to assess compatibility. Maezawa's moon voyage on Elon Musk's SpaceX rocket is set to generate significant buzz.

site_title: China's home price growth at almost 1½-year low in December
summary: China's new home prices grew at their weakest pace in 17 months in December, with average prices rising 6.6% in 70 major cities, slowing from a 7.1% gain in the previous month. This is the slowest pace since July 2018 and weaker than the 9.7% gain in December 2018. Analysts forecast a further slowdown in the market, with some cities relaxing rules to foster stability. Despite this, home prices marked the 56th straight month of gains, as policymakers aim to avoid squashing the property market amid slowing economic growth.

site_title: Bartenders among rising number who go dry
summary: A growing number of bartenders, like Jade Golden, are choosing sobriety, challenging traditional industry norms. The trend, driven by increased awareness of addiction and mental health, is reflected in the rising popularity of low-alcohol and nonalcoholic beverages. Nonalcoholic bars and venerable cocktail bars are adapting by adding booze-free drinks to their menus. Industry professionals, including Jack McGarry and Joanna Carpenter, attribute the shift to a combination of factors, including the #MeToo movement and the digital age's increased openness about substance abuse.

site_title: Minister drops hints on what's coming in Budget
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing hinted that more companies may be able to participate in government-led programs to enhance competitiveness and scale. This is likely to be announced in the upcoming Budget 2020 on February 18. The move aims to strengthen the competitiveness of local businesses.

site_title: Bending it like Beckham: when and why people bend the rules
summary: Research on professional football found that players often "bend the rules" to gain strategic advantage, blurring the line between compliance and rule-breaking. Fouling, typically seen as a rash move, was found to be a calculated decision, with players more likely to commit fouls when their team was ahead or when they were recently robbed of the ball. Time-wasting, another grey area, was also analyzed, revealing that players deliberately delay resumption of play to gain a competitive edge, potentially costing fans up to five minutes of lost gameplay per match.

images.alt_text: Managers should be wary of stoking their team's competitive passions to the point that employees would gladly bend or break rules in order to win, especially when loss framing is introduced to raise the stakes.

site_title: Saudi society is changing. Just take a look at these coffee shops
summary: In Saudi Arabia, the ultra-conservative social and religious codes are slowly relaxing, as seen in the increasing number of coffee shops allowing men and women to mix. The government's recent decision to drop segregation requirements for businesses has led to a surge in establishments offering mixed spaces, such as Nabt Fenjan and Draft Café. While some customers have reacted negatively to the change, others have welcomed it as a sign of a more open and inclusive society. The shift is also reflected in the growing number of women working in coffee shops and other industries, with some entrepreneurs opening spaces where Saudis can meet like-minded people of both sexes.

images.alt_text: Nabt Fenjan, a coffee shop in Riyadh originally opened only for women, began allowing male and female customers to mix in late 2018.

site_title: SGX RegCo's proposals aimed at healing trust deficit
summary: SGX RegCo launched a public consultation on proposals to enhance oversight of auditors and property valuers dealing with listed companies. The proposals aim to address the trust deficit, globally, particularly in audits. Key measures include appointing an additional auditor and requiring all listed companies to have a Singapore-based auditor. The goal is to improve the quality of work and restore trust in the market.

site_title: Reunion Dinners from the heart
summary: Chinese New Year dishes from the heart are shared by four chefs. LAP Fai Master Chef Hua Ting reminisces about her mother's simple yet lovingly prepared reunion dinners, featuring fried glutinous rice and roast duck. Cheung Siu Kong shares his fond memories of his family's reunion dinners, including savoury glutinous rice balls and suan pan zi. Martin Foo Group Executive Chef Crystal Jade Group highlights Hainanese chicken rice and suan pan zi as family favorites. Edward Chong, Executive Chinese Chef Peach Blossoms, recalls his mother's mushroom stuffed with fresh prawn paste and steamed kampong chicken as his favorite reunion dishes.

site_title: Commodities may not stay cheap forever
summary: Commodities have remained relatively cheap due to a long-term downward trend in industrial commodity prices and structural factors such as substitutions, technological advancements, and energy conservation. Despite a rising US equity market, commodities have been relatively inexpensive relative to stocks, with the exception of a few spikes. Factors such as a deflationary world, ageing populations, and a push towards renewable energy may keep commodities cheap, but some experts predict a potential shift towards gold and commodity assets if the US dollar weakens.

site_title: Show Me The Money
summary: Local creative brand Pine on Paper has released a new line of angpao designs, available for S$12 for a pack of six. The designs, inspired by various motifs such as batik, Ocean Jasper, and daffodils, can be used for all occasions and celebrations beyond Chinese New Year. The designs were created in collaboration with artists Pearlyn and Paper and Dora Prints and Paper Goods.

site_title: Green Fingers
summary: Veteran journalist Pauline Dawn Loh has written a memoir, "Dawn In The Garden: A Gardener's Memoir," detailing her love of plants and gardening in various locations worldwide. Loh's passion for botany began in her grandmother's garden and continued throughout her travels, including Hong Kong, San Francisco, and China. The book features watercolour illustrations by Bee KC Tan and chronicles her experiences with plants over the decades, providing a personal and visually stunning account of her love for gardening.

site_title: WeChat looks to edge out rivals with new features
summary: WeChat, a messaging super app developed by Tencent, is rolling out new features to edge out competitors, particularly in China's short-video boom. The platform will allow users to create short-form video content, directly competing with ByteDance's TikTok. WeChat founder Allen Zhang aims to retain users through features like mini programs, which enable users to buy train tickets and hail cabs, and a new pay wall feature for publishers. Despite a decline in instant messaging usage, WeChat's mini programs have seen significant growth, and the company hopes to monetize its platform through increased advertising exposure and e-commerce functionality.

images.alt_text: WeChat Mini Programs celebrating its third anniversary at the 2020 WeChat Open Class PRO event in Guangzhou.

site_title: Special Feature: Reunion with Style at Raffles Hotel Singapore
summary: Celebrity chef Jereme Leung shares his Lunar New Year memories and festive menus at his restaurant 藝 yì at Raffles Hotel Singapore. YU SHENG, a Singaporean dish, is a highlight, featuring freshly-made ingredients and a homemade Yunnan rose dressing. This marks the first year the dish is served at 藝 yì, with attention to detail in presentation, including a beautiful takeaway carrier.

site_title: Gin And Laksa
summary: Local food pairing event CIN CIN Gin & Food Pairing series showcases locally-made gin paired with popular hawker favorites like chicken rice, laksa, and Peranakan otak-otak. The three-course tasting menu, curated by head bartender Fadly Sujebto, highlights the suitability of local gin with spicy food. The event features brands such as Brass Lion Singapore Dry and Tanglin Orchid Gin, and is priced at S$85++ for up to six guests. Reservations can be made through the provided link.

site_title: STI jumps 0.7% on trade deal signing
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) jumped 0.65% to close at 3,278.67, following the signing of the US-China "phase one" trade deal, which boosted most Asian markets. China's markets retreated, however, due to concerns the deal's positive impact is limited for their economy. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index rose 0.7%, while South Korea's KOSPI climbed 0.8%. Singapore's top traded stocks, including Singtel and OCBC Bank, also ended higher.

site_title: Asia-Pac IPO share sales hit US$5.9b in just 15 days into 2020
summary: Asia-Pacific initial public offering (IPO) share sales reached US$5.9 billion in the first 15 days of 2020, the highest since 2007. Chinese companies accounted for 97% of the proceeds, driven by a strong fundraising period. This marks the fastest pace of IPO share sales in the region since the global financial crisis.

site_title: BreadTalk expects FY2019 net loss on HK unrest, F&B weakness
summary: BreadTalk Group expects a net loss for FY2019 due to weakness in its bakery and food concept divisions, and the turmoil in Hong Kong. The company expects significant deterioration in its Hong Kong business, including bakery and food atrium divisions, and widening losses at its Chinese and Thai bakery businesses. Despite lower sales in Hong Kong, BreadTalk has not laid off staff and plans to maintain its presence in the market.

site_title: TEE International secures Singapore project, renews Thailand contracts
summary: TEE International secured an engineering maintenance contract in Singapore and renewed contracts in Thailand. The company will provide services for a Grade-A office building and retail space in the Marina Bay Area, and will operate and manage the Lat Krabang affordable housing estate for nine more years. Additionally, TEE International received a five-year renewal on its contract with the Bangkok Metropolitan Administration to manage a wastewater treatment plant. The company's interim CEO Eric Phua emphasized the company's focus on technology advancements and delivering high-quality projects.

site_title: US retail sales increase in Dec; Nov sales revised up
summary: US retail sales rose 0.3% in December, marking the third consecutive month of growth, despite a decline in motor vehicle sales and a drop in foot traffic in malls. Excluding automobiles, core retail sales increased 0.5%. The strong sales data suggests the US economy maintained a moderate growth pace at the end of 2019, driven by consumer spending and higher savings.

site_title: German drug assessment body not convinced by Bayer's cancer drug Vitrakvi
summary: Germany's drug assessment body has expressed concerns over Bayer's cancer drug Vitrakvi, stating that data provided by the company does not demonstrate clear benefits. This setback comes as Bayer faces declining revenues from its two bestsellers, prompting concerns about its drug development pipeline. Despite European approval in September, Bayer's peak sales expectations of over €750 million have not been met, casting doubt on the company's financial outlook.

site_title: A Drive To Succeed
summary: Entrepreneurs Terence and Nelson Loh, founders of Novena Global Lifecare Group, attribute their success to disrupting existing industries in response to technological shifts and changing consumer habits. They express admiration for the Lamborghini Urus, a super SUV that helped nearly double Lamborghini's sales in 2019. The Lohs emphasize the importance of staying open to new ideas, trusting intuition, and embracing data to drive innovation. They also highlight the value of creativity and taking calculated risks to achieve success, likening the Urus to an example of disrupting one's own industry.

site_title: Gap in US-Sino influence in S-E Asia widening in China's favour
summary: A survey of 1,300 individuals in South-east Asia found that China's influence in the region is widening, while the US influence is declining. 60.4% of respondents have little to no confidence that China will "do the right thing." Respondents suggest that ASEAN should focus on building resilience and unity to counter the US-China rivalry. The survey highlights a growing divide in perceptions of China's role in global affairs.

site_title: French unions vow to stand firm as pension strike softens
summary: French unions have vowed to continue their strike against a pension overhaul, with about 452,000 people protesting across France on the sixth day of demonstrations. The strike, which has snarled train traffic and caused misery for millions of commuters, comes after Prime Minister Edouard Philippe temporarily withdrew a measure that would have forced people to work until 64 to qualify for a full pension. The unions, however, remain determined to stand firm, with some calling for port blockades and other walkouts.

site_title: EU says will assess if US-China deal meets global trade rules
summary: The European Union's trade chief, Phil Hogan, announced that the bloc will assess whether the US-China trade deal, signed to boost US-China trade by $200 billion over two years, complies with global trade rules, specifically the World Trade Organization (WTO) regulations. Hogan stated, "The devil is in the detail," emphasizing the need for thorough evaluation. This assessment aims to ensure the deal aligns with international trade standards, which may impact the agreement's implementation and effectiveness.

site_title: Rex unit secures stakes in two Norwegian Sea licences
summary: Lime Petroleum, a 90% unit of Rex International, secured stakes in two Norwegian Sea licences through the 2019 Awards in Predefined Areas round. Lime will hold 20% and 30% stakes in PL1061 and PL1062, respectively. The licences, located near the Åsgard complex, have significant exploration potential, according to Rex's proprietary de-risking technology. The initial two-year period will involve geological and geophysical analysis, followed by "drill-or-drop" decisions. This award allows Lime to have a continuous pipeline of exploration drilling projects in the short term.

site_title: Record 45 million need urgent food aid in southern Africa: UN
summary: Approximately 45 million people in southern Africa require urgent food aid due to drought, flooding, and economic hardship. The World Food Programme warns that a severe hunger crisis is unfolding, with families skipping meals, selling assets, and falling into debt. The region is experiencing its worst drought in 35 years, with temperatures rising twice as fast as the global average. The worst-hit countries include Eswatini, Lesotho, Madagascar, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Zambia, and Zimbabwe, where nearly half of Zimbabwe's population lives in chronic food insecurity.

site_title: Chasen to buy 30% stake in Vietnam unit for 6.665b dong
summary: Chasen Holdings has agreed to buy the remaining 30% stake in its Vietnam unit, Chasen Transport Logistics Company (Vietnam), for 6.665 billion dong (approximately $387,000). The acquisition aims to gain full control of the company to set a new direction for the Vietnam market. The deal is not expected to impact Chasen's performance for the financial year ending March 2020.

site_title: US: S&P 500 crosses 3,300 on trade deal, Morgan Stanley earnings
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the S&P 500 crossing 3,300 for the first time, and the Dow and Nasdaq opening at new highs. The trade deal between the US and China was signed, boosting investor sentiment. Morgan Stanley reported strong earnings, further fueling the rally. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 101.73 points, the S&P 500 opened 13.68 points higher, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 54.75 points. The market gains were despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims drop more than expected
summary: The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits dropped 10,000 to 204,000 for the week ended Jan 11, exceeding expectations. This marks the fifth consecutive weekly decline, indicating sustained labor market strength despite a recent slowdown in job growth. The four-week moving average of initial claims also fell 7,750 to 216,250. The data suggests the labor market remains on solid footing, with the unemployment rate near a 50-year low of 3.5% in December.

site_title: Muted reaction among currencies to US-China deal
summary: The signing of the Phase One trade deal between the US and China had a muted reaction among major currencies, with most expected outcomes already accounted for. The Euro/Dollar currency pair rose 0.1% to US$1.1161, while the US dollar index fell to an eight-day low of 97.134. The lack of tariff elimination and uncertainty surrounding the deal's impact on the global economy contributed to the subdued market response.

site_title: Competition watchdog seeks public feedback on ARA, Logos deal
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has launched a public consultation on a strategic deal between Logos Group and ARA Asset Management, involving the transfer of ARA's holdings in Cache Logistics Trust. The deal aims to create a single manager for the trust, but ARA Logistics claims it won't breach competition laws due to large competitors and high countervailing buyer power. The CCCS is seeking public feedback on the transaction until Jan 30.

site_title: These are the world's most expensive cities for luxuries
summary: Wealthy individuals should be cautious when spending on luxury goods and services in certain cities, according to Julius Baer Group's "Global Wealth and Lifestyle Report 2020". Hong Kong tops the list as the world's most expensive city, followed by Rio de Janeiro, New York, and London. The report highlights the growing trend of luxury services and experiences, such as fine dining and wellness, driving costs up. Other Asian cities like Shanghai, Tokyo, and Singapore also feature in the top half of the report, reflecting the growing opulence among the world's wealthy.

site_title: Wing Fong Court condo in Geylang up for en bloc sale
summary: A freehold condominium in Geylang, Wing Fong Court, has been launched for collective sale with a S$108 million reserve price. The 88-unit building, along with adjacent Wing Fong Mansions, is expected to be put on the market soon. The properties are zoned for commercial or institutional use and have a high land rate, making them attractive to foreign investors and Singapore developers. The open tender for Wing Fong Court closes on May 18, while Wing Fong Mansions has already received consent from 78.5% of owners for a collective sale.

site_title: Jobs from new investments mostly go to Singaporeans: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing stated that jobs created from new investments are predominantly filled by Singaporeans, with 85% of the resident workforce being Singaporean and 15% permanent residents. This ratio is consistent with the unemployment rate. Chan emphasized the need for a range of jobs to cater to older workers, despite an emphasis on high-tech sectors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.74 points to 1,587.88. The market saw 2.6 billion lots traded worth RM1.9 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 448 to 377.

site_title: US-China trade: truce, not peace
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to run for a second term, touting a "historic" trade deal with China as a major victory. The Phase 1 agreement, which cancels tariffs on some Chinese goods and increases Chinese purchases of US farm products, has been welcomed by corporate America and financial investors. However, the agreement's long-term impact on the US economy and jobs remains uncertain, and critics argue that the deal does not address the underlying issues driving the trade war. Trump's 25% tariffs on Chinese imports and Beijing's retaliatory tariffs remain in place, and the agreement does not address China's state-controlled economy or intellectual property concerns.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump's "big, beautiful monster" of a trade deal with Beijing could yet morph into a big monster if the US sees China as a global enemy in a new Cold War where the lines between geo-strategic and geo-economic interests are blurred.

site_title: IPC Corp issues profit warning for FY2019 results
summary: IPC Corp, a Mainboard-listed property developer, has issued a profit warning for FY2019 results due to a significant decrease in the fair value of its preference shares investment in Nest Hotel Japan. The company's 2018 annual report valued Nest Hotel Japan at S$34.6 million, but an independent valuation report indicates a lower fair value. This adjustment is expected to impact IPC's FY2019 results.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks climb amid cautious optimism after Sino-US trade deal
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.77% on Thursday, driven by gains in the automotive and pharmaceutical sectors, despite concerns over unresolved trade issues. The US-China trade deal, signed earlier, will roll back some tariffs but leave in place 25% tariffs on Chinese industrial goods. Investors remain cautious, as Phase 2 negotiations are expected to address structural economic issues. The KOSPI index gained 2.29% this year, and 6.8% in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing reported that jobs created from new investments in the country are mostly filled by Singaporeans, with an emphasis on high-tech sectors. The city-state exceeded its forecast with S$15.2 billion in fixed asset investments in 2019. Meanwhile, a group of investors in Hyflux is set to hold town halls on January 20, and CapitaLand won a tender to manage Bugis Village and Bugis Street.

site_title: Malaysia bets on diplomacy, not retaliation, to tackle India palm curbs
summary: Malaysia is choosing diplomacy over retaliation in its dispute with India over palm oil curbs. The move comes after India restricted imports of refined palm oil and asked traders to stop importing all kinds of palm oil from Malaysia in response to Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's criticism of India's policies. Malaysia's palm oil minister plans to engage with Indian industry and government officials to resolve the issue, treating it mainly as a trade issue. The country's exports to India were worth $10.8 billion in the previous fiscal year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with gains, driven by investors' positive reaction to the US-China trade deal. The Hang Seng index rose 0.38% to 28,883.04, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.52%. Despite the mixed performance in China, Hong Kong stocks ended on a positive note, with the benchmark Hang Seng index closing at a new high.

site_title: Qatar National Bank issues US$600m 40-year Formosa bond
summary: Qatar National Bank has issued a $600 million 40-year Formosa bond, marking efforts to diversify its funding sources. Morgan Stanley was the sole arranger of the transaction, which closed on Thursday. This deal offers Asian insurers and long-term investors securities matching their long-term commitments, following a trend of Gulf borrowers issuing sukuk bonds. The move comes as regional bond yields have fallen back after easing tensions in the region following a US drone strike on a top Iranian commander.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets steadied in initial trading, mirroring the performance of major Asian indices after the US and China sealed a trade deal. London's FTSE 100 index opened flat at 7,642.05 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gained 0.3% and 0.1%, respectively.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes slightly up following US-China deal
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed 0.07% higher at 23,933.13 following a US-China trade deal, despite thin trade. The deal pushed Wall Street to record highs overnight. Investors now await Japanese corporate results, set to be announced later this month. The agreement marks a step in ending global economic growth frictions, allowing traders to focus on other factors. Major shares like Sony and Fast Retailing rose, while SoftBank Group dropped.

site_title: Nestle to spend up to 2b Swiss francs on recycled-plastic plan
summary: Nestle plans to spend up to 2 billion Swiss francs (S$2.79 billion) to shift towards using more recycled plastic in its packaging. The company will pay a premium for food-grade recycled plastic due to limited supply and set up a 250 million franc venture-capital fund to develop new solutions. Nestle aims to keep the impact of this investment neutral on earnings through efficiencies. The move is part of the company's efforts to reduce its environmental footprint and increase its use of sustainable materials.

site_title: South Korea to decide on first transgender soldier amid debate
summary: South Korea's military will hold a meeting to discuss discharging the first transgender soldier who underwent gender reassignment surgery, sparking debate on the treatment of LGBT troops. The soldier, a staff sergeant, was discharged after expressing hope to continue serving in the female corps, as the military lacks regulations for transgender troops. Human rights groups criticized the military for discriminating against LGBT troops, urging them to reconsider the decision. The soldier's fate will be decided by the military next week, with some supporting their decision to serve and others advocating for their reapplication.

site_title: Pan Ocean to invest 157.4b won in 4 medium-range tankers
summary: Pan Ocean Co, a mainboard-listed shipping company, plans to invest 157.4 billion won (S$0.18 billion) in a shipbuilding contract for four medium-range tankers. The investment aims to strengthen the company's competitiveness. The first vessel is expected to be delivered in June 2021, subject to the shipbuilding process. This comes after Pan Ocean reported a 17% fall in sales to US$573 million and a 36.7% growth in earnings to US$45 million in Q3.

site_title: GuocoLand Q2 earnings triple on Martin Modern sales
summary: GuocoLand's Q2 earnings surged to S$32.4 million, tripling from S$10.9 million last year, driven by a doubling of revenue to S$299.6 million from Martin Modern sales. However, this was partly offset by a doubling in other expenses due to higher fair-value losses on derivative financial instruments. Earnings per share rose to 2.49 cents, while profits from associates and joint ventures dropped 89% to S$993,000.

site_title: Japan reports case of mystery virus behind China outbreak
summary: A case of the mystery respiratory infection related to the novel coronavirus has been confirmed in Japan, marking the second reported case outside China. The patient, who visited Wuhan, China, before being hospitalized, reported a persistent fever and was released on Wednesday. Authorities have urged people who developed a cough or fever after visiting Wuhan to wear a surgical mask and visit a medical institution. The outbreak has raised concerns about human-to-human transmission, with Chinese authorities suggesting it may have spread among family members.

images.alt_text: A case of the mystery respiratory infection related to the potentially deadly Sars virus, which first emerged in China, has been confirmed in Japan, authorities said Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia rejects all bids to buy its biggest highway operator
summary: Malaysia's government has rejected all bids to buy stakes in PLUS Malaysia Bhd, the nation's biggest highway concession-holder. The Cabinet has decided to maintain Khazanah Nasional Bhd and Employees Provident Fund's stakes in the company. In response to election pledges, the government plans to lower toll fares by 18% from the current rate, despite inflation or changes in traffic. This move aims to lower living costs and keep toll fares unchanged in 30 years' time.

site_title: Ex-Malaysian beauty queen, husband to pay RM3.5m to Q&M in settlement
summary: A former Mrs. Malaysia Universe, Zoe Chong Lee Lee, and her husband Matthew Hong An Liang, have agreed to pay RM3.5 million to Q&M Dental Group as part of a settlement for alleged breach of agreements. Q&M sued the couple in 2017 for depositing company funds into their personal accounts and setting up a competing dental clinic using Q&M's resources without permission. The duo had run Q&M dental clinics in Johor, Malaysia, before the lawsuit. The settlement amount includes S$1.2 million.

site_title: Hyundai, Kia invest US$110m in UK electric-van startup Arrival
summary: Hyundai and Kia have invested US$110 million in UK electric vehicle startup Arrival, which plans to begin selling battery-powered delivery vans in 2021. Arrival's vans will have a range of 300 miles and be built on a modular platform, similar to Rivian's skateboard design. The company will work with Hyundai and Kia to develop a variety of electric vehicles for the commercial market. Arrival has 800 employees in five countries and is testing its prototype vans with Royal Mail, DHL, and UPS.

site_title: Australia: Shares breach 7,000 level on Sino-US trade deal
summary: Australian shares broke the 7,000 level for the first time, rising 0.7% to a record close of 7,041.80, following the signing of a US-China trade deal.
