summary: China Everbright Water plans to issue 3 billion yuan (S$586 million) worth of medium-term notes in China's inter-bank bond market. The company aims to replenish working capital and optimize its financing structure. The notes will have a maturity of no more than five years and a coupon yet to be decided, with the first tranche of 800 million yuan. Approval from Chinese authorities is pending.

site_title: Mapletree Investments, MIT complete acquisition of 10 data centres
summary: Mapletree Investments and Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) have completed the acquisition of 10 powered shell data centres in North America for US$557.3 million through a 50:50 joint venture with Digital Realty. The deal includes an 80% interest in three existing Digital Realty hyperscale data centres. Following the acquisition, MIT's portfolio now comprises 87 industrial properties in Singapore and 27 data centres in North America.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines suspends taking delivery of Boeing 737 MAX jets due to grounding
summary: Malaysia Airlines has suspended taking delivery of 25 Boeing 737 MAX jets due to the grounded plane's delayed return to service. The airline cited the production stoppage and delayed return to service following two fatal crashes. This decision comes amid Boeing's worst annual net orders and lowest deliveries in 11 years due to the 737 MAX grounding. The Malaysian government is seeking a buyer for the debt-heavy airline, which is still recovering from the 2014 tragedies of MH370 and MH17.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS sees Fu Yu 'moulding for growth', initiates coverage with 'buy'
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on Fu Yu Corporation with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.35, citing a turnaround in the manufacturing sector, growth potential, and improving margins. The company's strong financial positioning, with no debt and high cash reserves, supports its dividend payout. However, risks include a slowdown in manufacturing activity and escalating trade tensions. The target price represents a 40% upside from the current price, with DBS analysts expecting an uptick in earnings and revenue for Fu Yu in 2020.

site_title: Forecast rain to bring both relief and new risks to fire-stricken Australia
summary: Australia is bracing for forecasted rain to bring relief to its worst bushfire season on record, with 100 blazes burning across NSW and Victoria. Heavy downpours could lead to landslides and water pollution, officials warned. The shift to more humid and wet weather may help control some fires and potentially extinguish others. The country has seen 28 deaths, over 2,500 homes destroyed, and bushland equivalent in size to Bulgaria ravaged since September.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slip as tariff comments dent trade deal optimism
summary: Japanese shares dropped 0.45% to 23,916.58, snapping a three-session winning streak, after US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said there was no agreement on further tariff reductions with China, denting trade deal optimism. The Nikkei has rallied nearly 20% since its August low on hopes of a truce.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei share average fell 0.45 per cent to 23,916.58, retreating from a four-week high of 24,060 touched the previous day, while the broader Topix lost 0.54 per cent to 1,731.06.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks snap 4-day gains ahead of trade deal signing
summary: South Korean stocks closed down 0.35% on Wednesday, snapping a 4-day winning streak, as investors awaited the fine print of a Phase 1 trade deal between the US and China. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's comments on maintaining tariffs on Chinese goods until the completion of a second phase agreement soured investor sentiment. Foreigners sold US$74.76 million worth of shares, while domestic investors were net buyers. The KOSPI has risen 1.52% this year, but the decline marks a reversal from its recent gains.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.08 points or 1.22% to 1,579.38 at 9:03am. The market saw 90.57 million lots traded worth RM20.15 million, with gainers beating losers 110 to 58.

site_title: Australia: Shares scale all-time peaks ahead of trade deal, New Zealand gains
summary: Australia's shares hit record highs ahead of the signing of a preliminary trade pact between China and the US, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.3% to 6,980.3. Mining stocks led the gains, with BHP Group soaring to a nearly one-month high. However, low trading volumes and concerns over the ongoing bushfires cast a pall over the market. New Zealand's benchmark also rose 0.3% as investors shifted focus to quarterly reports from miners and energy players.

site_title: Taiwan 'already independent', president warns China
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen has warned China that the island is already independent, saying it doesn't need to formally declare independence. Tsai won a second term with a record 8.2 million votes, a rebuke to China's efforts to isolate Taiwan. China views Taiwan as its own territory and has vowed to seize it by force if necessary. Tsai stated that invading Taiwan would be "very costly" for China, and she remains open to talks with Beijing without pre-conditions, despite Beijing's refusal to communicate with her administration.

site_title: Developers sell 538 private homes excluding ECs in Dec, down 53% m-o-m: URA
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 538 private homes in December 2019, a 53% decline from the previous month but a 10.6% increase from the same month last year. The fourth quarter sales totalled 2,635 units, a 43.5% increase from the same quarter in 2018. Yearly sales reached 10,104 units, 14.9% higher than 2018.

site_title: Rents for private non-landed homes and HDB flats rise in December 2019 from a year ago
summary: Rents for private non-landed homes and HDB flats in Singapore rose 3.7% and 1.3% in December 2019, respectively, from the previous year. Non-landed private home rents increased in all areas, with prime and core central region rising 3.9%, while HDB rents rose in December but remain 14.3% below their peak in August 2013. Rental volumes for private non-landed units fell 2.8% in December, while HDB rental volumes dropped 5.3% compared to December 2018.

site_title: Africa struggles to stem deadly flood of fake medicine
summary: African countries are struggling to combat the deadly flow of counterfeit medicine, with an estimated 100,000 people dying annually from taking fake medication. Weak laws, poor healthcare systems, and poverty have fueled the growth of the parallel market, with 42% of seized fake medicine coming from Africa since 2013. Efforts to crack down on the issue have made some headway, but the threat remains grave, with organized criminal networks involved and high profits for traffickers. A recent agreement signed by seven African countries aims to bolster cooperation and criminalize trafficking in fake drugs.

site_title: City Developments to issue S$200m of 5-year senior notes
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) plans to issue S$200 million of 5-year senior notes at par, with a 2.7% annual coupon. The notes will be listed on the Singapore Exchange and mature on January 23, 2025. Proceeds will be used for general working capital and corporate funding, or to refinance existing borrowings. CDL shares fell 1.6% to S$11.24 following the announcement.

site_title: Procurri scraps US$115m deal talks for business unit
summary: Procurri Corporation has terminated discussions over the sale of its third-party hardware maintenance business to Park Place Technologies for US$115 million. The decision comes after the two parties failed to agree on the final price and deal structure. The exclusivity period has been extended until 11.59pm New York City time on Tuesday, but further discussions will not proceed. Procurri shares fell 13.6% following the announcement.

site_title: Hong Kong protest shoppers show their true colours
summary: In Hong Kong, pro-democracy protesters are building a "yellow" economy by boycotting businesses that support the government and instead supporting shops and restaurants that show their support for the cause. This movement has been driven by a strong belief in human rights and democracy, and has led to a trend of "yellow" and "blue" labeling of businesses, with "blue" shops often being targeted by vandalism. The economy is experiencing its first annual contraction since 2009, and analysts say the protest movement is unlikely to reshape the city's economic landscape, but the "yellow" shoppers are adding fresh impetus to the protests.

images.alt_text: Seven months of unrest have taken a heavy toll on many Hong Kong businesses, but pro-democracy protesters are now seeking to reward shops and restaurants that support their cause by building a "yellow" economy.

site_title: Japan minister Koizumi to take paternity leave, aims to be role model
summary: Japanese environment minister Shinjiro Koizumi will announce he is taking paternity leave, aiming to be a role model for working fathers. The 2-week leave over 3 months is part of Japan's generous parental leave policies, which provide up to a year of partially paid leave. However, only 6% of eligible fathers take child care leave, falling short of the government's 13% target for 2020. Koizumi's move is seen as a response to criticism that men should prioritize their public duties, and he may set an example for other Japanese men to follow.

site_title: Hyundai unveils first Genesis SUV in renewed overseas premium push
summary: Hyundai Motor unveiled its first Genesis SUV, a crucial move for the premium brand's expansion in overseas markets. The brand, spun off in 2015, aims to revamp Hyundai's image and reach in the US, where consumer preference has shifted to SUVs. The Genesis SUV lineup is expected to help the brand compete with other premium automakers. This move follows Hyundai's struggles with dealerships in the US and its limited reach in the country's largest overseas market. The Genesis SUV is a key part of Hyundai's premium push.

images.alt_text: South Korea's Hyundai Motor unveiled the first sport-utility vehicle (SUV) under its Genesis brand on Wednesday, a move analysts said was crucial for the premium marque's expansion in overseas markets.

site_title: US, China set to sign vital trade truce
summary: The US and China are set to sign a trade truce, allowing businesses to breathe a sigh of relief despite remaining tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars of two-way trade. The agreement includes pledges from China to boost purchases of American crops and products, boosting stock markets worldwide. However, the most difficult issues remain to be addressed in "phase two" negotiations, including massive subsidies and forced technology transfer. The deal is seen as a temporary reprieve, with US officials stating that tariffs will remain in place until a phase two agreement is reached.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks barely moved at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at the open on January 15, 2020, ahead of the China-US trade deal signing. The Hang Seng Index decreased 7.28 points to 28,877.86. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also showed minimal movement. The signing of the trade deal is expected to have a significant impact on the market, but for now, stocks are showing little reaction.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda says won't hesitate to ease further if needed
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank won't hesitate to ease monetary policy further if needed to achieve its 2% inflation target. Consumer inflation is expected to accelerate towards the target, but will be temporarily affected by declining oil prices. Kuroda emphasized the need for policy adjustments as necessary to address risks from overseas economies.

site_title: Asia: Markets retreat as US, China prepare to sign trade pact
summary: Asian markets retreated on Wednesday as investors took a cautious stance ahead of the signing of the US-China trade pact. The mini pact, which de-escalated a two-year standoff, saw the White House halve tariffs on $120 billion of Chinese goods and Beijing pledge to buy US products. Analysts expect little progress on the next phase of talks, citing key sticking points such as subsidies for state industry and forced technology transfer. The deal is seen as a step in the right direction, but investors are bracing for uncertainty ahead of the November US presidential election.

images.alt_text: Asian markets mostly fell on Wednesday as investors took their foot off the pedal following weeks of gains, with focus on the signing later in the day of the China-US trade deal.

site_title: Retail tech startup StoreHub bags US$8.9m in Series A+ round
summary: StoreHub, a Singapore retail tech startup, has secured US$8.9 million in Series A+ funding led by Vertex Ventures Southeast Asia & India. This round brings the company's total funding to US$15 million. The new investment will be used to expand the company's operations in the region. Founded in 2013, StoreHub has grown from 3,000 stores to over 13,000 stores in South-east Asia, with a team of 325 employees across multiple offices. The funding is seen as a validation of the platform's value, with a high retention rate and rapidly growing user base.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI slips 0.14%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index lost 4.47 points or 0.14% to 3,266.07 on Wednesday, following a choppy US trade session that saw stocks end mostly lower. Gainers outnumbered losers 60 to 44, with Thai Beverage rising 0.6% and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust gaining 1.7%. Local banks had mixed results, with DBS gaining 0.1% and OCBC Bank losing 0.5%. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed up 0.3% after two sessions of losses.

site_title: MAS launches new VCC grant scheme to defray costs for fund managers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a new variable capital companies (VCC) grant scheme to support fund managers in incorporating or registering VCCs. The scheme, funded by the Financial Sector Development Fund, will co-fund up to 70% of eligible expenses, capped at S$150,000 per application. The goal is to encourage industry adoption of the VCC framework, allowing fund managers to structure investment funds with more flexibility and cost savings. The scheme is available for up to three years, and 20 investment funds have already been incorporated or re-domiciled as VCCs as part of a pilot programme.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after three sessions of gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, ending a three-session winning streak as investors awaited the signing of a US-China trade deal. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.42% to 23,923.12, while the Topix index declined 0.39% to 1,733.81. The losses follow a strong rally in previous sessions.

site_title: US states oppose Trump proposal to ship LNG by rail, citing safety risk
summary: US attorneys general from 16 states oppose a Trump administration proposal to ship liquefied natural gas (LNG) by rail, citing safety risks. The proposal, which aims to help natural gas drillers and rail operators, has been met with concerns from states that argue any leaks could increase safety risks to residents and emergency responders. The proposal has not been withdrawn, despite calls for it to be pending completion of safety studies and an environmental impact statement.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, TEE Intl, Mapletree Industrial Trust, OUE, Golden Energy, JEP
summary: Singtel's Indian associate Bharti Airtel issued US$1 billion of convertible bonds and placed 323.6 million shares, raising S$2.74 billion. TEE International reported a widened net loss of S$35.9 million for its second quarter, with shares falling 10.9% to 5.7 Singapore cents.

site_title: Fosun to reduce stakes in two Brazilian financial firms: source
summary: China's Fosun International plans to reduce stakes in two Brazilian financial firms, Guide Investimentos and Rio Bravo, due to a recent review of its global portfolio. Fosun aims to find a partner to fund investments, potentially leading to complete divestment, to avoid self-funding expansion costs. The decision follows a valuation of Guide at 600 million reais (S$195.4 million) and losses of 1.3 million reais in the first nine months of last year. Fosun has hired Credit Suisse to sell the stakes, with negotiations ongoing.

site_title: Ukraine plane struck by two missiles: NYT
summary: A Ukrainian passenger jet was struck by two Iranian missiles shortly after takeoff, killing all 176 people on board. The missiles, fired 30 seconds apart, disabled the plane's transponder before hitting their target. Verified security camera footage shows the double projectiles gliding through the sky before impact. The incident remains a mystery until now, as the plane's transponder was initially reported as not working. The cause of the strike is attributed to the Iranian missiles.

site_title: London heads European investment in tech sector: study
summary: London maintained its top spot as the leading European city for tech investment in 2019, with $9.7 billion in funding, accounting for nearly a quarter of the $39.8 billion invested across Europe. This surpasses major cities like Berlin ($4.5 billion) and Paris ($3.3 billion). Financial sector start-ups, artificial energy, and clean energy drove growth, with British firms such as Monzo and WorldRemit securing funding. London has held the top spot for four consecutive years and is home to 46 high-growth unicorn tech businesses since 1990.

site_title: Go local when expanding into S-E Asia
summary: International companies expanding into South-east Asia should tailor their products to each market's unique nuances. The region's diverse business environments require firms to adapt, rather than treating all countries as a single entity. Experts emphasize the need for patience when doing business in Indonesia, where processes take time. Localizing products and understanding consumer behavior are crucial for success in the region.

site_title: Final passage of USMCA likely this week: top US senator
summary: The US Senate is expected to approve the USMCA (United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement) this week, a win for President Donald Trump. The landmark trade agreement has already cleared the US House and has bipartisan support. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stated that the approval is a "good news" for the country. The agreement updates rules on auto manufacturing, e-commerce, intellectual property, and labor provisions. The Senate Budget Committee approved legislation to implement the new deal earlier Tuesday, ahead of Trump's impeachment trial.

site_title: TEE Intl sinks deeper into the red in Q2 on TEE Land loss
summary: TEE Intl reported a widened net loss of S$35.9 million in Q2, primarily due to a S$13.8 million loss from a discontinued operation involving its subsidiary TEE Land. Revenue more than doubled to S$97.5 million, while operating expenses widened to S$22.5 million. The company proposed to sell its 63.2% stake in TEE Land for S$50.6 million. The group's loss per share stood at 3.79 cents, from a loss per share of 0.31 cent a year ago.

site_title: Singtel associate Airtel to issue US$1b of bonds, 144b rupees in shares
summary: Bharti Airtel, an associate of Singtel, plans to issue $1 billion in foreign-currency convertible bonds due 2025 and 323.6 million shares at 445 rupees each, raising $2.74 billion. The move comes ahead of a fine payment to the Indian government. The bonds can be converted into fully paid-up equity shares at a premium of 20% on the issue price. The issuance is part of Airtel's mega fundraising exercise.

site_title: China to ramp up US buys under trade deal, but skeptics question targets
summary: China has agreed to purchase nearly $80 billion of additional US manufactured goods over the next two years as part of a trade deal, with purchases of US energy supplies and services also expected to increase. The Phase 1 agreement, set to be signed on Wednesday, includes increases in agricultural goods, energy supplies, and services, but does not address future tariff reductions. Analysts question the realism of China's targets, citing concerns over price and supply risks, and skepticism about enforcement of the agreement. The deal aims to defuse tensions between the US and China, but its long-term impact remains uncertain.

site_title: US-China trade deal fully enforceable, documents to be released Wednesday: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that the first phase of the US-China trade agreement will be fully enforceable, including China's pledge to refrain from manipulating its currency. The agreement includes China's commitment to purchase $200 billion of additional US goods and services over the next two years. Documents detailing the trade deal will be released on Wednesday, when US President Donald Trump is set to sign the agreement with Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He at the White House.

site_title: China carrying out 'intense' global attack on rights: HRW
summary: Human Rights Watch (HRW) has accused China of carrying out the "most intense attack" on the global human rights system, using its economic and diplomatic might to suppress critics and undermine international institutions. The annual report, launched by HRW executive director Kenneth Roth, describes China's government as overseeing "the most brutal and pervasive oppression" in decades, including a "nightmarish surveillance system" in Xinjiang province. HRW urges democracies to counter Beijing's strategy by offering alternatives to Chinese loans and freezing the assets of officials involved in the crackdown.

site_title: UK reaches deal to keep Flybe flying
summary: The UK government has reached a deal with Flybe to keep the airline flying, preserving around 2,000 jobs. The agreement includes additional investments from Flybe shareholders and government initiatives to strengthen regional connectivity. Flybe will continue to operate as normal, with flights to 170 destinations across Europe. The deal comes after Flybe was in danger of ceasing operations, following the collapse of Thomas Cook and flybmi last year. The airline's CEO, Mark Anderson, described the outcome as "positive" for the UK.

site_title: Google says it will phase out web-tracking 'cookies'
summary: Google plans to phase out third-party "cookies" on its Chrome browser within two years, aiming to preserve online privacy while supporting ad-supported services. The company's "Sandbox" program will allow advertisers to deliver targeted messages without tracking users with snippets of code called "cookies." This move aims to replace cookies with new mechanisms, such as fingerprinting techniques, to ensure a private and secure web experience for users. The goal is to render third-party cookies obsolete, but it remains unclear if this shift may give Google more control over online advertising.

site_title: Bolivia arrests ex-minister under Morales for corruption: prosecutor
summary: Bolivia arrested Carlos Romero, former interior minister under Evo Morales, on suspicion of corruption. Romero, close to Morales, resigned in November amid protests over a disputed election and fled the country. He will now face a judge to determine his fate, which may include keeping him in custody, releasing him with charges, or placing him under house arrest.

images.alt_text: The detainee is Carlos Romero, the former interior minister who was close to Morales, who resigned in November amid protests over a disputed election and fled the country.

site_title: BlackRock CEO puts sustainability investing at core of strategy
summary: BlackRock CEO Laurence Fink emphasizes the importance of sustainability investing, stating it's the strongest foundation for client portfolios going forward. Climate change poses a long-term structural crisis, driving a significant reallocation of capital. The asset manager aims to deepen its commitment to sustainability, including articulating company purpose and serving stakeholders. Fink notes that investors are increasingly recognizing climate risk as investment risk, and companies that fail to address sustainability risks will face growing skepticism from the markets.

site_title: T-Mobile, Sprint say DOJ approval of merger deserves 'proper weight'
summary: T-Mobile and Sprint have asked a federal judge to consider the Trump administration's approval of their $26.5 billion merger, claiming a group of states that sued to block the deal did not impartially evaluate the companies' plan to preserve competition. The states, including New York and California, argue the DOJ's approval should be ignored, citing the agency's failure to properly investigate the merger. The companies assert the DOJ's review concluded the merger would result in lower prices and higher quality for consumers. The case will be ruled upon by US District Judge Victor Marrero this week.

site_title: Pinterest pops past Snapchat in US
summary: Pinterest surpassed Snapchat as the third most used social media platform in the US, with 82.4 million users, according to eMarketer. Pinterest's user base grew 9% in 2023, outpacing Snapchat's 80.2 million users. Pinterest's shares rose 10% following the report, with eMarketer predicting continued growth for the platform in the coming years. The platform's universal appeal and wide age range are attributed to its success.

site_title: Egypt fighter jet crashes during exercise, killing pilot
summary: An Egyptian fighter jet crashed during a training exercise on January 14, 2020, killing its pilot. The incident occurred while the military was conducting exercises aimed at combating militant activity in northern Sinai. This is the second fighter jet crash in Egypt in recent months, following a December incident where the pilot ejected safely. Egypt has been involved in a long-standing conflict in Libya and has also been conducting military operations in North Sinai, resulting in over 830 suspected militant deaths and 60 security personnel fatalities.

site_title: Amazon reinstates FedEx for some Prime deliveries
summary: Amazon has reinstated FedEx for some Prime deliveries after banning the freight service during the holiday period due to performance concerns. FedEx is now "consistently" meeting on-time delivery requirements and can be used by third-party merchants for Prime orders. This decision comes after FedEx shifted its focus to Amazon rivals and Amazon bolstered its own logistics network.

site_title: US slaps sanctions over North Korea workers but appeals for dialogue
summary: The US imposed sanctions on two companies, Korea Namgang Trading Corporation and Beijing Sukbakso, for exploiting North Korean overseas labor, freezing their US assets and making transactions with them a crime. The move aims to curb North Korea's cash flow, as the regime is believed to earn illicit revenue from the exportation of workers. US officials and allies Japan and South Korea called for diplomacy to ease tensions with Pyongyang, following North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's threat to launch a new weapon.

site_title: Golden Energy unit to buy Australia gold mine for up to A$300m
summary: Golden Energy and Resources will acquire the Ravenswood gold mine in Australia for up to A$300 million through a joint venture with EMR Capital. The mine is currently owned by Carpentaria Gold and its parent Resolute Mining. The deal marks a significant expansion for Golden Energy, which is a mainboard-listed thermal coal miner. The joint venture, named Mining Gold Group, is expected to acquire the mine from the current owners, with the terms of the deal subject to due diligence and regulatory approvals.

site_title: Europe: LVMH rally boosts shares ahead of US-China trade deal
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, boosted by a rally in LVMH and Taylor Wimpey ahead of the signing of a US-China trade deal. The deal, set to be signed in Washington on Wednesday, marks the first step in winding down the 18-month trade war. Luxury stocks, including LVMH, rose after UBS analysts predicted a busy year for the sector, while homebuilder Taylor Wimpey jumped 3.9% after reporting a 22% jump in its order book.

site_title: Ghosn's wife slams Japanese justice
summary: Former Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn and his wife Carole have reunited in Beirut, where they claim to be united against Japan's justice system. Carole Ghosn has slammed Japanese authorities, calling the charges against her "a bit of a joke" and accusing them of being vindictive. Carlos Ghosn denies all charges and claims he was treated unfairly after his arrest in Japan, where he was held in isolation and prevented from speaking to his wife. The couple's lawyer is pushing for Ghosn to stand trial in Lebanon, but they do not want their case to hurt relations with Japan.

site_title: McDonald's sprinkles some MSG in race to best chicken sandwich
summary: McDonald's is testing fried-chicken sandwiches with MSG, a flavor enhancer that has drawn health concerns. The move is part of the company's effort to compete with Chick-fil-A. MSG adds a savory taste but has been a topic of debate among consumers. The company is testing the sandwiches in an attempt to improve its offerings.

site_title: Tech change brings about wave of opportunities in S-E Asia
summary: Singapore firms are capitalizing on the region's growing digital economy, with 76% of companies intending to expand into Southeast Asia. The top destinations are Vietnam, Indonesia, and Malaysia. Rapid technological advancements are fueling the growth of the region's internet economy, projected to triple in size by 2025. Companies are pushing for digital transformation to improve operational efficiency and serve digital-first customers. Logistics players are also seeking to merge technology into their operations, with initiatives like the Eastern Economic Corridor in Thailand and the Southern Transport Corridor connecting China to ASEAN. The Singapore brand is seen as a trusted and efficient partner, making it easier for companies to enter the region.

site_title: UK PM Johnson challenges US critics of Huawei
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson challenged US critics of Huawei, the Chinese telecoms giant, to come up with a better alternative as Britain considers letting Huawei develop its 5G network. Johnson said the British public deserves access to the best technology, but US officials fear Huawei's employees could spy for Beijing authorities and China could shut down rival nations' 5G communications in case of war. A final decision on Huawei's involvement has been delayed due to Brexit debates, with the Foreign Office set to issue a ruling in due course.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Tuesday challenged US opponents of Britain's potential decision to let China's Huawei telecoms giant develop its 5G network to come up with a better choice.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase, Citi surge on Q4 profits; Wells Fargo stumbles again
summary: US banking giants JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup reported strong profits in Q4, with JPMorgan's net income surging 20.6% to $8.5 billion and Citigroup's profits jumping 15% to $5.0 billion. The banks cited growth in credit card businesses and improved institutional client sentiment as key drivers. In contrast, Wells Fargo suffered another earnings stumble, with net income falling 55.4% to $2.5 billion due to high litigation costs. The banks' earnings results were driven by the resolution of trade issues and the holiday season's "robust" spending.

site_title: World's second-largest jeweller to shut down about a fifth of its Hong Kong stores
summary: Hong Kong jeweller Chow Tai Fook plans to shut about 15 stores in the city due to "macro headwinds" from protests, volatile gold prices, and US-China trade tensions. This marks the second significant pullback by a luxury retailer, following months of anti-China protests that have driven tourists away. The move is part of a broader contraction in Hong Kong's retail and tourism sector, with over 5,600 retail jobs at risk of being lost.

site_title: Yen is key to Japan buying abroad, not hedging or yields
summary: The cost of yen hedging has fallen to 2% over the past year, making it cheaper for Japanese investors to buy overseas assets. However, historical data suggests the yen's value, not hedging costs or yields, is the key driver of Japanese investment abroad. The yen's strength has consistently corresponded with increased overseas security purchases, while periods of weakness have led to decreases. Despite lower hedging costs, the pace of foreign purchases has slowed, and investors are now focusing on seeking positive returns or taking currency risks when the yen appreciates.

site_title: Australia 'open for business', Morrison tells tourists
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison has urged foreign tourists to visit the country despite raging bushfires, following a downgrade of the US travel warning from Level Two to Level One. The fires have killed 28 people, destroyed over 2,500 homes, and ravaged forests and farmland. Morrison said Australia is "open for business," but warned that the threat from bushfires is far from over. The fires have also created an ecological disaster for native species and have damaged the country's tourism industry, which accounts for over 3% of its annual economic output.

site_title: Encryption battle reignited as US government at loggerheads with Apple
summary: The US government is at odds with Apple over unlocking two iPhones in a mass shooting investigation, reviving a debate over law enforcement access to encrypted devices. Attorney General Bill Barr claims Apple failed to provide substantial assistance, while Apple disputes the claim and argues against backdoors for law enforcement. The dispute highlights the tension between law enforcement and the tech sector over encryption, with digital rights activists warning that any privileged access would weaken security and make it easier for hackers and authoritarian governments to intercept messages.

site_title: Carlos Ghosn's latest quest is mission impossible
summary: Carlos Ghosn, the former head of Renault and Nissan, has staged an extraordinary press conference from Lebanon, where he's in hiding from Japanese authorities who accuse him of financial misconduct. Ghosn claims he was unfairly treated and maintained his confidence, despite his arrest in 2018. He expressed regret over declining a 2009 GM offer and criticized the media for overlooking Mary Barra's salary. However, his bellicose attitude and justification of his worth by referencing numerous management books and case studies have raised concerns about his hubris and unattainable goal of rebuilding his reputation.

site_title: Seoul promises more ways to curb home price hikes
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in pledged stronger measures to curb rising home prices, citing excess liquidity and low global interest rates as the cause. If prices don't cool, the government will implement "endless" measures to address the issue. This comes as South Korea faces similar housing price hikes as other countries. The president's commitment aims to rein in speculative money in real estate and stabilize the market.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Sustainability through innovation with Rolls-Royce
summary: The Money FM podcast "Workday Afternoon: The Soul of Business: Sustainability through innovation with Rolls-Royce" discussed the company's approach to sustainability through innovation. Rolls-Royce emphasized the importance of adopting environmentally friendly practices and investing in sustainable technologies to reduce its carbon footprint. The company highlighted its efforts in reducing waste and energy consumption, as well as its commitment to using renewable energy sources. The podcast concluded that innovation is key to achieving sustainability goals, and Rolls-Royce's approach serves as a model for other businesses to follow.

site_title: Cyber security remains a challenge with threat of 'deep fakes'
summary: Cybersecurity experts warn of a growing threat of "deep fakes" in 2020, where sophisticated AI and machine learning technologies can mimic voices and pictures of actual people. This poses a significant challenge to traditional security protocols and could lead to widespread social disruption. With an estimated US$6 trillion in annual cybercrime losses, regulators and experts must prioritize employee training to differentiate between legacy phishing schemes and deep fake attacks. A shortage of skilled cyber security professionals also persists, with 3.5 million unfilled jobs globally by 2021.

site_title: The role of trust in business success
summary: A study by researchers at SMU's Lee Kong Chian School of Business found that integrity plays a crucial role in building trust across 30 countries, except for Ethiopia. The study, which spanned six continents, suggests that businesses should focus on creating a reputation for integrity to gain an edge over the competition. A higher willingness to trust others is also linked to societies with high levels of uncertainty avoidance, such as Singapore. The researchers argue that building safety nets and structures to facilitate trust-building can enable risk-taking and foster a greater willingness to trust others.

site_title: Top weather forecaster ramps up computing power for predictions
summary: The European Centre for Medium-range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) is upgrading its supercomputer to improve weather forecasting accuracy. A four-year contract worth over 80 million euros has been signed with Atos to supply a new supercomputer, which will enable more detailed forecasts for smaller areas and extended-range forecasts up to six weeks ahead. The upgrade aims to address the increasing impact of severe weather and climate change, with scientists linking extreme events to global warming. The new system will boost computing capacity by five times, placing it among the world's top 10 supercomputers.

site_title: BT gets on Habitap app to reach 60,000 users with business news
summary: The Business Times (BT) has partnered with Habitap, a smart office and smart home platform, to reach 60,000 users through its app. BT will provide complimentary business news to Habitap users, expanding its reach to non-traditional audiences. The partnership aims to introduce new readers to BT's content and build connectivity with users. Habitap's CEO, Franklin Tang, believes the partnership will enhance users' experience with daily news and innovative smart features.

site_title: Utico to hold townhall next week for Hyflux PnP investors, noteholders
summary: Utico, a Middle Eastern utility firm, will hold a townhall next week to address concerns of Hyflux's PnP investors and noteholders. The event aims to alleviate concerns about Utico's ability to deliver on its offer, particularly the additional payout from the second option. The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) has expressed pressing concerns about the deal terms, including a change in the upfront payment and deferred payment options, and has called for a full understanding of the fees paid to advisory firms.

site_title: Lucien Wong continues as Attorney-General for a second term
summary: Lucien Wong has been reappointed as Attorney-General of Singapore for a second term, with his tenure extended to 2023. In a recent speech, Wong hinted at his intention to serve a second term, and the decision was made to formalize this. The extension will allow Wong and his leadership team to continue their stewardship of the Attorney-General's Chambers.

site_title: A smoother channel for settling disputes
summary: International mediation is becoming a cost-effective means for small businesses to resolve commercial disputes. With the increasing number of smaller enterprises doing business internationally, mediation offers a flexible and confidential forum for businesses to resolve their differences. The Singapore Convention on Mediation, signed by 51 countries, provides an international legal framework for recognizing and enforcing mediated settlement agreements. The use of technology, such as artificial intelligence, is also facilitating online dispute resolution. As a result, mediation advocacy has emerged as a new legal specialisation, focusing on helping clients make smart business choices to resolve disputes.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end choppy session lower
summary: US stocks ended a choppy session lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.1%, the S&P 500 down 0.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index also dipping 0.2%. The report that the US could maintain tariffs on $300 billion in Chinese goods past November 2020 weighed on stocks, despite a partial trade deal expected to be signed. JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup rose, while Wells Fargo fell 5.4% after missing earnings expectations. The market had finished at all-time highs on Monday, with investors expecting a pullback following a surge in recent weeks.

site_title: Emerging markets' outlook: Subdued growth not bad news
summary: Emerging markets' outlook for 2020 is expected to be subdued but stable, with global monetary policy accommodation remaining largely in place. EM fixed income is forecast to deliver more subdued returns, while local rates in countries with disinflationary or stable inflation dynamics and generous real rates may offer value. Emerging market currencies could also provide value due to their underperformance against the US dollar in 2019.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: HC Surgical Specialists signed a three-year agreement with The Prestige Hospital in Cambodia, marking its entry into the South-east Asian market. This deal is expected to create an additional revenue stream and aligns with the group's long-term plans for regional expansion. Miyoshi, a manufacturer, reported a net loss of S$314,000 for its first quarter, mainly due to lower sales orders from China and the Philippines. Trendlines Group, a startup incubator, is in negotiations for the sale of one of its portfolio companies, which could have a material positive impact on its net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: Asia-Pac real estate investment tipped to return 5.4% in 2020
summary: M&G Real Estate forecasts 5.4% total returns for Asia-Pacific real estate investment in 2020, driven by accommodative macro policies and strong demand in logistics and office sectors. Logistics are expected to return 8.8%, while offices are forecasted to return 6.7% on an unlevered basis. This suggests a resilient real estate market in the region.

site_title: Gearing up even when bets are off
summary: Mooreast Asia, a mooring systems fabrication and supply business, has navigated a challenging year despite global economic uncertainty and an industry slump. The company has diversified into new sectors, including offshore renewable energy, and set up an engineering centre to support product innovation. Mooreast's readiness to transform, financial prudence, and staff confidence have enabled it to maintain a steady revenue of S$20 million. The company aims to expand into West Africa and has joined the Scale-up SG programme to boost its internationalisation efforts. With a focus on developing new capabilities and partnerships, Mooreast is well-positioned to capitalize on emerging opportunities in the renewable energy sector.

site_title: MOM raises penalties for unfair hiring practices; firm charged over false declaration
summary: The Ministry of Manpower in Singapore has increased penalties for unfair hiring practices, including the possibility of barring employers from renewing work passes for existing workers during a period of debarment. This change applies to employers caught discriminating in the recruitment of workers, with the previous debarment only applying to new applications. The move aims to deter unfair hiring practices and ensure a level playing field for all job seekers.

site_title: Oil edges up after five days of losses ahead of US-China trade pact
summary: Oil prices edged up on Tuesday after five days of losses, as the US and China prepared to sign a preliminary trade deal and as Middle East tensions eased. Brent futures rose 0.5% to $64.49 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 0.3% to $58.23, settling below the second month for the first time since November 19. The increase was attributed to traders' relief over the trade deal and easing tensions.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged higher on Tuesday after five days of declines as the United States and China prepared to sign a preliminary trade deal and as Middle East tensions eased.

site_title: Singapore Dec bunker sales rebound on IMO rules, despite annual drop: MPA
summary: Singapore's bunker sales rebounded in December, reaching the highest level since January 2018, with 4.5 million tonnes sold, driven by increased demand for low-sulphur fuel to meet International Maritime Organization (IMO) rules. Despite a 5% drop in 2019 sales, Singapore's bunker sales in December soared as vessels globally switched to cleaner fuels. The IMO rules cap sulphur content at 0.5%, boosting demand for low-sulphur bunkers, which rose to 3.1 million tonnes in December.

site_title: Global growth will continue to slow in new decade
summary: Global growth is expected to slow in the new decade, with the International Monetary Fund projecting L-shaped recoveries rather than V-shaped ones. The US, Europe, and Japan will experience slowing growth, with US potential growth at around 1.75%, Europe's at 1.3%, and Japan's at 0.5%. China's growth rate is expected to fall to 4% due to demographic and economic shifts. Emerging markets, including Latin America and India, will face headwinds due to declining commodity prices and inefficient economies. Policymakers will need to address these challenges to mitigate the impact of slowing growth.

site_title: Struggling Hong Kong theme park to end dolphin shows
summary: Hong Kong theme park Ocean Park will end its dolphin and sea lion shows, but allow visitors to hug dolphins. The park's chairman, Leo Kung, announced the change, stating that the "Ocean Wonder show will cease" and be replaced with "underwater viewing opportunities." This move has drawn criticism from animal-rights groups, who had previously protested the park's dolphin shows.

images.alt_text: Ocean Park said on Monday that it would replace the daily shows in its main enclosure with underwater viewing opportunities for visitors. But visitors will, for a fee, still be allowed to feed and pose with dolphins in the water.

site_title: GoImpact to start ESG fund under Singapore variable capital company scheme
summary: GOImpact, a Hong Kong-based sustainable finance platform, plans to launch an Asia-focused ESG fund in Q1 2020 under Singapore's variable capital company scheme. The fund is one of 20 participating in the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) VCC pilot programme and is the only ESG fund in the inaugural batch. GoImpact co-founder Helene Li made the announcement.

site_title: Finance companies to crank up game as digibanks target SME turf
summary: Singapore's three finance companies, Hong Leong Finance, Sing Investments & Finance, and Singapura Finance, face a tougher fight defending their turf in the SME segment as digital banks enter the market. The companies must ramp up their technology transformation, partner with innovative startups, or risk being left behind. Despite recent growth, finance companies may struggle to compete with digital banks' speed, simplicity, and potentially lower interest rates. The companies are exploring partnerships with fintechs, but analysts warn that incremental changes may not be enough to maintain their lead, and the finance companies' traditional customer base may be at risk.

site_title: STI advances as US-China tensions thaw
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Tuesday, erasing previous day's losses, as US-China tensions thawed. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,270.54, up 19.47 points. Most Asian indices followed suit, except for China and Hong Kong. This comes as the US and China signaled a thaw in tensions, bolstering market optimism.

site_title: Investors should hedge against geopolitical risks: UBS strategists
summary: UBS strategists advise investors to hedge against geopolitical risks in 2020, citing heightened anxiety from the US-China trade war, US presidential elections, and Brexit fallout. The bank favors regions and markets with domestic revenue, such as China, and consumer-focused companies. Key areas to watch include 5G smartphone deployment and the rivalry between the US and China, which could boost hardware and semiconductor stocks. UBS also expects earnings to rise 10% this year and recommends a long position in the US 10-year treasury as a hedge against geopolitical risks.

site_title: ST Engg partners SUTD to train 1,000 staff in design thinking
summary: ST Engineering partners with Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) to train 1,000 staff in design thinking. The partnership aims to equip employees with skills to approach problem-solving through a user's lens and develop new perspectives and creativity. A three-day MRO-centric design-thinking course and a two-year "ModularMasters" programme will be co-developed, allowing staff to advance to SUTD's Master of Innovation by Design degree programme. This collaboration builds on ST Engineering's past design innovation training and is expected to enhance employees' flexibility and learning opportunities.

site_title: Banks and payments players need to change their playbook
summary: The traditional banking and payment systems are evolving, with digital-native companies offering various services, including payments, to become one-stop solutions. By 2022, e-wallet payments are expected to account for almost half of e-commerce payments and over a quarter of point-of-sale payments globally. The rise of super-apps in Asia, such as Grab and WeChat, is driving this change, with providers using payments to build out broader ecosystems. To remain competitive, banks and payment companies need to adapt and become true business partners with their clients, helping merchants to sell more and create better experiences for consumers.

site_title: Emerging markets are facing growth slowdown, says IIF
summary: Emerging markets are facing a slowdown in growth, according to the Institute of International Finance (IIF), citing "secular stagnation". Since the 2008 financial crisis, developed nations' growth has outpaced that of emerging markets. The IIF estimates global growth slowed to 2.6% in 2019 and will only recover modestly to 2.8% in 2020. The World Bank also revised growth down in roughly two-thirds of countries it covers, citing a re-escalation of trade tensions and financial turmoil as major risks. Policymakers are urged to undertake structural reforms to achieve sustained growth.

site_title: Parasite director Bong says 'language barrier' broken after Oscar nod
summary: Korean film director Bong Joon-ho expressed surprise and joy after his movie "Parasite" received six Oscar nominations, a historic first for South Korea's film industry. The dark comedy, which explores class disparity in South Korea, also snagged nominations for best director and best screenplay. The film's success marks a breakthrough for South Korean cinema, demonstrating that language is no longer a barrier to global success. This achievement is seen as a significant milestone for the country's film industry.

site_title: COE supply for February-April dips
summary: The Land Transport Authority announced a reduction in certificates of entitlement (COEs) for the February-April quota period, with approximately 6,350 COEs available for bidding each month, down from 6,830 in the current period.

site_title: Abercrombie & Fitch willing to walk away from any mall to shrink footprint
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch is willing to close any mall to shrink its store footprint, with CEO Fran Horowitz prioritizing store adjustments in 2020. The teen retailer has closed about 500 stores over the decade, with 677 stores across the US as of November 2019. Shares jumped 6.9% after CEO Scott Lipesky stated the company is willing to walk away from any mall. The retailer aims to reduce its flagship stores, with 12 remaining by the end of 2020, as e-commerce improves its online sales to 30% of its business.

site_title: Shippers' container lashing row flares up
summary: Container ship operators are refusing to comply with the Dockers' Clause, a 2018 agreement that requires qualified dock workers to handle cargo handling services, not ship's crew. The clause, which was meant to improve safety, has been challenged by operators in Europe and Canada, who argue it restricts competition and increases costs. The International Transport Workers' Federation (ITF) and dockers' unions are preparing for a battle, with the ITF stating that the agreement is legally binding and must be enforced. The dispute is set to impact global trade, with crews typically coming from Asia and employed by regional shipmanagers.

site_title: HK pledges HK$10b in economic relief amid unrest
summary: Hong Kong's chief executive Carrie Lam pledged HK$10 billion in economic relief measures to address the city's recession, its first in a decade, amid months of anti-government protests. The measures target the elderly, unemployed, and low-income residents, including cash handouts and benefits. The proposal brings the total stimulus to HK$35 billion since the protests escalated in June. Economists say the initiatives may help some affected residents but are unlikely to have a significant economic impact.

images.alt_text: Mrs Lam joined other government officials at a regional financial forum on Monday in praising Hong Kong's resilience as a financial hub.

site_title: December US consumer prices rise less than expected
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in December, less than expected, and underlying inflation pressures retreated. This suggests the Federal Reserve may keep interest rates unchanged for the rest of the year. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, increased 0.1% and was up 2.3% year-over-year, the largest gain since October 2018. The slight increase in prices is a relief for policymakers, who had expected higher inflation and may have considered rate hikes.

site_title: Credit ratings, bond insurance were no protection in 2008 crisis
summary: Credit ratings and bond insurance were deemed ineffective in protecting retail investors during the 2008 global financial crisis. The retail bonds working group is studying proposals to require minimum credit ratings and bond insurance to safeguard retail investors. However, experts argue that overreliance on credit ratings and inadequate investor education contributed to the crisis. Analysts suggest that credit ratings may not be effective in predicting defaults, and bond insurance may only transfer risk to the insurer rather than eliminating it. Regulatory measures, combined with investor education, are seen as crucial in protecting retail investors from excessive risks.

site_title: HK regulator ends UBS's IPO sponsorship ban early
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) lifted the 10-month ban on UBS sponsoring initial public offerings (IPOs) with immediate effect, citing enhanced governance processes. The ban was initially set for one year due to UBS's due diligence failings on three prior IPOs.

site_title: Shift priorities from short to long-term issues: SBF chief to firms
summary: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) chief Ho Meng Kit warns that businesses are prioritizing short-term issues, such as rising costs and wages, over long-term concerns like training employees and hiring younger workers. The SBF's latest annual survey found that tax reliefs and easier access to government resources are top concerns for businesses, with 55% of companies seeking corporate or personal income tax rate reductions and corporate tax rebates. Industry players attribute this focus to immediate needs due to the fallout from China's economic slowdown and the trade war.

site_title: Will bushfires affect Australian Open tennis?
summary: Australian Open tennis tournament is expected to proceed as scheduled despite deteriorating air pollution conditions in Melbourne due to bushfires, with toxic air pollution levels reaching "hazardous" levels. Officials have implemented measures to minimize health risks, including monitoring air quality and suspending practice sessions. Despite health concerns, tournament organizers and experts believe the tournament can go ahead, with one expert suggesting delaying or canceling the event if air quality remains low.

site_title: OUE pares stake in Gemdale Properties to 23.8%
summary: OUE has reduced its stake in Gemdale Properties to 23.8% by selling approximately 635.5 million shares at HK$0.91 each, generating a consideration of about HK$578 million. The disposal is not expected to impact the company's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Forensic accounting must be more robust
summary: Forensic accounting is insufficient to detect and prevent large-scale financial crimes. Bernie Madoff's $65 billion Ponzi scheme, uncovered in 2009, highlights the need for more robust analysis of vast amounts of data. Globally, fraud costs organizations $6.3 billion annually, with firms losing up to 5% of their revenues. The Association of Certified Fraud Examiners warns that ordinary organizations are falling victim to the issue, emphasizing the need for improved forensic accounting techniques to combat financial crimes.

site_title: Yum China working with Goldman, CICC on HK listing: sources
summary: Yum China Holdings is working with Goldman Sachs Group and China International Capital Corp on preparations for a potential second listing in Hong Kong. The move could raise up to $2 billion and bolster the city's efforts to attract marquee Chinese firms. A successful listing would be a vote of confidence in Hong Kong's financial hub, following Alibaba's $13 billion share sale in November. The company, which operates Pizza Hut and KFC restaurants in China, has seen its shares rise 88% since its 2016 debut.

site_title: Singapore condo resale volume shrinks 27.4% in 2019: SRX
summary: Singapore condominium resale volume decreased by 27.4% in 2019, with 9,017 units resold, according to SRX Property's report. In December 2019, an estimated 650 units were resold, a 15.4% drop from the previous month but a 21.5% increase from the same month last year. This marks a significant decline in resale activity, indicating a potential slowdown in the Singapore condominium market.

site_title: US-China geopolitical rivalry in 2020 and beyond
summary: A growing US-China tech war is decoupling global value chains, marking a new era of "techno-nationalism." The rivalry will disrupt trade and commerce, as American and Chinese firms shift focus to self-sufficient value chains. The US and its allies are implementing industrial policies to counter China's state-centric economic approach, including funding alternative 5G networks and creating strategic alliances. China's massive investments in key industries, such as semiconductors and AI, are expected to pose a significant challenge to US technological supremacy. The decoupling and techno-nationalist policies will alter global trade and commerce, creating new opportunities for restructuring supply chains and innovation.

site_title: Hotel firm Oyo lays off 10% of India staff
summary: Oyo, a major Indian hotel firm, is laying off 1,000 employees, or 10% of its local staff, due to allegations of bribery and pressure from Japanese backer SoftBank to cut costs. The move is part of the company's efforts to reorganize its teams and reduce its unprofitable properties. Oyo's founder, Ritesh Agarwal, acknowledged that the decision was "not an easy one" and assured employees of assistance during the transition. The layoffs follow reports of questionable practices, including bribery and fraudulent listings, which the company denies.

site_title: Airlines add flights to India to meet rising demand
summary: Airlines are expanding their services in India, driven by the country's growing demand for air travel. International airlines such as Singapore Airlines, Air France-KLM, and United Airlines have added new flights, increasing seat capacity by 25% and introducing non-stop services. This follows a trend of over 20 airlines adding services in the past few years. India is expected to become the world's third-largest aviation market by 2024, fueling the growth of air travel in the country.

site_title: Jamie Dimon says his retirement from JPMorgan is still five years away
summary: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase's CEO, has reiterated his plan to remain at the top of the bank for another five years, a statement he made almost six years ago. Despite the bank reporting the most profitable year in US history, Dimon's retirement timeline remains unchanged. He has stated that if a specific retirement date is set, the bank will announce it. Dimon is the last remaining CEO of the Wall Street giants who led the industry through the financial crisis.

site_title: Trump to headline Davos summit as Iran drops out
summary: US President Donald Trump will headline the 50th edition of the Davos forum, which begins on January 21, amid heightened tensions with Iran following a US drone strike that killed Revolutionary Guards commander Qasem Soleimani. The summit will focus on climate change and a more inclusive model of capitalism, with notable attendees including Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg and global leaders such as Chinese Vice Premier Han Zheng and German Chancellor Angela Merkel. The event comes as the world grapples with uncertainty in the Middle East and a growing climate crisis.

site_title: Muji owner suffers worst-ever drop in shares
summary: Ryohin Keikaku Co, the owner of Muji, reported a 19% drop in shares after cutting its profit forecast by 17% to 37.8 billion yen, citing uncertainty in East Asian operations. This is the largest-ever drop in shares. The move follows a decline in sales due to global economic uncertainty and increased competition. The retailer's full-year operating profit target has been lowered to 37.8 billion yen.

site_title: UBS wealth management job cull starts with cuts in Asia, Europe
summary: UBS Group has started a sweeping round of job cuts at its global wealth management unit in Europe and Asia, targeting dismissals across all levels. The cuts are aimed at reducing costs and speeding up decision-making, with the goal of turning around the unit. The restructuring, led by new co-heads Iqbal Khan and Tom Naratil, will affect around 500 employees, primarily in Europe and Asia. UBS plans to reorganize the business into three regions, eliminate a unit dedicated to ultra-rich clients, and introduce a new organizational structure.

site_title: Iran warns Europeans of 'consequences' in nuclear dispute
summary: Iran has warned Britain, France, and Germany that it will respond seriously and firmly to any disloyalty or unconstructive action if they trigger a dispute resolution mechanism under the 2015 nuclear deal. The mechanism was triggered due to Iran's failure to honour its commitments under the accord, which the US unilaterally pulled out of in 2018. Iran's foreign ministry stated that if the Europeans seek to abuse the process, they must be prepared to accept the consequences, implying a potential escalation of tensions.

site_title: China trade rebounds in December
summary: China's exports and imports rebounded in December, beating market expectations, as trade tensions eased and domestic demand picked up. Dollar-denominated exports rose 7.6% year-on-year, while imports increased 16.3% from a year ago. China's crude oil imports surged 9.5% in 2019, setting a record for the 17th straight year. The rebound comes ahead of the signing of a "Phase One" trade deal between Washington and Beijing, which is expected to see China purchasing $200 billion worth of US goods.

site_title: Opel to cut 2,100 jobs at three plants as carmakers retrench
summary: Opel, a German car-making division of PSA Group, plans to cut up to 2,100 jobs at three locations by 2025 due to a sales slowdown and technological disruption. The company will reopen a voluntary leave program to eliminate the positions, while also investing more in its Rüsselsheim plant. This move is part of a larger trend of carmakers retrenching globally, with over 80,000 jobs expected to be eliminated in the coming years.

site_title: US consumer prices increase moderately in December
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in December, slightly above forecast, and underlying inflation pressures retreated, suggesting the Federal Reserve may keep interest rates unchanged for now. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, edged up 0.1% after gaining 0.2% in November. The 12-month increase in the CPI was 2.3%, the largest gain since October 2018. The data supports the Fed's decision to keep interest rates steady in December, and may allow it to maintain its monetary policy stance for at least this year.

site_title: US House to vote on Wednesday on sending Trump impeachment charges
summary: The US House of Representatives is set to vote on Wednesday on sending formal impeachment charges against President Donald Trump to the Senate, following a previous impeachment by the House on charges of abusing power and obstructing Congress. The vote would allow the Senate to begin the trial, which is expected to acquit Trump, as no Republicans have voiced support for his removal. The trial could begin as early as this week, with opening arguments likely not heard until next week.

images.alt_text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi arrives to attend a Democratic caucus meeting on Capitol Hill. She told the party meeting that she would name the Democrats' team of "managers" who will lead the prosecution of Mr Trump at the trial.

site_title: US drops China 'currency manipulator' label, yuan gains
summary: The US dropped China from its list of currency manipulators, causing the yuan to climb to its highest level since July and the Japanese yen to plummet to an eight-month low. The decision is seen as a positive sign ahead of a trade deal between the two countries, with China pledging to buy $80 billion of US goods over two years. The yuan strengthened to 6.8731 per dollar, its strongest since late July, and the offshore yuan hit a six-month high. However, some analysts warn that optimism may be short-lived if tensions rise between the US and China.

site_title: E-commerce giants shouldn't give big discounts: India commission
summary: India's antitrust commission has launched a probe into Amazon and Walmart's Flipkart, citing allegations of deep discounting and preferential treatment for select sellers. The commission's chairman, Ashok Kumar Gupta, says e-commerce giants should not offer steep discounts, must disclose discounting policies, and ensure they do not drive brick-and-mortar rivals out of business. Gupta emphasizes the need for openness and transparency in discounting policies and customer data usage. The move comes ahead of Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos' visit to India, where small business owners plan protests against perceived unfair business practices.

site_title: China's ties with key european ally nosedive over Taiwan
summary: China's relationship with the Czech Republic has deteriorated due to disagreements over Taiwan, Huawei, and espionage. The Czech Republic, a key European ally, has signed a partnership treaty with Taipei, Taiwan, prompting China to suspend official contacts with Prague. The move has strained ties to the breaking point, with Czech President Milos Zeman cancelling a planned visit to China. China accuses Prague of interfering in its internal affairs and acting inappropriately on core interests. The incident marks a significant shift in Czech-Chinese relations, with the Czech Republic now siding with Taiwan over China's claims.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq pull back from records
summary: Major US indices, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, pulled back from record highs on Tuesday due to mixed banking earnings and the removal of the US currency manipulator label on China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.2% to 3,282.64 and the Nasdaq dropped 0.3% to 9,250.25. Despite this, US data showed modest consumer inflation, which is unlikely to impact the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates steady.

site_title: PSA International reports 5.2% volume growth in 2019
summary: PSA International reported a 5.2% volume growth in 2019, handling 85.2 million twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) at its global port projects. The growth was driven by new terminals and the expansion of its PSA Cargo Solutions arm. CEO Tan Chong Meng attributed the growth to broadening reach and offering greater connectivity to new economies, while aiming to empower supply chain stakeholders with greater intelligence and agility through the Internet of Logistics in 2020.

site_title: Europeans trigger dispute mechanism in Iran nuclear deal
summary: European countries, including France, Britain, and Germany, have formally triggered the dispute mechanism in Iran's nuclear deal, aiming to enforce compliance without joining the US's "maximum pressure" campaign. The move, triggered after Iran rolled back its commitments, could lead to the reimposition of UN sanctions. The European powers stated their goal is to resolve issues and bring Iran back into full compliance, rather than implementing maximum pressure, and have notified the EU and other parties to the agreement.

site_title: Enigma Group leads consortium for digital full bank licence
summary: A consortium led by Singapore-headquartered Enigma Group has applied for a digital full bank licence in Singapore, aiming to serve underbanked SMEs and the digital workforce. The consortium includes Qrypt Technologies, 2359 Media, Blockchain Worx, and Enigma Global Holdings. The proposed digital bank will leverage expertise in financial services, technology, and emerging technologies to create financial products for the target segments. This is part of 21 digital bank applications received by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, with 14 applications for a wholesale banking licence.

site_title: 'Potential corporate fundraising' behind share price jump: BlackGold
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources, a Catalist-listed coal-mining firm, saw its share price jump 25% to S$0.015 after revealing "unusual price and volume movements" may be due to potential corporate fundraising exercises. The company is exploring ways to improve operations capability and has previously disclosed this in October and November. However, discussions are preliminary and no definitive agreements have been reached. The company will provide updates on any material developments.

site_title: Nissan denies reported plans to split with France's Renault
summary: Nissan denies plans to split with Renault, contradicting a report suggesting a potential divorce due to the Carlos Ghosn scandal. The Japanese carmaker stated that the alliance, which also includes Mitsubishi Motors, is the source of its competitiveness and will continue to deliver "win-win results." Renault's new chief, Jean-Dominique Senard, also denied the reports, saying the alliance is "not dead" and will "show why" in the future. Nissan shares fell nearly 3% after the report, but the company's statement suggests the partnership will endure.

site_title: Panama Canal cuts down slots for ships due to droughts
summary: The Panama Canal will start charging a fixed $10,000 fee for vessels over 38m long, as well as a variable surcharge based on Gatun Lake levels, due to droughts affecting the waterway. The charge will be implemented on February 15. Canal administrator Ricaurte Vasquez announced the measures to maintain the canal's levels and access to the important trading route.

images.alt_text: Any vessel over 38m long will be charged US$10,000, along with a variable surcharge based on the level of Gatun Lake.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares settle higher on US-China trade deal optimism
summary: Japanese shares rose to four-week highs on Tuesday, driven by optimism over a US-China trade deal. The Nikkei share average advanced 0.7% to 24,025.17, while the Topix added 0.3% to 1,740.53. The expected signing of a Phase 1 trade deal supported risk assets, with investors brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Singapore shares rise 0.6% amid thawing US-China trade tensions
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% to 3,270.54, driven by US-China trade tensions easing. The US lifted the currency-manipulator label off China, boosting optimism. Financial stocks led gains, with DBS Group and United Overseas Bank advancing. Exceptions included media group Singapore Press Holdings and SATS, which fell. Market sentiment improved ahead of the signing of the "Phase One" trade deal and the lifting of the currency-manipulator label.

site_title: Utico to hold townhall next week for Hyflux PnP investors, noteholders
summary: Middle Eastern utility firm Utico will hold a townhall next week for Hyflux PnP investors and noteholders to address concerns about Utico's ability to deliver on its offer. The Securities Investors Association of Singapore will facilitate the event, which will also include advisers and selected press members. Utico has capped all legal and financial advisory fees at S$40 million under the definitive restructuring agreement. The event aims to alleviate concerns about the additional payout for PnP investors.

site_title: Harry, Meghan criticised after royal crisis summit
summary: Prince Harry and his wife Meghan faced fresh criticism after an emergency royal meeting to discuss their decision to step back from frontline royal duties. The Queen agreed to allow the couple to split their time between Canada and the UK, but critics say the decision may be a "surrender to the petulant, selfish demands" of the couple. The couple's future, including how they will be funded, is still to be decided, with 5% of their income coming from public funds and the rest from the Duchy of Cornwall.

site_title: Miyoshi sinks into red with Q1 net loss of S$314,000
summary: Miyoshi, a Singapore-based manufacturer, reported a net loss of S$314,000 for its first quarter ended Nov 30, down from a net profit of S$4.3 million a year ago. Revenue declined 3.5% to S$14 million, mainly due to lower sales orders from China and the Philippines. The company attributed the loss to the absence of a one-off gain and a share of loss from its associate Core Power, a Chinese electric vehicle company. Management is in discussions to resolve financial-reporting matters, and the outlook for the next 12 months remains cautious due to global economic challenges.

site_title: JEP unit served writ of summons, statement of claim in High Court
summary: JEP Holdings' wholly-owned unit, JEP Industrades, has been served a writ of summons and statement of claim by YG-1 Co in the High Court of Singapore for US$219,284.25 in outstanding payables from 2016. JEP Industrades must respond within eight days, failing which judgment may be entered against it. The claim is expected to have a minimal impact on JEP's financial position. The company has engaged legal counsel and will provide updates on developments as necessary.

site_title: Gallant Venture partners Japanese firm to pilot high-tech greenhouse
summary: Gallant Venture has partnered Obayashi Corporation to pilot a high-tech greenhouse on Bintan island in Indonesia, focusing on eco-tourism. The greenhouse, named the Gallant Obayashi Green Agritech Park, will use advanced environmental controls to cultivate premium crops with improved sustainability and higher yields. The project aims to reduce water usage and promote agri-technology as part of the park's drive to become an eco-tourism destination. The greenhouse is expected to be completed in the future, coinciding with the opening of the Bintan Resorts International Airport and the Bintan-Batam sea bridge.

site_title: Lucien Wong continues as Attorney-General for a second term
summary: Lucien Wong has been reappointed as Attorney-General for a second term, extending his tenure until 2023. In a recent speech, Wong hinted at a second term, and the AGC has now confirmed the extension. This decision comes as Wong and his leadership team prepare for the next chapter in the Attorney-General's Chambers' history.

images.alt_text: Even if he were to serve out his current term, Mr Wong is already the third-longest serving Attorney-General since Singapore's independence.

site_title: New Delhi greets Bezos with an antitrust complaint
summary: India's Competition Commission has launched an antitrust investigation into Amazon and Flipkart, the Indian e-commerce giant owned by Walmart. Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos visited India for the first time in over five years, but instead of a traditional welcome, the government has taken this opportunity to scrutinize the company's business practices. The investigation aims to examine Amazon's and Flipkart's market dominance and potential anti-competitive behaviors. This move is seen as a significant challenge to Amazon's growing presence in the Indian market.

site_title: COE supply for Feb-April period dips
summary: The Land Transport Authority announced that COE supply for the February-April period will be 6,350 per month, down from 6,830 in the current period. The supply for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp will average 1,945 per month, while commercial vehicle COE bidders will have 629 certificates per month. The drop is attributed to more people extending vehicle lifespan, with 49,726 COEs revalidated in the first nine months of 2019. Motor traders expect demand for new cars to remain weak due to the economic outlook.

site_title: UK bans using credit cards for gambling
summary: The UK government has banned gambling companies from accepting credit cards for bets starting April 14, in an effort to curb problem gambling. About 800,000 consumers use credit cards for gambling, with 22% estimated to be problem gamblers. This move follows stricter regulations introduced last year, including slashed stake limits on in-store betting terminals, and aims to protect consumers from potential addiction. The ban is expected to have a significant impact on the UK's £14.2 billion gaming industry.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks climb on imminent signing of US-China trade deal
summary: South Korean stocks rose for a fourth session on Tuesday, boosted by optimism over a preliminary US-China trade deal. The KOSPI closed up 9.62 points, or 0.43%, at 2238.88, its highest close since April 17, 2019. China has pledged to buy nearly $80 billion in US goods and energy supplies over two years under the Phase 1 trade deal set to be signed on Wednesday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
