summary: Duty Free International (DFI) reported a 48% drop in Q3 earnings to RM7.9 million, primarily due to increased financial expenses. Revenue rose 25.6% to RM197.2 million, driven by contributions from Brand Connect Group and duty-free trading. DFI attributed the decline to higher financial expenses, lower profit margins, and foreign exchange losses. The company plans to implement cost controls amid a challenging business environment. For 9MFY2020, earnings dropped 45.3% to RM20 million, with revenue rising 15.1% to RM447.5 million.

site_title: SATS unit wins 25-year cargo terminal concession in Saudi Arabia
summary: SATS Saudi Arabia Company, a unit of gateway services provider SATS, has won a 25-year cargo terminal concession in King Khalid International Airport (KKIA) in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The terminal, expected to be completed in mid-2022, will handle up to 600,000 tonnes of cargo annually, including a cold-chain facility for perishables and a dedicated lane for pharmaceuticals. This is SATS' second cargo operation in Saudi Arabia, following its win in 2016, and will enhance connectivity and quality assurance for customers.

site_title: New CEO tells staff Boeing must be 'transparent'
summary: Boeing's new CEO, David Calhoun, has emphasized the need for transparency and integrity in the company's culture. In an email to staff, Calhoun called for rebuilding trust with customers, partners, and regulators, particularly after the release of embarrassing employee emails. He stated that returning the grounded 737 MAX to service safely must be the company's primary focus, involving collaboration with regulators to ensure compliance. Calhoun also vowed to incorporate outside perspectives and hold the company accountable to the highest safety and quality standards.

site_title: AstraZeneca abandons fish oil pill for bad cholesterol
summary: AstraZeneca is abandoning its fish oil pill, Epanova, for treating high levels of LDL (bad) cholesterol due to low efficacy. The medicine, which combines omega-3 fatty acids with statins, failed to show a significant benefit in clinical trials. Epanova is already approved to treat high triglycerides and was acquired by AstraZeneca in 2013. The decision marks the end of the medicine's development for this specific indication.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong's stocks rose over 1% on Monday, driven by investors' optimism over the planned signing of the mini China-US trade deal. The Hang Seng index climbed 316.74 points to close at 28,954.94, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also increased. This positive start to the week follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record-breaking close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: SPH posts 17.2% fall in Q1 net profit on lower print ad revenue
summary: SPH posts a 17.2% decline in Q1 net profit to S$46.3 million due to lower print ad revenue, despite a 8.8% rise in digital ad revenue. The media segment's bottomline was also hit by one-time retrenchment costs. However, the property segment saw a 38.2% profit before tax increase to S$54.9 million, driven by a price adjustment and expanded student accommodation portfolio.

site_title: Singapore shares dip 0.2% ahead of US-China 'Phase One' deal signing
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.15% on Monday to 3,251.07, amidst calm market sentiment ahead of the US-China "Phase One" trade deal signing. The index is seen hovering around 3,195 as a potential support level, according to analysts. The local benchmark was weighed down by Singtel's 1.5% drop, but other stocks like Creative Technology and ST Engineering showed gains. Trading volume was high, with 1.36 billion securities traded.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 6.73 points to 1,584.73. The index saw 2.6 billion lots traded worth RM1.6 billion, with 429 losers and 419 gainers. This marks the first decline in the index since January 2020.

site_title: Walmart fires more than 50 staff in India but denies exit plans
summary: Walmart has fired over 50 employees in India, including eight senior executives, as part of its restructuring efforts to incorporate technology and integrate e-commerce with its brick-and-mortar wholesale business. The company denies plans to shut down its physical presence in the country, despite reports suggesting otherwise. Walmart remains committed to growing in India and is reviewing its corporate structure to operate more effectively, amid growing competition and regulatory pressure from the Indian government.

site_title: Cityneon buys US animated figures design firm in S$50m deal
summary: Cityneon Holdings acquired US-based animated figures design firm Animax Designs in a S$50 million deal. The firm, which counts Disney and Nickelodeon among clients, will contribute to Cityneon's revenue and profits post-acquisition. The acquisition brings further diversification to Cityneon's management team and is seen as a strategic move to build its own intellectual property. The deal follows Cityneon's delisting from the Singapore Exchange in February and its valuation now exceeding S$1 billion.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close near 9-month high on trade deal optimism
summary: South Korean shares closed near a nine-month high on Monday, driven by optimism over a US-China trade deal and improved earnings outlook for chipmakers. The Kospi index rose 1.04% to 2,229.26, its highest close since April 2019. The won hit a six-month high against the US dollar and strongest since May last year against the Japanese yen. Chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix saw their shares firm, while foreigners were net buyers of 257.3 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Pricey 'American Dream' mall places big bet on retail
summary: A $5 billion mega-mall, "American Dream," in New Jersey is opening with various attractions, including an indoor ski facility, Nickelodeon Universe theme park, and an NHL-size rink. The mall aims to draw 40-50 million visitors annually, with a focus on high-end retail and experiential shopping. However, environmental concerns and skepticism about the project's viability have been raised, with critics citing its carbon footprint and competition from existing malls in the area. Despite this, developers believe the project will be a success, citing its Instagram-worthy features and appeal to younger generations.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open with gains
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.3%, and Paris's CAC 40 up 0.2%. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare sectors. US stocks also reached fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher.

site_title: Qian Hu sweetens dividend as Q4 profit rises sevenfold
summary: Qian Hu, a fish service provider, reported a sevenfold increase in Q4 earnings to S$346,000 due to the absence of an impairment charge and growth in its aquaculture segment. Revenue fell 5.1% to S$19.6 million. The company declared a 0.3 cent per share dividend, up from 0.2 cent last year. Qian Hu's full-year earnings more than doubled to S$920,000, but revenue fell 10.2% to S$76.9 million. The company plans to focus on growing its aquaculture business and implementing new technologies.

site_title: Sias asks Hyflux to address 'pressing concerns' of PnP holders
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (Sias) has expressed concerns over the proposed Utico rescue deal for Hyflux, which holds "substantial debt" in perpetual preference shares and securities (PnP). Sias asked Hyflux to address pressing concerns from PnP holders, including the viability of Utico's financial obligations and the adviser fees of up to S$25 million payable to Hyflux adviser nTan Corporate Advisory. Sias also requested information on the Aqua Munda deal, including the identities of its principals and funding intentions.

site_title: Grab offers Chubb travel insurance on its app
summary: Grab users in Singapore can now purchase Chubb's travel insurance product, Travel Cover, directly through the ride-hailing app. Premiums start from S$2.50 per day for global travel. Users will receive discounts for repurchases and can save their travel profiles for easier future purchases. They can also get instant quotes and pay directly using GrabPay.

site_title: 'Joker' leads Oscar nominations with 11
summary: The film "Joker" led the nominations for the Oscars with 11 nods, including best picture and best actor for Joaquin Phoenix. The nominations also included films like "Ford v Ferrari," "The Irishman," and "Parasite," which is the first South Korean movie to be nominated in both the best picture and best international film categories. A record 62 women were nominated, and notable snubs included Robert De Niro, Jennifer Lopez, and Disney blockbusters "The Lion King" and "Frozen 2." The Oscars ceremony will take place on February 9.

images.alt_text: This image released by Warner Bros Pictures shows Joaquin Phoenix in a scene from "Joker." The film was nominated for an Oscar for best picture.

site_title: Bye, bye London: British fashion star Green makes his Paris debut
summary: British fashion star Craig Green is making his Paris debut, joining a growing list of designers fleeing London for the French capital. Green, who has won menswear designer of the year three times, is one of four newcomers to Paris Men's Fashion Week, which has become increasingly dominant in the fashion world. The move is seen as a "political message" to show that too many frontiers aren't good for the fashion system. Green will show alongside other British brands, including Dunhill and Paul Smith, on the final day of the menswear shows.

site_title: Australia's bushfire crisis turns off tourists
summary: Australia's bushfire crisis has damaged the country's reputation as a tourist destination, with thousands evacuated and international visitors cancelling flights. The US Department of State has upgraded its security advice, warning travelers to "exercise increased caution." The crisis has also resulted in widespread devastation, including burned koalas and destroyed homes, with families grieving the loss of loved ones and property. The international community has shown sympathy, but the crisis is likely to have a lasting impact on Australia's tourism industry.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Shell Singapore invests in a polycarbonate development unit at its Jurong Island plant. ESR and GIC are setting up a US$500m joint venture to develop logistics facilities in China. Cityneon buys US animated figures design firm Animax Designs in a S$50m deal. Aspen awards an RM617m construction contract to Kerjaya Prospek. USP shareholders call for the removal of 5 directors. The Straits Times Index fell 0.15% to 3,251.07, amid US-China trade tensions. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy shrank for the second month.

site_title: Darco Water proposes S$6.5m private placement to 3 investors
summary: Darco Water Technologies has proposed a S$6.5 million private placement to three investors, with 18.7 million new shares to be issued at S$0.35 apiece. The deal, worth 16.62% of the company's enlarged share capital, was facilitated by Qarah Consultancy and is expected to raise approximately S$6.3 million in net proceeds. The funds will be used for strategic investments, acquisitions, and expansion, with S$1.9 million allocated to working capital.

site_title: Ford's vehicle sales in China tumble for third consecutive year
summary: Ford Motor Co's vehicle sales in China plummeted 26.1% for the third consecutive year, with 146,473 vehicles sold in the fourth quarter and 567,854 in 2019. The decline is attributed to a weakened economy and trade dispute with the US. Despite this, Ford plans to launch over 30 new models, including electric vehicles, and strengthen its product lineup to mitigate external pressure and improve dealers' profitability.

site_title: Aspen awards RM617m construction contract to Kerjaya Prospek
summary: Aspen Vision City has awarded a RM617 million construction contract to Kerjaya Prospek for two projects in Penang, Malaysia. The projects include the Vivo Executive Apartment and Viio, with work expected to commence in February 2020 and complete within 38 months and three years, respectively. The contract does not significantly impact Aspen's financials, with shares slightly down 2.3% following the announcement.

site_title: EFA makes first close of planned US$300m APAC private credit fund
summary: EFA Group, a Singapore-based alternative asset manager, has completed the first close of its US$300 million Asia-Pacific direct-lending fund, targeting established companies in South-east Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. The fund, which focuses on natural resources, manufacturing, and logistics sectors, aims for a 12-15% net internal rate of return and will be a five-year closed-end fund with possible one-year extensions. This is EFA's second close-end credit fund, following a successful first fund launched in 2016, which deployed over US$400 million and delivered a 12% net annualized yield.

site_title: Japan's Abe warns conflict with Iran impacts entire world
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe warned that a military conflict with Iran would impact global peace and stability, during a five-day Gulf tour amid heightened tensions. Abe called for diplomatic efforts to defuse tensions and discussed regional security with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. Japan will not join a US-led coalition in the region, but will send a destroyer and aircraft for intelligence activities. Abe's tour aims to ease tensions and ensure a stable oil supply from Saudi Arabia.

site_title: ESR, GIC setting up US$500m JV to invest in China logistics real estate
summary: ESR Cayman and Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC are establishing a $500 million joint venture to develop institutional-grade logistics facilities in China. The venture is subject to regulatory approval and follows their previous partnership in Japan. ESR's China portfolio includes 6.62 million square meters of gross floor area, with total assets under management exceeding $4.39 billion. The joint venture is expected to support China's growing e-commerce market, driven by demand for modern warehousing infrastructure.

site_title: Light on the horizon for Asia-Pac airlines: DBS
summary: Asia-Pacific airlines are expected to see a recovery in earnings for 2020, driven by a bottoming of the global economy and better supply-demand dynamics. The International Air Transport Association projects an aggregate profit of US$6.0 billion for FY20, up from US$4.9 billion in FY19. DBS analysts predict that Chinese carriers will clock the strongest recovery, with Air China as their top pick. Regional airlines are expected to have stable or improved passenger load factors, and passenger yields are forecast to stay firm or rise marginally.

site_title: Wanted: Girlfriend to fly to the Moon with Japan tycoon
summary: Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa has launched an online ad seeking a girlfriend to fly around the Moon with him on a SpaceX rocket in 2023 or later. Maezawa, 44, who recently broke up with a Japanese actress, is accepting applications from single women aged 20 or over who want to experience life to the fullest. The matchmaking exercise will be turned into a TV show, with Maezawa going on dates with applicants before making a final selection by the end of March.

site_title: Korea tourism stocks jump on bets for return of Chinese visitors
summary: Korean tourism stocks surged as analysts predict a return of Chinese visitors following the resolution of long-standing disputes between China and South Korea. Cosmetics producer Amorepacific Corp and travel agency Modetour Network Inc saw significant gains, with Amorepacific climbing 6.6% and Modetour Network rising 7.7%. Chinese tour agencies have started selling packages to South Korea again, with research indicating group-package trips are resuming, particularly for the upcoming spring festival. This positive trend is expected to benefit companies in the beauty and travel industries.

site_title: UAE's ADNOC agrees gas, petrochemical deals with two Indonesian firms
summary: ADNOC, the UAE's state-owned oil company, signed agreements with Indonesian firms Pertamina and Chandra Asri for gas and petrochemical deals. The deals include supplying 528,000 tonnes of liquid petroleum gas (LPG) to Pertamina by the end of 2020.

site_title: Australia: Energy, healthcare sectors drag Aussie shares lower; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares ended 0.4% lower on Monday, led by the energy and healthcare sectors, amid concerns over the US-China trade deal and the impact of bushfires on the country's economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,903.70, with energy stocks dropping 1.1% and healthcare stocks falling 1.1%. The US-China trade deal is set to be signed this week, but analysts warn that enforcement issues may hinder further negotiation progress. The bushfires have killed 27 people and scorched over 10.3 million hectares of land, with economists lowering their growth expectations for Australia's GDP to 2.1% from 2.4%.

site_title: Understanding China's BRI in Laos
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) in Laos is a continuation of the country's existing development strategies, rather than a new initiative. The China-Laos Railway, a $5.95 billion project, is an intensified and accelerated version of plans to integrate the region, which date back to the 1995 ASEAN Summit. The project is expected to significantly change Laos' physical, economic, and social landscape, but its impact is also influenced by local residents' aspirations and fears about Chinese encroachment on the local economy.

site_title: China's yuan at strongest since july amid trade deal optimism
summary: China's yuan strengthened to a five-month high, reaching 6.8968 against the US dollar ahead of a planned trade deal signing with the US. The currency rose 0.32% in morning trading, its strongest level since July 31. The trade deal, set to be signed by Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He on January 13-15, is expected to boost investor sentiment and fuel further yuan appreciation. However, analysts warn that the yuan's rally may be limited if another trade agreement beyond Phase 1 is unlikely before US elections in November.

site_title: Australian 'megablaze' brought under control
summary: Australian firefighters have finally brought under control the country's largest "megablaze," the Gospers Mountain fire, after almost three months of burning. The fire, which seared an area three times the size of Greater London, has ravaged national parks and killed an estimated one billion animals. Wet weather is expected to bring relief, with some areas potentially receiving up to 50mm of rain. The fire has also had a devastating impact on the environment and has sparked widespread criticism of Prime Minister Scott Morrison's handling of the crisis, with his approval ratings plummeting.

images.alt_text: Exhausted firefighters said they had finally brought Australia's largest "megablaze" under control on Monday, as wet weather promised to deliver much-needed respite for countryside ravaged by bushfires.

site_title: China disposes of 2t yuan of bad loans in 2019: regulator
summary: China's banking regulator announced that the country disposed of around 2 trillion yuan in non-performing loans in 2019 as part of a national campaign to restrict high-risk lending. The total assets of the country's shadow banking sector fell by 16 trillion yuan over the past three years. Despite this, loans to the real economy increased to 17 trillion yuan in 2019, up 7% from the previous year. The regulator also promised to support the struggling pig farming sector and introduce green finance products to promote environmental protection.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon down 0.07% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading Monday afternoon down 0.07% at 3,253.77 points, following a 0.4% gain on Thursday. The index saw 695.3 million shares traded worth S$407.6 million. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS gaining 0.6%, United Overseas Bank inching up 0.1%, and OCBC Bank falling 0.3%. Other notable movers included AusGroup up 2% and OEL up 15%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.47% to 28,772.37, driven by anticipation of the planned signing of the China-US trade deal this week. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index remained largely unchanged, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.06%.

site_title: Philippines: Financial markets shut after volcano spews ash over Manila
summary: Philippine financial markets were shut on Monday due to a volcano spewing ash over Manila, posing a risk to employee and trader safety. Markets for stocks, fixed-income, and dollar-peso spot trading were suspended. Regular fixed-income trading and settlement operations were expected to resume on Tuesday.

site_title: With nothing to lose, loners build future in China's hollowed-out north
summary: In China's far north, a small group of loners, mostly millennials, are moving to hollowed-out cities like Hegang in Heilongjiang province to build a future. With high living costs and economic growth at a 30-year low, affordable homes in these cities are attracting individuals seeking to save costs. Li Hai, a 32-year-old ship mechanic, and Zheng Qian, a 26-year-old internet marketer, are among those embracing this trend, with some even gaining online fame through social media.

site_title: Diesel exporter India buying from offshore before emission rules
summary: India, a major diesel exporter, is importing large quantities of the fuel ahead of new emission rules taking effect in April. In December, India imported 293,000 tons of diesel, a five-fold jump from November, despite remaining a net exporter. The country is importing ultra-low-sulfur diesel to comply with Bharat Stage VI standards, which mandate a maximum sulfur content of 0.001%. Indian Oil Corp and Bharat Petroleum Corp are stocking up on the cleaner fuel until refineries are upgraded. Imports are expected to ease off gradually as refineries resume production after planned maintenance.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam says financial hub's strengths intact despite protests
summary: Hong Kong chief executive Carrie Lam stated that the city's financial hub strengths remain intact despite months of pro-democracy protests. She expressed confidence in bridging divisions and achieving a reunited community and a flourishing economy.

site_title: Citi's Morse sees better commodities year but flags risks
summary: Citigroup's global head of commodities research, Edward Morse, predicts a positive year for commodities due to expected global growth, particularly in emerging markets. Demand for commodities is likely to increase, attracting investor inflows and supporting higher prices. However, Morse flags seven significant risks, including the impact of US-China trade relations, lower Chinese growth, and OPEC+ surprises on oil prices. Despite these risks, Morse expects a better year for commodities than previously feared.

site_title: World's most precious metal leaves everything else in the dust
summary: Rhodium, a rare and expensive metal used in autocatalysts, surged 32% this month, reaching its highest level since 2008, at $7,975 an ounce. The price rally, driven by stricter emissions rules and speculation, has outperformed other major commodities over the past four years. Tight supplies and industrial demand from the car sector have fueled the price surge, with some predicting it could reach a record $10,100. The metal's small market and lack of trading on exchanges make it vulnerable to price volatility.

site_title: Viking Offshore inks pact for proposed S$5m placement
summary: Viking Offshore and Marine has entered into a conditional placement agreement with Ruddin Advisory and Blue Ocean Capital Partners to raise S$5 million through a new share placement. The deal, subject to court-supervised debt restructuring, will see Ruddin Advisory subscribe for 53% of the enlarged share base for S$4 million and Blue Ocean take a 13.5% stake for S$1 million. The placement is part of the company's efforts to restructure its debt and improve its financial position.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as US-Iran conflict, bushfires curb risk appetite
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.4% on Monday, retreating from record highs due to concerns over the US-Iran conflict and deadly bushfires. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell, with heavyweight financial stocks and mining stocks also dipping. Investors are cautious about the impact of the bushfires on the economy, leading to speculation of an interest rate cut by the central bank. The market is also awaiting the signing of a Phase 1 trade deal between China and the US.

site_title: Koh Brothers to sell condo units in Van Holland to CEO's children
summary: The Koh Brothers Group has granted siblings Benjamin Koh Yong Jun and Rachel Koh Han Ling the option to purchase two condo units in its Van Holland development at discounted prices of S$1.5 million and S$2 million, respectively. The sale prices are 3% below the public list price, granted to all employees and their immediate families. The units, located on the third storey of Block 188, are part of the 69-unit development along Holland Road, which is set to obtain its temporary occupation permit in March 2023.

site_title: Singapore's Golden Equator expands to Brunei
summary: Golden Equator Group, a Singapore-based conglomerate, has expanded into Brunei with a S$24.6 million strategic investment. The company plans to establish three businesses in Brunei, including a multi-family office, consulting arm, and workspace subsidiary. The investment was led by Japanese serial entrepreneur Taizo Son, along with individual investors from Asia-Pacific and the Middle East.

site_title: Lifeline from India's biggest bank offers beaten builders hope
summary: State Bank of India (SBI) has launched a programme to finance both builders and homebuyers in the property market, aiming to address the crisis of stalled projects and lack of trust among developers. The programme will charge developers a premium and offer homebuyers a refund if their apartments are left unfinished, with SBI lending up to 4 billion rupees to developers for apartments priced up to 25 million rupees. This move is expected to restore trust and bring back confidence to the market, with other banks potentially following SBI's lead.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as focus moves to China-US pact
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday as investors shifted focus from the Middle East to the China-US trade pact, set to be signed this week. The US jobs report showed slower wage growth, leading to profit-taking on Wall Street, while other markets such as Hong Kong, Singapore, and Taipei rose due to positive economic news. The dollar slipped against high-yielding currencies, and oil prices dropped as concerns about Middle East supplies eased. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to maintain low interest rates for some time.

site_title: Goldman plans to double China headcount to 600 in five years: source
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to double its headcount in China to 600 within five years, provided the country continues to open up its financial markets. The move is part of a five-year plan to expand the investment bank's operations in the country, driven by growing wealth and increasing demand for asset management services. Goldman aims to boost its stake in a joint venture to 51% and go for full control if permitted by year-end, as China's President Xi Jinping has set plans to let foreign investment banks take full control of units by the end of the year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 1.57 points or 0.10% to 1,593.03. Volume reached 77.57 million lots worth RM24.17 million, with gainers outpacing losers 145 to 56.

site_title: Oil dips on easing US-Iran tensions, eyes on China trade deal
summary: Oil prices declined on Monday, falling 13 cents for Brent crude and 9 cents for WTI, as US-Iran tensions eased. The planned signing of a US-China trade deal this week is expected to boost demand. Oil prices surged after the killing of an Iranian commander, but then dropped as the US and Iran stepped back from conflict. The global benchmark Brent touched a four-month high above $70 before ending below $65, with geopolitical tensions remaining a focus for investors this week.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged down on Monday as fears of conflict between the United States and Iran eased, although the decline was checked by the planned signing of an initial US-China trade deal this week, which could boost demand.

site_title: Philippines on alert as volcano spews ash, lava
summary: The Taal volcano in the Philippines has erupted, spewing lava and ash, grounding hundreds of flights and prompting an alert for a possible "explosive eruption". At least 10,000 people have sought refuge in evacuation centers due to the quakes and ash fall. The volcano's eruption on Sunday was accompanied by a series of earthquakes, with residents describing the quakes as frequent and intense.

site_title: Australia PM slumps in polls amid bushfire anger
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's approval ratings have plummeted to 37% after widespread criticism over his handling of the deadly bushfire crisis, with 59% expressing dissatisfaction. The crisis has killed at least 27 people, burned an area the size of South Korea, and led to a significant shift in public opinion. Morrison has been criticized for his response, including going on holiday, making gaffes, and forcing victims to shake his hand. The crisis has also led to a shift in the polls, with the opposition Labor party now leading the preferred vote 51-49.

site_title: Koyo unit to buy property for engineering fabrication for S$2.54m
summary: KOYO International's subsidiary, Koyo Engineering (SE Asia), has exercised an option to purchase a property in Boon Lay for S$2.54 million. The 3,800 sqm property, valued at S$2.5 million, will be used for engineering fabrication and pre-fabrication of mechanical and electrical modules. The purchase is expected to improve operational efficiencies and cost savings, as the property's close proximity to the company's existing projects will facilitate smoother workflow. The acquisition is subject to approvals from relevant authorities.

site_title: USP shareholders call for EGM to remove 5 directors
summary: Two USP Group shareholders, Tanoto Sau Ian and Tan Khoon Yong, have requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove five directors and replace them with four new candidates. The proposed directors include Tanoto Sau Ian himself, along with Mak Chung Yee, Kelvin Tan Wee Peng, and Low Chee Chiew. The move comes after Tanoto Sau Ian acquired a 14.17% stake in the company. USP has stated it is verifying the shareholding and seeking legal advice on the request, and has advised shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in the company's shares.

site_title: Siemens to remain in Australia mining project: CEO
summary: Siemens has decided to remain involved in the Carmichael coal mine project in Australia, despite environmental criticism. The German conglomerate will supply rail infrastructure for the mine, worth 18 million euros, and has promised to create a body to manage environmental concerns. The mine, owned by India's Adani group, has faced delays and funding problems, but supporters say it will bring hundreds of jobs to rural Queensland. Conservationists warn that the project threatens local species and the already-damaged Great Barrier Reef. Siemens CEO Joe Kaeser stated that the company must fulfill its contractual obligations.

images.alt_text: Siemens boss announced Sunday that the German conglomerate has decided to remain involved in a controversial coal mining project in Australia, despite massive environmental criticism as the country faces unprecedented bushfires.

site_title: UK job vacancies drop most in a decade: BDO
summary: UK job postings dropped 59,000 in 2019, the largest decline in a decade, amid Brexit uncertainty. Despite this, overall employment levels remained strong. The BDO report attributed the drop to business planning disruptions caused by Brexit. The new UK government, led by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, faces a challenge to kickstart economic growth in 2020. Business optimism index remained flat between November and December, with employers seeking clarity on the government's post-Brexit plans.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, USP, AA Reit, Koh Bros, MNACT, SPH Reit, First Reit
summary: Stocks to watch on Monday include UOB, which is projecting a S$10 billion market opportunity in Asean, and USP Group, which faces a requisitioned EGM to remove five directors. AIMS Apac Reit completed a redevelopment project at 3 Tuas Avenue 2 and received a Temporary Occupation Permit. Koh Brothers Group's family members will buy units in the upcoming freehold residential development Van Holland. MNACT's manager announced efforts to reopen the Festival Walk mall in Hong Kong. SPH Reit reported a 3% improvement in distribution per unit, while First Reit's development works were impacted by road subsistence in 2018.

site_title: Caregiving service startup Homage raises double-digit millions in Series B round
summary: Homage, a caregiving service startup, has raised double-digit millions in Series B funding led by EV Growth, Alternate Ventures, and KDV Capital. This round, valued at double-digit millions, follows a $4.15 million Series A round in 2018 and a $1.2 million seed investment in 2017. The company aims to expand its operations across the Asia-Pacific, improve the quality of care professionals, and scale its care services. With the fresh funds, Homage plans to strengthen its network of qualified doctors and medication-delivery capabilities, and forge new partnerships to increase accessibility and affordability of care.

site_title: Ash pours from Philippine volcano, halting flights
summary: The Taal volcano in the Philippines erupted, spewing ash and forcing a halt to flights at Manila's main airport. Thousands were evacuated, but some locals remained. The volcano's explosive eruption was imminent, according to officials. Ash and earthquakes were reported, with lightning visible above the volcano's crest. The eruption raised concerns for nearby residents and tourists.

site_title: Australia's AAA rating not at risk from bushfires: S&P
summary: Australia's AAA sovereign rating from S&P Global Ratings is not at immediate risk from the fiscal and economic impact of bushfires, according to a statement by Anthony Walker. The fires are expected to have a relatively small impact on the country's budgets, and the capacity to absorb costs is sufficient to maintain ratings for the next 1-2 years. Total bushfire losses are estimated at around A$5 billion, with a 0.2-0.5 percentage point hit to GDP forecast. The crisis is becoming increasingly political, but S&P believes the government's ratings can withstand the fiscal costs.

site_title: Looking into the crystal ball
summary: Business leaders and experts predict various trends and outcomes for 2020, including a focus on sustainability, AI, cybersecurity, and the rise of citizen developers. Predictions range from hopes for governments to address climate change seriously to fears of global conflict and economic downturns. Experts also foresee increased adoption of electric vehicles, a shift towards greater accountability in global markets, and the growth of connected devices and cybersecurity threats.

site_title: Human Rights Watch chief says barred from entering Hong Kong
summary: Human Rights Watch chief Kenneth Roth was denied entry into Hong Kong, where he had arrived to launch the organization's annual report, amid months of civil unrest. Roth, who had previously been allowed to enter the city, stated that he was blocked by authorities at the airport. The move comes after China announced sanctions on American NGOs, including HRW, in retaliation for a US bill backing Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement. Roth's refusal to enter highlights Beijing's deepening assault on international human rights efforts.

site_title: Boeing employees' emails bemoan culture of 'arrogance'
summary: Boeing employees' internal emails reveal a culture of "arrogance" and a fixation on cost-cutting, which contributed to the company's difficulties, including the 737 MAX crashes that claimed 346 lives. The emails, dated between 2013 and 2018, show a lack of concern for safety and a dismissive attitude towards regulators and colleagues. Boeing's CEO, David Calhoun, faces intense pressure to restore public confidence and that of aviation regulators worldwide. The emails highlight a dysfunctional culture that has undermined the company's reputation and its decades-long tradition of excellence in aerospace engineering.

site_title: UOB extends online travel marketplace to Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand customers
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is launching its online travel marketplace, The Travel Insider, in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand, allowing customers to search for travel ideas and book holidays. The platform, launched in Singapore in 2018, has seen 25,000 unique visitors per month. This expansion marks the first time the marketplace will be available outside of Singapore, starting with Malaysia this year.

images.alt_text: Travel-related spend is one of the top card spend categories across the region, said Jacquelyn Tan, UOB's head of personal financial services Singapore.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.14%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 4.60 points or 0.14% to 3,260.55 on Monday, driven by gains in OEL, AusGroup, and CapitaLand Mall Trust. Despite US stocks ending lower on Friday, Singapore shares started the week higher. Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 41, with DBS and UOB gaining 0.7% and 0.5% respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.5% in the US, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.3% each.

site_title: China's US trade deal commitments not changed in translation: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that China's commitments in the Phase 1 trade deal with the US remain unchanged, including purchasing $40 billion to $50 billion worth of US agricultural products annually and $200 billion worth of US goods over two years. The language of the deal will be released this week, following a lengthy translation process, and the US still expects China to meet these commitments. The deal's signing on January 15 eases the 18-month trade war, but tariffs on $370 billion worth of Chinese imports will remain in place.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Difficult for digibanks to be profitable
summary: Singapore's Money FM podcast discusses the challenges of profitability for digibanks, citing high operational costs and intense competition in the market. Experts warn that digibanks may struggle to turn a profit despite growing demand for digital banking services. The podcast also touches on recent developments in the banking industry, including the appointment of Tan Teck Long as OCBC's new CEO.

site_title: Wholesale, retail sectors cling to hope in 2020
summary: Singapore's wholesale and retail sectors, hit hard by the US-China trade war and global economic slowdown, still see bright spots for 2020, according to a United Overseas Bank survey. While 46% of respondents held a positive outlook, concerns over global demand, trade tensions, and the strengthening of the Singapore dollar dominated discussions. Companies like Fortrec Chemicals and Petroleum are benefiting from the surge in oil prices, while others, such as retailers, are focusing on improving operational efficiency and adopting technology to stay competitive.

site_title: Trump to halt civilian drone programme over China tech concerns: FT
summary: The US government plans to permanently halt its civilian drone programme due to concerns over Chinese involvement in the production of the devices, which could be used for spying. The Interior Department is considering halting around 1,000 drones, with exceptions for emergencies such as fighting wildfires and training. The decision follows a risk assessment that deemed the potential use of the drones by Beijing too high, according to sources briefed on the plans. Interior Secretary David Bernhardt has not signed an official policy but is planning to pull the fleet from action.

site_title: Singapura Finance, fintech MatchMove believed to have teamed up for digibank bid
summary: Singapura Finance and fintech firm MatchMove are believed to have teamed up to bid for a digital bank licence in Singapore, with results expected by mid-2020 and operations starting by mid-2021. The partnership is among 21 digital banking contenders, with Singapura Finance holding a minority stake of 1.6% in MatchMove. The new digital bank would be eligible to collect deposits from retail customers, with a capital requirement of S$1.5 billion.

site_title: Biotech startup seeks to make money by lowering drug prices
summary: A biotech startup, EQRx, backed by Silicon Valley investors, aims to lower drug prices by up to 66% through developing innovative medicines in high-cost areas like cancer and genetic disease. Led by CEO Alexis Borisy, the company plans to develop one new drug in five years and 10 in the next decade, addressing the financial hardships faced by 24% of Americans struggling to afford prescription drugs.

site_title: Beijing says stance on Taiwan unchanged despite polls landslide
summary: China reiterates its stance that Taiwan belongs to it, despite President Tsai Ing-wen's re-election and rejection of China's "one country, two systems" model. Tsai vowed to deepen cooperation with the US on defense and economy, while China's Foreign Ministry warned she is courting disaster. The international community is divided, with the US and Japan congratulating Tsai and referring to Taiwan as a "precious friend," while China's Taiwan Affairs Office continues to promote the "one country, two systems" model for Taiwan.

images.alt_text: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen, who won another four-year term, was congratulated by US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo for seeking stability with China "in the face of unrelenting pressure".

site_title: Companies in China remain wary despite 'Phase One' US trade deal
summary: Chinese companies remain cautious despite the "Phase One" US trade deal, fearing it could be upended. Manufacturers and suppliers are diversifying operations, seeking new markets, and increasing domestic presence to mitigate potential risks. The deal's impact is uncertain, and existing tariffs continue to bear down on Chinese firms. Analysts also worry about other fronts, including technology tensions and China's subsidies to state-owned enterprises, which could undermine the agreement's benefits.

site_title: 'Historic time' for Northern Ireland, Johnson says ahead of visit
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson hailed "an historic time" for Northern Ireland ahead of a visit to mark the reopening of its power-sharing government. The devolved assembly reopened after three years of deadlock, with Democratic Unionist Party leader Arlene Foster as first minister and Republican Sinn Fein's Michelle O'Neill as deputy. The deal follows a new power-sharing agreement under the threat of a regional election. Johnson sees this as an opportunity for the UK and Northern Ireland to come together and unleash their potential, with the next decade expected to be an "incredible time of opportunity."

site_title: India blows up luxury high-rises over environmental violations
summary: India has demolished two luxury waterfront high-rises in Kochi, southern India, in controlled explosions over environmental violations. The 19-floor H2O Holy Faith complex and twin towers of Alfa Serene were razed after the Supreme Court ruled they were constructed in breach of coastal regulations. The demolitions followed a saga that began in 2006, with over 2,000 residents evacuated as a safety measure. The destruction aims to protect Kerala's environmentally fragile backwaters and lakes, which are famed for their unique ecosystem.

images.alt_text: India has seen a construction boom in recent years but developers have often ridden roughshod over safety and other regulations, and with the connivance of local officials.

site_title: Chinese tycoon in record £210m deal for London mansion
summary: Chinese property magnate Cheung Chung Kiu is set to break London's house-price record with the purchase of a 45-room mansion in Knightsbridge for £210 million. The sale, brokered by Beauchamp Estates, would eclipse the £140 million paid for a country house in Oxfordshire nearly a decade ago. The deal is a bright spot for London's luxury property market, with the UK's exit from the EU drawing investors to the weak pound.

site_title: False alarm sets off nuclear scare in Canada
summary: A false alarm sent an emergency alert to millions of residents in Ontario, Canada, warning of an incident at the Pickering Nuclear Generating Station near Toronto. The alert was issued by mistake during a routine training exercise and was meant for a 10km radius. The Ontario Power Generation company and provincial government apologized, stating there was no active nuclear situation and no danger to the public or environment. An investigation has been launched to determine how the error occurred, prompting calls for accountability from local officials.

images.alt_text: An alert signaling an incident at a major nuclear power plant near Toronto in Canada was sent in error to millions of residents Sunday, causing a scare and prompting calls for an investigation.

site_title: China set to strengthen cooperation with Zimbabwe
summary: China's foreign minister Wang Yi pledged to strengthen cooperation with Zimbabwe during a meeting with Zimbabwean counterpart Sibusiso Moyo, despite a spat over bilateral aid figures. China has funded and provided loans for infrastructure projects in Zimbabwe, and the two countries have a long history of cooperation, dating back to the 1970s. Wang Yi hailed their "win-win cooperation" in areas such as infrastructure, agriculture, and mining, and vowed to explore new areas of cooperation, while Zimbabwe's opposition parties criticized China's influence and accused the government of giving away natural resources in exchange for aid.

site_title: Renewable Energy Asia Group to delist from SGX on Feb 7
summary: Renewable Energy Asia Group (REA) will delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on February 7 due to the company's inability to demonstrate it could operate as a going concern. The decision follows a suspension in 2015 and the failure to revive the company through various measures. REA Group's shares have been suspended since July 2015, and the company will not submit any proposals for resuming trading or issuing share certificates to shareholders post-delisting.

site_title: US-China trade deal a mixed success for Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to sign a trade deal with China, touted as a major victory, despite the deal coming at a steep cost after a two-year standoff. The agreement addresses some but not all of the hard issues between the two economic powers. Trade policy expert Edward Alden notes that the deal "politically works pretty well for Trump," who is running for re-election. However, the agreement's long-term impact and resolution of outstanding issues remain uncertain.

site_title: Anti-government fun run draws thousands of defiant Thais
summary: Thousands of Thais participated in a "run against dictatorship" in Bangkok, with around 10,000 joining the event, shouting slogans and wielding three-finger salutes. The event, led by anti-government leader Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, aimed to show defiance against the government led by former junta leader Prayut Chan-O-Cha. The run was part of a larger show of political defiance, with similar events taking place across Thailand, reflecting the country's bitter division between pro-Prayut and pro-Thanathorn supporters.

site_title: Australia counts the cost of wildfire damage to crops and livestock
summary: Australia's wildfires have caused significant damage to the country's agriculture industries, particularly dairy, meat, wool, and fruit production. Over 11.4 million hectares of land have been scorched, with key regions in Victoria and New South Wales suffering the most. Dairy supply is expected to be hit hardest, with losses of about 1.7 million sheep and 450,000 head of cattle predicted. Wool production is also expected to decline, and fruit production may be affected in southern NSW. The impact on wine production is still unclear, but individual vineyards and wineries have suffered devastating damage.

site_title: US winter storms cause 10 deaths, flight cancellations, power outages
summary: A massive winter storm system caused 10 deaths, over 1,000 flight cancellations, and hundreds of thousands of power outages across five US states from Texas to Michigan. Hurricane-force wind gusts, hail, and 5-13 cm of snow fell on Friday night and early Saturday, with more snow expected through Sunday. Over 257,000 homes and businesses were without power, and driving conditions were treacherous due to ice accumulation and wind. The storm system also caused tornado damage in Arkansas and Missouri, with over 18 million people at risk of tornadoes and flooding rains.

site_title: UOB digital bank eyes S$10b Asean millennial market
summary: UOB's digital bank, TMRW, aims to tap into the S$10 billion Asean millennial market by focusing on high-quality customers in a cost-efficient manner. The bank has already gained traction with 12,000 customers and plans to expand to at least one other large market in Asean this year. TMRW will use fintech to provide personalized financial insights and has a 35% cost-to-income ratio goal after five years. The bank's strategy aims to protect the future of UOB's retail business and stay competitive in the region, where regulators are opening doors to non-banking digital entities.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The global shipping market saw mixed trends in the first full week of 2020, with the Capesize market struggling to gain traction. Pacific Basin rates were under pressure, while the Atlantic market fared better, with voyage rates rising due to geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and high fuel prices. The Panamax market saw healthy volumes, with East Coast South America grain demand supporting the market. Supramax and Ultramax rates were significantly lower than last year, with the Baltic Supramax Index closing at 570. The Handysize market was under negative pressure, and tanker rates saw firmer rates due to escalating tensions between the US and Iran.

site_title: Interruption in recent stock surge very likely in 2020, say strategists
summary: US stocks closed near record highs despite volatile trading due to ongoing US-Iran tensions and economic uncertainty. A mixed jobs report and concerns over a potential escalation in US-Iran tensions may keep gains in check. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, however, as investors remain optimistic about a potential "Phase One" trade deal with China.

site_title: More trees, plants at over 80 new HDB estates
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) is implementing a plan to increase green spaces at over 80 new estates in Singapore, aiming to create a liveable and sustainable environment for residents. This move follows the board's efforts to integrate more foliage and plants into residential areas.

site_title: HK's first digital bank ZA offers 6% introductory rate that dwarfs HSBC's
summary: Hong Kong's first digital bank, ZA Bank Ltd, has introduced a 6% introductory rate for deposits, surpassing major banks like HSBC and Standard Chartered. The offer is seen as a warning of upcoming competition in the city's $410 billion time-deposit market. While many doubt the new bank can maintain such rates, it's a sign of increasing competition and potential disruption to the traditional banking sector.

site_title: Is gender diversity actually good for boards?
summary: The push for gender diversity on boards has been ongoing globally, with progress made but differing opinions on its effectiveness. Having a gender-diverse board is necessary due to women making up half the global talent pool, yet they are disproportionately under-represented. Proponents argue that diversity leads to better decision-making, while skeptics claim it's an overdone exercise in political correctness. Despite the debate, the importance of gender diversity on boards remains, with women making up only a small percentage of corporate boards worldwide.

site_title: Species-saving Galapagos giant tortoise Diego can finally take a rest
summary: A 100-year-old Galapagos giant tortoise named Diego, credited with almost single-handedly saving his species from extinction, is being released back into the wild. Diego, who was part of a captive breeding program, will be returned to his native island of Espanola in March. The Galapagos National Parks service announced the release, marking the end of Diego's role in the program.

site_title: China reports first death from mystery pneumonia outbreak
summary: China has reported its first death from a mysterious pneumonia outbreak linked to a new strain of coronavirus, similar to Sars. Out of 41 diagnosed cases in Wuhan, one person died, two were discharged, and seven remain in serious condition. The Wuhan Municipal Health Commission made the announcement on January 11, 2020.

site_title: Future of mobility: Some wild rides spotted at tech show
summary: The 2020 Consumer Electronics Show (CES) featured numerous tech-inspired solutions for mobility, including autonomous and shared vehicles, electric bicycles, and futuristic transportation gadgets. Innovators showcased designs such as modular mobility vehicles, self-balancing armchairs, and personal transport pods. Companies like Bosch, Hyundai, and Toyota proposed networks of hubs to connect various forms of personal and mass transit, aiming to create a more sustainable future. Experts believe that better planning is needed to integrate new modes of transport, but the array of new options presented at CES suggests a promising future for mobility.

site_title: Dollar inches lower versus yen and Swiss franc amid Iran sanctions
summary: The US dollar edged lower against the Japanese yen and Swiss franc on Friday due to renewed US-Iran tensions and weaker-than-expected US payrolls data. The dollar index still posted its best weekly performance in two months, but fell 0.1% to 97.30 against a basket of currencies. The dollar lost steam after a soft US non-farm payrolls report, which followed strong economic figures, and eased from a four-week peak against the yen to trade at 109.49 yen and versus the Swiss franc to 0.9727.

site_title: Top Iran Guard briefs parliament over downed Ukrainian jet
summary: Iran's top Guards commander briefed the Iranian parliament on a Ukrainian jet that was shot down in error, sparking an angry demonstration. The armed forces' admission came after Britain's ambassador was temporarily arrested at a vigil for the victims. The incident occurred a day after the ambassador's arrest.

site_title: No more 'burn, baby, burn': VCs expect more caution in 2020
summary: Venture capital firms in South-east Asia expect a more cautious approach in 2020, shifting focus from hype to business fundamentals. After a year of mega funding rounds for regional unicorns, investors are emphasizing profitability and rational valuations. While the early-stage funding scene remains vibrant, the exit market is expected to mature, with more mergers and acquisitions (M&A) and initial public offerings (IPOs) in the future. The region's venture capital scene is also seeing increased innovation in the financial sector and a more mature approach to evaluating venture ideas.

site_title: Is Jazz on song for encore in Singapore Open?
summary: Thai golfer Jazz Janewattananond is set to defend his title at the SMBC Singapore Open, which will make him the second person to achieve a two-in-a-row victory in the tournament's history. Currently ranked 40th in the world, Jazz has had a phenomenal year, winning three other Asian Tour crowns in 2019 and ending the year with the Asian Tour's Order of Merit No 1. He will face a challenging field, including Major winners Justin Rose and Henrik Stenson, when the tournament begins on January 16-19 at the Sentosa Golf Club.

site_title: Bullish outlook for AUD/USD amid uptrend indicators
summary: AUD/USD is showing a bullish outlook amid uptrend indicators, reversing a downtrend since 2011. After a price rejection at 0.6700 in October, the currency pair turned to a long-term uptrend, forming higher highs and lows. A Fibonacci retracement analysis indicates a support level at 0.6873, coinciding with an oversold signal from the stochastic oscillator, which suggests a favorable upside move. This validates the strength of the support level, favoring an increase in the AUD/USD price.

site_title: Curtain falls on Chinese film festival as censorship intensifies
summary: China's longest-running independent film festival, the China International Film Festival (CIFF), has shut down due to intensified government censorship. Founded in 2003, the festival screened sensitive films on topics such as homosexuality and the Three Gorges Dam project, but was no longer able to operate independently. The shutdown marks a return to a more restricted era for film in China, with Beijing pushing media that glorifies the ruling Communist Party. The festival's closure comes amid a tightening of censorship under President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz to build smart brand cars with Geely in China's Xi'an: senior executive
summary: Mercedes-Benz and Geely Holding Group will collaborate to build smart-branded electric cars in China's Xi'an, with an annual production capacity of 150,000 vehicles. The venture will be based in Ningbo and will manufacture vehicles for China and sales operations in China and Germany. Both companies will invest 2.7 billion yuan (S$524.4 million) in the project, with Geely holding a 9.7% stake in Daimler. The partnership aims to produce "premium and intelligent electrified" vehicles under the Smart brand.

site_title: US sharply reduces flights to Cuba
summary: The US sharply reduced flights to Cuba, allowing only charter flights to Havana, in an effort to restrict revenue for the communist island. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated that this move will hinder the Cuban regime's ability to finance its repression and support for Venezuelan dictator Nicolas Maduro. Charter flights have 60 days to wind down operations, while commercial flights have already been suspended. The Trump administration has reversed Obama's rapprochement with Cuba, citing human rights concerns and support for Maduro.

site_title: Markets to focus on trade with impending phase one deal
summary: US and China are set to sign a phase one trade deal on Wednesday, which could boost both economies. The deal's details are scarce, but a successful signing would be a positive development amidst concerns over the US-Iran conflict and Boeing's 737 MAX crisis. However, investors should be cautious of other potential trade tensions, such as the US's planned tariff hike on EU automotive goods. The US will kick off a busy earnings season, with data releases including December consumer price index and industrial production numbers, while China is expected to report a rebound in December trade data and Q4 GDP growth.

site_title: Discipline is the name of the game as startup valuations soar
summary: Venture capital firms in South-east Asia are closely monitoring startup valuations amid a year of shake-ups in the industry. The rapid rise in valuations has been fueled by emerging new domestic and foreign funds expanding into the region. However, some industry players predict a correction in 2020, citing concerns over unsensible valuations and the need for long-term business model sustainability. Investors are also shifting focus towards environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing, prioritizing responsible businesses and their impact on society and the environment.

site_title: Creative Tech returns from CES with 6 awards in the bag
summary: Creative Technology won six awards for its new Super X-Fi products at CES, including the SXFI Carrier, a home theatre soundbar that combines Creative's Super X-Fi headphone technology. The company's CEO, Sim Wong Hoo, noted that the SXFI Carrier is the "little brother" of Creative's high-end Sonic Carrier, offering similar sound quality at a lower price. Creative plans to launch the SXFI Carrier in China through its online channel, and is working on software updates and new gaming and music profiles for its Super X-Fi products.

site_title: Flights halted as Philippine volcano spews ash
summary: A volcano near Manila, Philippines, Taal volcano, spewed a massive column of ash, grounding flights and prompting evacuations. Authorities warned of a "hazardous explosive eruption" possible within hours to days, citing magma movement and ash posing a risk to aircraft. Over 2,000 residents were evacuated from the volcanic island. Flights to and from Manila's Ninoy Aquino International Airport were suspended. The volcano, one of the country's most active, last erupted in 1977.

site_title: Heliconia-backed Rigel Technology eyes expansion, dismisses listing talk
summary: Rigel Technology, a Singapore-based bathroom products maker backed by Heliconia Capital, is focusing on overseas expansion and launching new products to achieve a 30% yearly revenue increase. The company has dismissed speculation about a potential initial public offering (IPO) and is financially healthy with no lack of funding. Rigel plans to expand in the Hong Kong-Macau market, Indonesia, and China, despite challenges posed by local cultures and regulatory environments. The company aims to improve its branding and profile before considering a listing, with a focus on driving growth through new products and talent recruitment.

images.alt_text: Mr Ng says the only consideration for listing would be to improve Rigel's branding and profile, something that would help the firm attract even better talent, and drive "meritocracy" within it.

site_title: Apple pushes recycling with 'Daisy' robot that can tear apart 200 iPhones an hour
summary: Apple has developed a robot called 'Daisy' that can disassemble 200 iPhones per hour, aiming to increase electronics recycling efficiency. The robot is part of Apple's plan to become a "closed-loop" manufacturer, reducing reliance on the mining industry. However, some industry analysts consider this goal impossible due to rising global demand for electronics, which would still require new mines. Apple's goal is to recover minerals and reuse them, but it acknowledges the need for new mines in the future.

site_title: Oman Sultan Qaboos has died: state media
summary: Oman's Sultan Qaboos, the longest-reigning leader of the modern Arab world, has died at 79, sparking discussions on a successor. He ruled since 1970 and had been ill with colon cancer. With no apparent heir, the royal family will determine the next ruler within three days. Potential successors include Asad bin Tariq, Haitham bin Tariq, and Shihab bin Tariq, who will likely follow a moderate approach similar to Qaboos' foreign policy.

site_title: 2020 starts with a director acquisition-to-disposal ratio of 3:1
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

In the first week of 2020, the Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.3% with other Asian indices following suit. Share buybacks totaled S$12.9 million, with OCBC, DBS, and ST Engineering leading the way. Director and substantial shareholder transactions saw 115 changes, with 16 acquisitions and 5 disposals. Notable transactions included Wilmar International's Tay Kay Chye selling shares, PEC's Robert Dompeling acquiring shares, and Heeton Holdings' Toh Giap Eng buying shares. Other transactions involved Yanlord Land Group's Zhong Sheng Jian acquiring shares, Stamford Tyres Corporation's Wee Kok Wah buying shares, and Hwa Hong Corporation's Steven Ong Kay Eng increasing his stake.

site_title: Airbus net orders rise but lag behind deliveries in 2019
summary: Airbus posted 1,131 gross orders for 2019, a 36% increase, but net orders after cancellations rose only 3% to 768 jets. This marks the second year in a row that deliveries have outpaced orders due to the cancellation of its A380 program and clearing of defunct deals.

site_title: Citic Envirotech's free float falls below 10% threshold
summary: Citic Envirotech's shares will be suspended from trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) starting January 13, after the company's free float fell below 10% due to Citic Group Corp's exit offer. The majority owner, Citic Environment Investment Group, made an offer to buy shares at S$0.55 per share, resulting in approximately 90.54% ownership. The company will not restore the free float requirement and will delist its shares in due course. Shareholders who accept the offer can expect payment within seven business days.

site_title: China says it won't cut subsidies for new-energy vehicles
summary: China will maintain relatively stable subsidies for new-energy vehicles (NEVs) this year, according to the country's industry ministry, signaling no significant cuts. The move was welcomed by vehicle makers, particularly those reliant on the subsidies. NEV sales in China dropped for the first time in two years in July due to subsidy cuts, and have continued to fall. The government plans to phase out subsidies after 2020, amid criticism that some firms have become overly reliant on the funds.

site_title: India to blow up luxury high-rises over environmental violations
summary: India plans to demolish four luxury high-rises in Kochi, southern India, over environmental violations. The 19-floor H2O Holy Faith complex and twin towers of Alfa Serene will be blown up this weekend, with the remaining two complexes to follow on Sunday. Authorities have deemed the structures in breach of rules in an ecologically sensitive coastal zone, and residents face a lengthy legal fight for compensation. The demolition is a rare example of authorities taking action against builders who disregard safety and environmental regulations.

site_title: Japan seeks Interpol wanted notice for Ghosn's wife
summary: Japan has requested Interpol to issue a wanted notice for Carole Ghosn, the wife of former Nissan Motor boss Carlos Ghosn. This move could restrict her travel outside of Lebanon, where she currently resides. Japanese prosecutors have already issued an arrest warrant for her on perjury charges. Ghosn himself has fled to Lebanon, where he denies financial misconduct charges. A travel ban on Ghosn may be lifted if Japan provides his case files within 40 days, according to Lebanese officials.

site_title: Mayor to name Paris street after David Bowie
summary: A Paris street will be named after late British rock star David Bowie, according to Jerome Coumet, mayor of the 13th arrondissement. The new road, near Austerlitz station in the southeast of Paris, will bear the name of the music megastar, who passed away in 2016. The decision was made by the socialist mayor, a self-proclaimed fan of Bowie.

site_title: 20 UOB commercial banking clients raise S$200k for charity
summary: Twenty United Overseas Bank (UOB) commercial banking clients raised S$200,000 for charity on Jan 10, as part of the bank's annual festive fundraising campaign. The clients participated in a Chinese New Year art jamming session, creating artworks symbolizing prosperity, wealth, and good luck. The funds raised will support the Central Singapore Community Development Council, The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, and Very Special Arts. UOB deputy chairman and CEO Wee Ee Cheong attended the event, which aimed to promote artistic talent among financially disadvantaged children and people with disabilities.

site_title: Brazil's education minister mocked for Twitter spelling error
summary: Brazil's education minister, Abraham Weintraub, faced ridicule on Twitter for a spelling error in a tweet. He misspelled the Portuguese word for "amazing" as "imprecionante" instead of "impressionante." This was not his first public orthographical error, with previous mistakes including misspelled words for "suspension" and "paralysation."

site_title: Downing of Ukraine jet 'unforgivable mistake': Iran's Rouhani
summary: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani has described the downing of a Ukrainian airliner as an "unforgivable mistake" and "great tragedy". An internal investigation by Iran's armed forces has concluded that human error caused the crash, resulting in the deaths of 176 innocent people. Rouhani has expressed deep regret and stated that investigations are ongoing to identify and prosecute those responsible.

images.alt_text: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani on Saturday said his country "deeply regrets" the shooting down of a Ukrainian airliner, which he described as "a great tragedy & unforgivable mistake".

site_title: Uber announces end of services in Colombia
summary: Uber is ending its services in Colombia on February 1, 2020, after losing a case brought by taxi drivers who claimed the company benefited from unfair business practices. The US ride-sharing giant had around 2 million active users and 88,000 drivers in the country. Uber immediately appealed the verdict but has now decided to cease operations. The decision comes after protests from taxi owners and unions, who claim Uber steals their work.

site_title: Taiwan votes in crucial election as China's shadow looms
summary: Taiwan held a crucial presidential and parliamentary election on January 11, 2020, with President Tsai Ing-Wen seeking a second term. The election is significant due to Taiwan's strained relationship with China, which views the island as part of its territory and has vowed to retake it by force if necessary. Tsai, a defender of Taiwan's liberal values, faces off against Han Kuo-yu, who favors warmer ties with China. The outcome is expected to infuriate Beijing, which has been increasing pressure on Taiwan.

site_title: Lufthansa extends Iran cancellations, resumes flights to Iraq
summary: Lufthansa has extended its suspension of flights to Iran until Jan 20 as a precautionary measure following the deadly crash of a Ukrainian airliner in a suspected missile strike outside Tehran. Austrian Airlines has resumed flights from Vienna to Erbil, Iraq, and Lufthansa has scheduled a Frankfurt-Erbil flight on Jan 14. The US and Canada blame the Ukrainian plane's crash on Iranian missiles, which Iran denies.

site_title: Boeing says no severance package for ousted CEO Muilenburg
summary: Boeing announced that former CEO Dennis Muilenburg, who was ousted over the 737 MAX crisis, will not receive a severance package. Muilenburg also will not receive 2019 compensation under an annual bonus plan. The decision comes after the grounding of the MAX has dragged on following two deadly crashes.

images.alt_text: Former Boeing chief executive Dennis Muilenburg, who was criticised for his handling of the 737 MAX crisis, will receive no severance package, the company disclosed on Friday.

site_title: Iran denies missile downed Ukrainian plane
summary: Iran's civil aviation chief denied that a missile downed a Ukrainian airliner, which crashed and killed all 176 people on board. Iran's investigating committee will announce the cause of the crash on Saturday. The US Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, reiterated that it was "likely" an Iranian missile was responsible, contradicting Iran's denial. Ukraine granted access to the black box flight recorders, while Western countries continue to investigate the incident.

images.alt_text: Iran's civil aviation chief denied Friday that a missile downed a Ukrainian airliner which crashed killing all 176 people on board, rejecting Western claims of a catastrophic mistake by Tehran's air defences.

site_title: Huawei's Meng can be extradited to US, Canada attorney general says
summary: Canada's Department of Justice has confirmed that Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou can be extradited to the US, as her offense is a crime in both countries. Meng faces an extradition hearing in Vancouver starting January 20, accused of lying to banks about violating Iran sanctions. However, her lawyers argue that violating US sanctions against Iran is not a crime in Canada, and the US alleges that her banking interactions amounted to fraud, which is a crime in Canada. The double criminality standard will be the focus of the first week of the extradition hearing.

site_title: Ukraine given access to crashed plane's black boxes: minister
summary: Ukraine has been granted access to the black boxes of a crashed Ukrainian plane in Iran, allowing experts to analyze the flight recorders' content. The Ukrainian team, comprising around 50 experts, also received access to the plane's fragments and the crash site. The investigation into the crash of the Ukraine International Airlines Boeing 737, which killed all 176 people on board, is ongoing. The Ukrainian government is considering all possibilities, including the possibility that the plane was shot down by a missile, and plans to present conclusions as soon as they are made.

site_title: Australia fires 'long way from over' but rain brings relief
summary: Massive bushfires in southeastern Australia, killing at least 26 people, destroying 2,000 homes, and scorching 100,000sq km, are "a long way from over," authorities warned. Rain brought relief to exhausted firefighters and communities, but relief is short-lived, with temperatures expected to rise again. Scientists attribute the crisis to climate change, and the Australian government is facing growing criticism to take stronger action. The bushfire season is not yet over, with hundreds of fires still raging across several states, and experts estimate over 1 billion animals have been killed.

site_title: Dressed to connect: wearable tech expands all over the body
summary: Wearable technology has expanded beyond traditional devices to include smart glasses, eyewear, and clothing that track various health metrics and provide real-time feedback. French startup Ellcie Healthy showcased drowsiness-detecting glasses, while US startup Narbis developed glasses with neurofeedback for brain exercises. In-ear devices, such as truly wireless earbuds and translation earpieces, also made a significant appearance. Additionally, companies like Myant and Welt unveiled wearable clothing and belts that track heart rate, physical activity, and other health conditions, with potential applications for medical use.

site_title: Emerging-market assets are making a comeback from trade-war hell
summary: Emerging-market assets are experiencing a rebound after two years of being impacted by the US-China trade war. Developing-nation stocks and currencies have regained lost ground, with momentum, relative value, and stock valuations returning to pre-trade-tension levels. Investors are optimistic about the asset class, driven by faster growth in emerging markets, moderate inflation, and accommodative central banks. However, the full-year outlook is uncertain, and investors may wait a couple of weeks before making decisions, with some metrics still indicating a lack of full recovery.

site_title: China's Communist Party expels ex-chairman of China Development Bank
summary: China's Communist Party has expelled former chairman of China Development Bank, Hu Huaibang, for serious violations of discipline. An investigation found Hu had abused his power, benefited others, and allowed family members to complain about property. Hu was also implicated in a graft trial involving a party official and a former conglomerate chairman. The party's graft watchdog will seize his illegal income and transfer his case to judicial bodies. This move is part of President Xi Jinping's sweeping anti-corruption drive since taking office in 2012.

site_title: Climate at mercy of politics in 2020, experts warn
summary: Experts warn that 2020 is crucial in preventing catastrophic global warming due to the implementation of the 2015 Paris agreement, which aims to limit temperature rises under 2 deg C. However, nearly three decades of diplomatic efforts have fallen short of science's requirements. The agreement's five-year implementation periods are set to begin, but the narrow path to safety is threatened by factors like the US election and Brexit, which could hinder climate action. The world's ability to dodge disastrous climate change is at risk, emphasizing the need for urgent and effective action.

site_title: Paws-perous business: The booming pets trade that's also feeding an illicit market
summary: Singapore's pet trade is booming, with a 19% growth in pet ownership over five years, reaching 196,600 in 2019. The industry's rapid growth has led to price inflation, with prices for popular breeds increasing by up to 300% in some cases. The black market is also thriving, driven by the high profits, and is dominated by backyard breeders who prioritize profit over animal welfare. The Animal and Veterinary Service (AVS) has begun a review of the pet trade to address concerns over standards and practices, and to recommend measures to improve animal welfare.

site_title: Greener HDB projects to be ready from this year
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) announced that flats built with enhanced greenery requirements will be ready from this year. The enhanced requirements, first piloted in 2016, require a minimum of vegetation in developments. Over 80 projects have implemented greenery provisions since then, and more will follow. This move aims to improve the living environment and contribute to Singapore's sustainability goals.

site_title: Democrats to send Trump impeachment articles to Senate next week
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi plans to send articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump to the Senate next week, marking the start of a historic trial. The move comes after weeks of a standoff with Republicans over trial terms, with Pelosi seeking assurances on allowing witnesses and documents. The trial, expected to begin this month, will be the first to test the constitutional duty of impartial justice, with five Democratic senators, including frontrunner Joe Biden, required to serve as jurors.
