Investigations are ongoing, with Iran leading the probe, and the US National Transportation Safety Board monitoring developments. The cause of the crash is unknown, and officials are warning against speculation.

site_title: Walmart opened 134 stores in Mexico in 2019, biggest expansion in 6 years
summary: Walmart opened 134 new stores in Mexico in 2019, marking its largest expansion in 6 years. The retailer now operates 3,407 stores in Mexico, with nearly all the new units belonging to the Bodega Aurrera family of stores. This expansion aims to compete with informal marketplaces and win over low-income shoppers. Analysts expect Walmart to maintain its growth pace, but worry about cannibalizing existing sales. The move follows a record 365 new store openings in 2011 and a slowdown in new openings after bribery allegations in 2012.

site_title: Britain hints at Brexit transition period workaround
summary: Britain hinted at piecemeal agreements with the EU in post-Brexit trade talks, potentially creating a barebones deal to avoid further extension requests. Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to pass his Brexit deal, which would see Britain leave the EU on January 31 and negotiate a new trade deal before December 31. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen warned of limited access to European markets without an extension, but is determined to avoid a "hard exit." Britain and the EU must agree on areas such as fishing, citizens' rights, and tariffs on British goods.

site_title: Britain's Prince Harry, Meghan to step back as 'senior' royals
summary: Prince Harry and his wife Meghan will step back as senior members of the British royal family to become financially independent, while continuing to support Queen Elizabeth. The decision comes after a turbulent year, with the couple facing pressure, family rifts, and media scrutiny. They plan to balance their time between the UK and North America, citing a need to carve out a progressive new role within the institution. The move is seen as a response to the intense media spotlight and the challenges of royal life, following a year of trials and tribulations for the monarchy.

site_title: HP says Xerox securing financing not basis for takeover talks
summary: HP Inc stated that Xerox securing financing for its $33.5 billion takeover offer is not a basis for a discussion, reiterating that the proposal undervalues the company. Xerox had offered HP shareholders $22 per share, while HP had previously stated it was open to exploring a bid for Xerox. Billionaire investor Carl Icahn, who has stakes in both companies, was not immediately available for comment.

images.alt_text: HP Inc said on Wednesday that Xerox Holdings Corp securing financing for its US$33.5 billion takeover offer for the personal computer maker is not a basis for a discussion and reiterated that the proposal still undervalues the company.

site_title: US lawmakers urge action on 'crimes against humanity' in China
summary: US lawmakers are calling for President Donald Trump's administration to impose sanctions on China for alleged "crimes against humanity" against the Uighur minority in Xinjiang. The Congressional-Executive Commission on China released a report describing the incarceration of over 1 million Uighurs as "crimes against humanity." Lawmakers, including Representative Chris Smith and Senator Marco Rubio, are urging the administration to take action, with Rubio promising a bill to restrict exports to Xinjiang. The US government must reconcile the bill with the House of Representatives' version, which was approved last year.

images.alt_text: US lawmakers called on Wednesday for President Donald Trump's administration to impose sanctions over rights abuses in China as they released a report describing "crimes against humanity" against the Uighur minority.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound from early losses as US-Iran tensions ebb
summary: European shares rebounded from early losses as Iran indicated its retaliation to the US killing of General Qassem Soleimani had concluded. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.2% after US President Donald Trump stated there were no American casualties in the attack, and Iran appeared to be standing down. Airbus rose 2% and travel and leisure subsectors led the charge, while Boeing suppliers declined. The rebound overshadowed data showing an unexpected fall in industrial orders in Germany, and shares of energy giants BP and Royal Dutch Shell were weighed down by lower oil prices.

site_title: Oscars to go without host for second year
summary: The Oscars will again go without a host for the second consecutive year, following the success of the format last year, which boosted ratings. The decision was made in collaboration with the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, with ABC entertainment president Karey Burke citing "huge entertainment values" and "big musical numbers" as key factors. The ceremony is scheduled for February 9.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at record amid lower anxiety at US-Iran conflict
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index reached a fresh record, closing at 9,129.24, as US stocks rose 0.7% amid reduced anxiety over the US-Iran conflict following an attack on American troops. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained, with investors focusing on an expected US-China trade accord and upcoming quarterly earnings season. Despite a decline in Boeing and Walgreens Boots Alliance, the market remained positive, with Grubhub surging 12.6% after considering strategic options.

site_title: GrabFood launches its first cloud kitchen in Singapore
summary: GrabFood has launched its first cloud kitchen in Singapore, housing 10 food and beverage merchants, including Thai Dynasty and PlayMade. The facility, called GrabKitchen, spans 6,000 sq ft and has a dine-in area. GrabFood plans to roll out a unified app for merchants with value-added services such as loans and supplies procurement. The company aims to grow its cloud kitchen business, which has outperformed expectations in Indonesia, and is targeting to add more properties in Singapore and other Southeast Asian markets.

site_title: Petrobras suspends shipping through Strait of Hormuz
summary: Brazil's state-owned oil company Petrobras has suspended shipping through the Strait of Hormuz due to tensions between Iran and the US. The decision was made after a risk assessment with the navy, but supplies in Brazil are guaranteed and oil prices are not expected to rise. The Strait of Hormuz, a vital shipping lane for a fifth of the world's crude, is congested and its closure could impact global oil markets. The move comes amid heightened tensions following the US drone strike that killed Iranian general Qasem Soleimani last week.

images.alt_text: Brazil's state-owned oil company Petrobras announced on Wednesday it will temporarily stop sending its tankers through the Strait of Hormuz because of tensions between Iran and the United States.

site_title: Safe haven units yo-yo after Iran strike on US base
summary: Iran fired 15 missiles at US targets in Iraq on Wednesday, sparking fears of a new war in the Middle East. The Japanese yen initially jumped to three-month highs against the dollar before retreating as reports of casualties steadied nerves. US President Donald Trump tweeted that a damage assessment was "So far, so good" and promised a further statement. Twitter posts from both sides downplayed the prospect of further escalation, calming currency markets. The yen and Swiss franc stabilized, while gold also recovered, as investors awaited a US response.

site_title: US House to vote on preventing Trump from Iran war
summary: The US House of Representatives will vote on Thursday to prevent President Donald Trump from waging war with Iran after the killing of a top general. Speaker Nancy Pelosi stated that the Democrats' concerns were not addressed in a briefing by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, citing insufficient War Powers Act notification. The House may also consider revoking the authorization of force approved after the 9/11 attacks. However, passage in the Senate, controlled by Trump's Republican Party, is uncertain.

site_title: Oil dives as US, Iran tensions ease and on US crude build
summary: Oil futures plummeted over 4% on Wednesday as US-Iran tensions eased following a rocket attack on US forces in Iraq. The attack, which did not damage oil facilities or harm Americans, led to a decrease in pressure on oil prices. The US crude stockpile build also contributed to the decline. US President Donald Trump backed away from angry rhetoric against Iran, defusing the crisis. The sudden shift in tensions led to a sharp reversal in oil prices, which had earlier soared near a four-month high.

site_title: CGS-CIMB maintains 'overweight' call on banks amid digibank race
summary: CGS-CIMB maintains its "overweight" call on Singapore's banks due to the ongoing digital bank race, despite anticipating stiff competition. Analysts believe the financial impact on deposits and fees will be manageable. The bank's sectoral flash note notes that while digital competition will be intense, it may not have a significant impact on the banks' financials.

site_title: Alita Resources told to apply for extension over court hearing
summary: The Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm, SGX RegCo, has directed Alita Resources to apply for an extension of time for an Australian court hearing related to its rescue plan, which involves transferring all shares to another firm for nil consideration. Alita Resources must also hold an information session for Singapore shareholders. The deadline for providing views is Jan 29, with the court hearing scheduled for Jan 30. SGX RegCo requires the administrators to ensure shareholders' interests are safeguarded and provide a platform for them to share their views.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Location and point of interest data is the future of advertising
summary: Tyler Simmons, managing director of APAC at Foursquare, discusses the future of advertising in Asia, citing location and point of interest data as key. This data can create smarter cities by enabling targeted advertising and location-powered apps. Simmons highlights the importance of utilizing location data to improve user experiences and drive business growth. The conversation is part of the Prime Time podcast on MoneyFM 89.3.

site_title: US water tech firm Xylem expands HQ in Singapore
summary: US water tech firm Xylem has expanded its regional headquarters in Singapore with a new multi-disciplinary centre for water, wastewater, and energy technologies. The centre will focus on developing technologies for water distribution and wastewater treatment, including a new computational fluid dynamics model for Xylem's SmartBall and PipeDiver applications. The centre will also be supported by Xylem's partnership with national water agency PUB and will feature a customer experience centre and training centre. The expansion marks Xylem's 43rd year in Singapore.

site_title: Sun shining after economy's difficult year: World Bank economist
summary: A World Bank economist, Ayhan Kose, says the global economy is experiencing a slight acceleration in growth, with expectations of a 2.5% increase in 2020, following a difficult year in 2019. However, the recovery is fragile and depends on reduced trade tensions and increased investment. Kose notes that a single day of improvement does not guarantee a sustained recovery and that the economy remains vulnerable to debt and policy uncertainty.

site_title: Oil rally cools as Iran strike on US bases seen as limited
summary: Oil prices eased after a rally triggered by Iranian airstrikes on US-Iraqi military bases, with US President Trump tweeting "all is well" and Opec officials promising to keep markets well supplied. The strikes, which killed a top general, led to a surge in futures but prices later retreated as officials downplayed the risk of further escalation. Brent crude rose to a three-month high, but then traded up 0.5% at $68.64 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate climbed 4.7% before retreating.

site_title: The great escape to brave new worlds
summary: A 2019 marked by global challenges saw 1.3 billion people travel annually, with 46% visiting just 100 destinations, contributing to chronic over-tourism. To counter this, Weekend Magazine recommends "recovery, rejuvenation, and inspiration" destinations, such as wellness getaways in India or Japan, the Puna desert in Argentina, and Star Wars land in Ireland's Skellig Michael Island. The article also features Lea Salonga, a veteran actress and musical theatre's most famous Asian star.

site_title: Is the euro zone ready to handle the long term?
summary: The euro zone faces a long-term economic challenge due to demographic decline, with a shrinking working-age population projected to fall by 0.4% per year. Policymakers must consider measures to boost sluggish growth, but options are limited, including raising the retirement age or increasing infrastructure investment, which may not be effective in achieving higher GDP growth. The European Central Bank should lower its inflation target and accept that continued economic stimulus is unlikely to offset demographic decline. The euro zone must accept an "age of diminished expectations" and focus on maintaining fiscal discipline to mitigate the effects of demographic decline.

site_title: Tots continue mission of raising money for senior citizens in need
summary: Kinderland preschool in Singapore has raised over S$12,000 this year for the Lions Befrienders, a social agency providing care and friendship to seniors, through their participation in the ECDA "Start Small Dream Big" initiative. Since 2018, Kinderland has raised over S$30,000 for the agency, using the funds for activities, meals, and excursions for the elderly. The preschool aims to cultivate character and values in its pre-schoolers, inspiring them to contribute to a culture of kindness and inclusivity.

site_title: Optus says financial impact from fires not material at moment
summary: Optus, a subsidiary of Singtel, reported that the financial impact of the Australian bushfires is not material at this time. 17 base stations were affected, with 7 confirmed damaged by fire, but Optus has operational intercity fibers connecting Sydney to Melbourne. The company is providing financial assistance to customers and will offer unmetered access to emergency services websites in bushfire-affected areas. Optus is prioritizing network service continuity and contingency planning for the evolving situation.

site_title: Asia markets seem complacent about risks of US-Iran conflict
summary: Asian markets showed complacency towards the US-Iran conflict, with key equity benchmarks declining 1.5-2.6% before recovering partially. Oil prices surged 4% in the immediate aftermath, but eased to around $68.60 as the day progressed. Analysts warn that a disruption in the Strait of Hormuz could severely impact oil supplies and send prices skyrocketing, potentially derailing the cyclical economic recovery. Despite the heightened tension, optimism remains due to improving trade data and monetary easing efforts by major central banks.

site_title: Samsung profit beats forecasts after chip prices rebound
summary: Samsung Electronics Co reported a 34% fall in operating income to 7.1 trillion won (S$8.2 billion) in the fourth quarter, beating analysts' estimates. Global chip prices rebounded due to easing US-China trade tensions and boosted by data centre operator orders. Demand for DRAM chips is expected to rise, driven by technology advances. Samsung is expected to ramp up capital expenditure in its memory business and unveil new foldable devices, including a second foldable device in San Francisco on February 11.

site_title: Disney faces pressure to help ease Hong Kong's housing crisis
summary: Disney faces pressure to convert a 60-hectare land site for temporary housing in Hong Kong to ease the city's housing crisis. The city's housing minister has asked the company to consider corporate social responsibility and exempt the site from its contractual restrictions. Unaffordable property prices have been identified as a cause of social anger in Hong Kong, where months-long pro-democracy protests have battered the economy. Disney has seen a decline in visitors to its Hong Kong theme park due to the protests, with operating income potentially declining by US$275 million.

site_title: Bidding war for Caltex Australia lacks fuel
summary: A bidding war for Caltex Australia is ongoing, with suitors including EG Group and Alimentation Couche-Tard vying for control. Couche-Tard's A$8.7 billion offer was earlier rejected, but the company is now under pressure to increase its bid. However, the offer is deemed too expensive, with a return on invested capital of just 5.6%, far below the target's 8% cost of capital. EG Group, a UK-based privately owned company, is also seeking to acquire Caltex, but its high leverage means it may struggle to take on more debt.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has increased its ownership in joint venture Dexus Australian Logistics Trust to 49% after exercising a second tranche of rights. GIC initially invested 25% in 2018 and exercised a $366.1 million (S$339.7 million) investment on Dec 23. The additional investment is consistent with the trust's estimated December 2019 valuations. Settlement is expected on April 1, with proceeds used to reduce debt and fund future commitments.

site_title: Boeing changes stance, recommends 737 MAX simulator training for pilots
summary: Boeing is recommending simulator training for 737 MAX pilots, a shift from its previous stance that only computer-based training was needed. The proposal, if approved by regulators, could delay airlines' preparation to fly the grounded jets, which have been out of service since March after two crashes. The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is expected to make a decision by February or March, and only a few MAX simulators exist, raising concerns about the feasibility of the training.

site_title: High Court quashes tribunal's decision that cleared SC Alvin Yeo of overcharging
summary: The High Court has quashed a tribunal's decision that cleared Senior Counsel Alvin Yeo of overcharging his client, an elderly widow, and directed a fresh tribunal to re-hear the case. The fresh tribunal will consider whether Yeo ensured his client had mental capacity to agree to the fees charged. The decision was made after the Law Society and Attorney-General applied to quash the original tribunal's decision, which found Yeo not guilty of overcharging.

site_title: Despite flat office rents, Reits set to enjoy positive rental reversions
summary: Singapore CBD Grade A office rentals remain stable, with a gross average monthly rental value of S$10.81 per square foot in the fourth quarter of 2019, unchanged from the preceding quarter. This marks a 28.5% increase from the trough of S$8.41 psf in Q1 2017, despite flat office rents.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit to lodge prospectus next week
summary: Elite Commercial Reit plans to lodge its prospectus next week, marking the first IPO of 2020 and the first SGX-listed Reit denominated in sterling pound. The portfolio, valued at £320 million, comprises 97 freehold properties in the UK, with a likely yield of 6-7% and a target raise of £150 million. The Reit's stability is attributed to long weighted average lease expiry and a strong tenant profile backed by the UK government, but concerns remain about tenant concentration risk and limited liquidity.

site_title: Koenigsegg, a supercar challenging Swedish stereotypes
summary: Swedish supercar manufacturer Koenigsegg has been challenging stereotypes of Swedish modesty with its high-performance vehicles. Founded by Christian von Koenigsegg in 1994, the company has produced 16 models, including the CC8S, which was named the world's most powerful production car by Guinness World Records in 2002. The Agera RS set a speed record in 2017, reaching 447.19 km/h, and the latest model, the Jesko, costs around €3 million. Despite limited production and secrecy surrounding high-profile buyers, Koenigsegg plans to launch a more affordable model in 2020.

site_title: Tsai's economic record solid, but her anti-China stance is her weak spot
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen is likely to secure a second term despite her economy being squeezed by China's pressure campaign. Tsai boasts a solid economic record, with low unemployment and strong export growth, but her anti-China stance is her weak spot. Her main challenger, Han Kuo-yu, favors warmer ties with China, which could boost Taiwan's fortunes. The outcome of the election will have implications for Taiwan's relations with China and the US, with Beijing watching closely and potentially reacting to the result.

site_title: Amid flygskaming, aviation and industry partners must respond
summary: Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg's selection as Time magazine's Person of the Year has sparked concerns within the global aviation community, with many airlines and airports seeing a decline in passenger numbers due to "flygskam" or flight-shame. Aviation's carbon emissions could rise to 20% by 2050, prompting the industry to respond with new technologies, sustainable fuels, and initiatives to reduce emissions. Industry leaders, such as Alexander de Juniac, CEO of the International Air Transport Association, aim to achieve carbon neutrality by 2020 and halve net emissions by 2050, with potential climate financing of $40 billion by 2035.

site_title: Construction sector must attract more Singaporeans to build strong local core
summary: Singapore's construction industry needs to attract more local workers to maintain a skilled and competent workforce. The sector has made progress in transformation, but the proportion of local professionals has decreased over the past decade. The government is investing in initiatives such as iBuildSG Scholarships and Sponsorships, and a Built Environment Skills Framework to create better job opportunities and upgrade skills. The industry must change practices to make jobs more attractive to locals, with a focus on work-life balance and career progression pathways.

site_title: Singapore eDevelopment units take legal action against vendor
summary: Singapore eDevelopment (SeD) units iGalen International and iGalen have filed a complaint against vendor Gara Group and its founder Kosta Gara in the San Diego County Superior Court, alleging breach of contract, breach of covenant, and intentional interference. Gara Group has also begun legal proceedings against SeD units, claiming breach of contract, quantum meruit, and intentional misrepresentation. The dispute began after Gara Group suspended services in September 2019, citing outstanding invoices. SeD has denied any payment issues, stating iGalen has paid its suppliers and distributors. A court hearing is set for January 8.

site_title: 'How can we cover this up?' ex-official asked Najib
summary: Malaysian investigators have released audio recordings of former Prime Minister Najib Razak seeking help from people, including Abu Dhabi royalty and former prosecutors, to cover up the 1MDB scandal in 2016. The recordings, verified by the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission, show Najib discussing how to resolve the issue and fabricate evidence, which fall under Malaysia's penal code. Najib is facing trial on several charges linked to 1MDB, and the recordings raise concerns about his involvement in corruption and money laundering.

site_title: Ghosn goes on the offensive in first appearance since escape
summary: Former Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn, a fugitive from Japan, has made his first public appearance since escaping, proclaiming his innocence and accusing Japanese prosecutors, government officials, and Nissan executives of conspiring against him. Ghosn, who fled to Lebanon, accused several individuals, including former Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa, of plotting against him to prevent a further integration of Nissan with Renault. He claims to have been a "hostage" of Japan's justice system, which he believes has a 100% conviction rate and allows for repeated grilling of suspects without their lawyers present.

images.alt_text: Now that he has slipped from Japan's grasp, Ghosn is taking his case to the court of public opinion - an arena where he gained a wealth of experience during two decades as one of the world's most prominent and media-savvy business leaders.

site_title: CITIC to sell 22% stake in McDonald's China business to its private equity arm
summary: CITIC Ltd, a Chinese state-owned conglomerate, plans to sell a 22% stake in McDonald's China and Hong Kong business to its private equity arm, aiming to raise at least 2.17 billion yuan (S$422 million). The sale is part of CITIC's efforts to diversify its investments and raise capital. The private equity arm is expected to acquire the stake, marking a significant move in the Chinese fast-food giant's business.

site_title: Bollywood A-lister backing protesters faces call to boycott her film - but is also praised
summary: Indian actress Deepika Padukone faces calls to boycott her upcoming film after joining students protesting against the government at New Delhi's Jawaharlal Nehru University. Her rare show of support drew praise for standing up against a crackdown on dissent in a country where top film stars typically avoid politics.

site_title: Impossible Foods stops talks to supply burgers to McDonald's
summary: Impossible Foods has ended talks with McDonald's to supply plant-based burgers, citing production capacity issues. The company aims to double production instead of pursuing a large deal with the fast-food chain. Shares of Impossible Foods rival Beyond Meat rose 12.5% after the news, while Beyond Meat's CEO said the company is on track to meet McDonald's demand globally. Impossible Foods CEO Pat Brown stated that having more big customers won't be beneficial until they scale up production.

site_title: The coolest architecture on Earth is in Antarctica
summary: Brazil's new Comandante Ferraz Research Station in Antarctica, designed by Estudio 41, has been inaugurated, replacing a facility lost to fire in 2012. The two low-slung buildings, built to withstand temperatures below -51°C and winds up to 161 km/h, house laboratories, living quarters, and provide a comfortable living and work environment. This marks a shift in architecture in Antarctica, where designers are now prioritizing aesthetics, efficiency, and human comfort, rather than just functionality. The station's design has been praised for its unique atmosphere and durability, setting a new standard for research stations on the continent.

site_title: China's super rich make their money from real estate
summary: China's super-rich individuals, who made their fortunes primarily in real estate, are increasingly using family offices for wealth maintenance and succession planning. According to a UBS report, 30% of participants surveyed have made their wealth from property, and around 1/3 of these families use a single-family office. The average net wealth of these families is $943 million, with the primary motivation being wealth preservation. Despite challenges, Chinese family offices have earned an average return of 11% over the past 12 months, with private equity being the top-performing asset class.

site_title: Bringing digital financial services to S-E Asia
summary: Digital financial services are poised to boom in Southeast Asia, with the region's six largest markets expected to generate $38 billion in revenue by 2025, with Singapore accounting for $9 billion. Despite challenges such as consumer and merchant reluctance to adopt digital services, and underdeveloped financial infrastructure, the industry is expected to grow rapidly, with digital payments and remittances leading the way. To reach its full potential, the industry will require supportive regulations, consistent policies, and investment in innovations, including digitized national ID systems, real-time payment systems, and effective credit bureaus.

site_title: Ukrainian airliner crashes in Iran, killing all 176 aboard
summary: A Ukrainian Boeing 737 airliner crashed shortly after taking off from Teheran's Imam Khomeini airport on January 8, 2020, killing all 176 people on board. The cause of the crash is attributed to technical problems, with no survivors. Iran's state television reported that one of the plane's black boxes had been found, and the pilot did not declare an emergency. The crash is being investigated by Iran, with Ukraine and the US also involved in the inquiry.

site_title: Major airlines re-route flights away from Iraq, Iran airspace
summary: Major airlines have re-routed flights to avoid airspace over Iraq and Iran following a US-led coalition's missile attack by Iran. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) issued a ban due to heightened military activities and increased tensions in the Middle East. Several non-US airlines, including Air Canada and Singapore Airlines, have altered their routes to avoid the affected areas, with some flights adding up to 50 minutes to their journey. The FAA ban also affects the Gulf of Oman and waters between Iran and Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Fires have limited impact on outbound tours to Down Under
summary: Despite the escalating Australian bushfires, outbound tours to Australia from Singapore have shown limited impact, with most travel operators reporting no significant changes to bookings or flights compared to last year. January and February are traditionally the off-peak season for Singaporeans heading to Australia, and demand remains roughly the same year-on-year. Some operators, such as Dynasty Travel, have seen a drop in bookings due to concerns about the hot weather and potential worsening of the situation, but most expect the impact to be temporary and are preparing to promote Australia as a travel destination once the bushfires are contained.

images.alt_text: A fire-ravaged region in Quaama, New South Wales. Most travel industry players say they have yet to see any significant changes to tour bookings or flights to Australia compared to last year.

site_title: Gold makes best hedge amid US-Iran flare-up, strategists say
summary: US-Iran tensions have led analysts to favor gold as a hedge against market volatility, citing its ability to reduce portfolio risk. Despite concerns over the potential for escalation, strategists expect the global economy to continue recovering, with central banks maintaining accommodative policies. As a result, equity calls for the year remain unchanged, with many maintaining overweight positions on developed and emerging markets. Gold prices have risen to a seven-year high, seen as a safe haven asset amid uncertainty.

site_title: Trump's trade deficit 'win' has plenty of caveats
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed by 0.7% in the first 11 months of 2019, with a decline in imports rather than an increase in exports contributing to the decrease. The drop in imports is attributed to a fall in shale oil prices, while the US manufacturing sector continues to struggle. Despite this, White House adviser Peter Navarro claims that President Trump's tariffs are working, citing a Phase One deal with China and a re-shoring of manufacturing. However, economists argue that the reduction in imports may be a sign of weaker demand rather than stronger domestic production, and that the trade deficit is not necessarily a positive indicator of economic growth.

site_title: JLL hires ex-CBRE veteran as head of valuation and advisory services for S-E Asia
summary: JLL has hired James Crawford, a former CBRE executive director, as head of valuation and advisory services for South-east Asia, starting this month. Crawford brings 20 years of experience in valuation and advisory services, with a focus on data centres, and will oversee JLL's service delivery across Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines. He will also manage JLL's expansion into Malaysia and work closely with the firm's institutional valuations team to assist clients with cross-border interests.

site_title: Is US-China deal more than 'truce' for troubled times?
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to sign a "stage 1" bilateral trade deal with Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He, marking a temporary truce in US-China tensions. The deal, finalized in late 2019, provides stability in China's most important economic relationship and may have a broader positive effect on international relations. However, experts warn that the agreement's limitations and potential future disputes, such as enforcement protocols and intellectual property violations, could lead to renewed tensions in 2020 and beyond. The deal's long-term implications remain uncertain, with both sides aware of the challenges in negotiating a "stage 2" agreement on long-standing issues.

site_title: California drafts law in fresh bid to raise housing density
summary: California State Senator Scott Wiener has unveiled a bill, SB 50, aimed at boosting the state's housing supply and moderating prices. The legislation would force cities to allow more homes, particularly around transit and in areas with jobs, and gives municipalities two years to decide how to comply. The measure, seen as a major effort to address the state's chronic housing shortage, is supported by various groups, including labor unions, student organizations, and tech companies. The bill's success depends on building support in the Democrat-controlled Senate by the end of the month.

site_title: Alibaba undercuts Amazon in Europe to woo wary brands
summary: Alibaba has launched a European platform, AliExpress, to woo wary brands by undercutting Amazon sellers' fees. The platform has attracted a flood of small businesses but has had limited success with larger brands, including Mango, Benetton, and Tendam. Alibaba has waived monthly rates for sellers in Spain and set lower commission rates to attract business. Despite efforts, some brands have expressed concerns about the platform's quality and appeal. Alibaba's CEO, Daniel Zhang, aims to double the customer base to 2 billion by 2036, with Spain being a key market.

site_title: Reits (Jan 9-10, 2021)
summary: Realty trends show a mixed picture. US mortgage rates rose after five consecutive weeks of decline, affecting the Singapore real estate market. Condo launches in Q3 will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with more increases expected. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. WeWork secured new tenants and filled space at 21 Collyer Quay after its bankruptcy. Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul.

site_title: Daimler pledges that cost cuts today will fund the cars of tomorrow
summary: Daimler AG CEO Ola Kallenius announced plans to cut costs across the company's industrial operations to fund investments in future technologies such as electric cars and self-driving software. The company aims to trim costs to free up cash for new technologies, despite expecting a "tough time" in the coming years. This investment in emerging technologies is seen as crucial for the company's long-term success.

site_title: ClassPass raises US$285m in Series E funding
summary: ClassPass, a fitness marketplace startup, raised $285 million in its Series E funding led by L Catterton and Apax Digital, with Temasek also participating. The funds will aid rapid scaling of its technology globally, expanding existing geographies, and adding more countries to its network. ClassPass has over 30,000 partners in 28 countries and a corporate wellness program with over 1,000 employers. The investment will also see L Catterton's Marc Magliacano and Apax Digital's Daniel O'Keefe join the ClassPass board of directors.

site_title: US private hiring surges to 202,000 in December: ADP
summary: US private hiring surged to 202,000 in December, exceeding expectations, according to ADP data. The increase was driven by gains in trade, transportation, and utilities, professional and business services, and construction. Manufacturing employment fell by 7,000, offsetting a modest gain in November. The total gain and increases in goods producing and services sectors were the largest since April 2019. Despite some moderation in the data, job growth continues to moderate, with signs of job shedding in manufacturers and small companies.

site_title: COEs rise on eve of Singapore Motorshow
summary: COE prices in Singapore rose across the board, with premiums for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp ending at S$35,320, up from S$32,889. Commercial COE prices closed at S$24,402, up from S$23,200. The Open COE category finished at S$38,000, up from S$37,989. The increase is expected to boost buying interest ahead of the Singapore Motorshow, which begins on Thursday.

site_title: One Championship on track for record 50 events in 2020
summary: One Championship, a Singapore-based martial arts organization, plans to host 50 events in 2020, surpassing its previous record of 42 events in 2019. The events will be held across various properties, including live mixed martial arts events, feeder shows, and its new e-sports arm, One Esports. The company has also announced strategic partnerships with global brands, including DBS Bank and Redbull, to leverage multiple platforms and create a unique synergy between the business, martial arts, and e-sports communities.

site_title: India reports H5N1 bird flu outbreak in Chhattisgarh state
summary: India reports an outbreak of the highly contagious H5N1 bird flu virus on a poultry farm in Chhattisgarh state, resulting in the deaths of 5,634 out of 21,060 birds. The remaining birds were slaughtered to prevent further spread.

site_title: British watchdog tells bosses to end bad behaviour in insurance
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has warned the bosses of commercial insurance companies to address bad behavior, such as non-financial misconduct, or risk losing their jobs. The warning follows last year's admission of sexual harassment at Lloyd's of London, which has introduced a plan to raise standards. The FCA will supervise firms and senior managers, with senior managers' approval based on integrity and reputation. Other insurers, such as AXA UK, are also taking steps to improve conduct, including management training for brokers.

site_title: Why did the US kill Suleimani?
summary: The US killing of Major General Qassim Suleimani highlights America's lack of a clear grand strategy, which is essential for its role in the world. The US has had only two effective grand strategies: Washington's "Great Rule" and the Truman Doctrine. However, these strategies are outdated and fail to match the country's current abilities, goals, and global threats. A new grand strategy is needed to address emerging challenges such as global warming, cyber warfare, and artificial intelligence. Three possible strategies are proposed: leading by example, a "city on a hill" approach, and a "world policeman" approach, each with its own set of risks and rewards.

site_title: 2020 building demand likely to stay robust after reaching 5-year high last year
summary: Singapore's construction demand is expected to remain strong in 2020, reaching between S$28 billion and S$33 billion, driven by sustained public sector demand and major infrastructure projects. The public sector is projected to contribute 62% of total demand, while the private sector is expected to contribute 38%. The construction industry is expected to hold steady over the medium term, with total nominal construction output projected to increase to between S$30 billion and S$32 billion in 2020.

site_title: Lennar's 2020 home sales to go above estimates as lower prices boost demand
summary: Lennar Corporation has forecast 2020 US home sales above analysts' estimates, driven by lower home prices and mortgage rates. The company expects to deliver 54,000 to 55,000 homes, surpassing the average analyst estimate of 53,954 unit sales. This positive forecast led to a 3% rise in Lennar's shares. The strong demand is attributed to the decrease in home prices and mortgage rates, indicating a boost in the US housing market.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as Boeing drags, Middle East tension eases
summary: US stocks opened flat on Wednesday, weighed down by Boeing's losses, despite relief from Iranian signals that overnight missile strikes have concluded. The Dow Jones fell 0.10% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.01%, while the S&P 500 opened higher. Middle East tensions eased following the US killing of Qassem Soleimani, but investors remain cautious amid tariff uncertainty.

site_title: STI claws back early loss sparked by Iran attack
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded from an early 1.3% drop, ending the day 0.06% lower at 3,245.89, following Iran's surprise attack on US bases in Iraq. Despite initial fears of escalation, the lack of immediate US retaliation contributed to the recovery. Trading volume reached 78% of the daily average for the first 11 months of 2019, with gold prices rising to $1,600 per ounce, attracting interest in gold-related stocks.

site_title: OCBC hires former HSBC Greater China CEO to lead wholesale banking unit
summary: OCBC has hired Helen Wong, 58, as deputy president and head of global wholesale banking, effective February 3, 2020. Wong, former HSBC Greater China CEO, brings 35 years of banking experience to the role. She will oversee global relationships with small and medium-sized enterprises, large corporates, and financial institutions, as well as cash management and trade under the transaction banking business. OCBC group chief executive Samuel Tsien stated Wong's extensive market knowledge and experience make her a valuable addition to the senior management team.

site_title: OCBC hires former HSBC Greater China CEO to lead new wholesale banking unit
summary: OCBC appoints Helen Wong, former HSBC Greater China CEO, as deputy president and head of global wholesale banking, effective February 3, 2020. Wong brings 35 years of banking experience to the role, overseeing global relationships with small- and medium-sized enterprises, corporates, and financial institutions, as well as investment banking and cash management. OCBC's COO Ching Wei Hong will also assume deputy president responsibilities.

site_title: Time for the Big Four to rethink auditing's purpose
summary: A series of high-profile UK failures has reignited concerns about conflicts of interest among the Big Four accountancy firms, prompting a reevaluation of their business models. Regulatory initiatives, including increased disclosure of "key audit matters" and operational separation from other activities, aim to improve audit quality. The profession is also encouraged to prioritize public interest and challenge management. As the audit market changes, firms are seen as an opportunity to rebuild their reputation and serve the interests of savers, lenders, and the economy, rather than just focusing on consulting services.

site_title: India to tweak proposed content regulations to ease burden on some
summary: India plans to amend proposed content regulations to apply only to big social media firms, easing the burden on other tech players. The original proposal would have forced all tech companies to deploy automated tools and appoint an officer for 24/7 coordination with law enforcement. The new two-tier system would impose stricter rules on social media companies, while other tech firms would face minimal and simple requirements. This move aims to tackle disinformation and "fake news" while giving relief to smaller tech players.

site_title: Japanese billionaire to give away US$9m as a 'social experiment'
summary: Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa is giving away $9 million to 1,000 randomly selected Twitter followers as a social experiment to see if the payment boosts their happiness. The money will be tracked through regular surveys. Maezawa, a fashion tycoon, will give each recipient 1 million yen (approximately $9,420) after they retweeted a post on January 1.

site_title: Thailand on verge of US watch list as trade surplus hits US$20b
summary: Thailand's 12-month trade surplus with the US exceeded $20 billion, meeting two of the three criteria set by the US Treasury to add a country to its watch list of currency manipulators. The surplus reached $20.05 billion, violating the US$20 billion limit set by the Treasury. The US is Thailand's third-largest trading partner, with total trade of $47 billion in 2018. Bank of Thailand governor Veerathai Santiprabhob is engaged in a "close dialogue" with US officials about Thailand's performance, amid efforts to trim the current account surplus and boost investment.

site_title: Prioritisation needed in EU-UK deal talks: EC chief
summary: European Commission head Ursula von der Leyen warned that EU-UK deal talks must prioritize key aspects by the end of the year due to insufficient time. The EU wants to uphold the integrity of its single market and customs union, while Britain will remain bound by EU rules until the end of the year. Von der Leyen emphasized the need for a comprehensive partnership with Britain, including zero tariffs, zero quotas, and zero dumping, to address various issues such as climate action, data protection, and security.

site_title: Digital currencies will not displace the dominant dollar
summary: The dominance of the US dollar in global trade and finance is unlikely to be challenged by digital currencies in the near term. Despite technological advancements, central banks are considering public digital currencies to address retail payment gaps, but these efforts are improbable. The dollar's widespread use, network effects, and institutions, such as the US's rule of law and investor protection, have cemented its status as a global reserve currency. While private and central bank-backed digital currencies may offer some advantages, they are unlikely to displace the dollar, and the US may leverage its leadership in combating global money laundering and terrorism finance to maintain its dominance.

site_title: Travelex says financially unaffected by hacking
summary: Travelex, a British foreign currency company, said it will not suffer financial impact from a cyber attack on New Year's Eve, despite stopping the virus from spreading and encrypting some data. The attack, known as Sodinokibi and REvil, was reportedly seeking a ransom of US$3 million. Travelex's parent group, Finablr, confirmed no material financial impact was anticipated, and its other brands remain unaffected. The company's share price did drop by 17% following the attack.

site_title: 2 SeD subsidiaries in legal proceedings against vendor
summary: Two subsidiaries of Singapore eDevelopment (SeD), iGalen International and iGalen, have filed a complaint against vendor Gara Group and its founder Kosta Gara in the San Diego County Superior Court, alleging breach of contract, breach of covenant, and intentional interference with economic relations. iGalen had paid Gara Group over US$2.3 million for services from March 2017 to August 2018. Gara Group has also begun legal proceedings against SeD units.

site_title: EU warns of tough post-Brexit talks with UK
summary: The European Union's top official, Ursula von der Leyen, warned Britain that it may lose open access to the European market if it refuses to extend post-Brexit partnership talks beyond 2020. Despite Prime Minister Boris Johnson's assurance that there will be no extension, von der Leyen cautioned that Britain would likely lose unfettered access to its closest trading partner after 2020, forcing prioritization of key aspects. The EU has never reached a trade agreement with a partner in less than a year, and von der Leyen emphasized the importance of maintaining close relations to avoid disruptions to global supply chains.

site_title: Boeing crash probe protocol seen hampered by Iran-US tensions
summary: Iran is unlikely to hand over the recovered flight recorders from the Ukrainian passenger jet crash to the US for investigation, amid heightened tensions between Teheran and Washington. The 1944 Chicago Convention governs air crash investigations, but Iran's refusal to cooperate may hinder the US National Transportation Safety Board's involvement. Boeing, the manufacturer, and Ukraine International Airlines also have representatives in the probe. The US and Iran's tensions, including a recent missile strike on Iraqi bases housing US troops, may complicate the investigation.

site_title: GIC raises stake in Dexus Australian Logistics Trust
summary: SINGAPORE sovereign wealth fund GIC has increased its ownership in the Dexus Australian Logistics Trust to 49% after exercising second tranche rights. GIC initially invested 25% in 2018 and acquired an additional 24% for A$366.1 million. The investment is consistent with December 2019 valuations and will be used to reduce debt and fund future commitments. Settlement is expected on April 1, with proceeds initially going towards debt reduction and future funding.

site_title: SGX RegCo directs Alita Resources to apply for time extension for rescue plan hearing
summary: The Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm (SGX RegCo) has directed Alita Resources to apply for an extension of time for an Australian court hearing, related to its rescue plan that would transfer all shares to another firm for nil consideration. The deadline for providing views on the matter is January 29, with the court hearing scheduled for January 30. SGX RegCo requires Alita to hold an information session for Singapore shareholders and provide an expert report on the value of Alita's shares by January 10.

site_title: COEs rise on eve of motor show
summary: COE prices in Singapore rose across the board at the latest tender, with premiums for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp ending at S$35,320, up from S$32,889. The Open COE category closed at S$38,000, up from S$37,989. This increase is on the eve of the Singapore Motorshow.

images.alt_text: Certificates of entitlement (COE) prices ended higher across the board at the latest tender Wednesday on the eve of the Singapore Motorshow.

site_title: Carlos Ghosn goes on the offensive in first appearance since escape
summary: Former Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn has made his first public appearance since escaping from Japan, accusing the country's justice system of being "rigged" and conspiring against him. Ghosn, who fled to Lebanon last week, has proclaimed his innocence and named several Nissan executives and government officials as being involved in a plot to topple him. He has also accused Nissan of leaking false information and withholding evidence to support his case. Ghosn's escape has sparked a media frenzy, with Nissan also launching an internal investigation and obtaining an arrest warrant for his wife.

site_title: GrabFood unveils its first cloud kitchen in Singapore
summary: GrabFood, a food delivery service, has launched its first cloud kitchen in Singapore, dubbed GrabKitchen. The 6,000-square-foot facility in Hillview will enable merchants to rent cooking space and equipment, serving customers in the area without a dine-in area. GrabKitchen joins rivals foodpanda and deliveroo, and independent operators Smart City Kitchens, in the competitive vertical. The launch is part of GrabFood's expansion plans, which include opening more cloud kitchens across Southeast Asia and rolling out a unified app for merchants.

site_title: Antler injects US$1.4m into 14 startups from third Singapore programme
summary: Antler, a Singapore-founded startup generator, has invested US$1.4 million in 14 new companies from its third Singapore programme. The third cohort includes startups in healthtech, proptech, and greentech, with founders averaging eight years of work experience. Since its first Singapore cohort in 2018, Antler has generated 47 new tech companies from South-east Asia, with follow-on funding exceeding US$10 million. Globally, Antler has over 120 companies in its portfolio through its programmes in several cities. The investment was facilitated by a US$50 million funding round led by Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's construction demand remains strong in 2020, reaching a 5-year high of S$33.4 billion, driven by industrial construction demand. Singtel's Optus expects no material financial impact from Australian fires affecting its network. Retail shops in Sim Lim Square are up for sale at S$22 million. COE premiums rose on the eve of the motor show, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp ending at S$35,320. Indonesia's Bank BRI partners with Investree to offer loans to entrepreneurs. Singapore shares stage a recovery, dipping 0.1% on Wednesday.

site_title: Goat farm Hay Dairies wins tender for Lim Chu Kang land parcel
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) awarded a tender for a 10,000-square-metre land parcel at Lim Chu Kang to goat farm Hay Dairies for S$500,000. Hay Dairies' proposal incorporated innovative farming systems, including automation and water recycling. The agency will not award the other two parcels due to lack of proposals meeting requirements. SFA plans to tender out more sites for farming in the first half of 2020, prioritizing proposals that achieve high production levels sustainably.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 21.94 points to 1,589.10. Volume reached 3.9 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 883 to 171.

site_title: South Korea: Shares end at near 1-month low on escalation in Middle East crisis
summary: South Korean stocks closed at a near one-month low, down 1.11% at 2,151.31, due to heightened tensions in the Middle East. Iran's missile attacks on US-led forces in Iraq in retaliation to a US drone strike have raised fears of a wider war, dampening risk appetite among investors. The escalation in the crisis has led to a decline in global markets, with shares in the US and Europe also experiencing losses.

site_title: Indonesia's Bank BRI teams up with Investree to offer loans to entrepreneurs
summary: Bank BRI in Indonesia partners with Investree to offer up to $194.1 million in working capital loans to entrepreneurs, primarily in the creative sector. The loans will be based on invoice financing and will be approved through Investree's credit scoring analysis. This partnership aims to address the gap between banks and the creative sector, which typically lacks physical collateral. Bank BRI has already disbursed over $2 billion in loans on Investree, achieving a zero non-performing loan rate.

site_title: Australia: Shares pare losses as Trump reassures after Iran attacks; NZ down
summary: Australian shares trimmed losses after US President Donald Trump's comment on Middle East tensions, reassuring investors following Iranian missile attacks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.1% down, while New Zealand's benchmark fell 0.6%. Export-reliant healthcare stocks gained, while safe-haven gold stocks surged. The energy sector extended gains, while financials were hurt. Trump's tweet reassured investors, saying "all is well" and an assessment of casualties was underway.

site_title: Singapore shares stage recovery, dip 0.1% on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% in early trading on Wednesday, but recovered to end the session at 3,245.89, down 1.97 points or 0.06% from the previous day. The market rebounded after Iran's statement that it does not seek escalation or war, despite the US-led airstrike that killed top Iranian general Qasem Soleimani. Trading volume was high, with 2.12 billion securities traded, and the market saw a mix of gains and losses, with only 12 of the 30 counters ending in the red.

site_title: Hong Kong: Market closes down
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed down 0.83% on January 8, 2020, amid global market volatility due to US-Iran tensions. The Hang Seng index fell to 28,087.92, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 1.22% and 1.24%, respectively.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng index was down 0.83 per cent, or 234.14 points, to finish at 28,087.92.

site_title: The Avenir condo in River Valley to launch this weekend
summary: The Avenir condo in River Valley, jointly developed by GuocoLand, Hong Leong Holdings, and Hong Realty, is set to launch for sale on Jan 11, offering 376 freehold units from S$2,930 to S$3,030 per square foot. The condo is built on a 129,648 sq ft site and is near the Great World MRT station and Great World City mall. The developers had previously acquired the site for S$980 million, the largest collective sale in over a decade. The condo is expected to obtain its temporary occupation permit on Aug 1, 2025.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip as Iran targets US forces in Iraq
summary: Europe's main stock markets slid at the open on Wednesday following Iran's missile attacks on US targets in Iraq, a response to the killing of its top general. London's FTSE 100 index dropped 0.4%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index fell 0.8%, and the Paris CAC 40 reversed 0.5%. The attacks led to a decrease in investor confidence and a rise in volatility.

site_title: Facebook's new Singapore team to serve China advertising business
summary: Facebook is establishing a new engineering team in Singapore to focus on its China advertising business, developing regionally localized ad-buying tools for Chinese customers who work around internet restrictions. The team, with an "Asia-first" mission, will aim to ease access for Chinese advertisers, improve fraud detection systems, and provide e-commerce tools to organize influencers and set up storefronts. With China being Facebook's second-largest revenue source after the US, the move is seen as a key step to expand the company's presence in the region.

site_title: S-E Asia healthtech investments more than double in 2019
summary: Healthtech investments in South-east Asia more than doubled in 2019 to US$266 million, with an average funding value of US$5.6 million. The increase was driven by startups such as Halodoc's US$65 million Series B fundraise. Singapore led in terms of deal volume share, but its share narrowed as neighboring countries developed their ecosystems. Indonesia and Vietnam increased their deal volume share, while Thailand and the Philippines maintained their share. Healthtech funding has climbed at a rate of about 40% each year since 2014.

site_title: JLL hires ex-CBRE veteran as head of valuation and advisory services for S-E Asia
summary: JLL has hired James Crawford, a former CBRE executive director, as head of valuation and advisory services for South-east Asia, effective January 2020. Crawford brings 20 years of experience in valuation and advisory services, with a focus on data centres, to the role. He will oversee valuation services activities across Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines, and manage JLL's expansion into Malaysia. Crawford will report to John Talbot and Chris Fossick, and will work closely with the firm's institutional valuations team to assist clients with cross-border interests.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon down 0.63% on day
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.63% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index falling to 3,227.39. Trading resumed after morning losses, with AusGroup and Singtel seeing heavy volumes. Local banks DBS and UOB also experienced losses, while OCBC pared some of its losses. Despite the decline, Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks sag as US-Iran tension escalates
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 1.57% on Wednesday due to heightened US-Iran tension. The Nikkei 225 index fell 370.96 points to 23,204.76, while the Topix index dropped 23.65 points to 1,701.40. Iran stated it had concluded its missile attacks on US forces in Iraq for now, preventing a free-fall in the market.

site_title: Singapore Airlines adding fifth weekly flight to Kolkata
summary: Singapore Airlines will introduce a fifth weekly flight to Kolkata, India, on March 29, replacing SilkAir services. Existing SilkAir bookings will be re-accommodated on SIA flights. The additional flight will be operated by the Airbus A350-900 aircraft. This change follows SilkAir's integration into SIA's operations, with SilkAir to continue flying to four Indian cities. The move comes as SIA navigates regional developments, including Iran's missile strikes on US-Iraqi airbases.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars skid after attack on US forces in Iraq
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars plummeted after reports of a rocket attack on US forces at Iraq's Ain Al-Asad airbase, amid escalating tensions in the Middle East. The Australian dollar hit a three-week low of US$0.6850, while the New Zealand dollar fell 0.11% to US$0.6633. The attacks, attributed to Iran, prompted a surge in US crude prices and gold, while US stock market futures extended losses. Market analysts attributed the decline to risk sentiment, with investors seeking safe havens.

site_title: Lidar laser-sensing technology: from self-driving cars to dance contests
summary: Lidar laser-sensing technology, commonly used in self-driving cars, is being explored for various alternative uses, including monitoring cattle growth, synchronizing dance music, and even helping delivery robots. Companies like Ouster and AEye are seeking new customers to drive revenue, as the automotive market for lidar is expected to take years to materialize. These startups aim to diversify their business and keep their technology relevant, leveraging their expertise to serve diverse industries and applications.

site_title: Japan will keep deployment to Middle East to secure shipping lane: government
summary: Japan plans to maintain its military deployment to the Middle East to ensure ship safety, despite heightened tensions following the US killing of an Iranian military commander. The country's National Security Council will discuss the situation, but no decision has been made on Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's planned trip to Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Oman. Japan opted for its own security operation instead of joining a US-led mission, with plans to start deploying patrol planes in January.

site_title: Explore business opportunities in ASEAN
summary: ASEAN's regional economy continues to thrive despite global economic downturns, attracting global investors with its growing trade and commerce. The ASEAN market is seen as a "utopia" in a troubled world. Key business opportunities include sustainable marine fuel, with a startup aiming to halve its price. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Meanwhile, Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and puts a building up for sale, cutting 42 staff. Other notable developments include the rebranding of heritage businesses and the modernization of traditional snacks.

site_title: US water tech firm Xylem adds multi-disciplinary hub to regional HQ in Singapore
summary: US water tech firm Xylem has expanded its regional headquarters in Singapore with the launch of a new centre for water, wastewater, and energy technologies. The centre features a technology hub focusing on developing advanced products for water distribution and wastewater treatment. Xylem will collaborate with A*Star's Institute of High Performance Computing and PUB, the national water agency, to develop technologies such as high-precision leak detection and condition assessment. The centre also includes a customer experience centre and a training centre for South-east Asia, marking Xylem's 40-year presence in Singapore.

site_title: Koon Holdings to hold creditors' scheme meetings on Feb 25
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Koon Holdings and its subsidiary KCT will hold meetings on February 25 for their schemes of arrangement as part of debt restructuring. The Singapore High Court approved the applications and extended court protection until April 30. Koon Holdings has been assessing the ability of KCT to continue on a going concern basis since August 30 when its shares were suspended. Creditors will vote on the proposed schemes at 2pm and 4pm on February 25.

site_title: M1, SIT to jointly develop AI solutions for mobile network management
summary: TELCO M1 Limited and the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) have collaborated to develop artificial intelligence (AI) solutions for mobile network management. The partnership aims to reduce manual analysis of network key performance indicators and improve the efficiency of mobile networks. M1 will provide real-world data for data preprocessing, analysis, and interpretation, while SIT will research and develop algorithms for AI machine learning to detect mobile traffic anomalies and predict mobile traffic volume. The project's goals include developing a performance anomaly detection methodology and modeling active users in mobile networks.

site_title: Eastspring hires ex-TPG Capital exec as new CFO
summary: Eastspring Investments, the Asian investment management arm of Prudential plc, has appointed Francis Woo as its new Chief Financial Officer (CFO). Woo previously worked as CFO Asia for TPG Capital, overseeing profitability and investments in Asia. Eastspring also announced the appointment of Joyce Chan as head of intermediaries and, subject to regulatory approval, general manager of its Hong Kong office, where she will oversee sales and distribution of products through key channels. The appointments aim to drive business growth and improve financial management.

site_title: Luckin Coffee seeks more of China market with new vending machine business
summary: Luckin Coffee, China's largest coffee chain, is expanding into vending machines to sell hot beverages and snacks, aiming to tap into the market further. The company, founded by Qian Zhiya, has over 4,500 stores across China and has overtaken Starbucks. Luckin showcased two vending machines at an event, allowing it to be asset-light and nimble. The company made a net loss of 532 million yuan for the third quarter and is looking to expand overseas. This new strategy aims to increase its presence in the China market.

site_title: Ukrainian Boeing 737 crashes in Iran, all 170 aboard killed
summary: A Ukrainian Boeing 737-NG crashed shortly after taking off from Tehran's Imam Khomeini airport on January 8, 2020, killing all 176 people aboard. The cause of the crash is attributed to technical problems, according to Iranian state television. There were 167 passengers and 9 crew members on board, with 32 foreigners among the victims. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy expressed condolences to the families of the deceased, while Iran's emergency services struggled to access the site due to heavy flames.

site_title: Japan PM Abe to cancel weekend trip to Middle East: TV Asahi
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to cancel his weekend trip to the Middle East due to a National Security Council meeting, likely discussing Iran's attack on US forces in Iraq.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will cancel plans to visit Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Oman this weekend, TV Asahi reported on Wednesday.

site_title: AI-powered avatar at tech show touted as 'artificial human'
summary: A startup, Star Labs, has unveiled AI-powered avatars called NEONs at the Consumer Electronics Show, claiming they can "converse and sympathize" like real people. The digital creations, modeled after humans, can show highly detailed expressions and gestures, and even speak in languages they haven't spoken before. While some experts are impressed, others express concerns about the technology's potential for abuse, including its implications for deepfakes and the potential for NEONs to be used in ways that people may tolerate or actively hate.

site_title: Central banks might struggle to fight deep downturn: Carney
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned that central banks may struggle to combat a deep economic downturn due to depleted monetary policy arsenals from the 2008 global financial crisis. Carney stated that if a sharp economic downturn were to occur, it's unclear if monetary policy would have sufficient space to stimulate the economy. He also suggested that governments could boost growth through spending and tax policies, and reiterated Britain's decision not to agree to EU rules for the financial services sector post-Brexit.

site_title: SIA diverts flights from Iran airspace after attacks
summary: Singapore Airlines diverts flights from Iran airspace after Iran fires rockets at US-Iraqi airbases in response to the killing of General Qassem Soleimani. The attacks targeted the Ayn al-Asad base in western Iraq and another facility in Erbil. No immediate casualties or major damage were reported. The move comes as fears of a wider conflict in the Middle East reignite.

site_title: UK's Johnson to make Brexit demands in talks with EU chief
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will make Brexit demands in talks with EU Chief Ursula von der Leyen, stating Britain will not extend the Brexit transition period. Johnson's office said he will call for a "confident and positive future relationship" by the end of December, when the implementation period is due to end. The UK will not negotiate an extension to the transition period, and talks on a free trade agreement cannot formally begin until then. A failure to reach an agreement by the end of the year would result in Britain trading under World Trade Organisation rules.

site_title: Taiwan economy an electoral weak spot for Tsai despite strong record
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen is expected to secure a second term in elections this weekend, despite an economy squeezed by China's pressure campaign. Despite boasting a solid economic record, including low unemployment and strong export growth, her main challenger Han Kuo-yu has gained traction by emphasizing the need for warmer ties with China to boost Taiwan's fortunes. The outcome will have implications for Taiwan's relations with China and the US, and could impact global trade.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen looks set to secure a second term in elections this weekend, but her Achilles heel is an economy that China has squeezed relentlessly in an effort to assert its control over the island's future.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB maintains 'overweight' on banks amid digibank race; DBS top pick
summary: Singapore's banks are expected to face "manageable" financial impact from the digital bank race, according to CGS-CIMB analysts. Despite stiff competition, the brokerage maintains its "overweight" call on the sector, with DBS as its top pick at S$28.29. The analysts warn that regulatory requirements and compliance can be underestimated, giving banks with financial institution partners an advantage. However, the relaxation of regulatory requirements is a downside risk to the sector. Banking shares declined amid US-Iran tensions, with DBS falling 1.7%, OCBC decreasing 1.6%, and UOB dropping 1.6%.

site_title: Singtel's Optus does not expect material financial impact from Australian fires
summary: Optus, a subsidiary of Singtel, says the Australian bushfires will not have a material financial impact, despite initial damage to 17 base stations. The situation has improved, with intercity fibres operational, and sites requiring rebuilds. CEO Allen Lew stated that the damage is "pleasingly" limited to partial or full rebuilds.

site_title: Alibaba undercuts Amazon in Europe to woo wary brands
summary: Alibaba is undercutting Amazon sellers' fees to attract European vendors, with a flood of small businesses joining its AliExpress platform. However, larger brands such as Mango, Benetton, and Tendam have had limited success in partnering with the site. Despite this, Alibaba continues to approach well-known brands, indicating the company's efforts to expand its presence in Europe.

site_title: Singapore construction demand to remain strong in 2020 after hitting 5-year high last year
summary: Singapore's construction demand is expected to remain strong in 2020, reaching a five-year high in 2019 with a total value of S$33.4 billion. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) attributes the growth to a stronger-than-expected increase in industrial construction demand for petrochemical facilities. For 2020, BCA forecasts a total construction demand of S$28 billion to S$33 billion, driven by sustained public sector construction demand.

site_title: Japan's November household spending seen falling at slower pace: poll
summary: Japan's household spending is expected to fall at a slower annual rate in November, according to a Reuters poll, with a 1.7% decline from the previous year predicted. This marks a slower pace of decline than the 5.1% fall in October, which was the fastest pace since March 2016. The effect of the October sales tax hike may be slowly wearing off, but it is still expected to keep a lid on spending. The slower decline is seen as a positive sign for the economy.

site_title: US civil flights banned over Gulf, Iraq, Iran: regulator
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has banned US-registered carriers from flying over Iraq, Iran, and the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman due to rocket attacks on US forces in Iraq. The ban, effective immediately, prohibits civil aviation operations in the affected airspace. The FAA will continue to monitor the situation in the Middle East.

site_title: LHN joint venture to buy industrial property from Ascendas Reit for S$17m
summary: LHN, a Catalist-listed company, has entered into a 50:50 joint venture with an unnamed firm to acquire an industrial property in Singapore for S$17 million. The property, located at 202 Kallang Bahru, has a gross floor area of 20,465 square meters and a remaining tenure of over 20 years. LHN plans to manage the property for self-storage and logistics, and as an ancillary office. The acquisition is expected to complete by February 14, with no material impact on LHN's earnings per share or net tangible assets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 20.58 points lower, or 1.28%, at 1,590.46, with 174.55 million lots traded worth RM64.04 million. Losers outpaced gainers 286 to 80.

site_title: 'World cannot afford war': US Democrats respond to Iran missile strike
summary: US Democrats warn of escalating conflict in the Middle East after Iran launched a retaliatory missile strike against US forces in Iraq, in response to the US drone strike killing elite Quds Force commander Qassem Soleimani. The attack, which targeted at least two Iraqi military bases, has heightened tensions between the two countries. Democrats, including presidential contenders, urge caution and restraint to avoid further conflict. The incident has raised concerns about the global implications of the crisis and the ability of the world to afford another war.

site_title: WeWork's Adam Neumann in talks to boost investment in mortgage-servicing startup
summary: WeWork co-founder Adam Neumann's family office is in talks to invest an additional $1 million in Peach Street Inc, a mortgage-servicing startup. The investment, part of a $4 million convertible note, will support the company's growth and enable mortgage holders to make payments and access information on a secure digital platform. Peach Street was founded by three friends, and the investment is seen as an opportunity to disrupt the antiquated mortgage-servicing industry.

site_title: Trendlines co-invests in pesticides startup
summary: Trendlines Group, a startup incubator, has co-invested in ProJini Agchem, a pesticides startup, through its Bayer Trendlines Ag Innovation Fund. ProJini Agchem focuses on developing novel pesticides with new modes of action, targeting protein-protein interactions. The investment boosts Trendlines' ag-bio sector and aims to discover targeted pesticides less harmful to the environment. No investment amount was disclosed.

site_title: Impersonators, fake accounts creep in as world leaders shun TikTok
summary: World leaders and politicians are shunning TikTok due to national security concerns, leaving room for impersonators to spread false information. The Chinese-owned app lacks a robust verification system, allowing fake accounts to impersonate prominent figures, including US President Donald Trump and UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Despite efforts to remove fake accounts, the platform's immature verification process has raised concerns among experts, who describe it as a "ticking time bomb".

site_title: United takes US$90m charge on drag from strife in Hong Kong
summary: United Airlines is taking a US$90 million non-cash charge in the 2019 fourth quarter due to a decline in demand for flights to Hong Kong, affected by protests against the Chinese government. Visitor arrivals fell 56% in November, with a 43% year-on-year decline from the US. This marks the second time United has taken a significant charge related to slot restrictions at congested airports, following a US$412 million charge in 2016. United's fourth-quarter financial results will be reported on January 21.

site_title: Singapore passport no longer most powerful in the world
summary: Singapore has lost its top spot in the Henley Passport Index, ranking second with 190 visa-free or visa-on-arrival destinations, behind Japan's 191. Japan retained access to Suriname, a country Singapore previously had visa exemptions for, which led to Singapore's drop. The US and UK also fell to eighth place, experiencing a significant decline in passport power since 2015. The index highlights a growing global mobility gap, with Japanese passport holders accessing 165 more destinations than Afghan nationals.

site_title: Oil prices spike over 4.5% after Iran attacks
summary: Oil prices surged over 4.5% after Iran fired ballistic missiles at US and coalition forces' airbases in Iraq, prompting a US response to the assassination of military commander Qasem Soleimani. The benchmark WTI jumped to US$65.54 a barrel before settling down. The spike in oil prices is attributed to heightened tensions in the Middle East, which may lead to potential disruptions in oil production and supply.

site_title: Shareholders pile pressure on Barclays to cut fossil fuel financing
summary: A group of Barclays shareholders, backed by responsible investment lobby group ShareAction, have filed a resolution to phase out financing of fossil fuels, stepping up pressure on the bank to align with the Paris climate agreement. Eleven institutional investors, managing £130 billion, are calling for Barclays to set specific targets to stop providing financial services to firms not aligned with the Paris climate agreement. The move comes after outgoing Bank of England governor Mark Carney warned of the financial industry's slow response to cut investment in fossil fuels.
