images.alt_text: A group of Barclays shareholders coordinated by responsible investment lobby group ShareAction want the bank to phase out financing fossil fuels, stepping up pressure on one of Europe's biggest funders of the sector.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares slip as rocket attack on Iraq base quells risk appetite
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.9% to 6,768 due to a rocket attack on a US-led base in Iraq, sparking concerns of a wider war in the Middle East. US President Donald Trump vowed to retaliate if Iran attacked any US assets or Americans. Risk-averse sentiment hurt financials, with the "Big Four" lenders and healthcare stocks declining. Safe-haven gold stocks surged, and energy stocks reached a 15-month high. The decline affected both Australia and New Zealand, with the NZ benchmark S&P/NZX 50 falling 0.6%.

site_title: Singapore shares open sharply lower on Wednesday amid US-Iran tensions; STI down 1.23%
summary: Singapore shares plummeted 1.23% on Wednesday amid rising US-Iran tensions, with the Straits Times Index falling 39.82 points to 3,208.04. The US reported Iran had fired over a dozen ballistic missiles at Iraq airbases housing US and coalition forces. Local banks also fell, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB losing 1.4%, 1.7%, and 1.5% respectively. Global markets also slid, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 closing lower, while the Nasdaq Composite dipped a fraction.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slump in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened sharply down on January 8, 2020, due to escalating Middle East tensions, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.26% to 27,965.84. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, retreating 0.34% and 0.46%, respectively. The decline was attributed to heightened global uncertainty and market volatility.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares opened sharply down Wednesday morning, as Middle East tensions dramatically escalated with Iran launching a missile attack.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open sharply lower on geopolitical worries
summary: Tokyo stocks opened sharply lower on January 8, 2020, due to escalating tensions between the US and Iran, weighing on investors' confidence. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.57% or 370.40 points to 23,205.32, while the Topix index fell 1.35% or 23.32 points. This was amidst a global economic backdrop, with the US and EU in trade talks and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Stocks to watch: QAF, Kimly, Trendlines, LHN, TEE, China Haida
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore-listed companies saw new developments that may affect trading of their shares. QAF's pork production business remains unaffected by ongoing Australian bushfires. Kimly's lead independent director is retiring, while Trendlines Group co-invested in pesticides startup ProJini Agchem. LHN will acquire a JTC industrial property for S$17 million. TEE International's proposed sale of shares is still pending completion. China Haida's shares are under review by SGX RegCo due to recent trades. Mercurius Capital Investment requested a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: 11 retail shops in Sim Lim Square up for sale at S$22m
summary: A portfolio of 11 retail shops in Sim Lim Square, a 99-year leasehold electronics mall in Singapore, is up for sale via expression of interest for S$22 million. The total strata area is approximately 5,000 square feet, with unit sizes ranging from 291 sq ft to 506 sq ft. The sale is open to locals and foreigners with no additional buyer's stamp duty and seller's stamp duty imposed. The sale exercise closes on February 18, following a previous collective sale tender in December 2019.

images.alt_text: The shops, which can be bought collectively or as individual units, face the central podium on the fifth floor of Sim Lim Square mall.

site_title: Samsung Electronics estimates Q4 operating profit down more than a third
summary: Samsung Electronics estimates its Q4 operating profit will fall 34.2% year-over-year to 7.1 trillion won, down from the previous period. Sales are forecasted to remain flat at 59 trillion won. This decline is attributed to the company's decreased operating profit.

site_title: Iran fired 'more than a dozen' missiles at US forces in Iraq: Pentagon
summary: Iran fired "more than a dozen" ballistic missiles at US airbases in Iraq on January 7, targeting Al-Assad and Irbil bases hosting US and coalition forces. The attack, which occurred at approximately 5:30pm GMT, was launched from Iran and caused damage to the facilities. The Pentagon confirmed that the missiles were launched and attributed the attack to Iran.

site_title: Trial opens in Japan for grisly murder of 19 at disabled home
summary: A trial has opened in Japan for the 2016 murder of 19 disabled people at a care home, with Satoshi Uematsu, a 29-year-old former employee, admitting to the stabbing rampage. Uematsu faces six charges, including murder, and could face the death penalty if convicted. His lawyer plans to enter a plea of not guilty on grounds of diminished capacity, citing Uematsu's reported use of marijuana at the time of the attack. The case has raised questions about Japan's integration of people with disabilities, with critics arguing the country still falls short in fully including them.

site_title: Gold holds near six-year high with Iran's next moves in focus
summary: Gold prices remain near a six-year high due to escalating tensions in the Middle East, particularly with Iran, as investors seek the metal as a safe-haven asset. Spot gold rose 0.4% to $1,572.64 an ounce, with analysts citing geopolitical risks and bullish fundamental tailwinds as supporting factors. However, history suggests that gains driven by tensions may be short-lived, and other factors such as a weaker dollar and uncertainty over US-China trade deal also contribute to gold's price stability.

site_title: Australian bushfire smoke obscures skies half a world away
summary: Smoke from Australian bushfires has spread halfway across the world, darkening skies in Argentina and beyond, 11,793km east of Sydney. Over 10 million hectares have burned, killing at least 24 people and generating their own weather systems. The fires have destroyed 1,500 homes in New South Wales, with 480 million animals killed. The Australian government has pledged A$2 billion for recovery efforts, but critics blame Prime Minister Scott Morrison's conservative stance on climate change for exacerbating the crisis.

site_title: US insists no plans to pull out of Iraq
summary: The US has denied plans to withdraw its over 5,000 troops from Iraq, with President Donald Trump calling it the "worst thing" for the country. Defense Secretary Mark Esper said US policy remains unchanged, dismissing a letter from a US general stating the US would redeploy troops due to Iraq's sovereignty. The letter was reportedly sent to Iraq's government, but its authenticity was disputed by the Pentagon.

site_title: Ghosn accuses Nissan of sham takedown
summary: Former Nissan executive Carlos Ghosn has accused the company of conducting a sham internal investigation to block his integration with Renault. Ghosn claims the investigation was designed to take down his allies and protect favored executives, not to find the truth. Ghosn, who fled Japan on December 31 to escape what he described as a "rigged justice system," is now facing trial for alleged crimes. Nissan has stated it will take "appropriate legal action" against Ghosn.

site_title: Money FM podcast: sgCarMart's Car of the Year
summary: The sgCarMart Car of the Year podcast discusses the winners and nominees in various categories, including sedans, hatchbacks, and SUVs. Julian Kho and Claressa Monteiro share their opinions on the selected cars, with no specific winners announced in the article.

site_title: Oil falls 1% as investors reassess Middle East risks
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Tuesday, reversing recent gains, as investors reassessed the likelihood of Middle East supply disruptions after the US killed a top Iranian military commander. Brent crude fell to $68.27 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell to $62.70 a barrel. Despite fears of escalating conflict, Chevron's CEO said oil markets remain well supplied, and consultancy Eurasia Group predicted Iran would focus on US military targets rather than energy infrastructure.

site_title: S&P raises Argentina debt rating, citing prior mistake
summary: S&P Global Ratings has raised Argentina's debt rating to 'CCC-' from 'CC', two notches higher than its previous rating in December 2019. The agency acknowledged it made a mistake when it initially changed the rating and is now correcting the error. The rating change is attributed to a prior misapplication of criteria.

site_title: Portal to track cross-border payments launched
summary: Standard Chartered has launched a publicly accessible portal, SC GPI Track, allowing cross-border payments to be tracked in real-time. The portal enables clients to track payments processed by the bank's major clearing centers to their customers and counterparts. This move aims to enhance trust and dependability in cross-border payments, supporting the growth of supply chains. The launch is seen as a sign of leadership and innovation, as it facilitates e-commerce by moving money faster. The portal is available for use by over 11,000 banking and securities organizations worldwide.

site_title: Carlos Ghosn's wife says she wasn't in the loop about his escape
summary: Former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn's wife, Carole, says she was unaware of his escape from Japan on December 29-30, calling it the "only choice possible" due to his trial being postponed indefinitely and detention conditions. Ghosn denies financial misconduct charges and accuses Nissan executives of a "plot" to prevent closer integration with Renault. He fled Japan, boarded private jets, and entered Lebanon on a French passport, exploiting a loophole in airport security rules.

images.alt_text: Former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn's wife Carole said on Tuesday she was not in the loop about his audacious escape from Japan, adding that it was the "only choice possible."

site_title: Europe: Chip rally help shares rise amid geopolitical tensions
summary: A rally in semiconductor stocks, led by Microchip Technology's sales outlook, helped European shares rise on Tuesday. German and Italian shares strengthened, with the DAX and Italian stocks rising 0.8% and 0.6%, respectively. The Stoxx 600 index finished 0.2% higher, despite falling in the past two sessions due to tensions between the US and Iran. Oil prices and auto stocks also made gains, while luxury carmaker Aston Martin plummeted 16% due to weak European markets.

site_title: US: Stocks slide amid geopolitical uncertainty
summary: US stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 0.4% to 28,583.68, and the S&P 500 shedding 0.3% to 3,237.18. The decline came amid escalating tensions between the US and Iran following the killing of Qasem Soleimani. Despite a mass funeral procession in Iran, which led to a stampede, and Iranian lawmakers' designation of all US forces as "terrorists", the market is expected to recover once the initial shock wears off. Positive economic news, including a low US trade deficit and a rising services index, also supports the markets.

site_title: Pompeo defends legality of US killing Iran's Soleimani
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo defended the legality of the drone strike that killed Iranian General Qasem Soleimani, stating that the administration thoroughly reviewed any potential action. He focused on Soleimani's past actions rather than the "imminent" threat claim used to justify the strike. Pompeo also rejected claims that Soleimani was on a diplomatic mission and not involved in any peace deal. He assured that any future US action will adhere to international laws of war, including avoiding attacks on cultural sites.

site_title: North America trade deal advances in US Senate but delay possible
summary: The US Senate voted 25-3 in favor of ratifying the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), a trade pact signed in 2018. The bill's implementation is now uncertain due to the ongoing impeachment trial of President Donald Trump, which may delay the process. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell plans to focus on the USMCA after the trial, but the bill is also being subjected to procedural moves that could further delay a final vote. Despite this, most US lawmakers appear to favor the bill, which aims to improve market access, manufacturing, and a level playing field for American workers.

site_title: Uber partners Hyundai on electric air taxi
summary: Uber and Hyundai have teamed up to develop electric air taxis, joining the global effort to reduce urban congestion. The partnership aims to commercialize air taxi services by 2028, with Hyundai producing and deploying the vehicles and Uber providing aerial ride-share services. The companies have differing timelines, with Uber aiming to launch its air taxi service by 2023 and Hyundai expecting a 2028 launch. The partnership also includes Boeing's Aurora Flight Sciences, with a concept electric aircraft to be unveiled at CES.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ISEC Healthcare is set to acquire Indah Specialist Eye Centre in Johor Baru, Malaysia for RM37.4 million (S$12.3 million). The eye centre has maintained stable income and a profit track record for three years. The purchase price is based on a multiple of 13 times the eye centre's adjusted profit. ISEC Healthcare will conserve cash reserves by partially settling the consideration through the allotment and issue of new shares. The acquisition is expected to provide a growing stream of recurring income and cash flow.

site_title: Recipe for success
summary: Business owners must adapt to disruption and transformation to stay ahead in the ever-changing landscape. Dian Xiao Er, a Chinese restaurant chain, overcame initial skepticism about automating cooking processes, resulting in increased productivity and growth. Similarly, You Tiao Man's Audrey Chew is innovating her family's food business, introducing new products such as charcoal and wholegrain you tiao. These entrepreneurs' success stories highlight the importance of embracing change and innovation to achieve business success.

site_title: HK landlords face tough times as shop, office rents sink
summary: Hong Kong landlords face a challenging year due to anti-government protests and a slump in tourist arrivals, leading to declining shop and office rents. Over 5,600 jobs could be lost and thousands of stores may shut in the next six months. International brands have scaled back operations, and luxury brands such as Prada and LVMH have closed stores. However, some analysts see the downturn as an opportunity, with Citigroup predicting sequential improvements in retail sales from January onwards.

site_title: Boeing changes stance, recommends 737 MAX simulator training for pilots
summary: Boeing is recommending that 737 MAX pilots undergo simulator training before resuming flight operations, a shift from its previous stance that only computer-based training was required. This change could delay airlines' preparation to fly the grounded 737 MAX jets, which have been grounded since March after two crashes. Regulatory approval from the US Federal Aviation Administration is expected to be given at least by February, possibly March or later, with Boeing working on revised pilot training and software updates.

site_title: Ingredients for success
summary: Dian Xiao Er's founder, Samuel Yik, attributes the success of his restaurant to a combination of technology solutions and a quality workforce. Despite investing in automation and tech, he emphasizes the importance of his staff, paying them higher than market rate, providing career prospects, and encouraging strong relationships. Yik also values transparency and honesty, setting an example by never scolding his chefs and teaching employees self-respect. The company's membership program and app have been successful in building a community of fans and encouraging customer loyalty. With 13 outlets in Singapore and plans to expand to China, Dian Xiao Er's focus on quality, technology, and staff satisfaction has contributed to its success.

site_title: Gold prices edge higher as US-Iran tensions persist
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,569.27 per ounce, erasing early losses, amid persistent US-Iran tensions, with warnings of new strikes and retaliation by both countries. The US denied a visa to Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, boosting concerns about a broader Middle East conflict. Analysts predict gold prices may reach $1,625 this quarter, but then normalize between $1,500-1,600, depending on events.

site_title: Liberalisation of power retail market fuels trading surge in SGX futures
summary: Singapore's electricity futures market saw a significant surge in trading volumes in 2019, with the contract more than tripling to nearly 30,000 gigawatt hours, driven by the liberalisation of the power sector under the Open Electricity Market. The liberalisation allowed electricity retailers to manage price risks and lock in selling costs, leading to increased participation from the sector. The market now accounts for 60% of the underlying spot market, with most retailers using the contracts to hedge their risks, although only one out of five major "gentailers" is actively using them.

site_title: Shippers' forum adds fuel to the ire
summary: The Global Shippers Forum (GSF) has released "Top Ten Tips for Sulphur-Surcharged Shippers," which advises shippers to challenge the basis of surcharges from shipping lines for complying with the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) new sulphur emissions limit. GSF suggests shippers negotiate with carriers, scrutinize fuel costs, and demand clear explanations for surcharges. However, shipping and bunker industries have criticized GSF's advice, particularly regarding the term "low sulphur fuel oil" (LSFO), which refers to fuel oil with less than 1.0% sulphur and does not meet current regulations.

site_title: Markets rise as US-Iran worries recede
summary: US-Iran tensions recede, lifting markets as global economic recovery and accommodative monetary policy continue to support equities. The Straits Times Index in Singapore jumped 0.9% to close at 3,247.86, with regional markets also rising. However, Taiwan's Taiex Index fell 0.6% due to a strengthening New Taiwan dollar. Analysts expect more volatility this week, but note that Iran is likely to respond indirectly and with plausible deniability, rather than a direct and ham-fisted response.

site_title: Asian currencies gain after jitters over US-Iran
summary: Asian currencies rose after a brief jitters over US-Iran tensions, with the South Korean won gaining 0.7% and the Indian rupee and Indonesian rupiah appreciating 0.3% each. The Chinese yuan reached a five-month high, while the Philippine peso gained 0.6%. Oil prices moderated, and markets remain cautious due to the ongoing confrontation. Analysts expect sustained oil price increases to pose upside risk to inflation in the Philippines, but retain a view that the central bank can cut its policy interest rate as early as the first quarter this year.

site_title: Is China becoming the world's most sophisticated surveillance regime?
summary: China is reportedly developing the world's most sophisticated surveillance regime, with the social credit system set to be implemented in 2020. Despite being criticized as Orwellian or Black Mirror-esque, experts argue that the system is more about reinforcing government blacklists and giving them "teeth." China's dominance in the digital economy, particularly through companies like Alibaba and Tencent, allows for the extraction of vast amounts of behavioral surplus data, fueling concerns about the erosion of individuality and the potential for digital tyranny.

site_title: Pan Pacific group looks to landmark year with new brand, more hotels
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group is set for a landmark year with key openings in London, Bangkok, Hanoi, Jakarta, and China's first Parkroyal hotel in Dalian. The group, which has nearly 50 properties across 29 cities, will open eight new properties across its brands in 2020, with a focus on gateway cities in Vietnam, China, Germany, and the US. The launch of Parkroyal Collection Hotels & Resorts, a new eco-friendly brand, marks a significant expansion for the group, with Singapore expected to account for 50-60% of revenue in the future.

site_title: When climate risks and politics collide
summary: A growing divide between climate activism and nationalism threatens global cooperation on climate change. Despite scientific consensus that this decade is humanity's last chance to change course, nationalist narratives prioritizing national interests over global solidarity are gaining traction. Climate activists are pushing for a "one planet" approach, emphasizing human responsibility and solidarity, but nationalist politicians are resisting, prioritizing short-term gains and minimizing losses. The lack of progress in COP25 climate negotiations and the rise of populist nationalism make a global climate agreement increasingly difficult to achieve, with China and India playing a crucial role in the outcome.

site_title: China sales will remain weak this year: GM
summary: General Motors (GM) predicts China's auto market will remain weak in 2020, with sales expected to decline further due to a prolonged economic slump and trade tensions with the US. In 2019, GM sold 3.09 million vehicles in China, a 15% decline from the previous year. The company expects ongoing headwinds in its China business, with a focus on introducing at least 10 new energy vehicles in the next four years.

site_title: China digibank players are old hands in search of fresh pastures
summary: Chinese players are entering Singapore's wholesale banking space, driven by their expertise and experience in serving the Chinese market. Four out of five digital wholesale bank license applications involve Chinese companies, including Ant Financial and ByteDance. Industry watchers note that this could lead to concentration risk, but also bring new perspectives and innovative approaches to risk management. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will assess the applications, considering factors such as the risk of overdominance by one group.

site_title: Facebook tightening policy against deepfakes
summary: Facebook has strengthened its policy against deepfakes, a type of doctored video, to address the growing threat ahead of the US election. The platform will remove content edited or synthesised beyond adjustments for quality or clarity, but will not apply to parody or satire. Videos deemed misleading will be fact-checked by over 50 organisations and may still be removed. Facebook collaborated with Reuters to help newsrooms identify deepfakes through online courses, following a similar incident last year involving a manipulated video of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

site_title: Frittering away corporate life
summary: Audrey Chew, founder of You Tiao Man, transformed her family's traditional you tiao business into a successful food manufacturing company in Singapore. After returning from China in 2017, Chew took the risk of starting a new venture, leveraging her experience in the commodities industry to create innovative products like charcoal and wholegrain you tiao. Through resilience and adaptability, Chew overcame challenges and expanded her business, supplying her products to restaurants, hotels, and food courts, earning recognition, including the Healthier Choice Symbol.

site_title: An exceptional Liverpool year deserves a treat
summary: Liverpool is set to win England's top football division for the first time in 30 years, with the title likely to be sealed on April 11 with an expected victory over Aston Villa at Anfield. The Reds currently hold a 13-point advantage over Leicester and 14-point lead over Manchester City with a game in hand. If Liverpool were to falter, the title could be decided as early as April 4 if they prevail at Manchester City's Etihad Stadium.

site_title: Toronto smart city project faces timber use challenge
summary: Toronto's Sidewalk Labs is facing challenges in building a "smart city" project, with a proposed 30-plus storey timber building exceeding current building codes. The project, which aims to incorporate sustainability, is being scrutinized by Waterfront Toronto's board, citing outdated regulations and geography constraints. Experts warn that North America has been slow to adopt timber buildings, which have climate-friendly potential, and that Sidewalk must adapt to meet building code requirements. The project's fate will be decided by the Waterfront Toronto board on March 31.

site_title: Smart cities aren't smart without trust
summary: Singapore's Smart Nation initiative aims to transform daily life with IoT and digital connectivity. The city has introduced SingPass Mobile, a fingerprint authentication system for government services, and a Personal Alert Button for older citizens to call for help. Additionally, smart sensors are being developed to improve living standards. However, the increasing reliance on digital technology also raises concerns about vulnerability to hacking. Experts emphasize the importance of trust in smart city initiatives to ensure their benefits are realized and security is maintained.

site_title: Debunking myths about business payment cards
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore can benefit from using business payment cards by extending their days payable outstanding, optimizing working capital, and improving cash flow. With up to 55 days of interest-free payment, SMEs can "buy now and pay later." Despite common misconceptions, business credit cards can provide rewards, better control of cash flow, and increased efficiency. The use of digital payments, such as PayNow Corporate and eInvoicing Framework, is also becoming more prevalent among SMEs, with over 110,000 organizations signing up for digital payment options.

site_title: Consumer Internet firm Sea flies solo in bid for full digibank licence
summary: Sea, a consumer internet firm, has announced its solo bid for Singapore's full digital bank licence, focusing on serving millennials and SMEs. The company, which remains loss-making, has a market capitalization of $19 billion and plans to draw from its digital ecosystem to innovate financial services. Sea's founder and chairman Forrest Li has emphasized the company's ability to address unmet needs and has developed capabilities to design and scale a full digital bank. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has revealed seven applicants for the digital full bank licences, with three more expected to announce their bids.

images.alt_text: Consumer Internet company Sea, formerly known as Garena, is the first to officially announce its solo bid for the digital full bank licence in Singapore, even as the New York-listed entity remains loss making.

site_title: OCBC Cycle launches new all-women cycling race
summary: OCBC Cycle has launched the OCBC Cycle Speedway Women's Championship, an all-women cycling race category, to encourage female participation in competitive cycling. The event features teams of four, with two pairs competing in a unique format where the first pair cycles five laps and the second pair completes the next five laps on a one-kilometre track. The initiative aims to promote women's cycling and provide a platform for female cyclists to showcase their skills.

images.alt_text: (From left) Samuel Tsien, group CEO of OCBC Bank; Chiang Hock Woon, deputy CEO of Sports Singapore, and Lee Yulin, sports editor of The Straits Times at the launch at Singapore Sports Hub's OCBC Square.

site_title: Balancing speed with sustainable growth
summary: Market-leading entrepreneurs have a disciplined framework for driving growth, known as the EY 7 Drivers of Growth, which helps companies align capabilities with growth strategies. The framework focuses on seven distinct levers: customer, people, technology, operations, transactions, finance, and risk. To balance speed and sustainability, entrepreneurs must manage these growth drivers, prioritize customer agility, leverage technology, and invest in talent. Effective risk management is also crucial, involving calculated risks and mitigating risks through partnerships, acquisitions, and alliances. By adopting this approach, entrepreneurs can achieve sustainable growth and create a competitive advantage.

site_title: Payment delays worsen among Singapore firms for third straight quarter
summary: Singapore firms saw a third consecutive quarter of increasing slow payments, with the retail and services sectors leading the way. Slow payments rose 2.46 percentage points to 39.75% in Q4 2019, with retail payments increasing by 4.33 percentage points. The construction sector also saw a rise, while manufacturing payments decreased. Prompt payments fell 2.58 percentage points to 46.23%, while partial payments reached a new peak. The trend suggests companies are taking steps to ensure creditworthiness despite payment delays.

site_title: Property data
summary: Key property news in Singapore includes Royal Healthcare's planned opening of a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, and Shatec's decision to shut its Orchard campus and put the building up for sale, resulting in 42 staff layoffs. OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Meanwhile, Hao Mart's Taste Orchard struggles with poor footfall and vacant units, prompting tenant concerns. Chinatown Business Association seeks compensation from Nanyang Old Coffee over the use of an outdoor area.

site_title: Oil dips as fears of supply disruption ease
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday as fears of Middle East supply disruptions eased following the US killing of Iran's military commander Qassem Soleimani. Brent crude dropped 1.5% to $67.86 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures fell 1.5% to $62.85 a barrel. Analysts tempered expectations for a widespread conflict, citing Iran's need for foreign currency earnings from oil exports and the potential for low-level harassment of commercial shipping. Opec production met quotas, and US crude oil stockpiles likely dropped for a fourth week in a row.

site_title: Boeing to reassign 3,000 workers as airlines reach deals over grounded MAX
summary: Boeing will reassign 3,000 workers to other jobs as it halts 737 MAX production in mid-January due to the ongoing grounding. This follows settlements with airlines like American Airlines Group and Aeromexico, which will receive undisclosed compensation. Boeing will not lay off or furlough workers, and some staff will be reassigned to work on other aircraft models. The Federal Aviation Administration is expected to delay the plane's return to service until at least February, with US airlines planning to resume flights in early April.

site_title: Making customer experience everybody's job
summary: Singaporean brands struggle to provide a good customer experience, with 14 out of 16 brands ranked in Forrester's 2018 Singapore Customer Experience Index scoring poorly. To improve the customer experience, companies can build a customer-centric culture, align employee incentives with customer success, and encourage customer-centricity within their teams by updating job descriptions, moving the goalpost, making it visible, and making it actionable. By doing so, companies can stand out from the competition and drive business growth through customer loyalty, increased lifetime value, and word-of-mouth recommendations.

site_title: Harvey Weinstein charged with rape in Los Angeles as NY trial opens
summary: Harvey Weinstein has been charged with rape in Los Angeles, in addition to his ongoing trial in New York. Two women alleged that Weinstein raped them in separate incidents in 2013, with one woman reporting that he threatened her life after the assault. The Los Angeles charges carry a maximum sentence of 28 years in prison. Weinstein, 67, has been accused of sexual misconduct by over 80 women, including prominent actresses, and faces up to life in prison if convicted of predatory sexual assault.

site_title: Managing cash flows together
summary: Banks are partnering with fintechs to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) manage cash flows. SMEs require three types of financing: capital investment, operational costs, and managing receivables. A tight cash cycle allows for better financial forecasting, but late payments pose a challenge, with up to 40% of payments arriving late. This partnership aims to offload financial risk and provide better liquidity management for SMEs, enabling them to make informed business decisions and invest in growth initiatives.

images.alt_text: "Many businesses continue to hold the belief that having debt on their balance sheet is detrimental. Our studies show that debt can be a growth-enabler when prudent capital management is exercised."- Vikas Nahata, co-founder and executive chairman of Validus.

"We focus on the life cycle of the business. What that means is supporting businesses as they grow from startups, into middle market and then established SMEs." - Tan Chor Sen, head of International, Global Commercial Banking at OCBC Bank.

site_title: Astaka auditors flag going concern issues amid muted M'sian property market
summary: Astaka Holdings, a Singapore-listed property developer, has been flagged by its auditors for going concern issues due to the muted Malaysian property market. The auditors, KPMG, highlighted uncertainties related to the company's ability to generate sufficient operating cash flows to cover operating costs and settle current liabilities. Astaka incurred a net loss of RM113.7 million for the year ended June 30 and has prepared an 18-month consolidated cash flow forecast to ensure sufficient funds. The company's financial statements are prepared on a going concern basis, pending the outcome of an independent review.

site_title: China's Dec forex reserves rise as yuan rebounds
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves rose $12.3 billion in December to $3.108 trillion, exceeding expectations. The yuan rebounded after the US and China reached a partial trade deal. For 2019, reserves climbed $35.2 billion, compared to a $67.2 billion drop in 2018. Strict capital controls have helped China maintain control over outflows. The People's Bank of China plans to let financial markets decide exchange rates, while keeping the yuan stable within a reasonable range. China's economic growth target for 2020 is set at around 6% due to increased state infrastructure spending.

site_title: China farmers reap rich harvest through video-sharing apps
summary: Chinese beekeeper Ma Gongzuo has turned his family's honey production business into a successful venture through video-sharing apps like Douyin, a platform with 400 million users in China. By showcasing his daily life on the farm, Ma has attracted a large following and earns up to 2 million yuan in annual sales. Douyin's parent company has also trained 26,000 farmers on how to make videos, further fueling the trend of farmers using online platforms to sell their products.

site_title: US$5b New Jersey mall bucks retail nightmare, nears 90% lease rate
summary: The US$5 billion American Dream mega-mall in New Jersey has leased almost 90% of its 3.3 million square feet, with all retail anchor stores secured. This contradicts the slow demise of physical retail, with fewer than half of US malls expected to survive store closings. The mall's attractions, including a Nickelodeon Universe park and ice skating rink, have contributed to its success, and its accessibility to New York City has also drawn in businesses. The retail side of the mall will open in March with over 450 businesses.

site_title: Fed signals high bar for rate move while Iran tensions simmer
summary: The Federal Reserve signaled a high bar for a rate move, indicating it will take a significant change in the economic outlook to raise or lower interest rates. Despite heightened tensions with Iran, the Fed will keep rates on hold for the year, citing the country's economic resilience and the effects of recent rate cuts. Economists believe the US economy is sound, and any material reassessment of the outlook is unlikely, with higher oil prices being a potential risk.

site_title: 'Dividend aristocrats', EM bonds key strategies in 2020 for conservative investors: BNP Paribas
summary: BNP Paribas advises conservative investors to focus on "dividend aristocrats" in 2020, given depressed bond yields and moderate earnings recovery. These developed-market stocks have increased payouts in each of the past 25 years, offering better-than-average risk/return compared to other equities. This strategy is particularly suitable for investors allocating a larger proportion to fixed income.

site_title: Fund managers cite ESG adoption as major growth driver: IMAS survey
summary: A survey by the Investment Management Association of Singapore (IMAS) found that 68% of fund managers cite environmental, social, and governance (ESG) adoption as the biggest driver of investment growth over the next three years. This is a significant increase from 47% in last year's survey. ESG integration is seen as a key strategy to attract investors, with the European Union expected to implement a taxonomy on ESG this year. The survey also highlighted tensions between the US and China as the top concern among asset managers, with 79% citing this as a major issue.

site_title: Byron Wien predicts S&P 500 will top 3,500 as Fed cuts rates
summary: US stocks are expected to continue their record-setting rally in 2020, with the S&P 500 predicted to top 3,500 at some point this year, according to Byron Wien's annual list of surprises. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates to 1% to spur economic growth, which will trail forecasts but avoid a recession. Wien and investment strategist Joe Zidle also predict a US-China trade deal will not be reached, with President Trump cutting payroll taxes to stimulate growth, and yields on 10-year Treasuries to approach 2.5%.

site_title: Samsung enters smart home market with array of gadgets
summary: Samsung has entered the smart home market with a range of gadgets, including the Galaxy Home Mini smart speaker and prototype augmented reality glasses. The Galaxy Home Mini, powered by Bixby, focuses on voice commands and appliance control, prioritizing consumer privacy over AI-driven conversations. Samsung aims to build a unique ecosystem around the Mini, connecting it to various devices and appliances. The company's smart home strategy is part of its "Age of Experience" initiative, which includes wearable technology and artificial intelligence-driven products.

site_title: Johnson to press EC president for quick trade talks
summary: Boris Johnson is urging the European Union to speed up trade talks after Brexit, aiming to complete a deal by year's end. However, EU President Ursula von der Leyen doubts this can be achieved in 11 months. The UK's Foreign Secretary and trade secretary are pushing for parallel trade negotiations with the US to pressure the EU, while others consider this tactic unwise. The UK's new Cabinet, led by Michael Gove, will form in early February, and trade negotiations are expected to continue with a potential EU summit in March.

site_title: Data, platform building key for SourceSage
summary: SourceSage, founded in 2015, has successfully introduced price transparency into B2B physical commodities trading, despite initial challenges. The company, which is already profitable with over 100,000 users in 110 countries, is now focusing on building platforms as its primary source of revenue. Despite its growth, SourceSage's leadership continues to deepen its expertise in commodity trading, aiming to disrupt the murky world of B2B commodities trading.

site_title: SGX RegCo reviewing China Haida trades
summary: SGX RegCo is reviewing China Haida's recent trades due to a surge in on-market volume on Dec 16, with over 4 million shares traded. The share price more than doubled to close at 1.1 Singapore cents, with high trading activity continuing between Dec 16 and Jan 6. SGX RegCo notes that trades by a small group of market participants accounted for a significant portion of the total volume traded, and is reviewing the case, potentially referring it to statutory authorities.

site_title: Staying ahead of the pack
summary: Two Singaporean businesses, Rug Maker and CDL Trading, adapt to changing consumer tastes and technological advancements. CDL Trading, a desktop hardware distributor, aims to improve efficiency with its lean workforce, having grown from 3 employees in 1988 to 10. Rug Maker's business remains true to its roots despite adjusting to changing consumer tastes.

site_title: Singapore shares post strong recovery, gain 0.9% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.9% on Tuesday, reversing Monday's losses, as regional markets rebounded following a brief downturn. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,247.86, driven by gains in blue-chip stocks such as DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank. Traders attributed the rebound to the global economy continuing its recovery path and accommodative monetary policy. However, volatility is expected to persist, with Iran assessing scenarios to retaliate against the US over the killing of a top commander.

site_title: America should drop the 'Dr Evil fallacy' on assassination
summary: The US should reconsider its reliance on assassination as a foreign policy tool, known as the "Dr Evil fallacy," after the killing of Iran's Qassem Soleimani. Eliminating a "bad guy" doesn't solve complex foreign policy problems and often creates more issues. The US has failed to achieve lasting gains in security and influence after targeting Saddam Hussein, Osama bin Laden, and Muammar Gaddafi. Instead, these countries have descended into chaos and become more dangerous adversaries. The US should adopt a more patient and vigilant approach, as recommended by George Kennan, to address Iran's expansive tendencies.

site_title: Oil: Geopolitical risks back to the fore
summary: US-Iran tensions have intensified following the US air strike killing an Iranian general in Baghdad, with Iran threatening retaliation and potential war. Oil prices remain elevated, but are expected to normalize in the short term as fundamentals catch up. Geopolitical risks are high, but the possibility of outright war is considered low, with both sides unlikely to engage in an all-out conflict due to high costs and public opposition. Oil prices could spike towards $75-80/bbl for a few days but are likely to normalize around $65/bbl levels.

site_title: US-Iran conflict - Containment strategy needed to prevent war
summary: US President Donald Trump's decision to kill Major-General Qassem Soleimani, Iran's top security and intelligence commander, has escalated the four-decade-long conflict between the US and Iran. The strike is viewed as a declaration of war by the Iranian leadership, raising global anxieties over a potential full-blown war. The Trump administration blames Soleimani for instigating the assault on the US embassy in Baghdad, but questions remain about the wisdom of the military strike and its impact on core American security and economic interests. A containment strategy is needed to prevent war and ensure de-escalation.

site_title: A 'bright new future' for the UK in 2020
summary: The UK general election, held just before Christmas in 2020, resulted in the Conservatives gaining a majority, giving Boris Johnson a mandate to get Brexit done. The election outcome was unexpected, with the public voting for a second Brexit referendum, but the Conservative Party's share of the popular vote remained relatively unchanged. The election was seen as a victory for democracy, as it reflected the will of the people, despite the polarized debate over Brexit. Johnson's mandate is expected to last for the next decade.

site_title: Newly registered companies
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Newly registered companies include a specialist centre Royal Healthcare planning to open in Tokyo or Osaka, and a startup from NUS researchers aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants of Hao Mart's Taste Orchard express concerns about low footfall and vacant units. OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting staff and putting the building up for sale. Meanwhile, businesses are rebranding heritage and modernising traditional snacks, and a Chinatown Business Association seeks compensation for alleged use of outdoor space.

site_title: Samsung unit unveils AI-powered digital avatar
summary: Samsung's unit Star Labs unveiled an AI-powered digital avatar called NEON, capable of "conversing and sympathizing" like real people. The technology, developed using neural networks and computational reality, allows for customized digital beings that can appear on displays or video games, and could be used as TV anchors, spokespeople, or companions. NEONs are said to create life-like reality with latency of less than a few milliseconds, and each avatar has its own unique personality and expressions. The announcement raises concerns about the potential misuse of AI-manipulated computer videos, also known as "deepfakes."

site_title: QAF's Australia business unaffected by bushfires so far
summary: QAF's Australian pork production business, Rivalea Australia, remains unaffected by the ongoing bushfires, despite some restrictions on road access and visibility due to smoke. The company is closely monitoring the health and safety of its workers and herd, and has undertaken relief efforts for firefighters and bushfire victims. Rivalea's sites are covered by insurance policies for the current bushfire risk, and the company prioritizes the safety of its employees and herd.

site_title: Alita Resources replies to SGX queries on application for power to transfer shares
summary: Alita Resources, a CATALIST-listed lithium miner, has replied to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding its application for power to transfer shares under section 444GA of Australia's Corporations Act, as part of a rescue plan to avoid insolvency. The plan involves transferring 100% of Alita's shares to Liatam Mining for nil consideration. Alita has assured shareholders will have sufficient time to review and respond to the plan, with the deadline for entering an appearance set at Jan 29.

site_title: Aston Martin warns of 50% drop in annual profit after grim Dec
summary: Aston Martin warned of a 50% drop in annual profit due to tough trading conditions, citing weak UK and European markets and subdued demand for its Vantage model. The company expects 2019 adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) of £130-140 million, down from £247.3 million in 2018. The shares dropped 12% after the announcement, with the company reviewing its planning for 2020 and considering a cost-cutting program.

site_title: Productivity tops Singapore SME priority list in 2020: poll
summary: Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) prioritize boosting productivity in 2020, with 51% of surveyed SMEs focusing on implementing productivity measures. Digital solutions are also key, with 65% already using digital solutions and planning to implement them in areas such as expense management, customer relationship management, and sales. Sustainability is another area of importance, with 59% looking to improve business operations. Business outlook varies, with 46% holding a positive outlook, 31% a negative outlook, and 23% a neutral outlook, with the top concerns being global demand slowdown, US-China trade tensions, and a strengthening Singapore dollar.

site_title: Rolls-Royce sales hit an all-time global high
summary: Rolls-Royce Motor Cars achieved an all-time global high in sales, with 5,152 cars sold in 2019, a 25% increase from the previous year. This marks a five-fold increase in production since Torsten Müller-Ötvös became CEO in 2010. The company's sales growth is attributed to the success of models like the Cullinan and Black Badge, which have attracted younger buyers. Müller-Ötvös aims to maintain exclusivity by keeping sales volumes under control, citing the luxury brand's sensitivity to economic climate and global trade.

site_title: The workplace as a destination
summary: Traditional work environments are unsuitable for emerging work patterns, hindering workers' full potential. The workplace strategy, a complex process that aligns the organization's work patterns with physical space, is essential for improving performance and reducing costs. Studies show that 70% of meeting rooms are underutilized, and flexible working has altered the 50:50 ratio of individual and collaborative space. Common pitfalls include lack of focus spaces, assigned versus unassigned seating, and inadequate technology infrastructure. Companies that ignore workplace strategy risk being at a disadvantage, while a well-executed strategy can boost employee morale, engagement, and productivity.

site_title: Data analytics and automation part of the tool kit for a safer banking environment
summary: Banks are investing heavily in sophisticated tools to combat money laundering and financial crime, amid a global scourge estimated to cost up to US$3 trillion annually. Despite strict Know Your Customer processes and regulations, evolving threats require more agile detection and enforcement methods. Financial institutions are turning to data analytics, automation, and artificial intelligence to gain an advantage over potential financial criminals, with 18% of respondents citing AI as the key platform technology capability required to scale up their core systems. Self-updating databases and machine learning tools are being leveraged to automate KYC processes, reducing processing time and improving productivity.

site_title: Singapore's digibank push draws 21 bids
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) received 21 digital bank applications, with 14 seeking wholesale licenses and seven for full bank licenses. The majority of applicants are consortia, including e-commerce firms, fintech companies, and financial institutions. MAS aims to issue up to five digital banking licenses by June this year, with new banks expected to start operations by mid-2021. The regulator is focused on tapping unmet needs and ensuring that existing banks remain strong local anchors. The long-term sustainability and viability of new digital banks will be a key area to watch.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow open slightly lower, chips support Nasdaq
summary: US stocks opened slightly lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 64.20 points, or 0.22%, to 28,639.18, and the S&P 500 opening 4.42 points lower, or 0.14%, at 3,241.86. However, the Nasdaq Composite gained 5.18 points, or 0.06%, to 9,076.65, driven by positive corporate updates from chipmakers. The slight decline was attributed to healthcare and energy stocks.

site_title: Putin hails 'huge' progress in talks with Syria's Assad
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that significant progress has been made in talks with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, with a "huge distance" covered towards restoring Syrian statehood and territorial integrity. The meeting took place at a command post for Russian forces in Syria, where Putin emphasized the importance of the talks. The Kremlin has not disclosed the details of the discussions.

site_title: Money pours into Taiwan's markets as election nears
summary: Taiwan's financial markets are experiencing a surge in investor sentiment ahead of its presidential election, with the Taiwan dollar strengthening past 30 per greenback for the first time since June 2018. Government-bond yields remain near all-time lows, and stocks are nearing a record high, driven by new tax breaks and a 3.8 per cent dividend yield among the world's highest. Analysts predict a 20 per cent earnings rebound for this year, with growth forecast to top 2.5 per cent, and foreign inflows boosting the currency.

site_title: M&A, yield play to drive Singapore equities market in 2020: Credit Suisse report
summary: Credit Suisse predicts Singapore's equities market will be driven by mergers and acquisitions (M&A) and high dividend yield in 2020, amid a modest economic recovery. The report recommends restructuring and high-yield opportunities, particularly in the offshore and marine sector, where consolidation is expected. Singapore Reits are also expected to perform well due to their attractive yield levels and growth potential through acquisitions. The property market is expected to remain stable, with annual price increases within the 2-3% range, favoring developers with portfolio restructuring potential.

site_title: Proposed share sale by TEE controlling shareholder 'pending completion'
summary: TEE International, a mainboard-listed firm, says the proposed share sale by controlling shareholder Phua Chian Kin is pending completion due to ongoing discussions between Mr Phua and the buyer. The sale completion date was originally set for October 31, but was delayed to December 31, 2019, at the buyer's request. Mr Phua will update the board once the completion date is finalized.

site_title: Singapore's digibank experiment is right balance of innovation and prudence
summary: Singapore has introduced a digital banking experiment, allowing innovation while maintaining prudence. The move aims to address funding gaps for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which struggle to access traditional bank loans due to collateral requirements. The Singapore regulators have set high capital requirements for digital bank aspirants, with a calibrated approach to mitigate risk. Chinese tech companies, such as Ant Financial, have expressed interest in obtaining digital banking licenses in Singapore, with a total of 21 applications submitted. The regulator will only issue up to three digital wholesale bank licenses and two digital full bank licenses, with strict requirements for demonstrating profitability and regional connectivity.

images.alt_text: An emerging player in this area in Singapore is Grab, which has rolled out loans to SMEs in Singapore. Grab would not say how big of a market it has captured thus far, except to say that most of its SME customers are from the food & beverage and retail segment, speaking to its merchant base that swelled from having GrabFood in its network.

site_title: Kimly director retires, does not intend to seek re-election
summary: Kimly's lead independent director, Ter Kim Cheu, 73, is retiring due to the ongoing investigations by regulatory authorities. The investigations, sparked by Kimly's 2018 purchase of Asian Story Corporation, have raised concerns over Mr. Ter's familial relationship with Ong Eng Sing, Kimly's former director. Mr. Ter is stepping down at the upcoming annual general meeting on Jan 21, citing a desire to avoid negative perceptions. The company's sponsor has found no other material reasons for his retirement as an independent director.

site_title: QAF's Australia business not affected by bushfires to date
summary: QAF's Australia business arm, Rivalea Australia, has not been affected by the ongoing bushfires in the country, with its properties and operations remaining safe to date. While some stock feed deliveries have been impacted by road closures and movement restrictions, Rivalea is working to maintain vital feed supplies. The company's sites are insured against bushfire risk, and it has supported firefighters and bushfire victims with relief efforts. Employees and livestock are safe, and Rivalea will continue to monitor the situation closely.

site_title: US trade deficit drops to more than three-year low
summary: The US trade deficit decreased to a three-year low in November, falling 8.2% to $43.1 billion. Imports declined further, likely due to the Trump administration's trade war with China, while exports rebounded, suggesting a solid economy end in 2019. The trade deficit has narrowed 0.7% through November and is on track to record its first annual decline since 2013, which could boost the fourth quarter's GDP growth.

site_title: Saudi Arabia allows Bank of China to open branch in kingdom
summary: Saudi Arabia's Cabinet has approved Bank of China's licence to open a branch in the kingdom, following in the footsteps of Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, which launched its first branch in Riyadh nearly four years ago. The move is seen as part of China's growing presence in the region, with Beijing maintaining close ties with Saudi Arabia as its top oil supplier. This development is part of a broader trend of Chinese firms expanding in the kingdom.

site_title: Thais asked to shower less as drought worsens
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha has urged citizens to reduce their water usage due to a worsening drought in northern and central Thailand. The capital's tap water is becoming saline as seawater enters the Chao Phraya river, a primary water source. The government plans to spend 3 billion baht (S$133.8 million) on boreholes and pipes to extract groundwater, aiming to alleviate the drought, which is expected to worsen in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Bangkok's water authority said the capital's tap water was becoming saline as seawater pushed up the depleted Chao Phraya river, a source of much of central Thailand's water.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Tuesday with gains, reversing losses from the previous two days as concerns over the Middle East eased. The Hang Seng index rose 0.34%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices also increased. The gains were attributed to investors shifting focus to the global economy.

site_title: Oil producers seek to lock in price gains from US-Iran tension
summary: US oil producers are locking in price gains from rising oil prices due to US-Iran tension. Producers have added hedges, using options strategies to secure higher selling prices, as oil prices exceeded $70 a barrel in London for the first time since September. The 13 largest US oil producers hedged 13% of their 2020 output, potentially undercutting calls for a slowdown in the shale boom. This move may extend a lifeline to producers, allowing them to maintain higher output despite expected growth slowdown.

images.alt_text: US oil producers are taking advantage of the rally following the killing of a top Iranian general to lock in prices for more of their 2020 and 2021 output.

site_title: Arrest warrant issued in Japan for Carlos Ghosn's wife
summary: Prosecutors in Japan have issued an arrest warrant for Carole Ghosn, the wife of former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn, who fled the country in December after jumping bail. The warrant was issued amid tightened border controls and the seizure of Ghosn's forfeited bail money. Ghosn, who faces trial in Japan on charges of financial misconduct, was reunited with his wife in Lebanon. Authorities are seeking to apprehend Carole Ghosn, who remains at large, as the fallout from her husband's escape continues.

site_title: SGX RegCo reviewing trades in China Haida, urges caution
summary: SGX RegCo is reviewing trades in China Haida, urging caution due to unusual trading activity. On Dec 16, the firm's shares surged in volume and price, with over four million shares traded and the price more than doubling. The review found that a small group of market participants accounted for a significant portion of the trades. SGX RegCo will take necessary actions, including referring the case to statutory authorities if warranted. The review is ongoing, with the shares closing unchanged at 1.1 Singapore cents on Tuesday.

site_title: EU takes aim at ticket bots, data harvesters
summary: The European Union is implementing tougher laws against online operators who exploit consumers, including those harvesting personal data and using bots to snap up tickets. The new rules, set to be implemented in two years, include banning automated ticket bots, requiring genuine price reductions, and informing consumers about potential price variations. The regulations will impact major online vendors such as Amazon, Google, and Facebook, with fines of at least 4% of annual turnover for non-compliance. The aim is to protect 500 million EU consumers.

site_title: ING Bank builds bot to finally replace humans in clubby bond market
summary: ING Bank has developed an artificial intelligence platform named Katana to help traders pick bonds for buy and sell. The platform uses machine-learning algorithms to scan millions of transactions, aiming to raise £3 million to fund its growth. Katana has already helped ING win 20% more market-making transactions and reduce costs. The platform is expanding to asset managers, with Dutch pension fund manager PGGM among investors using the system. Katana is the latest fintech venture from ING's Labs unit, which also developed an app to manage money and a platform for companies to manage multiple bank accounts.

site_title: Iran vows 'historic nightmare' while dozens die in stampede
summary: Iran has vowed to inflict a "historic nightmare" on the US in response to the killing of General Qassem Soleimani, a national hero who was killed in a drone strike in Iraq. Following a stampede that killed 35 people during Soleimani's funeral procession, Iran has designated the Pentagon and affiliated companies as terrorists and warned of potential reprisals against US maritime interests. The US has responded by deploying additional forces to the Middle East and warning of potential Iranian action. The situation remains tense, with the US and Iran engaging in a game of brinksmanship over the future of US military presence in Iraq.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on Tuesday, driven by easing fears of a Middle East conflict. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.3% to 7,597.23 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gained 0.8% and 0.7% respectively. The rally was attributed to a decrease in tensions and focus on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Manulife CEO apologises for executives' spoof rap video
summary: Manulife CEO Roy Gori apologized to employees after a spoof rap video featuring the executive team was retracted due to offense. The video, meant to be lighthearted, was criticized for its cultural insensitivity and lack of diversity. The incident comes amid heightened sensitivity over issues like race relations and workplace diversity. Manulife's response was seen as a step to address these concerns and create a more respectful environment for employees. The company had previously featured similar videos in an annual series, but this one sparked a stronger reaction.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 13.28 points to 1,611.04. The market saw 3 billion lots worth RM1.8 billion traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 441 to 388.

site_title: Cautious consumers push sales down at British supermarket Morrisons
summary: British supermarket Morrisons reported a 1.7% decline in underlying sales over the Christmas period, better than forecasted at 2.2%. The decline was attributed to a tough economic backdrop and consumer uncertainty, but the company remains on track to meet analysts' full-year profit forecasts. Morrisons' turnaround efforts, focusing on competitive prices, product ranges, and customer service, have been successful, with the company selling a £120 million site in Camden, north London.

site_title: Philippines's BSP to go ahead with policy cuts despite higher Dec inflation
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) plans to proceed with a monetary policy cut despite a higher-than-expected December inflation rate in the Philippines. Analysts from Barclays and ANZ believe the central bank has room to ease its policy in Q1 2020, citing a favorable growth outlook and reduced need for further monetary easing. A 25 basis point rate cut is expected, with inflation remaining within the target range of 2-4%. The BSP governor has stated that the chances of an upside breach to the inflation target are remote, and the central bank still sees a rate cut in Q1 2020.

site_title: Dominant US service sector revs up in December
summary: The US services sector rebounded in December, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing index rising 1.1 points to 55%, its highest level since August. This growth contrasted with the manufacturing sector, which hit its weakest activity in a decade. Strong activity in retail, entertainment, and healthcare, but slowing activity in education, real estate, and wholesale trade, were reported. Recent positive economic news, including a US-China trade war truce and job creation, supported the services sector. Analysts expect "solid, albeit slower growth" in the service sector in early 2020.

site_title: Europe must find a response to Iran's nuclear violations: Germany's Maas
summary: Germany's Foreign Minister Heiko Maas stated that Europe must respond to Iran's decision to ignore nuclear arms control agreement limits. Maas said Europe cannot accept the move, emphasizing the need for a joint response. The 2015 nuclear deal allows signatories to reimpose UN sanctions on Iran, but Maas did not elaborate on potential actions.

site_title: UBS names regional wealth heads in private-banking restructuring
summary: UBS is restructuring its European wealth management business into three regions, cutting up to 500 private banking jobs globally. Christl Novakovic will lead Western Europe, while Caroline Kuhnert and Ali Janoudi will oversee central and eastern Europe and the Middle East and Africa, respectively. The move aims to boost lending to rich clients and speed up loan approvals, eliminating time-consuming negotiations between wealth managers and the investment bank. Other management changes include new roles for Paula Polito, Chicco di Stasi, Patrick Grob, and Mark Haefele.

site_title: Thai Cabinet approves 260b baht of loan measures to help smaller firms
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved 260 billion baht (S$11.6 billion) in loan measures to support small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) affected by weak exports due to global trade tensions and a strong currency. The measures include soft loans worth 195 billion baht and 65 billion baht in loan guarantees. The government also offers tax breaks and fee reductions to aid debt restructuring. The move aims to mitigate the impact of the US-Sino trade war on Thailand's exports, which have been hit hard by the country's strong currency.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) received 21 applications for digital wholesale and full bank licenses, with Sea, an internet group, being the first to pursue a solo bid for the digital full bank license. Singapore shares gained 0.9% on Tuesday, closing at 3,247.86. In international news, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy contracted for the second month, while Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May.

images.alt_text: This comprises 14 applications for the digital wholesale bank licences, and seven applications for the digital full bank licences.

site_title: Aston Martin earnings slump, clouding turnaround prospects
summary: Aston Martin's earnings slumped to £130-140 million in 2020, down from £247 million in 2018, as the company faces an industry downturn, Brexit uncertainty, and weak sales. The company's shares fell 12% and its market value dropped to £1 billion. Despite a strong response to its DBX sports-utility vehicle, Aston Martin needs to attract new capital to fund a turnaround. The company is in talks with potential investors, including Canadian billionaire Lawrence Stroll, to reduce pressure from high-interest debt and boost sales.

site_title: Flu scare gives Hong Kong's Carrie Lam a diversion from protests
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam is using the recent surge of mysterious pneumonia cases in mainland China as a diversion from the ongoing protests that have plagued her government for seven months. Lam devoted her press briefing to addressing the government's response measures to the outbreak, urging residents to be cautious of false information spreading on social media. Despite the pneumonia outbreak, Lam refused to address the protests, calling them "heart-wrenching" and sticking to her stance on refusing an independent inquiry into police behavior.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end up 1.6% on US rallies, yen's fall
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.6% on Tuesday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a decline in the yen's value amid US-Iran tensions. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 23,575.72, while the broader Topix index gained 1.62%. This follows a breather in the yen's rise after US President Trump made new threats.

site_title: London designer Wales Bonner making waves
summary: London designer Grace Wales Bonner, 29, unveiled her 2020 autumn/winter collection "Lovers Rock" at London Fashion Week Men's, blending British and Caribbean influences. The collection features traditional fabrics with a twist, inspired by her Caribbean roots and personal history. Bonner, who has gained recognition for her work, including a L'Oreal Professionnel Talent Awards win and a British Fashion Award, says her designs aim to promote identity and representation. The collection's success has been boosted by celebrity endorsements, including Meghan Markle, Wales Bonner's first royal patron.

site_title: Hong Kong startup Dash Living enters Singapore's co-living space
summary: Hong Kong startup Dash Living has expanded to Singapore by acquiring Easycity, a local co-living operator. Dash Living now manages over 1,100 units in the Asia-Pacific, with 200 units added in Singapore. The acquisition brings co-living to its fastest-growing product. Founded by Alex Liu and Wesley Wen, Dash Living has $10 million in funding and 100,000 sq ft of space in Hong Kong. The founders have been appointed as the executive management team for Dash Living Singapore.

site_title: Freehold shophouses in East Coast, Geylang put on market
summary: Two freehold shophouses in Singapore's East Coast and Geylang areas have been launched for sale by tender. The properties offer guide prices of S$9.9 million and S$4.98 million, respectively. The East Coast shophouse has a student hostel license and a rental yield of over 3%, while the Geylang shophouse has the highest rental yield among shophouses at 4.5%. The properties are expected to attract high-net-worth individuals and family boutique real estate players.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare proposes RM37.4m acquisition of Johor Bahru eye centre
summary: ISEC Healthcare proposes the acquisition of Indah Specialist Eye Centre in Johor Bahru, Malaysia for RM37.4 million. The eye centre has maintained a stable income stream and profit track record over the past three years, with ISEC Healthcare expecting a growing stream of recurring income and cash flow from the location. The acquisition is expected to provide ISEC Healthcare with a new source of recurring revenue.

site_title: Carmaker Rolls-Royce annual sales surge 25%
summary: Rolls-Royce, a luxury carmaker, reported a 25% surge in annual sales in 2019, reaching a record 5,152 cars. The increase was driven by strong demand for its first-ever SUV, Cullinan, launched in 2018. North America was the largest contributor to sales, followed by China and Europe. This success contrasts with the global automobile industry's challenges, including economic slowdowns affecting major automakers like Volkswagen and Ford.

site_title: Green boom may limit Japan bond sale slowdown after record
summary: Japan's corporate bond issuance reached a record 13 trillion yen in the fiscal year ending March 31, with a slowdown likely in the next fiscal year due to rising borrowing costs and fewer maturing notes. However, a boom in environmentally-friendly bonds, such as green notes and transition debt, may limit the slowdown. Sales of green notes in Japan may double in 2020, with companies using the cash to boost shareholder returns and finance environmental projects, pushing Japan into the top 10 for green bond issuance.

site_title: StanChart's new public portal offers real-time tracking of cross-border payments
summary: Standard Chartered has launched a public portal, SC GPI Track, allowing real-time tracking of cross-border payments. The portal enables clients to track payments processed by StanChart's major clearing centers, using a SWIFT unique transaction reference. This move aims to facilitate e-commerce by moving money faster, showcasing the bank's leadership in innovation, according to SWIFT's chief business development officer.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon up 0.8% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading with a 0.8% gain, reaching 3,243.75 at 1:02pm, driven by gains from AusGroup and MarcoPolo Marine. Banking stocks also rose, with DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank increasing by 0.8%, 1.2%, and 1% respectively. The gains come ahead of GDP data release and follow a 5-day rally.

site_title: China won't hike grain import quotas for US trade deal
summary: China will not increase its annual import quotas for corn, wheat, and rice to accommodate US trade deal demands, according to a senior agriculture official. The decision aims to protect China's farmers, who are under pressure to buy more US agricultural goods. China's grain imports have been below quota levels in recent years, and increasing imports could weigh on domestic producers. The US had expected China to double its purchases of US agricultural products as part of a Phase 1 trade deal, but China's decision may ease market concerns.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks bounce back as US-Iran tensions ease
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded on Tuesday as US-Iran tensions eased, with the KOSPI rising 20.47 points, or 0.95%, to 2,175.54. Investors breathed a sigh of relief after no immediate escalation in tensions, despite some confusion over US troop repositioning in Iraq. The rally follows a previous session's losses, with US stocks also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Payment delays worsen among Singapore firms for third straight quarter
summary: Singapore firms experienced worsening payment delays for the third consecutive quarter, with slow payments rising 2.46 percentage points to 39.75% in the fourth quarter of 2019. Retail and services sectors led the increase, while construction payments also rose. Prompt payments fell to 46.23% and partial payments hit a new peak at 14.02%. Experts attribute the decline to increased payment delays in retail and services sectors, with companies taking steps to maintain creditworthiness.

site_title: China's farmers reap rich harvest through video-sharing apps
summary: Chinese farmers are leveraging video-sharing apps like Douyin to sell their products, with some turning into celebrities and earning significant income. Ma Gongzuo, a 31-year-old beekeeper, credits the platform for his success, selling 2-3 million yuan worth of honey annually. His videos showcase rural life, capturing audience interest and providing a window into rural China. The trend has helped reduce poverty in rural areas, with the number of people living under the poverty line decreasing from 700 million in 1978 to 16.6 million in 2018.

site_title: Internet group Sea first to go solo in bid for digital full bank licence
summary: Singapore's internet group Sea has become the first solo applicant to bid for a digital full bank licence, focusing on serving millennials and SMEs. The licence requires a capital requirement of S$1.5 billion and must be Singaporean-controlled. Sea, with a market capitalization of over S$25 billion, plans to leverage its digital ecosystem to innovate financial services. The move comes as seven applicants have been shortlisted for the licence, with three others yet to announce their bids. Sea's founder and chairman Forrest Li has emphasized the group's capabilities to design and scale Singapore's first full digital bank.

site_title: Van Holland condo in District 10 to start public sales this weekend
summary: The Van Holland condominium in District 10, Singapore, will launch for public sales on Jan 11 with indicative prices starting from S$2,600 per square foot. The 69-unit development, set to obtain its temporary occupation permit in March 2023, offers apartments ranging from 495 to 1,991 square feet. This marks the freehold residential development by Koh Brothers Group, a prime location along Holland Road.

site_title: Australia firefighters race to contain blazes as heatwave looms
summary: Australia firefighters are racing to contain massive bushfires in southeastern Australia ahead of a looming heatwave, with temperatures expected to pick up again by Friday. Despite a brief drop in temperatures and some rainfall, dozens of vast blazes continue to burn out of control, with 25 deaths and over 1,800 homes destroyed since September. The fires have already burned an area the size of Ireland or South Carolina, with smoke spotted over 12,000km away in Chile and Argentina.

site_title: Jetstar outranks SIA for on-time performance: report
summary: Jetstar Asia has outranked Singapore Airlines (SIA) for on-time performance, according to the Punctuality League 2020 report by OAG. Jetstar Asia achieved an on-time performance (OTP) of 85.48% in 2019, while SIA recorded 85.32%. Jetstar Asia jumped four spots to rank 8th, while SIA jumped six spots to rank 9th. Garuda Indonesia topped the list with an OTP of 95%.

site_title: Avon-Natura tie-up to yield more cost savings: CEO
summary: Brazilian cosmetics group Natura & Co has increased its cost savings target for its takeover of Avon Products to $200-300 million per year over 36 months, exceeding initial estimates. CEO Roberto Marques aims to reinvest in growth, focusing on branding, product development, and digitalization. Avon's sales decline is attributed to a lack of innovation and inability to compete with larger rivals. The companies will maintain separate commercial structures and brand management, but may share industrial and distribution facilities. Natura & Co will provide more details on the integration in April and a combined strategic business plan in October.

site_title: Philippine inflation speeds up in December on higher food costs
summary: Philippine inflation rose 2.5% in December, exceeding the median forecast of 2.1%, driven by higher food, non-alcoholic beverages, and utilities prices. The average 2019 inflation rate was 2.5%, within the central bank's 2-4% target. Annual inflation has declined from a peak of 6.7% in 2018, and the central bank is expected to review its policy on February 6.
