Governor Benjamin Diokno plans to ease policy further in 2020, with at least 50 basis points expected, and reduce reserve requirements to single digits by 2023.

site_title: Toyota to build prototype city of the future in Japan
summary: Toyota plans to build a prototype "city of the future" called Woven City, near Mt. Fuji in Japan, as a laboratory for autonomous cars, smart homes, and AI. The 71-hectare community, expected to initially house 2,000 residents, will be powered by hydrogen fuel cells. Designed by Danish architect Bjarke Ingels, the project aims to test and develop cutting-edge technologies. Construction is set to start next year, with Toyota open to partnerships with other companies to use the project as a testing ground.

site_title: M&A, yield play to drive Singapore equities market: Credit Suisse report
summary: Credit Suisse expects Singapore's equities market to be driven by M&A and high dividend yield in 2020 amid a modest economic recovery. The report recommends a portfolio of restructuring opportunities and high yield, citing a 4.2% trailing dividend yield. The O&M sector is expected to consolidate, with Singapore yards recovering to S$5.5 billion in new orders in 2020 and S$6 billion in 2021. Retail Reits are favored for their rental resilience and growth potential through acquisitions. Singapore banks are expected to maintain a strong capital cushion, supporting a 2020 yield of 4.7-4.9%.

site_title: AMD unveils new laptop chips aimed at bulk of PC market
summary: AMD unveiled its new Ryzen 4000 U series laptop chips, targeting the thinnest and lightest notebooks, aiming to eclipse Intel's performance. The highest-end version features eight cores, each capable of handling two processing loads simultaneously. AMD's CEO Lisa Su pitches the new products at CES, following a 150% stock surge last year driven by investors' confidence in the company's improved chips. The Ryzen 4000 U series is designed to help AMD grab market share and shed its status as a cheap alternative to Intel.

site_title: Asia: Stocks track US gains as Iran fears ease but traders on alert
summary: Asian stocks rebounded on Tuesday as fears of a Middle East conflict eased, with the US assassination of a top Iranian general sparking concerns of retaliation. Despite this, investors remained cautious, with oil prices retreating and gold slipping from six-and-a-half-year highs. The global economic outlook and the China-US trade deal signing planned for January 15 took center stage, with strong service sector data providing hope that the worldwide growth slowdown is easing. Markets are now in a "wait-and-see mode," with experts warning of potential escalation and its impact on global growth.

site_title: 2 Tras Street shophouses up for sale with S$12m and S$10m guide prices
summary: Two conservation shophouses along Tras Street in Singapore are up for sale with guide prices of S$12 million and S$10.8 million, respectively. The properties, with a total floor area of 7,109 sq ft, have a 99-year lease and are zoned for commercial use. They are fully leased to food and beverage operators and are within walking distance of Tanjong Pagar MRT Station. The sale comes as investors shift their interest to 99-year leasehold shophouses in well-located areas, offering better value and higher yields.

images.alt_text: Both three-storey shophouses with attic have a 99-year lease, and are currently fully leased to food and beverage operators on the ground floor and soho users on the upper floors.

site_title: Chinese developers' offshore bond pipeline meets firm new year demand
summary: Chinese property developers kicked off the new year with a strong pipeline of offshore bond issuance, selling notes between 6 to 12 years. Analysts say this is due to easier regulatory approvals and robust market demand, despite tightened financing for the sector. At least seven more developers, including top players, plan to sell bonds. The high-yield emerging markets, dominated by Chinese property names, achieved record returns in 2019, driven by a change in US Fed rates. Experts forecast the bond market to perform well in the next two months, benefiting large developers with strong cash flow.

images.alt_text: Chinese property developers kicked off the new year with a strong pipeline of bond issuance, in particular for long-tenor notes, taking advantage of easier regulatory approvals and robust market demand.

site_title: Bentley returns to profitability as sales rise in 2019
summary: Bentley, a luxury carmaker owned by Volkswagen, has returned to profitability in 2019, driven by a 5% sales increase. The company sold 11,006 vehicles, boosted by the new Continental GT Convertible model and limited edition models. Despite a 12% decline in Chinese sales, Bentley's operating profit stood at 65 million euros in the first nine months of 2019. The company's CEO, Adrian Hallmark, attributes the turnaround to the successful implementation of a turnaround strategy, signaling a promising future for Bentley in 2020.

site_title: Ghosn escape breaks up legal 'dream team'
summary: Carlos Ghosn, the former Nissan boss, has escaped from Japan, bringing down his "dream team" of lawyers, including high-profile lawyer Junichiro Hironaka, known for his enviable acquittal record. Hironaka and other team members had prepared Ghosn's defense, but Ghosn became increasingly frustrated with the pace and method of his defense, fearing the trial would take years. Ghosn's escape has been met with criticism from some Japanese lawyers, who view it as a major embarrassment and a breach of trust.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong shares rose slightly on Tuesday, boosted by relief over Middle East tensions and anticipation of the planned China-US trade deal signing next week. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.45%, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.07%. The rally follows a 5-day streak in Singapore, where stocks also rose ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Impossible Foods debuts its first plant-based pork products
summary: Impossible Foods, the maker of the "bleeding" soy-based burger, is debuting its first plant-based pork products, Impossible Pork and Impossible Sausage, at CES in Las Vegas. The products use soy as the primary ingredient and contain "heme," an iron-containing molecule, to mimic the flavor and texture of pork. The sausage will be rolled out at 139 Burger King locations in five test markets starting in late January. This move aims to expand the company's presence in the market and compete with rival Beyond Meat.

site_title: With clock ticking, British MPs scrutinise Brexit deal
summary: British MPs resume scrutiny of Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit deal as the UK prepares to leave the European Union on January 31. Despite his general election victory, Johnson is under pressure to ratify the deal before departure day. Both the British and European parliaments must approve the legislation, which enshrines EU divorce terms, within the next few weeks. Johnson's deadline is tight, with the UK's departure date fast approaching, and the outcome is uncertain.

site_title: UK's EG Group weighs counterbid for Caltex Australia
summary: UK-based EG Group is considering a counterbid for Caltex Australia Ltd, which has a market value of A$8.6 billion, in response to Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc's A$34.50 per-share cash offer. EG Group has been making acquisitions to expand globally, including the purchase of 540 Australian fuel convenience sites from Woolworths Group Ltd and US convenience store business from Kroger Co. The move could start a takeover battle, following Caltex's rejection of Couche-Tard's previous offer.

site_title: China must cancel new coal plants to achieve climate goals: study
summary: China must cancel new coal-fired power plants to meet long-term climate goals, according to a study co-authored by a government-backed research institute. The country aims to peak carbon emissions by 2030 as part of the 2015 Paris agreement, but has continued to approve new coal plants despite economic growth slowing. Ending new coal plant construction is the most economically feasible way for China to meet its climate goals.

site_title: Productivity tops Singapore SME priority list in 2020: poll
summary: Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) have identified boosting productivity as a top priority in 2020, with 51% of surveyed SMEs citing it as a key goal. Implementing productivity measures through investments in technology is a key strategy, with 65% already using digital solutions in at least one area of their business. SMEs also plan to increase their use of electronic payments and focus on sustainability. Despite a mixed business outlook, 46% of SMEs have a positive outlook, while 23% are concerned about the slowdown in global demand and ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Agriculture trader Louis Dreyfus cuts jobs to rein in costs
summary: Agriculture trader Louis Dreyfus Co is cutting jobs, primarily in support, back office, and administrative functions, amid low profits. The cuts, which started in December, are part of a cost-cutting program and systematic review of hiring and salary increases announced by the firm. The move follows the company's decision to sell assets and exit certain businesses, controlled by billionaire heiress Margarita Louis-Dreyfus. The exact number of affected workers is unclear.

site_title: China needs more than just rules to tackle bond defaults
summary: China's regulators have taken steps to address a surge in bond defaults, with draft rules on handling defaults and creditor meetings. However, the rules lack details on enforcement and recovery for investors. Onshore bond defaults reached a record 134.1 billion yuan in 2022, with only 74 defaults completed through proper debt restructuring. Analysts say China needs to improve its bankruptcy law and strengthen bond covenants to better protect investors. The government's efforts to modernize the capital markets are hindered by the lack of concrete measures to tackle wayward debtors.

site_title: Medtech startup eko.ai raises US$4m in funding round co-led by Sequoia India, EDBI
summary: MEDTECH startup eko.ai has raised US$4 million in a funding round co-led by Sequoia India and Singapore investment fund EDBI. The funding will be used to grow the company's development team and accelerate its US and Europe commercial operations. Participating investors include Partech Ventures, SGInnovate, and Startup Health.

site_title: Xerox lines up US$24b M&A loan in pursuit of deal with HP
summary: Xerox Holdings has arranged a $24 billion loan with a group of banks to pursue its deal with HP Inc, the largest-ever bridge loan in the technology sector. The loan, provided by Citigroup, Mizuho Financial Group, and Bank of America, includes a $19.5 billion 364-day facility and a $4.5 billion 60-day facility. The loan aims to remove doubt about Xerox's ability to raise financing, following concerns raised by HP's largest shareholders. The deal is seen as a welcome sign for banks hoping for more merger activity in 2020.

site_title: Ancient wine measuring table unearthed in Jerusalem
summary: Israeli archaeologists have unearthed a 2,000-year-old ancient wine measuring table in Jerusalem's City of David National Park. The table, which could be filled with liquid to provide a unified measure, helps prove a market once stood at the site. According to archaeologist Ari Levy, the find provides evidence of trade in the area, which lies south of Jerusalem's Old City. The discovery is the third artifact of its kind to be found in Jerusalem, shedding light on the historical significance of the site and the region's trade activities.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen eases
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a decline in the yen's value amid US-Iran tensions. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.52% to 23,325.77, while the broader Topix index gained 0.54%. The gains followed a 2% drop on Monday.

site_title: GM delivered 3.09m vehicles in China in 2019, down 15% y-o-y
summary: General Motors delivered 3.09 million vehicles in China in 2019, a 15% decline from the previous year. This marks the second consecutive year of declining sales for the US automaker in the country. The company's sales were affected by a prolonged slowdown in the Chinese market and increased competition in the mid-priced SUV segment. In comparison, GM sold 3.65 million vehicles in China in 2018.

images.alt_text: General Motors' vehicle sales in China fell 15 per cent in 2019, as the US automaker suffered a prolonged sales slowdown in the world's biggest auto market and faced heightened competition in its key mid-priced SUV segment.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump 1% as Mideast tensions ease; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Tuesday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street, as Middle East tensions eased. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 1% to 6,803.10, driven by gains in healthcare and tech sectors. Defensive stocks, such as CSL and Wisetech Global, also rose. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% due to pressure from electricity and aged-care service providers.

images.alt_text: Australian shares climbed 1 per cent on Tuesday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street, as the mood calmed with no fresh aggression in the Middle East while defensive stocks provided a boost to the index.

site_title: Europe will emulate Japan's foreign takeover binge
summary: European companies are poised to follow Japan's lead in pursuing foreign takeovers, driven by shrinking domestic markets and low borrowing costs. Firms such as Siemens, Eni, and banks like BNP Paribas and ING are expected to expand into faster-growing markets. The European Union's economy is expected to expand by 1.4% next year, with companies already spending $273 billion a year on overseas purchases. Despite risks of overpaying and mistakes, shareholders are eager to reward companies demonstrating growth, and European CEOs are likely to follow Japan's lead in pursuing foreign acquisitions.

site_title: Bed Bath & Beyond sells real estate as part of turnaround
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond sold approximately 2.1 million square feet of real estate, including retail stores, a distribution facility, and offices, for over $250 million. The properties are located in various states and include the company's headquarters in New Jersey. The sale-leaseback deal is part of the retailer's turnaround plan, which aims to unlock shareholder value and boost earnings per share. The company's shares rose 5.3% following the news, with CEO Mark Tritton's management shake-up and plan to divest non-core assets seen as positive steps for the company's turnaround.

images.alt_text: Bed Bath & Beyond, the US home-goods retailer mired in a lengthy sales slump, rose after selling some real estate in a deal that generated net proceeds of more than US$250 million.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.08 points or 0.01% to 1,597.84. The market saw 116.70 million lots traded worth RM36.21 million, with 144 gainers surpassing 66 losers. The rally comes despite global market uncertainty, with US stocks reaching fresh records and Europe's mining and healthcare sectors supporting shares.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.74%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 23.86 points or 0.74% to 3,242.72 at 9:04am on Tuesday, tracking a US market session that saw gains. Gainers outnumbered losers 105 to 36, with AusGroup and SGX among the most traded stocks. All three banks gained, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB rising 1.2%, 0.6%, and 0.7% respectively. US stocks also rose, with the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq advancing 0.2%, 0.4%, and 0.6% respectively.

site_title: Uber, Hyundai team up to develop electric air taxi
summary: Uber and Hyundai plan to jointly develop electric air taxis, with Hyundai producing and deploying the air vehicles and Uber providing airspace support services and customer interfaces. The companies unveiled a concept electric aircraft at CES in Las Vegas, designed for trips up to 60 miles with a cruising speed of up to 180 miles per hour. Uber aims to begin demonstrator flights in 2020 and commercial operations in 2023, marking the first collaboration between a carmaker and a ride-hailing company in the project.

site_title: Arena Pharma CEO targets brain diseases as next drug frontier
summary: Arena Pharmaceuticals CEO Amit Munshi targets brain diseases as the next frontier for his company's drug development. He plans to focus on movement disorders like Parkinson's and Lou Gehrig's diseases through a new subsidiary, Arena Neuroscience Inc. The company also expects to start one new human trial each year for the next five years. With patent protections expiring, Munshi considers spinning out or selling the neuroscience unit, potentially attracting new private investors.

site_title: Tel Aviv residents 'not afraid' of Iran threat
summary: Tel Aviv residents express confidence in Israel's strength, with many doubting an Iranian threat. Despite Iran's warning to turn the city to dust, residents and officials see the threat as unlikely. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has cut short a foreign visit and security chiefs have held emergency talks, but the government remains tight-lipped about the threat. Experts say an escalation of events is possible, but attacking Israeli cities would be a "great provocation" that could lead to a large-scale military conflict.

site_title: Delayed Zika effects seen in babies who appeared healthy at birth
summary: Researchers in Colombia found that babies exposed to the Zika virus in the womb, despite appearing healthy at birth, showed motor and cognitive development delays in their first 18 months of life. A study of 70 babies born between 2016 and 2017 found they performed worse than average on developmental assessments, with subtle brain abnormalities detected in about 30% of the group. The delays were estimated to be several months, but the long-term effects on these babies are still unknown.

site_title: Facing Brexit unknowns, UK financial sector pays record taxes
summary: The UK financial sector has paid a record £75.5 billion in taxes in the year to March, accounting for one in 10 of all UK tax receipts. Despite Brexit uncertainty, the industry remains crucial to funding the state, employing 1.1 million people nationwide. The sector's tax contributions are expected to be impacted by Brexit, with potential patchy access to the EU, leading to a possible acceleration of staff relocation to EU hubs. The City of London Corporation emphasizes the need for the UK to remain competitive to safeguard the sector's employment base and tax contribution.

site_title: Astaka auditors flag going concern issue
summary: Independent auditors KPMG have flagged a going concern issue for Astaka Holdings, citing uncertainties due to the property market slowdown in Malaysia and potential doubts about the company's ability to continue operating. The auditors noted a net loss of RM113.7 million for the year ended June 30, 2019, and RM400.7 million in development properties. Astaka has prepared a 18-month consolidated cash flow forecast, but the outcome of an independent review and settlement of outstanding balances remain uncertain, casting doubt on the company's ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Britain's first post-Brexit budget set for March 11
summary: Britain is set to unveil its first post-Brexit budget on March 11, promising increased public service spending and an end to a decade of austerity. Finance minister Sajid Javid said the budget will "unleash Britain's potential" and invest in the health service, schools, and police. The government aims to keep public sector borrowing under 2.0% of GDP, despite warnings from economists. This comes after Prime Minister Boris Johnson won a comfortable majority in the early election, paving the way for the UK's departure from the European Union by the end of January.

site_title: Ex-New York Federal Reserve boss says it's time to overhaul repo toolkit
summary: Former New York Federal Reserve boss William Dudley recommends introducing a standing repurchase-agreement facility to ensure calm US cash markets. The facility would be open to a broad set of counterparties and accept Treasury and agency securities as collateral, effectively capping repo rates. This move would address the issue of the Fed providing liquidity to primary dealers who may not lend to other market participants. Dudley's proposal joins a chorus of proponents seeking to implement this tool to stabilize the financial markets.

site_title: Letter on Iraq pullout 'genuine' but sent by 'mistake': top US general
summary: US Joint Chiefs Chairman Mark Milley said a letter informing Iraq of troop withdrawal was "genuine" but sent by mistake. The letter was intended for a different time, according to Milley, referring to US Central Command commander General Frank McKenzie. The mistake was acknowledged, but no further details were provided.

site_title: Japan's December services sector shrinks at fastest pace in over 3 years: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector saw its largest contraction in over 3 years in December, with the final seasonally adjusted PMI falling to 49.4, its lowest level since September 2016. The sector's business activity was hit by weak demand at home and abroad, with new export business slumping to a 6-month low. Retail sales also fell 2.1% in November, while backlogs of work decreased to the lowest since May 2018. Analysts expect the economy to shrink in the quarter through December due to internal and external strains.

site_title: Contenders we know so far in Singapore's digibank race
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has received 21 digital bank applications, with up to five full bank licenses and three wholesale bank licenses to be issued by June 2021. Contenders include Sea, Grab and Singtel, Razer Youth Bank, Beyond, and Ant Financial. Other applicants include iFast Corporation, Hande & Yillion, ByteDance Technology, Sheng Ye Capital, PhillipCapital, and Advance.AI. Companies like OCBC, Validus Capital, Keppel Corp, and Vertex Ventures have withdrawn from the race, while Revolut and Nium have also dropped out. The MAS aims to liberalize the financial sector, providing more options for millennials and SMEs.

site_title: AMTD-led consortium confirms digibank wholesale application in Singapore
summary: A consortium led by AMTD Group, along with SP Group, Xiaomi Finance, and Funding Societies, has submitted an application for a digital wholesale banking license in Singapore. The proposed bank aims to cater to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in South-east Asia and the Greater Bay Area, providing financing options, green and sustainable developments, and improving productivity through IoT platforms. The group's goal is to establish Singapore's most innovative platform bank, driving innovation and financial inclusion in the region.

site_title: Ex-Trump aide Bolton ready to testify in impeachment trial
summary: Former White House national security advisor John Bolton has announced he is willing to testify in the Senate impeachment trial of President Donald Trump if subpoenaed. Democrats believe Bolton's testimony could support charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. Bolton, who was fired by Trump in September, has not disclosed whether his testimony would be damaging or helpful to the president. His decision comes as Democrats seek to build a case against Trump.

images.alt_text: Former White House national security advisor John Bolton, in a surprise announcement, said on Monday that he is willing to testify if subpoenaed in the Senate impeachment trial of President Donald Trump.

site_title: Food software startup Olo planning US IPO in 2020: sources
summary: Olo, a food-ordering software company, plans a US initial public offering (IPO) this year, with a potential valuation of around $1 billion. The New York-based company, which includes Shake Shack founder Danny Meyer on its board, has interviewed potential advisers and could seek an IPO by the end of 2020. No final decision has been made, and plans could change.

site_title: Controversial dual-class stocks get their very own ETF
summary: Exchange Traded Concepts has launched the North Shore Dual Share Class ETF, tracking companies with multiple US-issued share classes, typically one for investors and another for founders/executives. This structure has sparked controversy over unequal voting rights, but advocates argue it's advantageous for company growth. The new ETF focuses on companies like Alphabet Inc, which has used multiple share classes to maintain founder control.

site_title: Brazil looks to smooth impact of oil price spikes: minister
summary: Brazil's government is working on a policy to reduce the impact of oil price spikes, but will not create a subsidy, instead offering "compensation" to Petrobras. The plan aims to smooth the impact of price hikes on the state-owned oil firm, which has struggled with losses due to price controls. President Jair Bolsonaro has stated he won't interfere in Petrobras' fuel pricing decisions, following a previous controversy in which he pressured the company to cancel a price hike. The move aims to maintain the company's independence and avoid further market volatility.

site_title: KFC owner Yum adds burgers to menu with Habit purchase
summary: Yum! Brands, the parent company of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell, has agreed to purchase Habit Restaurants Inc. for $375 million. Habit, a fast-casual chain, offers chargrilled burgers and sandwiches. The acquisition marks Yum's entry into the fast-casual market, where it competes with chains like Shake Shack and Five Guys. Habit's self-ordering kiosks and drive-thru windows will be integrated into Yum's existing operations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, ComfortDelGro, Ascendas Reit, Frasers Prop, Cache Logistics, Olam
summary: Singapore stocks were affected by the Australian bushfires, with Singtel and ComfortDelGro experiencing falls due to Optus' network disruptions. However, other Singapore-listed firms with Australian assets, such as Ascendas Reit, Frasers Property, and Olam International, were not directly impacted. ST Engineering's strong orderbook and recent acquisitions are expected to boost earnings, making it a potential preferred pick for 2020.

site_title: JetBlue says to go carbon neutral by July 2020
summary: JetBlue, a US airline, announced it will become the first major US airline to go carbon neutral for all domestic flights starting this summer. The company aims to offset 7-8 million metric tons of emissions annually through partnerships with carbon offset providers. JetBlue's move follows growing consumer awareness of air travel's environmental impact and industry pledges to cut emissions in half by 2050. The airline's goal is to prepare its business for the lower-carbon economy, and it will not affect airfares, according to CEO Robin Hayes.

site_title: Ghosn used bullet train to escape: NHK
summary: Former Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn fled Japan on December 29, 2020, by boarding a bullet train with two men at Tokyo's Shinagawa station. They checked into a hotel near Kansai Airport, but Ghosn was not caught on security camera. He is believed to have taken a private jet from the airport, bound for Istanbul, then switched planes to Beirut. Japan's justice minister says border controls will be bolstered after the escape, and prosecutors are investigating how Ghosn slipped past security measures.

site_title: Solid 2019 US auto sales underscore consumer strength
summary: US auto sales in 2019 reached approximately 17 million, slightly below the all-time peak of a few years ago. Despite a slight dip, the sales demonstrate underlying resilience, driven by a tight labor market and offsetting recession and trade war worries. Experts expect a slightly cooler market in 2020, citing a tight labor market as a key factor. The strong sales also reflect the continued dominance of large vehicles in the market.

images.alt_text: US auto sales in 2019 dipped slightly from the prior year, but still demonstrated an underlying resilience as large vehicles strengthened their stranglehold over the market.

site_title: SpaceX launches third batch of Starlink satellites
summary: SpaceX launched its third batch of 60 Starlink satellites into orbit, bringing the total to nearly 180 satellites, with plans to reach 42,000 by 2025. The constellation aims to control a significant share of the global internet market, valued at $30 billion annually. Astronomers have raised concerns about the impact on night views and potential collisions between satellites, but SpaceX claims to have measures in place to mitigate these issues. The company's goal is to control 3-5% of the global internet market, with plans to deploy satellites for Canada and the northern US by next year.

site_title: 21 Singapore digibank applicants, two-thirds for wholesale licence: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has received 21 digital bank applications, with 14 seeking wholesale licenses and 7 for full bank licenses. The applications include e-commerce firms, fintech companies, and financial institutions, with a majority being consortia. MAS expects to issue up to five digital banking licenses by June this year, with the first digital banks expected to start operations by mid-2021. The regulator is focusing on tapping unmet needs and ensuring the long-term sustainability of new digital banks, with applicants required to show a path towards profitability and a clear value proposition.

images.alt_text: A total of 21 digital bank applications were received by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), the regulator said on Tuesday.

site_title: Amazon revs up auto ambitions with in-car TV, Alexa integration
summary: Amazon has unveiled plans to expand its presence in the auto sector, partnering with car brands to integrate its Fire TV platform and Alexa digital assistant into vehicles. The "Echo Auto" program will roll out in 15 countries, allowing car owners to add Alexa to their vehicles through a phone application. Additionally, Amazon will offer in-car entertainment through its Fire TV platform and integrate Alexa into electric vehicles, including Rivian's delivery vans and Lamborghini's Huracan Evo range. The move aims to bring Alexa to places beyond the home, making it easier for customers to interact with technology.

site_title: Occidental plans to slash US$7.8b debt with pipeline split
summary: Occidental Petroleum plans to split its pipeline business, Western Midstream Partners, into a stand-alone company, removing approximately $7.8 billion of debt from its balance sheet. The move aims to reduce leverage incurred in the purchase of Anadarko Petroleum Corp. Western Midstream's CEO Michael Ure is seeking new customers to reduce reliance on Occidental. The company's shares surged over 4% after the announcement, while Occidental's shares rose 4% to vie for the top spot in the S&P 500's Energy Index.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop as Washington and Tehran trade threats
summary: European shares dropped 0.4% on Monday, extending a decline for the second straight day, amid escalating tensions between the US and Iran. US President Donald Trump warned that Washington would strike back if Iran retaliated, while Iran vowed to avenge the killing of a top general. Despite this, shares of Pandora rose 12% after meeting 2019 sales targets, while the European oil and gas index reached its highest level in nearly three months. Markets are expected to remain volatile, with defensive plays such as telecoms and utilities outperforming the wider market.

site_title: Trump says Zuckerberg told him he's Facebook's 'number one'
summary: US President Donald Trump claimed Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg told him he's the platform's "number one" at a dinner in October, despite a Facebook spokesman stating the dinner took place in October and Trump's statement being later. Trump emphasized the importance of social media for his messaging and said without it, he'd be "lost" in conveying the truth. This comes amid criticism of social media platforms for enabling misinformation and fake news, particularly during the 2020 presidential election.

site_title: US slams Russia, China at UN for failure to condemn embassy attack
summary: The US criticized Russia and China for failing to condemn an attack on its Baghdad embassy by pro-Iranian demonstrators, which occurred on December 31. The US mission to the UN stated that Russia and China's silence undermined the Security Council's credibility. US President Donald Trump had responded to the attack by ordering a drone strike that killed Iran's top military commander, Qasem Soleimani. Russia and China rejected the US allegations, citing their own condemnation of embassy attacks and the need for a nuanced response to the situation.

site_title: Boeing reassigns 737 MAX workers with factory shutdown looming
summary: Boeing plans to shut down its 737 MAX assembly lines in mid-January, affecting 3,000 workers. The company has reassigned workers to other programs, including the 767, 777, and 777X, and the 787 program in South Carolina. Workers will also be involved in managing stored MAX aircraft and improving standard work processes at the Renton factory. Production will halt when the line number 7896 rolls out of the factory, but the restart date remains uncertain due to ongoing regulatory issues with the plane's design and certification process.

site_title: Safe-haven currencies in demand amid US-Iran tension
summary: The yen and other safe-haven currencies surged amid US-Iran tension, with the yen reaching a three-month high against the US dollar. Gold and oil prices also rose due to concerns of a broader Middle East conflict. Bitcoin hit a two-week high, while currencies sensitive to global risk appetite weakened. Analysts expect investors to remain nervous until there is more clarity on the geopolitical tensions between the US and Iran, potentially hurting global economic growth.

site_title: Hong Kong landlords face tough times as shop, office rents sink
summary: Hong Kong landlords face a challenging year as shop and office rents continue to decline. Protests since 2019 have led to a slump in tourists and retailers, with over 5,600 jobs at risk and thousands of stores potentially shutting down. Retail-leasing transactions have dropped 26% in the second half of 2019, and international brands are scaling back operations. Office rents in Central are expected to decline by 10% per annum over the next two years, with grade A office rents in the area projected to drop by 13% in 2020.

site_title: Trump's blacklisting of Huawei failing to halt its growth
summary: Huawei, the Chinese technology giant, has defied US President Donald Trump's blacklisting by recording an 18% rise in sales to a new high of $164.5 billion in 2019, despite being blocked from buying vital American components. The company has diversified its supply chain, partnering with Japanese and South Korean suppliers, and has also redesigned its products to reduce its reliance on US-made parts. Despite facing challenges in the smartphone business and enterprise sector, Huawei's 5G capabilities and global market presence continue to pose a threat to US national security concerns.

site_title: Oil steadies as market ponders Iran's next move
summary: Oil prices steadied on Monday after reaching above $70 a barrel due to tensions in the Middle East following a US air strike that killed a top Iranian military commander. Despite growing doubts about Iran striking back, prices rose due to initial rhetoric from the US, Iran, and Iraq. However, as a dialogue emerged suggesting it wasn't in Iran's interest to attack oil infrastructure, prices pared gains. Brent crude futures settled at $68.91 a barrel, up 31 cents from Friday's settlement.

site_title: American Airlines reaches deal with Boeing on MAX losses
summary: American Airlines has reached a deal with Boeing on compensation for financial losses related to the 737 MAX grounding, which caused thousands of flights to be cancelled. The deal covers 2019 financial damages, estimated to be $540 million in pre-tax profits, and includes $30 million in compensation for employees under the company's profit-sharing plan. This follows a similar agreement announced by Southwest Airlines last month, as Boeing has set aside $4.9 billion for customers harmed by the MAX grounding. The agreement marks a step forward for the airline industry, but production of the MAX remains halted due to regulatory delays.

site_title: US military tells Iraq it is preparing to 'move out': official letter
summary: The US military informed its Iraqi counterparts that it is preparing to "move out" of the country, according to a letter from Brigadier General William Seely, head of the US-led coalition's Task Force Iraq. The letter, dated Monday, stated that forces would be repositioning over the coming days and weeks to prepare for their departure, following Iraq's parliament's vote to rescind its invitation for foreign troops to stay. The move comes a day after the Iraqi parliament urged the government to oust foreign troops.

site_title: sgCarMart: Singapore's ebay of cars
summary: Singapore's sgCarMart, the country's largest online car trading platform, has achieved significant success with 95% of used car dealers using its platform, drawing 2.6 million monthly visitors. The company, acquired by Singapore Press Holdings in 2013, generates revenue from classified ads and after-sales support services, with no commission taken from transactions. sgCarMart's CEO Vincent Tan attributes the platform's success to its ability to bridge the information gap between buyers and sellers, and its commitment to providing a reliable and trustworthy platform for the used car market.

site_title: MVI Technologies works to remain future-proof
summary: MVI Technologies, a Singapore-based payment solutions provider, aims to expand its global footprint and become a premier provider of mission-critical financial and payment software solutions. Founded in 1991 by CEO Foo Say Juan, the company has developed its flagship product, M^Dynamics, which enables real-time payment with minimum risk and maximum reliability. MVI's flexible solutions allow new and old systems to coexist, empowering its staff and clients. The company continues to innovate, conducting R&D to enhance its software products and provide cloud compatibility, with plans to form partnerships to resell and distribute its top software solution in Asia.

site_title: Parts of Singtel's Optus network disrupted by fires
summary: Fires in Australia's New South Wales and Victoria states have disrupted parts of Singtel's Optus network, affecting rural and regional areas. The fires have impacted the telecom network, but no further details were provided.

site_title: HK exchange to ensure relevance as East-West connector: CEO
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) aims to maintain its relevance as a connector between East and West by boosting market connectivity and embracing technology. CEO Charles Li believes Hong Kong's unique contributions to China's financial markets will continue to grow, despite concerns over China's growing wealth and Hong Kong's economic decline. HKEX plans to enhance its Stock Connect platform for equities and commodities markets, and Mr. Li sees Hong Kong playing a key role in China's internationalisation and bridging the gap between China's market structures and the West.

site_title: Superfast 5G on the slow road at Consumer Electronics Show
summary: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas showcased the slow rollout of 5G technology, despite its potential applications in fields such as self-driving vehicles, holographic interactions, and augmented reality. Networks are still nascent, and devices capable of accessing them are scarce, with only 20 countries having deployed 5G networks. Backers expect 5G to enable seamless virtual experiences, eliminate data lag woes in VR, and usher in the era of "ambient computing." However, consumers may have to wait until spring or summer for 5G-enabled devices to become available.

site_title: Diversification helped Singapore avoid recession in 2019: Chan
summary: Singapore's economy avoided recession in 2019 due to diversification, with three services sectors - banking and finance, professional services, and infocomm technology - contributing to growth. Trade Minister Chan Chun Sing attributed this to the country's diversified economy, which brings resilience and stability. Despite cautiously optimistic growth expectations for 2020, uncertainties in the global economy, including the US-China trade deal and Brexit, remain. The government is focusing on the digital economy to drive growth, with strategies to strengthen fundamentals, internationalize companies and workers, and pursue new growth opportunities in emerging industries.

site_title: Textile industry faces mounting pressure to meet environmental standards
summary: The textile industry faces significant pressure to meet environmental standards due to its high water consumption, with over 80 billion cubic meters of water used annually. Fast-changing fashion trends, lower prices, and new technologies have accelerated this issue. Effluent wastewater from textile manufacturing processes can harm the environment and human health, prompting governments to implement stringent regulations. To comply, companies are adopting modern wastewater treatment technologies, such as Zero Liquid Discharge solutions, to reduce their environmental footprint and create a sustainable future for the industry.

site_title: Prudential Vietnam inks exclusive bancassurance deal with SeABank
summary: Prudential Vietnam Assurance has inked a 20-year exclusive bancassurance deal with SeABank, starting from April, to offer life insurance products to the bank's customers. The partnership will also make Prudential Vietnam the preferred life insurance provider to BRG Group, a Vietnamese conglomerate with over 10 million customers. The tie-up aims to enhance Prudential's reach in Asia, particularly in Vietnam, which has a growing demand for health, protection, and wealth management products.

site_title: Bosch unveils smart virtual sun visor for cars
summary: Bosch unveiled a smart virtual sun visor for cars at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. The device uses artificial intelligence and a camera to block glare from sunlight, a major cause of road accidents. It darkens the section where sunlight is hitting a driver's eyes, providing relief from glare. The Virtual Visor is inspired by LCD televisions and aims to enhance driver comfort and safety.

images.alt_text: The Virtual Visor uses algorithms and a camera to analyse what the driver sees, and darkens the section where the sunlight hits their eyes.

site_title: Iran's leader Khamenei weeps at general's funeral as nation grieves
summary: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei wept during the funeral of slain military commander Qassem Soleimani, who was killed in a US drone strike. Large crowds gathered in Tehran, the largest since 1989, to bid farewell to the commander of the Quds Force, a unit in charge of foreign operations of Iran's Revolutionary Guards. The outpouring of national grief has been fueled by Soleimani's death, with many Iranians expressing anger and sadness over the US strike. The funeral marked a significant moment in Iran's mourning process.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US stocks open lower due to President Trump's new tariffs on Canada. Companies report mixed earnings, with Creative Technology warning of below-target revenue and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow considers increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore stocks rally for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data, while Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in H2, leading to a downgrade from CGSI to 'hold'.

site_title: Nervy markets flip risk-averse switch on
summary: Investors shifted to risk-averse assets, including gold, crude oil, and Singapore-listed gold shares ETF, as rising US-Iran tensions led to a surge in geopolitical tensions. Gold hit a six-year high, while Brent crude oil reached over US$70 per barrel. Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.6% down, with other regional markets also posting losses. Analysts expect the tensions to be a temporary blip on market sentiment, with global economic recovery expected to eventually support market confidence.

site_title: Chop and change is Trump's game
summary: President Donald Trump's foreign policy strategy remains undefined, likened to Schrödinger's Cat, as he embodies both hawkish and dovish tendencies. Despite initial success in avoiding new military conflicts, his engagement with North Korea and Iran has stalled. The US-Iran nuclear deal was revoked, and economic sanctions were imposed, but negotiations have failed to yield results. The assassination of Iranian General Qassem Soleimani has heightened tensions, potentially leading to a regional war. Trump's actions have created a precarious environment, with the risk of military escalation and retaliation from Iran, and could impact the US economy and global stability.

site_title: MP among three lawyers appointed Senior Counsel
summary: Murali Pillai, Jason Chan Tai-Hui, and Mohamed Faizal Mohamed Abdul Kadir have been appointed as Senior Counsel in Singapore, joining the elite ranks of the country's equivalent of Britain's Queen's Counsel. Pillai, a Member of Parliament and litigator, has argued several landmark cases, including a recent acquittal for a businessman and his trading firm. Chan, a partner at Allen & Gledhill, has experience as a former prosecutor and judicial officer, while Faizal, a deputy chief prosecutor and senior state counsel, has established scholarships and a book grant to encourage law students.

site_title: How to protect yourself from real estate scams as email exchanges increase
summary: Real estate scams involving wire fraud have increased, with scammers hacking into email accounts to pose as participants in transactions and request down payment funds be wired to fraudulent bank accounts. Since 2014, the FBI reported 3,766 victims of real estate scams with losses totaling nearly $339 million. To protect yourself, verify email requests with the actual participant, use a virtual private network (VPN) to encrypt traffic, and never send money without verbal verification. If you discover a fraudulent transfer, contact your financial institution and report the incident to law enforcement.

site_title: Boeing and FAA review wiring issue on grounded 737 MAX
summary: Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) are reviewing a wiring issue on the grounded 737 MAX, which could cause a short circuit and potentially lead to a crash. The issue involves two bundles of wiring being too close together, and Boeing is working with the FAA to design a solution. The FAA has directed Boeing to complete an audit, and the issue could delay the plane's return to service, with some reports suggesting it may not be approved until March. Production of the 737 MAX will halt this month due to the grounding.

site_title: US: Stocks shake off early weakness and end higher
summary: US stocks ended higher on Monday, despite early weakness, as investors weighed escalating US-Iran tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.2%, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.4% and the Nasdaq Composite jumped 0.6%. Large tech companies, including Alphabet and Salesforce, saw significant gains. Analysts believe the market is voting that the tensions won't disrupt the economy and corporate profits. Key economic indicators, including the services sector report and December US jobs report, are set to be released this week.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks shrugged off early weakness and pushed higher on Monday as investors weighed whether escalating US-Iran tensions would significantly affect the economy.

site_title: BNP Paribas to unveil e-FX pricing, trading engine in Singapore
summary: BNP Paribas to unveil an electronic foreign exchange (e-FX) pricing and trading engine in Singapore, with support from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The new engine will offer e-FX trading of 50 currencies and commodities, including precious and base metals. This move is part of BNP Paribas' expansion into the Asian market, marking a significant development in the region's financial sector.

site_title: Ghosn 'fled by bullet train'; Tokyo vows to bolster borders
summary: Former Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn fled Japan by bullet train nearly a week ago, skipping bail on multiple counts of financial misconduct he denies. Japan's justice minister vows to bolster border controls. Details of Ghosn's escape remain spotty, with the country still investigating a security lapse.

site_title: S-Reits key driver of market turnover in 2019: SGX
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) contributed 24% of the day-to-day turnover of the country's stock market in 2019, despite making up only 12% of the total market capitalization. The 43 trusts generated an average total return of 23% and an average 6% distribution yield. S-Reits outpaced the broader market, with 25 out of 43 trusts exceeding the 9.4% total return of the Straits Times Index. Global Reits also performed well, with a median total return of 21% in 2019, driven by macro uncertainty and the US Federal Reserve's dovish stance.

site_title: Building an inclusive, sustainable Yangon, one trash alley at a time
summary: A social enterprise in Yangon, Myanmar, called Doh Eain is transforming the city's alleys into green spaces, promoting community ownership and inclusivity. The project aims to make the city more livable by transforming trash alleys into vibrant areas with murals, plants, and community amenities. Local resident Yee Lay, who previously suffered from the negative impact of trash-filled alleys, now enjoys the newly created space. The initiative seeks to bring the community together and improve the quality of life for Yangon's residents.

site_title: Getting to the truth of what happened in Hong Kong
summary: In Hong Kong, a massive anti-government march on New Year's Day turned violent, with 400 people arrested for illegal assembly. The police claimed rioters hijacked the demonstration, but protesters argue the police acted to suppress the peaceful rally. China replaced top official Wang Zhimin, the first to be removed since protests began last June, with Luo Huining, who has little experience in Hong Kong affairs. Beijing may be seeking to address the crisis by appointing an outsider and using Luo's financial expertise to stabilize the economy. Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam is seen as an opportunity to resolve the crisis, but her government has so far refused to seek a compromise with protesters.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jackspeed Corporation, a leather trim manufacturer, suspended its share sale and ceased operating business after selling its assets for S$48 million to a special purpose vehicle. GuocoLand Malaysia sold a parcel of agricultural land in Malacca for RM119.3 million, expecting a net gain of RM35.4 million. US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariffs on Canada. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss, while London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Economists expect extended period of slow growth
summary: Economists predict a prolonged period of slow economic growth, subdued inflation, and low interest rates. The US and other developed economies are unlikely to see significant increases in productivity growth or trend GDP growth, and may be at risk of deflation. Policymakers will need to rethink their approach, with fiscal policies playing a larger role in combating recessions. The US is better positioned than other major economies, but the euro area faces greater risks of "Japanification" if it fails to address its economic challenges.

site_title: Deadly fires Down Under: Australia should wean itself off fossil fuels
summary: Australia is experiencing its worst-ever forest fire season, with nearly 6 million hectares burning and at least 24 people dead, amid a backdrop of climate change. The country's reliance on fossil fuels, particularly coal, has been criticized for exacerbating the issue. Despite warnings from former top firefighters, Prime Minister Scott Morrison has been slow to acknowledge the reality of climate change, instead framing the fires as a natural disaster. The government's handling of the crisis has been widely criticized, with many questioning the country's commitment to addressing climate change and transitioning to renewable energy sources.

site_title: Going high-tech with a human touch
summary: Singaporean industries traditionally reliant on manpower and service quality are leveraging technology to free up workers, not replace them. Online retail insights and digital presence can drive offline gains, enabling warmer service at key points. Self-service kiosks, tablets, and apps in food services and hotels allow staff to focus on customer service or higher-value tasks. Digital technologies also simplify processes in retail, such as stock-taking and inventory management, freeing up employees to interact with customers. The rise of e-commerce does not mean the obsolescence of brick-and-mortar shops, with customers seeking a physical experience to complement digital one.

site_title: Deadly bushfires hit businesses; damage still being assessed
summary: Deadly bushfires in Australia have hit businesses, with resorts shutting doors, cheesemakers struggling to secure milk supplies, and insurance claims on the rise. As of January 6, 2020, 5,850 fire-related insurance claims have been lodged with estimated losses of A$375 million (S$350 million). The fires have destroyed over six million hectares of land, killed 24 people, and left some towns without electricity and mobile coverage. The full cost of the disaster is not expected to be known for several weeks.

site_title: When central banks go green
summary: Central banks are considering the implications of climate change on financial stability. Climate change poses two types of financial risks: transition risks (e.g., stranded assets) and physical risks (e.g., natural disasters). Financial regulators and supervisors have been aware of these risks since the 2015 Paris climate agreement. Some central banks, like the Bank of England, are exploring ways to incorporate climate mitigation into their monetary policies, such as favoring green bonds and other environmentally friendly securities. This could potentially become a secondary objective of monetary policy, with the goal of supporting the economic policy of governments and contributing to sustainable development.

site_title: Citi's investment bank plans to hire 2,500 programmers this year
summary: Citigroup's investment bank plans to hire 2,500 programmers this year, bolstering its technology team as the company shifts towards technology to enhance salespeople and traders' effectiveness. The hires reflect the bank's focus on technology, which now accounts for about 20% of its expenses. This move comes as global banks invest billions in technologies to make front-office staff more efficient and keep clients trading. The bank's technology investments have already saved it around $600 million in 2020.

site_title: Amazon Fire TV crosses 40m active users globally
summary: Amazon's Fire TV streaming device has surpassed 40 million active users globally, maintaining its lead over rival Roku Inc. This growth is attributed to the increasing popularity of streaming devices, which offer content from various platforms. The figure is an 8% increase from 37 million users in September.

site_title: AMTD, Xiaomi gun for digibank licence with SP Group, Funding Societies
summary: AMTD Group, a Hong Kong financial services firm, has partnered with Xiaomi, Funding Societies, and SP Group to vie for a digital wholesale bank license in Singapore. The consortium aims to offer data-driven financial services, with SP Group providing expertise in sustainable finance and green energy projects. The proposed bank would serve SMEs and non-retail segments, with a capital requirement of S$100 million. This move follows AMTD's interest in Singapore, seen as a regional gateway to Asian markets, and its existing virtual banking license with Xiaomi in Hong Kong.

site_title: Why 2020 will be key global election year
summary: Key global elections in 2020 will shape domestic politics, economics, and international relations. Notable elections include the Taiwanese presidential and legislative elections on January 11, Israeli elections on March 3, and US presidential and congressional elections in November. The US elections will determine whether Donald Trump wins a second term, while Taiwan's election may impact cross-strait relations with China. Other significant elections will take place in the Middle East, Africa, and Europe, including in Germany and Japan. The outcome of these elections will have far-reaching consequences for global politics and economies.

site_title: Singapore, its firms optimistic about India's long-term prospects: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam from Singapore expressed optimism about India's long-term prospects, citing growing investments in technology parks and logistics. During a working visit, Tharman met with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, discussing economic cooperation and mutual interests in infrastructure, skills, and the digital economy. Modi expressed desire to strengthen cooperation in areas like infrastructure, tourism, and innovation. Both sides agreed on sustained growth and inclusivity for India's young population.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on rising Middle East tensions
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday due to rising Middle East tensions, with the Dow Jones falling 0.59% to 28,465.50, the S&P 500 down 0.53% to 3,217.55, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 0.86% to 8,943.50. Investors sought safer assets like gold and government bonds amid escalating tensions between the US and Iran.

site_title: Star Wars begins 2020 as box-office champ
summary: Star Wars: Rise of Skywalker continued its box-office dominance in the first weekend of 2020, earning $33.7 million in the US and Canada. The film is closing in on $1 billion worldwide and will mark a record seventh US$1 billion release for Disney in 2019. Meanwhile, holiday holdovers like Jumanji: The Next Level and Greta Gerwig's Little Women remained strong, with Little Women becoming an outright hit with a modest budget.

images.alt_text: Above: Star Wars: Rise of Skywalker will mark a record seventh US$1 billion 2019 release for Disney.
Frozen 2 is the highest grossing film ever directed by a woman in worldwide ticket sales.

site_title: Money FM podcast: 'Musings on Leadership' with Tor Mesoy
summary: Singaporean business leaders discuss various topics on the 'Musings on Leadership' podcast, including managing complexity in mergers and acquisitions, the importance of authentic leadership, and tracking leadership development. Recent news includes DBS appointing Derrick Goh as group COO and Citi Private Bank hiring Hoo Peng Han to rebuild its family office team in Asia. Companies are also exploring ways to improve leadership, such as eliminating executive chairmen and investing in CEO salaries. These discussions aim to raise Singapore's global competitiveness and provide insights into effective leadership strategies.

site_title: ST Engg worth a look on record orderbook
summary: ST Engineering's orderbook stands at a record S$15.9 billion, providing visibility for strong growth over the next two years. The company's recent acquisitions are expected to bolster earnings, with contributions from engine nacelle maker MRA Systems and satellite communications firm Newtec Group. Analysts predict near-term earnings will be robust, with a target price of S$4.34. The company's cash reserves are sufficient to undertake further acquisitions, and analysts see potential for organic growth in its engine maintenance and marine divisions.

site_title: SBF's digibank bid raises impartiality question; SMEs hope for more financing help
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has announced a minority stake in a digital full-bank licence consortium, raising questions about impartiality. SMEs welcome more financing options, but some express concerns about the SBF's potential conflict of interest. The SBF aims to provide financing solutions for its members, but its role as a neutral party is being scrutinized. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to announce the results of the digital banking applications by mid-year, with Grab and Singtel among the other players vying for a licence.

site_title: Aeromexico reaches compensation deal with Boeing over MAX crisis
summary: Aeromexico has reached a compensation deal with Boeing over the 737 MAX crisis, joining a growing list of airlines settling with the US company. Details of the payment were not disclosed, with Aeromexico remaining in talks with Boeing and regulatory authorities. The deal follows similar agreements from Southwest Airlines and Turkish Airlines. Boeing is also considering raising debt and deferring capital expenditures to bolster its finances amid the grounding of its 737 MAX jet.

site_title: Singapore property players spared from crisis so far
summary: Singapore property players have been spared from the crisis caused by Australia's raging bushfires, with urban areas not affected. Logistics and office properties in cities like Sydney and Melbourne remain intact. Companies such as Ascendas Reit have contingency plans and insurance coverage in place. The situation may worsen if rural and regional areas are impacted, but for now, Singapore's real estate players have avoided the worst of the crisis.

site_title: Sectors with ITMs saw more jobs created for Singaporeans, PRs
summary: Singapore's Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) have created 19,500 jobs, with 39,300 positions filled by Singaporeans and 8,600 by permanent residents, offsetting a decrease in foreign employment by 28,500. Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad emphasized the importance of medium- to long-term employment outcomes. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing acknowledged anxieties about the local-foreign workforce balance, emphasizing the need for fair opportunities and merit-based practices, citing the success of Singapore's electronics industry in the 1970s.

site_title: Indonesia mobilises fishermen in stand-off with China
summary: Indonesia mobilizes 120 fishermen to join warships in the South China Sea to defend against Chinese vessels, escalating a stand-off in the northern Natuna islands. President Joko Widodo stated there will be no negotiation on sovereignty, amid a souring relationship with China. Indonesia has already sent six warships to the area, with four more on the way, and the fishermen will operate in the Natuna islands and other areas. China claims the South China Sea, including the Natuna islands, as its own, but the move is seen as a response to the presence of a Chinese coastguard vessel.

site_title: Australian bus depots so far not affected by bushfires: ComfortDelGro
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp's Australian bus depots face "low to moderate exposure to bushfire risk" but have not been affected so far. The company's bus commuter services in fire-stricken states remain operational, with depot evacuation plans in place. ComfortDelGro has set up a relief fund to support Australian firefighting efforts and will provide emergency service volunteers with paid leave and transport.

site_title: Australian gallery shuts to protects Matisse, Picasso works from smoke
summary: Australia's capital, Canberra, closed the National Gallery due to hazardous air quality caused by smoke from devastating bushfires. The gallery protected its Matisse and Picasso works, including Picasso's portraits of his wife and lover, from potential damage. The city's 400,000 residents were advised to avoid physical activity, and many businesses ordered staff to stay home. Air quality readings showed the smoke was at hazardous levels, prompting the gallery's closure. The closure was a precautionary measure to mitigate risks to the public and artworks.

site_title: HK parents eye Singapore schools as protests linger
summary: Hong Kong parents are increasingly considering Singapore as an alternative for their children's education due to ongoing protests in the city. The protests have disrupted the economy and education system, prompting parents to look for safer and more stable options. International schools in Singapore have seen a surge in interest from Hong Kong parents, with some reporting a quarter increase in applications. However, the process can be complex and expensive, with many schools having long waiting lists and high fees. Singapore's government has also offered support to families relocating due to the crisis, including a long-term visit pass for parents accompanying children studying in the city-state.

site_title: 1917 wins top Golden Globe as Netflix favourites fall short
summary: The 2020 Golden Globes saw 1917 win the top prize for best drama, beating out Netflix favourites. Despite lavish spending and numerous nominees, Netflix only took home two awards. The win for 1917, directed by Sam Mendes and Universal Pictures, was seen as an upset, as the film was set to release in theaters just days prior. The Golden Globes lived up to their reputation as an unpredictable awards show, with 1917's victory marking a surprise in the awards race.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower as Middle East tensions hit risk appetite
summary: South Korean stocks closed 0.98% lower on Monday, their lowest close since December 12, due to Middle East tensions. US President Donald Trump threatened to impose sanctions on Iraq and retaliate against Iran after the killing of its top commander. The won dropped 0.43% against the US dollar, and the Kospi fell 21.39 points. Foreigners were net buyers of 99.1 billion won worth of shares, while the benchmark bond yield fell 2.0 basis points to 1.532%.

site_title: Saudi credit default swaps soar on US-Iran crisis
summary: Saudi Arabia's credit default swaps (CDS) have soared by a sixth to 64 basis points, up from 55 bps on January 2, amid the US-Iran crisis following the killing of Iranian commander Qassem Soleimani. International bonds issued by Saudi Arabia and Aramco are yielding 10 basis points more, while regional markets, including Dubai and Abu Dhabi, have seen less marked increases. Market volatility is expected to delay any potential plans by regional borrowers to issue new debt, with foreign investors hesitant to invest in the region due to the escalating tensions.

site_title: Meant to cripple Iran's clout, US strike unites its allies
summary: The US killing of Iranian general Qasem Soleimani in a Baghdad drone strike has had the opposite effect of intended, uniting pro-Iran factions in the Middle East under an "axis of resistance." Analysts see this as a strategic mistake that will lead to a unified response from resistance forces, including Iraq's Kataeb Hezbollah, the Mahdi Army, and Houthi rebels in Yemen. The strike has also sparked a surge in popular support for Soleimani in Iran, potentially bolstering the Iranian government.

site_title: Samsung seen drawing line under lacklustre 2019 with chip revival
summary: Samsung Electronics is expected to post its biggest annual profit drop in at least a decade, with a 40% slump in operating profit in the fourth quarter of 2019. The company's 2019 earnings were marred by bloated chip stockpiles and the US-China trade war, but optimism for the rollout of new 5G networks is driving market recovery expectations. Analysts forecast a nearly 40% surge in Samsung's annual profit in 2020, despite caution from industry experts about the strength of the recovery.

images.alt_text: Despite 2019's tough times for the world of chips, Samsung still generated half of its January-September profit from the business.

site_title: Milkman concept revived by Dutch online supermarket seeking edge
summary: An Amsterdam-based online grocery company, Picnic BV, has revived the concept of the milk float by launching "Milkman 2.0," a service that delivers groceries using electric vehicles, reducing food waste and emissions. The company has 1,000 electric vans and plans to add hundreds more, with a focus on local delivery and minimal emissions. Backed by $375 million in funding, Picnic aims to expand its infrastructure and build a robotised fulfillment center, processing 150,000 orders weekly, with plans to disrupt the e-commerce market and eventually expand beyond groceries.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 13.62 points to 1,597.76. Losers outnumbered gainers 646 to 269, and volume reached 3.4 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion.

site_title: Startup generator Antler raises additional US$50m in funding
summary: Antler, a Singapore-founded startup generator and early-stage venture capital firm, has raised an additional US$50 million in funding from investors including Eduardo Saverin, Kistefos, Canica International, and Credit Saison. Since its launch in 2018, Antler has invested in over 120 companies across 17 industries, with founders from 36 nationalities. The firm plans to expand its portfolio and launch new programs in 2020.

site_title: 'Win a Picasso' charity draw postponed
summary: A charity raffle for a Picasso painting worth over $1.5 million has been postponed until March. The event was initially set for January but was delayed due to insufficient ticket sales. The raffle aims to raise funds for clean water projects in Africa through the charity CARE. The winner of the painting, a still-life by Spanish master Pablo Picasso, will be selected in March, with the goal of maximizing the amount of money raised for the charity.

images.alt_text: The draw is being run through the 1picasso100euros.com website.

site_title: Investors in Australian real estate unlikely to be put off by wildfire crisis
summary: Institutional investors, including those from Singapore, are unlikely to be deterred from investing in Australian real estate due to the devastating wildfires. Despite the crisis, most investments are focused on gateway cities such as Sydney and Melbourne, which are not directly affected by the fires. Experts note that the fires are primarily in regional forest and grassland areas, and that the smoke impact on major cities is temporary. Transactions by Singapore investors in Australia in 2019, totaling US$3.4 billion, demonstrate confidence in the market's resilience.

images.alt_text: Without minimising the tragedy of the Australian wildfire crisis which has killed 24 people so far and destroyed some 2,000 homes, consultants note that the fires are not in the gateway cities favoured by institutional investors.

site_title: Software firm SAP names new S-E Asia president, managing director
summary: SAP has appointed Rachel Barger as the new president and managing director of SAP Southeast Asia, based in Singapore. Barger will drive strategy, customer operations, and customer transformation into intelligent enterprises. She will report to Scott Russell, president of SAP Asia Pacific Japan. This appointment aims to accelerate SAP's growth in the Southeast Asian market.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.6% amid rising US-Iran tensions
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.6% amid rising US-Iran tensions, as investors sought safe havens and crude oil surged. Gold reached a six-year high, the Japanese Yen hit a three-month high, and Brent crude surpassed $70 per barrel. This comes despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: India plans to cut spending to curb deficit; may hurt growth
summary: India's government is planning to cut spending by up to 2 trillion Indian rupees (S$37.5 billion) for the current fiscal year due to a 2.5 trillion rupee revenue shortfall. This move could hurt the economy, which is already growing at its slowest pace in over six years. With a target of keeping the fiscal deficit under 3.8% of gross domestic product, the government may announce additional borrowing of 300-500 billion rupees. Analysts warn that the move could further drag down growth, which has slowed to 4.5% in the last six consecutive quarters.

site_title: Aldi UK's Christmas sales growth fuelled by alcohol and premium ranges
summary: Aldi UK reported a 7.9% year-on-year sales growth in the four weeks to Dec 24, driven by strong demand for beers, wines, and spirits, as well as its premium product range. The company aims to reach 1,200 stores by 2025, maintaining pressure on larger rivals. Aldi UK's aggressive store opening programme has been winning market share from the big four, with a current market share of 8%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks suffer more losses on US-Iran fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.79% on Monday, extending losses from last week due to US-Iran tensions. The Hang Seng index fell to 28,226.19, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained unchanged. Despite a 0.44% gain in the Shenzhen Composite Index, overall market sentiment remained cautious. The decline follows the US assassination of a top Iranian general, fueling fears of a Middle East conflict.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop further at open
summary: European stocks declined at the open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.4%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 1.1%, and Paris' CAC 40 down 0.7%. Investors were cautious amid fallout from the US assassination of a top Iranian general. Despite this, mining and healthcare shares saw gains, and the US stock market edged towards fresh records.

site_title: Supermarket retailer Carrefour buys lunch delivery startup Dejbox
summary: Carrefour, a French supermarket retailer, has agreed to buy Dejbox, a lunch delivery startup, without disclosing financial terms. Dejbox is the largest online canteen firm in France, delivering meals to businesses in suburban and outlying areas, and employs around 300 staff. This acquisition aims to expand Carrefour's presence in the food delivery market.

site_title: Huge crowds in Iran for general's funeral
summary: Thousands of Iranians gathered in Tehran for the funeral of General Qassem Soleimani, killed in a US drone strike, with mourners chanting "Death to America." Soleimani's successor vowed to drive US forces out of the region in revenge, while Iran's Supreme Leader wept at the funeral. The US has listed 52 Iranian targets, including cultural sites, that could be hit if Iran retaliates. The killing has stoked concern of a broader Middle East conflict, with tensions escalating between Iran and the US.

images.alt_text: Iranian people on Monday attended a funeral procession for Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani, head of the elite Quds Force, and Iraqi militia commander Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis, who were killed in an air strike at Baghdad airport on Friday.

site_title: No Signboard applies for AGM deadline extension
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Catalist-listed seafood restaurant operator, has applied for a two-month extension to its annual general meeting (AGM) due to an ongoing independent review by Nexia TS Public Accounting Corporation. The review is examining the company's adoption of actual group accounting principles for its unaudited group financial statements. The AGM, initially set for February 2020, is now expected to take place by March 30. This extension will provide more time for the review's conclusion and issuance of the independent review, offering shareholders clarity on the company's financial position.

site_title: Offer for AVIC ends, paving way for delisting
summary: China Merchants Industry Investment's offer for AVIC International Maritime Holdings closed with 90.92% of shares accepted, paving the way for delisting. The offeror will compulsorily acquire dissenting shareholders' shares at S$0.15 per share and delist AVIC. As a result, AVIC lost its free float, and shareholders with dissenting shares need not take action. The delisting date will be announced in due course.

site_title: At least two injured in Jakarta building collapse
summary: A five-storey building in Jakarta partially collapsed on Monday morning, injuring at least two people. The building, which housed a convenience store and rental units, had no functioning water drainage system, and evidence of flooding on the rooftop may have contributed to the collapse. Lax construction standards have raised concerns about building safety in Indonesia, following previous incidents such as the 2018 collapse that killed seven people and injured 75.

site_title: Money Hacks podcast: What is a robo-advisory? (Ep 62)
summary: A robo-advisory is a type of automated investment service that provides personalized investment advice and portfolio management. Evy Wee, head of financial planning at DBS, explains that robo-advisers are easier for those starting their investing journey due to lower fees and user-friendly interfaces. However, fees can range from 0.5% to 1.5% of the investment amount. The main considerations for equities vs ETF portfolios include investment goals, risk tolerance, and fees. The podcast concludes that robo-advisers are a viable option for those looking for a low-cost, user-friendly investment solution.

site_title: UBS, JPMorgan see little Asian market impact from US-Iran tensions
summary: US-Iran tensions have limited impact on Asian markets, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index falling 1.1% on Monday. However, experts predict the effect will be short-lived, with rising global trade volumes and a reviving manufacturing cycle supporting earnings in Asian markets. Oil prices may be a key factor in determining the market's reaction, but investors are advised to consider diversification strategies and capital protection. The Middle East situation may distract the US from its trade conflict with China, which is a more significant factor for Japanese stocks.

site_title: Little Caesars to deliver pizza - finally - with DoorDash service
summary: Little Caesars, the world's third-largest pizza chain, has partnered with DoorDash to offer delivery services at 3,600 US and Canadian locations starting Monday. This marks Little Caesars' first foray into delivery, as the company had previously not offered this service. Orders will be fulfilled through DoorDash's driver fleet, with prices remaining the same as for takeout. The deal aims to help Little Caesars compete with other pizza chains and delivery platforms, which have seen sales decline due to growing competition.

site_title: Asean consumer sector set for soft start to 2020: DBS
