summary: China has temporarily blocked the planned cross-border listings between the Shanghai and London stock exchanges due to ongoing political tensions with the UK. The Shanghai-London Stock Connect scheme aimed to build ties between Britain and China, expand Chinese firms' investor base, and give mainland investors access to UK-listed companies. The suspension casts a shadow over the project's future.

site_title: Singapore developers to deliver strong ROE for FY2020-21: DBS Research
summary: DBS Research predicts Singapore developers will deliver strong return on equity (ROE) for FY2020-21, driven by recent mergers and acquisitions, and asset recycling activities. CapitaLand and City Developments Limited (CDL) are recommended as "diversified plays" with raised target prices. The brokerage anticipates a new era of growth for CapitaLand following its merger completion, but notes risks from a slowdown in Asian economies, particularly China. CDL's strong sell-through rates and recent policy measures to improve household affordability also support its "buy" rating.

site_title: Here's The Beef
summary: Veteran Swiss-born chef Otto Weibel has opened Black Marble, a steak and grill concept at Raffles Holland V shopping mall, at the age of 73. The restaurant features high-quality beef from Australia, Japan, and the US, grilled simply with no fuss, alongside non-steak dishes like pan-seared foie gras and lobster risotto. Weibel aims to "stand out as a destination for good quality food at affordable prices" in a cosy environment with good service provided by his team from Otto's Deli Fresh.

site_title: Private equity firms starting 2020 with more cash than ever
summary: Private equity firms are entering 2020 with a record $1.5 trillion in unspent capital, according to Preqin. This is the highest year-end total on record, fueled by low interest rates, the rise of index-tracking funds, and years of lackluster hedge fund performance. Many firms are expanding their investment options, including private credit and emerging markets, and are expected to make large deals in 2020, driven by tailwinds such as Brexit uncertainty and low rates.

site_title: Capturing rewards of platform business models
summary: A platform business model is transforming industries, with the total market value attributed to platform economics estimated at US$7 trillion in 2018, projected to reach US$60 trillion by 2025. Platforms trade information, enable commerce, drive social exchange, and offer value propositions, generating rewards for platform providers, including revenue, profit, market share, and disproportionate market influence. To tap into the greatest possibilities of platforms, companies must assess marketplace value shifts and future value propositions, deciding whether to initiate their own platform or participate in existing or emerging platforms.

site_title: Ono, Oh Yes
summary: Japanese-Brazilian singer Lisa Ono, 57, is set to perform in Singapore with her concert "La Vie En Rose" on January 4 at the Esplanade Theatre. Born in Brazil, Ono channels her birth country's memories through her music, popularizing bossa nova across Asia with her 1999 album "Dreams" selling over 200,000 copies in Japan. The concert will feature classic French song "La Vie En Rose" and other popular numbers.

images.alt_text: La Vie En Rose - Lisa Ono 2020.

site_title: HSBC kicks off new year with HK branches closed, vandalised amid protests
summary: HSBC branches in Hong Kong were vandalized and closed on the first day of the year, amid anti-government protests. Graffiti was daubed on the bank's city-centre headquarters, including the famous pair of lions, and some branches had their windows smashed. The closures were linked to HSBC's decision to shut an account held by a group called Spark Alliance, which helps pay protesters' legal costs. HSBC denies any connection to the arrests of four Spark Alliance members on money laundering charges, stating the account closure was in accordance with international regulatory standards.

images.alt_text: The two lions guarding the bank's city-centre headquarters were daubed with graffiti and briefly set alight after being doused in a flammable liquid.

site_title: Sezzle fails to win California lending licence
summary: Sezzle Inc, a buy-now-pay-later firm, failed to secure a lending license in California, dealing a significant blow to the company. The California Department of Business Oversight determined that Sezzle's practice of purchasing sales contracts meant it was already engaging in lending without a license. This decision led to a decline in Sezzle's shares by over 20% and a significant drop in the company's valuation. The rejection is part of a growing scrutiny of the buy-now-pay-later industry, with regulators questioning its business model and potential compliance with money-laundering laws.

site_title: For a sweet 2020, look to the bitter in wine
summary: A growing trend in wine appreciation is embracing the bitter flavors often found in red wines, particularly in Italian and French varieties. Bitterness is not only a natural defense against children's consumption, but also a desirable component in wine, providing a cleansing and revitalizing effect. Tannins, derived from grape skins, seeds, and stems, contribute to bitterness and are often balanced by sweet fruit flavors. Italian and French wines, such as Barolo and Beaujolais, showcase this attractive bitterness, while American wines with high alcohol levels tend to favor sweetness. As the author hopes, 2020 may mark a year for rehabilitating the notion of bitterness in wine.

site_title: New goal for 2020? Adding an integrity function within organisations
summary: A growing number of companies worldwide are recognizing the importance of practicing good governance, starting with requiring ethical conduct of management and employees. To formalize this, some companies are appointing Chief Integrity Officers (CIOs) within senior management to spearhead integrity programs and ensure an ethical culture. This concept, known as integrity management, aims to promote social and financial health by making prudent and ethical decisions in all aspects of business. Companies like Volkswagen, which has appointed a Board Member for Integrity and Legal Affairs, are adopting this approach to rebuild trust after scandals.

site_title: Julian Castro drops out of Democratic presidential race
summary: Former US Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro has dropped out of the Democratic presidential race, citing lagging fundraising and opinion polls. Castro, the sole Latino candidate, focused on immigration reform and criticizing President Donald Trump's handling of the border crisis. His departure means the Democratic field loses another minority candidate, leaving concerns about the party's diversity. Castro's campaign struggled to raise funds, with a goal of $800,000 by the end of October, and consistently polled below 1%.

site_title: Butcher's Block makes the cut
summary: Butcher's Block, a new Singapore restaurant, has received a 6.5-star rating for its focus on high-quality, sustainable meat. The eatery, located in Raffles Hotel, offers a limited menu with prime cuts of beef, lamb, and Australian Black Angus. Despite some teething issues with service and food presentation, the restaurant shines with its tender, well-cooked meats. Standout dishes include the A5 Kagoshima wagyu, Club Steak, and Mottainai sustainable lamb chops. Minor distractions include overpriced and overly elaborate dishes, but the restaurant's meat-centric approach is sure to please hardcore carnivores.

images.alt_text: Butcher's Block concentrates so much on its meat - which they say is sourced only from sustainable farmers dedicated to raising stress-free animals (left); Club Steak (right); soft-cooked egg covered in gold leaf with mushroom sauce.

Butcher's Block concentrates so much on its meat - which they say is sourced only from sustainable farmers dedicated to raising stress-free animals; Club Steak; soft-cooked egg covered in gold leaf with mushroom sauce (above).

site_title: Watches - Rat Pack
summary: Watch brands are launching special-edition Chinese zodiac animal timepieces in time for the Lunar New Year, with the Year of the Rat being particularly auspicious due to its association with cleverness, optimism, and success. Luxury brands such as Vacheron Constantin, Panerai, Piaget, Chopard, and Harry Winston have released limited-edition watches featuring hand-engraved rat designs, with prices ranging from S$32,900 to S$152,000. The watches showcase traditional techniques such as enamel dial craftsmanship and urushi lacquer art.

site_title: Libra finds buyer for one unit, while another stays mired in legal trouble
summary: Libra Group has entered a legally-binding agreement to sell its 100% stake in Libra Engineering to Cascade Metals for S$100,000 in cash. The sale is part of Libra's restructuring efforts to dispose of non-operational assets. Meanwhile, Libra Engineering & Manufacturing faces legal trouble, with a supplier filing a winding-up petition and another company filing a writ of summons and statement of claim. The outcome of these disputes is uncertain and will be addressed through further announcements from Libra.

site_title: Skills of the past, for the future
summary: Human beings are losing traditional skills and crafting abilities, leading to a decline in creativity and innovation. Some individuals are taking a journey of self-rediscovery to reclaim lost skills, emphasizing the importance of practical applications in higher education. Experts like Michel Rochat, CEO of EHL Group, advocate for a shift away from book smarts and exams, and towards more hands-on learning. As technology advances, these lost skills are seen as crucial for the future.

site_title: Trends for the 2020s
summary: The 2020s are expected to be marked by significant changes in various industries. Plant-based food is set to become mainstream, with major companies like Tyson Foods, Kellogg, and Nestle introducing their own plant-based products. Alternative proteins such as pea, mung bean, and insect-based options are gaining popularity. The travel industry is also undergoing a digital transformation, with AI-powered personalization and predictive analytics helping to curate more personalized travel experiences. Responsible travel and sustainability are becoming increasingly important, with travel operators adopting eco-friendly practices. In the design sphere, there is a growing emphasis on sustainability and well-being, with features like smart sensors and home automation systems becoming more common. The retail landscape is expected to be highly competitive, with brick-and-mortar stores maintaining an edge over online shopping.

site_title: Toh Yah Li, Director of Light Collab
summary: Singapore-based lighting designer Toh Yah Li, director of Light Collab, specializes in enhancing spaces with light. A certified lighting designer, she has worked on various projects, including the Singapore Buddhist Lodge and the Love Bonito store, to create unique lighting experiences. Despite facing misconceptions about the value of lighting design, Li has received recognition, including being named one of 40 under 40 at the Lighting Design Awards in London. Her work aims to elevate the status of the built environment and bring people together through light.

images.alt_text: ''Anyone can pick out light fixtures but not everyone can design a luminous concept, which is the role of a lighting designer.'' - Toh Yah Li

site_title: The lesson of an Albanian earthquake: The Balkans aren't ready for the big one
summary: A devastating earthquake in Albania on November 26, 2020, killed 51 people, injured hundreds, and left thousands homeless. The tragedy highlights the region's lack of preparedness for a major earthquake, with ageing buildings posing significant risks. Successive governments in Romania, Bulgaria, and other Balkan nations have failed to address the risks, leading to millions living in homes unlikely to survive a major quake. Experts warn that the region is ill-prepared for a large-scale earthquake, with Romania's progress in retrofitting buildings hindered by complicated ownership.

site_title: US dollar snaps losing streak; offshore yuan firms
summary: The US dollar ended a six-day losing streak with a 0.2% gain on the first trading day of 2020, pushing the euro off five-month highs. The offshore yuan remained stable despite reserve ratio cuts that could add $115 billion in liquidity. Trading may be thin until Tuesday, but market players were relieved the dollar avoided money market squeezes.

site_title: China's Moutai misses expectations for first time since 2015
summary: China's Moutai Co reported revenue and earnings growth of 15% for 2019, missing analyst estimates for the first time since 2015. The company's stock plummeted 5.7% in morning trading, citing a slowdown in China's economy and internal structural changes. Despite setting a 10% sales growth target for 2020, analysts express concerns about the company's resilience. Moutai's baijiu remains a status symbol in China, but its long distilling period and land constraints limit supply, contributing to the disappointing results.

site_title: India steps up effort to claw back overdue telecom fees
summary: India's government is seeking at least $30 billion in overdue telecom fees from mobile-phone service providers to meet its budget deficit target. The demand includes $2.8 billion from Gujarat Narmada Valley Fertilizers & Chemicals Ltd, $3 billion from Vodafone Group Plc's Indian unit, and $24 billion from GAIL India Ltd. The Supreme Court's verdict is helping the government in its hunt for funds, with companies facing demands for licensing fees based on their entire revenue. The government must address the budget deficit to stimulate an economy that has slumped to a six-year low.

site_title: EY calls for tax credits to keep R&D in Singapore
summary: EY is calling for tax credits to encourage R&D activities in Singapore, rather than tax deductions, to sustain businesses in a tax-loss position. The firm also suggests easing tax rules for venture capital funds and family offices. Additionally, EY recommends tax breaks on divestment gains from joint ventures, merger and acquisition allowances for tech startups, and a more targeted funding model for SkillsFuture Credit. The firm's suggestions aim to support innovation and jobs in Singapore, echoing earlier calls from rival firms and in response to the economic slowdown.

site_title: Singapore offshore and marine industry ripe for consolidation
summary: The Singapore offshore and marine industry is ripe for consolidation due to intense competition from Chinese and Korean yards. Despite a gradual recovery, Singaporean yards have only seen modest improvements in new orders, with Chinese yards dominating the global production unit construction market. A lack of financing options for large-scale infrastructure projects has hindered growth. However, the industry remains optimistic, with potential opportunities in gas-related and renewable solutions, and is expected to contribute S$5.8 billion to Singapore's GDP by 2025 and create 1,500 new jobs. Consolidating yard capacity and exploring financing options could help the industry emerge stronger.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon up 0.39% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.39% to 3,235.42 as trading resumed on Thursday, following advance estimates of GDP growth in line with private sector economists' expectations. Trendlines jumped 27.1% and GSS Energy gained 13.5%, while banking stocks were mixed. The rally follows a 5-day streak and comes ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US consumer comfort rises to five-month high on economic views
summary: US consumer comfort reached a five-month high in December, with Bloomberg's index rising 1.6 points to 63.9, driven by optimism about the economy and personal finances. The reading for the state of the economy also reached a five-month high, while the personal finances index reached its best level in three months. The gains followed a year of strong economic performance, including near-record stock levels and a low unemployment rate.

site_title: Lebanon receives Interpol arrest warrant for Ghosn
summary: Lebanon received an Interpol arrest warrant for ousted Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn, who fled Japan to face trial for alleged financial misconduct. The request was received by Lebanon's internal security forces, but no decision has been made on what action to take. In past cases, suspects with red notices have had their passports confiscated and a bail set, but not detained. The Lebanese government has yet to comment on the warrant.

site_title: Airbus reclaims world's largest plane-maker title
summary: Airbus reclaimed its title as the world's largest plane-maker for the first time since 2011, delivering a forecast-beating 863 aircraft in 2019, surpassing US rival Boeing's 345 deliveries. The record European data underscores Boeing's distance to recoup its market position amid a crisis over the grounded 737 MAX. Airbus deployed extra resources to meet its revised target, driven by a buffer stock of semi-finished aircraft and a high volume of single-aisle aircraft, which will partially offset potential costs and impact on profit margins.

site_title: Chinese tech firm ByteDance guns for digibank licence in Singapore: sources
summary: ByteDance, the Chinese tech firm behind TikTok, has applied for a wholesale digital banking licence in Singapore, according to sources. This move comes as the company, valued at over $75 billion, signals its intention to expand into financial services. The application marks the arrival of Chinese tech companies in Singapore's banking sector, with Ant Financial also pursuing a similar licence. This development is seen as a significant move towards non-banks entering the financial sector in Singapore.

site_title: Fired British vegan files landmark discrimination case
summary: A British employment tribunal began a landmark hearing on whether strict veganism is a protected philosophical belief in law. Jordi Casamitjana, a former employee of the League Against Cruel Sports, claims he was fired for raising concerns about the charity's alleged investment in animal testing companies. The case will determine if ethical veganism, which excludes animal-derived products and items tested on animals, is protected from discrimination under Britain's 2010 Equality Act. The outcome will establish whether ethical vegans are entitled to protection from discrimination if they hold this belief.

site_title: Decade-low growth in 2019 clouds 2020 forecasts for Singapore GDP
summary: Singapore's 2019 GDP growth was 0.7%, the worst in 10 years, according to advance estimates from the Ministry of Trade and Industry. Despite this, economists hold a cautiously positive outlook for 2020, citing signs of bottoming and confidence in the services sector. Forecasts range from 0.9% to 1.8% growth, with some attributing the poor 2019 performance to manufacturing sector contractions, particularly in electronics. The upcoming 2020 Budget statement is expected to provide further guidance on measures to support businesses and workers.

site_title: Surprise partnerships can create new niche banking services
summary: Singapore's latest digital banking contenders, including a consortium of Razer Fintech and Sheng Siong Group, have applied for a digital full bank licence. Analysts suggest that diverse partnerships are crucial to offering niche services in heavily-banked Singapore. The move aims to capitalize on untapped markets, but the challenge of providing digital banking services as an entity may be a hurdle for diverse groups. The application comes as the country's financial regulatory body, MAS, continues to oversee the development of the digital banking sector.

images.alt_text: Singapore's latest contenders for a digital banking licence may have included several names that are left-of-field to banking, but diverse partnerships are needed to offer niche, untapped services in heavily-banked Singapore, said analysts.

site_title: Creative to launch improved version of Super X-Fi at CES 2020
summary: Creative Technology is launching the improved Super X-Fi Gen2 at CES 2020, featuring enhanced precision in personalizing audio profiles, improved surround-sound configuration, and higher positioning accuracy. The new version was developed using a large database of user profiles, accumulated from the successful launch of the original Super X-Fi. The company will also showcase its upcoming USB gaming headset, SXFI GAMER, which optimizes the Super X-Fi audio profile for first-person shooter games.

site_title: Denmark sources record 47% of power from wind in 2019
summary: Denmark set a new record in 2019, generating 47% of its electricity from wind power, surpassing its previous record of 43% in 2017. This increase was largely due to the start of operations at the Horns Rev 3 offshore wind farm in August. Denmark aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 70% by 2030 and plans to source 100% of its electricity from renewable power. The country's wind power production has become a significant contributor, with wind turbines at sea accounting for 18% of total power generation.

site_title: Refurbishments at AA Reit's NorthTech boost value to S$116.5m
summary: Aims Apac Reit's (AA Reit) industrial property NorthTech has seen its value increase to S$116.5 million following a successful refurbishment project. The enhancement works, which began in July 2018, included upgrades to the property's facilities and landscaping. The project was completed within budget and did not affect the property's rental income. The manager believes the government's new masterplan for Woodlands North Coast will further enhance the property's value. The refurbishment has raised the property's value by S$14.5 million compared to its value at end-March 2018.

site_title: US: Wall St begins 2020 near record level on China stimulus, trade hopes
summary: US stocks began 2020 near record levels on January 2, driven by fresh Chinese stimulus and optimism over easing trade tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.35%, the S&P 500 gained 0.43%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.75%. The positive start to the year reflects a global economic outlook and investors' hopes for improved trade relations between the US and China.

site_title: Cheung Woh, Willas-Array expect losses for current fiscal periods
summary: Two Mainboard-listed companies, Cheung Woh Technologies and Willas-Array Electronics, have issued profit guidance for their current fiscal periods. Cheung Woh expects to report a loss after taxation due to low turnover, while Willas-Array expects a consolidated net loss for the period ended Dec 31, 2019, mainly due to US-China trade tensions and slow market demand. The companies' results are expected to be released in mid-February 2020.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS sees developer returns rising in 2020-2021 on recent M&As
summary: DBS Group Research expects Singapore developers to deliver strong returns on equity (ROE) for 2020-2021 due to recent merger and acquisitions (M&As) and asset recycling activities. CapitaLand and City Developments Limited (CDL) are recommended as "diversified plays" with target prices raised to S$4.50 and S$13, respectively. A slowdown in Asian economies, particularly China, and government tightening of the property market are key risks. The brokerage also expects the residential sector to remain stable, with a risk of government intervention if prices rise too fast.

site_title: Dell to let Apple users control iPhones from their laptop
summary: Dell is releasing software that will allow iPhone users to control their iPhone screens on Dell laptops. The feature, part of Dell's Mobile Connect software, will also enable file transfers and messaging. The update will work with Dell XPS, Inspiron, Vostro, and Alienware laptops running Windows 10. This move aims to attract more iPhone users to Dell's products, as Apple already offers similar integration with its Mac computers. The software update is set to roll out in coming months.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 0.7% in 2019, following a 0.8% rise in Q4. Private home prices increased 2.5% for 2019, while the Straits Times Index (STI) advanced 0.9% at 3,252.00. A consortium led by Razer Fintech submitted an application for a digital full-bank licence, and NEC Asia Pacific appointed a new managing director for its Singapore operations. The day also saw mixed economic news globally, including a slowdown in China's GDP growth and a shrinking UK economy.

site_title: Singapore shares get strong start to 2020
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 2020 with a 1% gain, reaching 3,252.00, as most Asia-Pacific markets rose. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong was the top performer, while South Korea bucked the trend. Investors are optimistic due to recent developments, including the US-China trade deal, China's manufacturing sector survey, and local growth forecasts. Property developers such as CapitaLand, City Developments, and UOL Group also saw gains, with DBS Group Research maintaining "Buy" calls on the sector.

site_title: MeGroup inks deal with Mitsubishi Motors to operate a dealership
summary: MeGroup, a Malaysian-based automotive company, has signed a deal with Mitsubishi Motors Malaysia to operate a 3S dealership in Kuala Selangor, Malaysia. The dealership is expected to begin operations in the second quarter of 2020. This is MeGroup's first Mitsubishi dealership, adding to its portfolio of nine dealerships under six brands. The company will fund the dealership using S$327,321 from its initial public offering proceeds, with no expected material impact on its current financial year.

site_title: Alliance Healthcare wins contract to provide healthcare services to 38 firms
summary: Alliance Healthcare Group has won a contract to provide managed healthcare solutions to 38 companies, including major healthcare institutions, for a period of two years. The contract, valued at undisclosed amounts, will deliver outpatient medical and/or dental clinic services to over 80,000 individuals. Alliance Healthcare signed a master services agreement with ALPS Pte Ltd, acting as the agent for the entities, and expects to deliver services starting January 2020. The agreement may be extended based on satisfactory performance reviews.

site_title: Tata petitions India top court against verdict to rehire ex-chairman
summary: Tata Sons Ltd, the $111 billion conglomerate, has petitioned India's top court to halt a tribunal's order to rehire Cyrus Mistry, the chairman it fired in 2016. The petition, filed by Tata Sons' lawyer, seeks an urgent hearing for a stay on the order, which was deemed "oppressive" by the court and instructed Mistry's reinstatement. The ruling has paralyzed the Tata leadership and hindered efforts to revive growth. Tata Sons has four weeks to appeal the ruling, which also called the actions of Ratan Tata, the group's chairman emeritus, "oppressive".

site_title: Indonesia floods leave nearly 30 dead, several missing
summary: Indonesia's disaster agency reported at least 29 deaths and several missing after torrential rains and floods hit the Jakarta region on New Year's Eve, causing widespread destruction and displacement. Tens of thousands fled to temporary shelters, with scores of houses damaged. The floods, which were triggered by heavy rainfall, also caused landslides and electrocutions, with 26 deaths confirmed in the greater Jakarta area and three in neighboring Lebak regency. Rescuers used inflatable boats to evacuate residents trapped in their homes, with many children and seniors among those rescued.

site_title: US job cuts at lowest since July 2018 as labour market holds up
summary: US employers announced 32,843 job cuts in December, the lowest since July 2018, as the labor market remained tight despite uncertainty from the trade war. This marks a 26% decrease from November and a 25% decrease from the previous year. For the full year, employers announced plans to cut 592,556 jobs, up 10% from 2018 and the highest total since 2015. The labor market held up despite a weak manufacturing sector, with the unemployment rate likely remaining at a 50-year low of 3.5% in December.

site_title: Trendlines in talks over potential exits for multiple portfolio firms
summary: The Trendlines Group, a startup incubator, is in discussions for potential exits for multiple portfolio companies, with no agreements signed. The company's stock price surged 27% to a one-year high, amid an abnormally high volume of shares traded. Trendlines explores exits as part of its ordinary business, but notes no assurance that agreements will be finalized or exits completed. Further announcements will be made when material developments occur.

site_title: US shale producers to tap brakes in 2020 after years of rapid growth
summary: US shale oil producers are expected to slow down production in 2020, marking a shift from years of rapid growth, after years of high spending and drilling to keep up with increasing demand. Analysts forecast a modest growth rate of around 100,000 barrels per day, and some producers are even cutting spending and production to focus on paying down debt. This marks a significant change in the shale industry's strategy, which had previously relied on drilling to boost profits.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch higher on energy, tech stocks
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 6,690.60 on the first trading session of the year, aided by energy and tech stocks. The gains were driven by news that the US and China would sign a trade pact soon, and a 0.2% increase in the energy sub-index. Afterpay Ltd advanced 4.6% after California approved its lending licence, while telecom stocks also rose. The mining sector inched higher, with BHP Group Ltd and Rio Tinto Ltd gaining 0.1% and 0.8% respectively.

site_title: Ant Financial applies for Singapore digital banking licence
summary: Billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Financial has applied for a digital banking licence in Singapore, targeting corporate clients. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is offering up to five digital banking permits, with two for full digital banks and three for wholesale banks. Ant Financial, China's largest online financial platform, aims to expand outside the mainland and compete with traditional incumbents like DBS Group Holdings Ltd and OCBC. The move follows similar efforts in Hong Kong, where Ant and Chinese competitors obtained licences earlier this year.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse discussing second listing with Trip.com, Netease: sources
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is discussing secondary listings with Chinese tech companies Trip.com and Netease, following Alibaba's $13 billion share offering in 2019. The discussions are preliminary and subject to change, but would bolster the exchange, which has lost many Chinese tech stars to US rivals. A secondary listing would help hedge risks amid the US trade war, and could pave the way for more "new economy enterprises" to seek listings. The move comes as Hong Kong's fundraising from initial public offerings is expected to drop 27% in 2020.

site_title: China's Kweichow Moutai misses expectations for first time since 2015
summary: China's Kweichow Moutai Co reported revenue and earnings growth of 15% for 2019, missing analyst estimates for the first time since 2015. The company's stock plummeted 5.7% in morning trading, its largest decline since May. Despite a 10% sales growth target for 2020, the disappointing numbers raise concerns about China's economic slowdown affecting its consumer sector. Internal structural changes and a former chairman's arrest have also impacted the company's performance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start year with rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the year with a rally, driven by China's central bank measures to boost lending and kickstart the economy. The Hang Seng index jumped 1.25%, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.15%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 1.93%. This follows a strong finish to 2024, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Uber Eats goes local to find niche in South Africa
summary: Uber Eats has launched in South Africa, targeting traditional local fare in the country's online food delivery market, which was worth 10.49 billion rand (S$1 billion) in 2019. The company is working with local restaurants, including Dumile Badela's in Soweto, to offer popular dishes such as stewed tripe and caterpillars. Uber Eats aims to capture 50% of the market, which is currently dominated by Uber and Mr D Food, and is seen as a potential boon for black communities where unemployment is high.

site_title: Vietnam exports likely to keep overperforming: Report
summary: Vietnam's exports are expected to outperform the rest of Southeast Asia in 2020, according to a report by Maybank Kim Eng economists. Year-on-year growth is projected to ease to 6.6% in 2020 and 2021, driven by improved trade relations between the US and China and a global technology market upswing. This growth is expected to benefit Vietnam's export-oriented manufacturing and trade-related services industries, driven by favorable trade terms and a rebound in global demand.

site_title: Asian shares rise on China's policy easing, trade deal hopes
summary: Asian shares rose on January 2, 2020, after China eased monetary policy to support slowing growth and ahead of a potential US-China trade deal. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index increased 0.35% in morning trade, building on a 5.6% gain in December. The news boosted investor confidence, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Asian shares kicked off the new decade higher on Thursday, after global stocks ended the previous one at record highs, and buoyed by Chinese markets after Beijing eased monetary policy to support slowing growth.

site_title: Singapore shares start new year with gains; STI up 0.27% at Thursday's open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.27% higher at 3,231.46 on January 2, 2020, following the release of advance estimates showing the country's GDP expanded 0.8% in the fourth quarter of 2019. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 35, with notable gains from AEM, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and Oxley Holdings. Banking stocks were mixed, while the Singapore Exchange set up a working group to review its retail bonds framework.

site_title: Tokyo: Japanese markets closed for holiday
summary: Japanese financial markets are closed on January 2, 2020, for a public holiday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. In Asia, traders are brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally. In the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion. The STI rose 0.4% on Thursday, as investors remain positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Indonesia's Dec inflation slows more than expected
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate in December eased to 2.72%, the slowest increase since March, beating expectations of 2.9%. The Consumer Price Index rose 0.34% on a monthly basis, and the core inflation rate cooled to 3.02%, within Bank Indonesia's target range of 2.5-4.5%. The central bank aims for a 2-4% inflation rate in 2020, and the recent data suggests it may meet its target.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mostly up at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Thursday, January 2, 2020, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.4% to 7,575.33 points, and Paris's CAC 40 growing 0.7% to 6,017.69 points. In contrast, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index slipped 0.1% to 13,239.51 points. The rally was driven by mining and healthcare shares, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

images.alt_text: London's benchmark FTSE 100 index climbed 0.4 per cent to 7,575.33 points compared with the close on Tuesday.

site_title: HSBC kicks off year with Hong Kong branches closed, vandalised
summary: HSBC has closed two of its Hong Kong branches and vandalized several others amid anti-government protests, with protesters accusing the bank of being complicit in the arrest of activists. The bank has denied any connection, citing international regulatory standards. The closures come as HSBC's Hong Kong operations account for over half of its $12.5 billion pre-tax profits, and the protests have tipped the city's economy into recession.

site_title: South Korea: Shares tumble on first trading day of 2020
summary: South Korean stocks ended lower on their first trading day of 2020, with the KOSPI index down 1.02% at 2,175.17 points. Investors booked profits from market heavyweights amid anticipation of the Phase 1 US-China trade deal, with US President Donald Trump set to sign the agreement on January 15. The decline was attributed to uncertainty surrounding the deal's details.

images.alt_text: The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI ended down 22.50 points, or 1.02 per cent, at 2,175.17.

site_title: CIMB Bank Singapore names new CEO as Mak Lye Mun retires
summary: CIMB Bank Singapore has appointed Victor Lee as its new CEO, replacing Mak Lye Mun who is retiring after 10 years. Lee, a Singaporean with over two decades of experience in retail and commercial banking, aims to diversify the business and grow four key pillars: partnerships, technology, sustainability, and customers. His vision focuses on deepening the bank's presence in Singapore and prioritizing its people, staff, and customers.

site_title: Hot stock: Trendlines calls for trading halt after shares surge 27% on heavy volume
summary: Trendlines, a startup incubator, has requested a trading halt on the Singapore Exchange after its shares surged 27.1% on heavy volume, surpassing its 52-week high. The sudden price increase, with 46.3 million shares changing hands, raised concerns about unannounced information. The company's market cap is approximately S$75.7 million. The Singapore Exchange has asked Trendlines to confirm its compliance with listing rules and provide explanations for the unusual price movements.

site_title: Oil prices climb on US-China trade optimism, Middle East tensions
summary: Oil prices rose on the first trading day of 2020, driven by warming US-China trade relations and rising tensions in the Middle East. Global benchmark Brent crude futures increased 21 US cents to $66.21 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 21 US cents to $61.27 a barrel. The price increases follow a thaw in the US-China trade dispute and OPEC's pledge to cut oil supply by 500,000 barrels per day. Analysts expect Brent to average $63.07 a barrel and WTI to average $57.70 a barrel in 2020, citing the trade deal and supply cuts.

site_title: China halts British stock link over political tensions: sources
summary: China has temporarily blocked planned cross-border listings between the Shanghai and London stock exchanges due to political tensions with Britain, sources say. The suspension affects the Shanghai-London Stock Connect scheme, which aimed to build ties between the two countries and provide mainland investors with access to UK-listed companies. The move comes amid Britain's stance on the Hong Kong protests and the detention of a former staff at its consulate in Hong Kong. China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs hopes for a fair business environment for Chinese companies in the UK, but the UK remains uncertain under newly-elected Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

site_title: NEC Asia Pacific picks ex-NCS exec to manage Singapore ops
summary: NEC Asia Pacific has appointed Teh Chong Mien as managing director for its Singapore operations, with experience as head of communications, media, and technology at Singtel's NCS and senior roles at StarHub and Oracle.

site_title: Tokyo prosecutors raid residence of former Nissan boss Ghosn: NHK
summary: Tokyo prosecutors raided the residence of former Nissan Motor Co chairman Carlos Ghosn, following his surprise escape from Japan. Ghosn, awaiting trial on four charges of financial wrongdoing, has repeatedly denied the allegations. The raid comes after Ghosn fled Japan days ago and is now in Lebanon.

images.alt_text: Tokyo prosecutors on Thursday raided the residence of former Nissan Motor Co chairman Carlos Ghosn, Japanese public broadcaster NHK said.

site_title: Treasury's Mnuchin to head US delegation to Davos conclave
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin will lead a US delegation to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, from January 21-24. The delegation includes Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, Labour Secretary Eugene Scalia, and other officials. The event comes as President Donald Trump faces a trial on impeachment charges in the Senate. Trump's attendance may be affected by events in Congress, following his impeachment on December 18.

site_title: China municipal bond sales start sooner than ever as growth slows
summary: China's local governments are selling municipal bonds earlier than usual to boost their economies amid a slowing growth. Authorities in Sichuan and Henan provinces issued a combined 87.6 billion yuan of special bonds, the earliest such issuance since 2015. This move aims to manage the pace of the economy and is expected to be well-received by investors seeking lower-risk alternatives to corporate bonds. Analysts predict the debt will be attractive due to higher yields and sovereign ratings, potentially contributing to a slower decline in bond yields.

site_title: China tech industry straps in for more turbulence after a wild 2019
summary: China's tech industry enters 2020 facing uncertainty after a tumultuous 2019. The US campaign to contain China's economy led to heightened scrutiny of tech giants like Huawei, ByteDance, and Alibaba, with pressure from Beijing to scrub sensitive content from their apps. This led to a decline in venture capital activity, depressing the sector and demoralizing tech professionals, who rebelled against the 70-plus hour workweeks. The industry's growth is expected to remain slow, with investors and lawmakers continuing to scrutinize China's tech champions deemed a threat to national security.

site_title: Thai Dec inflation quickens to 0.87%, slightly below forecast
summary: Thailand's consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.87% in December, slightly below expectations, marking the seventh consecutive month below the Bank of Thailand's target range. This follows November's 0.21% increase. The annual core inflation rate was 0.49%, also below forecast. The commerce ministry projects headline inflation to be between 0.4% and 1.2% for 2020, maintaining a relatively low inflation rate.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares up at Thursday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.83 points to 1,593.59, opening higher on Thursday. The index saw 175 gainers and 80 losers, with a total trading volume of 105.9 million lots worth RM54.3 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on healthcare, technology gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.13% on the first trading day of 2020, driven by gains in the healthcare and technology sectors. Afterpay Ltd rose 2.7% after California approved its lending license, while CSL and Cochlear also advanced. The energy sector rose 0.4% and the healthcare index climbed 0.9% higher. The broader mining index fell 0.4% to its lowest since Dec 24, despite oil prices notching a 3-year annual gain in 2019.

site_title: South Korea factory activity returns to growth in Dec
summary: South Korea's factory activity returned to growth in December, ending a seven-month contraction, according to a private business survey. The Nikkei/Markit purchasing managers' index rose to 50.1, the highest reading since April, driven by improving demand, especially from abroad. Manufacturing output expanded for the first time in 14 months, and new export orders jumped to 51.3, the highest reading since June 2018. This growth is expected to contribute positively to overall economic output if sustained.

site_title: China injects US$115b to stabilise its economy
summary: China's central bank has injected US$115 billion into the economy to stabilize its growth, following a similar action in September. The move is seen as a sign of concern from Beijing about faltering growth despite signs of stabilization. The injection comes ahead of the release of year-end growth estimates and follows a recent meeting of the country's top economic planners. The relatively modest move highlights the vast size of China's economy, which remains a major driver of global growth.

site_title: Australia orders mass evacuation of fire-ravaged towns before heatwave
summary: Australia orders mass evacuation of fire-ravaged coastal communities due to an impending heatwave. Thousands of tourists have been given less than 48 hours to leave as catastrophic blazes killed at least 8 people, stranding holidaymakers. The evacuation zone spans 200km and includes areas in New South Wales and Victoria. The heatwave, forecast to bring gusting winds and temperatures above 40°C, will create dangerous fire conditions, making it Australia's deadliest day of fires in months.

site_title: China's Ganzhou launches rare earths exchange
summary: China's Ganzhou city has launched a rare earths exchange, the second in the country after Baotou, to boost global influence and pricing power. The exchange, launched on December 31, will trade rare earths, molybdenum, tungsten, tin, and cobalt. It aims to revive China's rare earth trading hub, following the collapse of the Fanya Metal Exchange in 2015. The move is seen as a strategic move to maintain China's dominance in the global rare earth market and alleviate supply concerns amid a trade war with the US.

site_title: Asia's factories end 2019 with brighter outlook led by China
summary: Asia's manufacturing industry ended 2019 on a brighter note, with fewer economies signalling contraction at factories. China's manufacturing sector expanded output in December, bolstering views of a stabilizing economy. South Korea's manufacturers enjoyed the strongest performance since April, driven by a rebound in the electronics sector. Global manufacturing has recovered somewhat from a mid-2019 slump, with businesses anticipating a more positive 2020 due to new product launches and lower tariffs. The improved outlook is attributed to positive developments on the trade front, particularly the US-China trade deal set to be signed on January 15.

images.alt_text: Asia's manufacturing industry finished 2019 with a modestly brighter outlook, with fewer economies signalling contraction at factories.

site_title: Study finds Google system could improve breast cancer detection
summary: A Google artificial intelligence system has proven as effective as expert radiologists in detecting breast cancer from mammograms, with a potential to reduce errors. The study, published in Nature, found that the system accurately identified breast cancer in 92% of cases, comparable to human radiologists. This technology could help address the 20% error rate of radiologists in detecting breast cancer and the 50% false positive rate among women who undergo screenings.

site_title: Prices of HDB resale flats sold in Q4 2019 rose 0.4%
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Q4 2019 rose 0.4% compared to the third quarter, the largest quarter-on-quarter increase for the year. There was no change in resale flat prices for the whole of 2019. HDB will launch 16,000 to 17,000 Build-To-Order flats for sale this year, with the first batch of 3,000 flats in Sembawang and Toa Payoh available in February, and another 3,700 flats in May.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UIC, UOL, CapitaLand, EHT, Keppel, DBS, OUE
summary: Singapore stocks experienced various developments on Thursday, January 2, 2020, with key changes including UIC and UOL Group's rebranding and stake acquisition, Eagle Hospitality Trust's management change, and Keppel Corporation's plan to shed non-core businesses. DBS revised its savings account terms, while OUE's leadership transitioned with Stephen Riady's son taking a more hands-on role.

site_title: Drugmakers to hike US prices on over 200 drugs
summary: US drugmakers, including Pfizer, GlaxoSmithKline, and Sanofi, plan to increase US list prices on over 200 drugs, with nearly all price hikes below 10%. The median price increase is around 5%, and more increases are expected to be announced later this week. The price hikes are expected to affect the presidential election, with President Trump, who campaigned on bringing down prescription drug prices, running for re-election in 2020.

site_title: Australian home prices end year with strongest gains since 2009
summary: Australian home prices ended 2019 with a 4% quarterly gain, the strongest since 2009, driven by major cities like Sydney and Melbourne. The median Sydney home value reached A$840,072, while household wealth reached a record-high A$10.9 trillion. The sector's growth is attributed to low interest rates, but experts warn that housing affordability may deteriorate further as dwelling values outpace household incomes. This resurgence in the housing market promises to support consumer spending, but also poses challenges for those saving for a deposit.

site_title: Singapore private home prices up 0.3% in Q4, 2.5% for 2019: URA flash data
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 0.3% in Q4 2019, the third consecutive quarter, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) flash data. For the year 2019, prices increased by 2.5%, a smaller margin than the 7.9% rise in 2018. Landed property prices rose 4% in Q4, while non-landed prices varied by region, with CCR falling 3.7% and OCR increasing 2.9%. Experts attribute the slower pace of price increase to a decline in super-luxury home sales in CCR and RCR.

site_title: Singapore's GDP grows 0.7% in 2019 following 0.8% rise in Q4
summary: Singapore's economy grew 0.7% in 2019, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry, slightly below expectations. The fourth quarter saw a 0.8% growth, with the manufacturing sector contracting 2.1% and the construction sector expanding 2.1% year-on-year. The services sector grew 1.4% year-on-year. Economists predict a slow recovery in 2020, with some expecting growth between 0.9% and 2%. The upcoming Budget 2020 statement is expected to announce measures to support businesses and workers.

site_title: Razer names new CIO, CFO
summary: Razer has appointed Edwin Chan as its new Chief Investment Officer (CIO), effective January 1, 2020. Chan will be succeeded by Tan Chong Neng, who will take over as Chief Financial Officer (CFO). Chan previously served as CFO from June 2013 to December 31, 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on January 2, 2020, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.21% to 28,249.37, following China's central bank announcement to reduce reserve requirements. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains of 0.53% and 0.68%, respectively, as the market started the new decade on a positive note.

site_title: Renewing Singapore's oldest MRT lines to cost more than S$2.5b: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore's oldest and most heavily used MRT lines, the North-South and East-West lines, will undergo a multi-year renewal program costing over S$2.5 billion. The second phase of the program, which includes replacing power supply systems, track circuits, and trains, is underway. The renewal program is expected to be completed by 2024, with the power supply system renewal scheduled for 2023. The upgraded system will allow for more trains and reduced waiting times. The program is part of a larger effort to expand Singapore's rail network, with plans to double the network to 360km by 2031.

site_title: Japanese media blasts 'cowardly' Ghosn after escape
summary: Japanese media has heavily criticized former Nissan executive Carlos Ghosn as "cowardly" for jumping bail and fleeing to Lebanon to avoid trial in Japan. Multiple media outlets, including Yomiuri Shimbun, Tokyo Shimbun, and Sankei Shimbun, have condemned Ghosn's actions, citing the loss of opportunity to prove his innocence and the mockery of Japan's justice system. The decision to grant Ghosn bail has also been questioned, with some papers suggesting it was influenced by "foreign pressure."

site_title: Austrian conservatives and Greens strike New Year's coalition deal
summary: Austrian conservative leader Sebastian Kurz struck a coalition deal with the Greens, bringing the left-wing party into government for the first time. The deal marks a swing left for Kurz and will see the Greens control four ministries, with Kurz as chancellor and vice chancellor. Key campaign pledges include reducing the tax burden and making environmentally damaging products more expensive. The deal aims to address climate change, following Austria's participation in EU member states with Greens in government.

site_title: Netanyahu seeks immunity from Israeli corruption charges
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has requested immunity from prosecution in three graft cases, a move that critics say undermines the principle of equality before the law. Netanyahu, facing charges of bribery, fraud, and breach of trust, claims the immunity request is a "temporary" measure to prevent "political indictments" and maintain the will of the people. The request could delay criminal cases against Netanyahu, who is running for re-election in two months, and may further polarize the divided nation.

site_title: MindChamps sells Toa Payoh centre to franchisee for S$5.1m
summary: MindChamps PreSchool has sold its Toa Payoh centre to Iconic Investment for S$5.1 million on a turnkey basis. The subsidiary, MindChamps PreSchool @ TPY Pte Limited, will continue to operate the centre under a franchise agreement, generating royalties for MindChamps. The sale is expected to positively impact the group's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2019.

site_title: Major commercial plane crash deaths worldwide fell by more than 50% in 2019: report
summary: A report by Dutch consulting firm To70 found that commercial plane crash deaths worldwide decreased by more than 50% in 2019, resulting in 257 fatalities, down from 534 in 2018. Despite a high-profile Boeing 737 MAX crash in Ethiopia in March, the fatal accident rate for large airplanes in commercial passenger air transport decreased to 0.18 fatal accidents per million flights. This represents a significant improvement over 2018, with a fatal accident every 5.58 million flights.

site_title: Britain's zero-carbon power outstrips fossil fuels in 2019
summary: Britain's zero-carbon power production surpassed fossil fuels for the first time in 2019, according to National Grid data. Wind, solar, hydro, nuclear, and imports accounted for 48.5% of electricity, while fossil fuels contributed 43%. This marks a significant shift from 1990, when fossil fuels provided 75% of electricity. The increase in zero-carbon power is attributed to rapid growth in renewable capacity, with wind and solar producing 24% of electricity in 2019, up from 2.3% in 1990. Britain's commitment to reaching net-zero emissions by 2050 has driven this growth.

site_title: Australian authorities scramble to reach victims of deadly fires as death toll rises
summary: At least 15 people are believed to have died in Australia's devastating bushfires, with a fourth person missing and feared dead. The military has been deployed to reach isolated residents, and navy ships are providing supplies and assisting with evacuations. Thousands remain cut off, and new blazes are sparked daily by hot and windy conditions. Cooler conditions have allowed authorities to count the cost, but over 100 blazes remain in New South Wales, and thousands of firefighters are on the ground. The death toll is expected to rise as authorities reach more damaged areas.

site_title: Keppel Corp charts plan for new decade
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singaporean conglomerate, is developing a plan for the new decade, focusing on core strengths and divesting non-core businesses. CEO Loh Chin Hua outlined key strategies, including building an agile organizational culture, tapping third-party funds for growth, and achieving interim targets by 2025. The 2030 vision aims to capitalize on these ideas, with significant areas of convergence including focusing on core strengths and divesting non-core businesses.

site_title: As the efficient markets hypothesis turns 50, it is time to bin it
summary: The efficient markets hypothesis, a 50-year-old concept, is being reevaluated as it fails to account for trends, momentum, and bubbles. Despite reservations, the hypothesis continues to influence investor decisions, leading to distorted prices and overvaluation. Research suggests that the use of benchmarking pressures and short-term price movements exacerbate the issue, creating a bias towards overvaluation. A revised approach focusing on long-term cash flows and improved monitoring could help address the distortions and promote more efficient markets, potentially revitalizing capitalism.

site_title: DPM Heng to deliver 2020 Budget Statement on Feb 18
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat will deliver Singapore's 2020 Budget Statement in Parliament on February 18, aiming to support households with their cost of living and improve social safety nets. The budget will also focus on supporting businesses to raise productivity and help workers find new jobs. Economists are cautiously optimistic about growth, but analysts are divided on the generosity of the budget, considering it may be an "Election Budget" ahead of the next General Election.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices snap 5-month decline in Nov
summary: Hong Kong private home prices rose 1.8% in November, the first gain since May, driven by increased small flat transactions after the government relaxed mortgage rules. Small flats of up to 69.9 square meters led the gains. Despite this, market observers predict a 10-15% fall in the first half of 2020 if unrest continues, while some realtors expect prices to rise 10% next year due to pent-up demand.

site_title: Insectta sees a big future from small insects
summary: Singapore-based urban insect farm Insectta aims to produce biomaterials from black soldier fly larvae, including chitosan, organic semiconductors, and protein and probiotics. The company has already secured funding and is scaling up production, with plans to close its seed funding round by the first quarter of this year. Insectta's goal is to capitalize on the growing global insect protein market, valued at US$1.34 billion by 2025. The company's innovative approach, which triples the larvae's final product value, sets it apart from other insect farming companies, and it is now seeking angel investors to further its R&D and commercialization efforts.

site_title: US holiday returns seen surging with booming e-commerce
summary: US holiday returns are expected to surge with a 26% year-over-year volume increase on "National Returns Day" (Jan 2). UPS anticipates shipping 1.9 million items back to retailers, with apparel being a major contributor to returns due to inconsistent sizing. The industry faces significant losses, estimated at nearly $1 trillion annually, with retailers losing $369 billion in sales each year. New startups, such as Happy Returns, aim to reduce returns-related expenses by up to 30% through streamlined processes and partnerships with retailers.

site_title: Thai central bank girds for New Year battle with baht strength
summary: The Thai central bank is preparing for a potential battle with the strengthening baht, which jumped 0.9% to surpass 30 US dollars per baht for the first time since 2013. Despite a record-low interest rate and easing measures, the baht's appreciation is forecasted to continue, with analysts predicting it will reach 30.2 US dollars per baht by the end of the first quarter. The central bank may announce further easing measures or an off-cycle meeting to stem the baht's gains, but its large current-account surplus and foreign reserves are expected to remain a constraint.

site_title: Europe's largest poultry producer Poland hit by bird flu outbreak on turkey farms
summary: Bird flu has been detected in turkeys in eastern Poland, affecting three farms with up to 350,000 birds at risk. The outbreak, caused by a highly pathogenic H5N8 subtype, requires up to 40,000 birds to be slaughtered. This is Poland's first bird flu outbreak since 2017, and authorities are implementing virus eradication procedures. The situation is being closely monitored, with crisis meetings held and police presence reported in the area.

site_title: US dollar index records smallest-ever annual move in 2019
summary: The US dollar index recorded its smallest-ever annual move in 2019, rising 0.24% for the year, after a decline in December reversed early gains. The dollar's weakness coincided with the Fed's balance sheet expansion and reduced pessimism over global growth, with investors betting it will weaken further in 2020. The euro and sterling reached multi-month highs, while the Australian dollar, Chinese yuan, and Scandinavian crowns also surged against the dollar.

site_title: Boris Johnson looks to an era of innovation, renewed optimism
summary: Boris Johnson secured a majority in the UK's December election, allowing him to pass the Brexit bill. The British prime minister is seen as a skilled leader who can bring optimism and innovation to the country. Johnson aims to rebrand his Brexit negotiating team as "Taskforce Europe" and secure an EU free trade agreement by the end of 2020. On the domestic front, he plans to invest in depressed regions, boost funding for the NHS and infrastructure, and pursue regional Keynesian policies to drive economic growth.

site_title: High flying Canadian dollar may struggle for encore in 2020
summary: The Canadian dollar may struggle to top its 2019 performance in 2020, according to Credit Suisse's global head of foreign-exchange strategy. The Bank of Canada's policy makers are expected to curb the currency's rise, and the central bank's search for a new governor may create uncertainty. Experts predict the US dollar-loonie rate to consolidate at around C$1.28, with some forecasting a forecast of C$1.295 for the end of 2020.

site_title: Analysts expect central banks to hold or cut policy rates
summary: Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, are expected to hold or cut their policy rates in 2020, according to a survey of research houses and analysts. The majority believe the Fed will keep its funds rate at 1.5-1.75%. Some predict an insurance cut if necessary, while others expect rate cuts, with BNP Paribas predicting two 25-basis-point cuts. The European Central Bank is also expected to hold its policy steady, while the Bank of Japan is likely to maintain its current rate. China's central bank has already cut its reserve requirement ratio by 50 basis points.

site_title: Electric cars threaten heart of Germany's economy
summary: Germany's economy is threatened by the rise of electric cars, particularly in the city of Öhringen, a hub for the country's automotive industry. Despite low unemployment (2.3%), the city's restaurants, nursing homes, and kindergartens struggle to find workers. The city government's tax revenue is being used to build new infrastructure, but the shift to electric cars may lead to job losses and economic disruption. The article highlights the challenges posed by the growth of electric vehicles, which could have a significant impact on Germany's economy.

site_title: EPA advisers chide Trump's plan to ease auto emissions rules
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency's Science Advisory Board has criticized the agency's 2018 proposal to roll back automobile fuel efficiency and emission standards, stating that the Obama-era standards may provide a better outcome for society. The board cited significant weaknesses in the scientific analysis and recommended addressing these issues before finalizing the rule. The EPA and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration continue to work on finalizing the rule, despite the panel's concerns. The Trump administration claims the revised rule will lead to less expensive new cars and reduce traffic fatalities.

site_title: Is Germany's car industry hitting the brakes?
summary: Germany's car industry is experiencing a shift as the country faces growing pressure to address climate change and adapt to changing global dynamics. Despite Tesla's expansion with a new giga-factory, Audi is cutting 9,500 jobs, highlighting the industry's vulnerability. Germany's reliance on exports, particularly to China, has made it vulnerable to external pressures, including US tariffs. The industry's failure to modernize and invest in low-emissions vehicles has led to a culture war, with some advocating for a car-free future. However, companies like Volkswagen are shifting gears and investing in electric vehicles, and external pressure may prompt Germany to change its approach.

site_title: Ranking of Singapore companies by market capitalisation
summary: Singapore companies saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with market capitalisation rankings unchanged. Helen Wong is set to retire as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long named her successor. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, will become the bank's new CEO. Additionally, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers, and Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to $3.1 million.

site_title: 'China + 1' hedge will keep Asean in spotlight
summary: ASEAN is poised for increased supply chain shifts in 2026 as companies invest more in the region. This comes after the region benefited from trade diversion, with goods and services flowing in. Meanwhile, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast, and a Malaysian agency plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. Foreign investors are returning to Vietnam and Indonesia, with GoTo shares tipped for a rebound. The region is also seeing growth jitters, with Malaysia considering a rate cut to shield the economy from tariff threats.

site_title: Trump Organization fires unauthorised labourers
summary: The Trump Organization has fired dozens of unauthorized laborers who worked at its hotels, golf courses, and other properties. The firings come after a New York Times story last year exposed the organization's use of unauthorised workers, who were often from El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Mexico. The company has vowed to use E-Verify checks to confirm employment eligibility, but many former workers have found better-paying jobs. Immigration lawyer Anibal Romero represents about 40 people living in the country illegally who have worked at Trump properties, saying the firings are a "sad" outcome for those affected.

images.alt_text: Several workers at Trump Winery in Charlottesville, Virginia, were fired this week.

site_title: Taking a peep into the next decade
summary: Experts predict the 2020s will see significant changes in food, travel, and shopping. Plant-based burgers, insect protein, and lab-cultured meat will become more affordable. Travel will focus on environmental conservation, while shopping will prioritize design, arts, and personalized retail. Co-living spaces, luxury retirement villages, and immersive theatre will define the decade.

site_title: Lodha Group urges unconventional policies to fight growth woes
summary: India's largest developer, Lodha Group, is urging unconventional policy measures to combat the nation's economic slump. Managing director Abhishek Lodha calls for drastic action to change sentiment, citing a lack of liquidity in the banking system. The country's property market has been struggling due to a prolonged cash squeeze and a slump in demand since 2016. Approximately 576,000 home projects are running behind schedule, with prices having fallen 10-15% in real terms over the last four to five years. Authorities are under pressure to unveil more steps to stimulate growth.

site_title: Ghosn escape theories: a music instrument box, private jet, Lebanese aid
summary: Former Nissan Motor Co and Renault SA head Carlos Ghosn evaded Japanese authorities to flee to Lebanon, sparking numerous unconfirmed theories about his escape. Ghosn, awaiting trial for financial misconduct, was allegedly smuggled out of Japan in a large musical instrument box, then flown to Turkey on a private jet and finally to Lebanon. His wife, Carole, and her brothers are reported to have played a key role in the operation. Despite various claims about Ghosn's escape, including the use of forged passports and ignored arrival formalities, the French and Lebanese foreign ministries have stated they do not know how he pulled off the escape.

site_title: US FDA plans to ban most e-cigarette flavours except menthol: officials
summary: The US FDA plans to ban most e-cigarette flavors except menthol, in a partial retreat from a previous commitment to a full ban. The decision allows menthol and tobacco flavors to remain on the market, with flavored liquid nicotine used in open tank systems still permitted. The move aims to restrict flavors most appealing to teenagers, but public health experts warn that teenagers may switch to menthol instead. The ban is expected to be announced "very shortly" by US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Metals upswing hangs on US-China trade truce
summary: A thawing in the US-China trade war is expected to fuel a rally in base metals in 2020, following a prolonged conflict that kept prices in check in 2019. The easing trade tensions led to a 3.4% gain in benchmark copper and a 2.4% rise in the LME industrial metals index. Nickel has been the best performer, with a 31% gain in 2019, but its price was down 2% at the end of the year. A transition to cleaner energy will require larger amounts of copper, nickel, and other metals, with analysts calling for accelerated projects and resource discovery.

site_title: Oil posts biggest yearly rise since 2016 on supply cuts, US-China trade deal
summary: Oil prices notched their biggest annual gain in three years in 2019, rising 23% for Brent and 34% for WTI, driven by supply cuts from major oil producers and a thaw in the US-China trade war. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its allies pledged output cuts, supporting the price increase. The recent breakthrough in trade talks also contributed to the surge. This marks the largest yearly gain since 2016, indicating a significant shift in the global oil market.

site_title: Companies lining up to raise US$120b in debts in January
summary: Companies in the US are set to raise $120 billion in debt in January, a 9% increase from 2019, according to an informal survey of dealers. This comes as the high-grade bond spread has fallen to 94 basis points, the tightest level since February 2018. With $78 billion in high-grade corporate bonds coming due or that may be called in January, issuers are seeking to get ahead of the risk associated with the Democratic presidential primaries in March. Despite a strong 14.7% return in investment-grade corporate debt this year, strategists expect a 5-8% decline in 2020.

site_title: Weaker dollar helps to seal best year for gold since 2010
summary: Gold reached its best annual performance since 2010, gaining 19% in 2019, as a weaker dollar and central banks' loose monetary policy boosted growth. The metal traded at a three-month high, with spot gold rising 0.7% to $1,525.38 an ounce. Analysts, however, caution that gold's strength may not be sustained this year, with some predicting that bonds may offer better portfolio protection.

site_title: Fireworks, smoke, tear gas: Hello, 2020!
summary: The world bid farewell to 2019 and welcomed 2020 with mixed emotions, reflecting the tumultuous year dominated by demonstrations, climate change, and global uncertainty. Billions of people gathered in cities worldwide, including New York, Paris, London, and Rio, to ring in the new decade. Despite the optimism of some, many expressed pessimism about the future, with protests and unrest continuing in countries such as Hong Kong and Chile. The start of a new decade marked a time for reflection, hope, and uncertainty, as the world looked to the future with a mix of excitement and trepidation.

site_title: China cuts banks' reserve ratios, frees up 800b yuan for economy
summary: China's central bank cut banks' reserve ratios by 50 basis points, releasing around 800 billion yuan (S$155 billion) to support the slowing economy. The move, effective January 6, aims to boost investor confidence and support economic growth. The cut is the eighth since early 2018 and will bring the reserve requirement ratio down to 12.5% for big banks. Analysts expect further economic growth to cool this year, but the move is seen as a step to stabilize the economy ahead of the Lunar New Year holidays.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation results were published on January 1, 2020. However, the article does not provide further information on this topic. More relevant news includes: Companies like Creative Technology and Grab received market updates, with Creative Technology warning of potential revenue below target and Grab downgraded to 'hold' due to expected slowing earnings growth. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks are on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release, and MAS and PBOC are to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Tan Teck Long is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse proposes allowing corporate weighted voting rights
summary: The Stock Exchange of Hong Kong has proposed allowing companies to hold weighted voting rights in Hong Kong listed companies. This move comes after the bourse previously allowed companies to list with shares carrying different voting rights, but with limited ownership to individuals. The proposal was strongly opposed by corporate governance advocates in 2018, but it remains to be seen how this latest proposal will be received.

site_title: Iraqi paramilitaries tell supporters to withdraw from American embassy
summary: Iraqi paramilitaries have told supporters to withdraw from the US embassy in Baghdad, following a day of protests against US air strikes that killed at least 25 fighters. The protests, which marked a new turn in the shadow war between Washington and Teheran, have raised questions over the US military presence in Iraq. The US has deployed hundreds of extra troops to the region and threatened retaliation against Iran. The Iraqi government sought to preserve the prestige of the state, and senior officers failed to convince protesters to leave.

site_title: Why populism may only grow in the 2020s
summary: A two-decade rise in populism has seen a staggering two billion people governed by populist leaders, with 20 years ago, only a handful of states with populations over 20 million had such leaders. The growth of populism is driven by factors such as economic downturn and austerity, and is marked by diverse flavours across the world, including socialism in South America and right-of-centre populism in Europe. The current wave of populism may not yet have peaked, with the US presidential election in November potentially generating new inspiration for populists worldwide, despite critics pointing to weak records in power for populist leaders like Trump and Bolsonaro.

site_title: Mukesh Ambani's Reliance unveils online store in challenge to Amazon
summary: Reliance Industries, controlled by billionaire Mukesh Ambani, has launched JioMart, an online store offering over 50,000 grocery products with free home delivery and a return policy. The pilot site is currently available in three Mumbai neighborhoods, marking the company's entry into the Indian e-commerce market. Ambani aims to replicate the success of his wireless carrier, Reliance Jio, in online retail, seeking to "completely transform" India's unorganised retail market.

site_title: Famed Knopf publisher Sonny Mehta dies at 77
summary: Sonny Mehta, the 77-year-old former president and editor-in-chief of Alfred A. Knopf, has died due to complications of pneumonia. Mehta, who guided Knopf for 32 years, was a literary savant and instinctive decision-maker who published works by nine Nobel laureates, including Kazuo Ishiguro and Gabriel Garcia Marquez. He was known for his aggressive marketing and sales approach, which helped Knopf deliver literary quality and runaway sales. Mehta's legacy includes publishing popular books by Toni Morrison, John Updike, and Michael Crichton, and expanding the company's brands through strategic acquisitions.

site_title: Shanghai Turbo unit awarded compensation in suit against ex-director
summary: Shanghai Turbo's subsidiary, Changzhou 3D Technological Complete Set Equipment, has been awarded 504,300 yuan (S$97,920) in compensation in a Chinese court's decision against former group CEO Liu Ming and six ex-employees. The award stems from a 2017 dispute over the handover of a factory in China, with Changzhou 3D claiming damages for civil trespass, workers' wages, and security fees. The decision is part of a larger lawsuit that has resulted in the defendants being ordered to pay 72,300 yuan for temporary office rental and 432,000 yuan for security guard fees.

site_title: OUE board changes take effect, with Stephen Riady becoming CEO
summary: OUE's long-time CEO Thio Gim Hock has retired after 13 years, and Indonesian tycoon Stephen Riady, 59, has taken over as CEO, expanding from his current role as executive chairman. Riady's son also joined the company as part of the board changes. The changes took effect on January 1, 2020.

site_title: French unions vow no surrender in month-long strike
summary: French unions have vowed to continue their month-long strike against President Emmanuel Macron's plan to merge France's 42 pension schemes into a single system, requiring people to work longer. The CGT union leader has urged all workers to join the strikes, which have crippled public transport. Macron has refused to back down, sparking a standoff that has entered its second month.

images.alt_text: Reacting to Mr Macron's speech, CGT's Mr Martinez (above) has called for strikes "everywhere" from next week, both "in the public and the private sector".

site_title: Working group to review SGX retail bonds framework
summary: A working group in Singapore is reviewing the retail bonds framework to improve protection for retail investors in case of defaults. Key proposals include tightening admission criteria, introducing insurance coverage for bond issuers, and improving disclosures on bond issues. The group aims to clarify the roles of parties involved, such as the issuer and trustee, and discuss how to fund trustees acting for bondholders.
